webTitle: EU gives all-clear to British transfers

fields.headline: EU gives all-clear to British transfers
fields.standfirst: The European commission's emphasis on international transfers has relieved the threat to the domestic game
fields.trailText: The European commission emphasis on international transfers has relieved the threat to the domestic game, writes Vivek Chaudhary.
fields.body:
Moves between British clubs will not be affected by plans to amend the transfer system, but clubs will have to draw up radically different contracts that give players the right to break them if they want to move abroad, the European Commission said yesterday in a clear indication that it is softening its stance on the issue.

The ruling will not affect, for instance, transfers between British clubs like Rio Ferdinand's £18m move from West Ham to Leeds or the £12m deal which took Tore Andre Flo to Rangers. But Viviane Reding, the EC commissioner responsible for sport who is spearheading the drive to overhaul the current system, said that there has been a lot of confusion over the commission's plans and that it had no intention of banning transfer fees or amending the movement of players within their own country.

Reding, who was in London to meet the sports minister Kate Hoey and Chris Smith, who is responsible for sport at cabinet level, said: "We don't want to tackle national transfer rules and the national transfer system, which means that if there's the transfer of a player between British clubs then that's none of our business. It's only international transfers that are causing us problems."

Under EC proposals, players would have the right to terminate a contract, provided they give adequate notice, if they want to move to a club outside the country they are playing in. Transfer fees would not be totally wiped out but football authorities across the continent are concerned that they could be based solely on the remaining length of a player's contract, costing clubs millions in lost revenue.

Reding insisted yesterday that the transfer value of a player would be calculated by taking into account the amount of time a club has spent on his training, the market value of the player and the remainder of the contract. Where a player's value is in dispute then the matter will be settled by an arbitration panel.

Her comments are the clearest indications to date that the EC is watering down its views following weeks of pressure from politicians and football officials that abolishing transfer fees and giving players complete freedom of movement would irreparably damage the game.

Reding said that the current system impeded the free movement of players across Europe and that this contravened the Treaty of Rome, which gives all citizens of the continent the right to work where they want in Europe. She added that the EC objected to the current system on two fundamental grounds: first, that a player can be prevented by Fifa from breaking his contract unilaterally and changing clubs; and second that there is an obligation on the new club to pay a transfer fee to the old one even when a player's contract has been terminated by mutual consent.

"The Treaty [of Rome] obliges us to act. At the moment a player's freedom of movement across Europe is being restricted . . . This cannot be allowed to continue," she said.

Reding insisted that the nature of a footballer's contract would have to change and include areas such as the required period of notice prior to resignation. "All conditions should be included in a player's contract, giving them the right to terminate them," she said. "There will continue to be transfers and transfer payments but the conditions under which those are made are going to change."

Those comments suggest the EC and football authorities are moving closer to agreement, particularly over the importance of transfer fees so that small clubs continue to benefit from the sale of players.

But the EC is still dissatisfied at some of the proposals submitted by Fifa and Uefa in October, particularly the proposed ban on all transfers for players aged under 18.

Reding said: "This also curbs freedom of movement. But the idea is right . . . I believe we can have the same result if we had agreed rules on how young footballers should be treated."

webTitle: Follow Guardian Unlimited's netjetters around the world

fields.headline: E-mail bonding
fields.standfirst: This weekend three people - an 18-year-old gap student, a fed-up 29-year-old civil servant and a 51-year-old divorced mother of three - are embarking on a unique travel experience. They will be going around the world for six months, reporting weekly into our website, and looking for advice. Follow the Netjetters' progress and e-mail them tips that could change their lives - or at least point them in the direction of a good time. Catch up with them at www.guardian.co.uk/netjetters
fields.trailText: This weekend three people - an 18-year-old gap student, a fed-up 29-year-old civil servant and a 51-year-old divorced mother of three - are embarking on a unique travel experience. They will be going around the world for six months and reporting weekly into our website.
fields.body:
Name: Milly Newman
Age: 18
Place of residence: Devon
Occupation: gap-year student going to study law at Cardiff University

I remember reading through the details of the Netjetters competition when my mum handed me the advert and getting quite excited. I was already planning to travel for six months or so before going to uni, so this prize would be brilliant. The next morning, I went on the Guardian website and rambled 500 words about myself. I never expectted to hear about it again - after all, no one really wins these competitions.

When, a good month later, I got a letter from the Guardian saying they'd been attempting to contact me and I was on a shortlist, I couldn't believe it. That alone would have been something to tell the grandchildren about (not that I've got any).

Anyway, I phoned and arranged to meet the next morning at the Guardian offices in London for a chat. I tried asking how short the list was but no one would tell me. It wasn't until later I found out over 1,000 people had entered. They promised to let me know soon, but I didn't expect my mum to phone me at work the same night to tell me I'd won! I think my main feeling was shock, and that I'd wake up the next day to find out it was either a joke or they'd made a mistake or something like that.

Since then, I've been trying to take the whole thing in. At the moment, as well as the excitement of leaving England and its miserable weather, I am very nervous at the thought of travelling alone. If you ask anyone, they would agree that I have little common sense or sense of direction so I can't help feeling that I'll end up alone in a completely strange country with no one to turn to for help. Or at least for the three months before my friends who are leaving later catch me up.

I was already firmly set on the route I wanted to take before I entered, and that has been no problem. I exchanged a few e-mails with debs.w from Bridge the World, then went to see her at their big outlet in Camden Town. She couldn't have been more helpful with ideas to get the best from my trip, such as a stop at Ayres Rock and travelling overland from Singapore to Bangkok. For anyone who is travelling, I would definitely say go to the travel agents in person, sit with them for an hour or so and then you can find exactly the right route for you. For a big trip, it's more reassuring than doing everything by computer.

Apart from organising my route, I feel scarily unpre pared. I have a new passport - if you're going to Oz, it needs to be valid for six months after you get back - and had injections (ask your doctor for details a good month before you leave), but that's about it. My main aim has really been to raise the money I need, so I've been working full-time - a big hello to everybody at Holes Bay in Poole - and hoping everything else falls into place.

One thing I've found about travelling is that everyone knows somebody somewhere I'm going, and has useful advice for me, which is great. Also, other travellers are very sociable. On the train back from London, I met two guys - one from New Zealand and one from England - who had done a lot of travelling and we easily filled a two-hour journey talking about their/my travels. I picked up lots of useful things from their experiences and also got some hope that I won't end up completely alone!

So, if anyone else has any advice, particularly about Vancouver, my first stop, please pass it on. How cold is it in Canada? Where are the best bars/cafés/hostels/things to do? I promise to try out all the best suggestions so I can pass on my opinion of them!

Until next time . . .

Name: Sam Rowbury
Age: 29
Place of residence: London
Occupation: civil servant

My entry was written on a dark, Sunday evening in London. The rain was spattering the window and I was desperately trying to push away the thought of work the next morning. So, I wrote about how frustrated I was with my job and how wonderful it would be to see lions and elephants in Africa. This was very therapeutic but I never for a moment dreamt I would win or what that would actually mean. Fate decided to call my bluff.

Most people spend months planning a trip like this. I've just had a few short weeks. Deciding on a route was the first thing. When you're presented with the whole world, it's a little overwhelming - particularly if you have never even been outside Europe. I started off by trying to do everything, but I soon realised it would be better to focus on a few countries. So I listed my priorities: I wanted to visit friends in San Francisco, see Southern Africa, go whale-watching in New Zealand, go skiing (anywhere) and spend lots of time relaxing.

Eventually, I fixed on a route that would allow me to do all this. So it's New York and overland by train to San Francisco; then Fiji for New Year; travel down through New Zealand for a month; Sydney for three weeks with a stop-over in Alice Springs, before flying to Johannesburg. I'll spend about three months in Africa and I'll figure out my exact route later but I want to take in Zanzibar, Namibia, Tanzania, Cape Town and, if I can, Madagascar. There's a solar eclipse that will pass through the region next June so, if I still have any cash left, I'll stay on for that. It took me ages to come up with this itinerary and I'm sure it will all change once I'm out there but, for the moment, it sounds pretty exciting to me.

I have had to learn about all the different types of immunisations you need. In the past I have had bad reactions to vaccinations so I am spreading the injections out over a few weeks to lessen the effect. My friends have taken great delight in listing all the horrible insects that will be waiting to infest me. These include a horrific creature found in freshwater lakes in Africa. Apparently, it swims up your urine and then attaches itself inside you with a sort of barbed grappling hook. My friends insist I must pee in staccato bursts to reduce the risk.

On the practical side, I've fixed everything up at home. Work has been very good and given me six months unpaid leave. I've paid off my bills, cancelled all my standing orders and redirected my post. I've found someone to rent my room (my wise and generous landlady even said I could have it back again when I return).

But the hardest thing has been the thought of leaving my girlfriend. I will miss her terribly and, although she is going to try and come out to meet me at some point, it will be months before I see her again. As my departure date has got closer, we have found ourselves spending as much time together as possible - squeezing out every last minute. Small things take on an unusual significance - our last trip to the cinema, our last Sunday morning. But she knows I love her very much and will always be there for her, no matter where I am.

So, after all the planning, I'm nearly there. The tickets are booked. I've bought my rucksack and sleeping bag. I've had the jabs. I've got my passport and visas. The world's waiting for me. I wonder what it will be like.

Name: Sue Stubbings
Age: 51
Place of residence: Cambridge
Occupation: works for the county council's education department

I started my entry for the Netjetters competition with the sentence "I am 50, fairly fit and fed up". None of it is true any more: yet another birthday has crept up on me; I have started a fitness regime (a grand name for running up and down the stairs every day) and I am certainly no longer fed up. I consider myself to be the luckiest and most excited person I know.

I have never won anything before, probably because I've never entered anything. I cut the Netjetters advert out for my son, who is "resting" after finishing his degree. Having been desperate to travel for many years, on a whim I decided to enter myself. The words came easily as I imagined travelling for six months and all the places I wanted to go. I then forgot about it.

My colleagues at work still laugh about my reaction when the Guardian contacted me. Apparently, I had my mouth hanging open, couldn't utter a word and then started shaking. Since that day my whole world has been turned upside down and it has been a frenzy of activity. There was a trip to the Guardian two days later for an interview where it was confirmed I was chosen. My three children happened to be going to London that weekend and we had a wonderful, very alcoholic time. They are as excited as I am.

There were many immediate issues to be tackled:

Work - in the jargon of my job in Education Welfare, would I be given "authorised absence" or would I be "taken off roll"? After an anxious week, I was given six months unpaid leave for which I am extremely grateful.

Money - this proved to be worryingly easy as the bank was very accommodating. The fact that I could be 76 when I finish paying off the loan didn't seem to worry them.

House - my son is currently in residence so it was decided to get in a couple of lodgers to help pay the bills. This means clearing my and my daughter's bedrooms, a mammoth task as tidiness is not a family trait. I do not know if anyone will fancy her orange and turquoise walls.

The most pleasurable decision to be made was my route. Having the whole world to choose from was a bit daunting. The major choice was Africa or South America, as there were not enough air-miles for both. South America won. The final route is India, overland to Nepal, back to India, on to Singapore and around Malaysia, to Bali, Australia and New Zealand. Tahiti was to have been next but was crossed off by the airline no longer flying there (bang goes my fantasy of garlands and a grass skirt). It's straight on to South America and back home with a stop off in Spain. Not bad!

I have never travelled alone. It is very scary - but I have been getting loads of advice from experienced travellers. I decided to join an overland trip from Mumbai, where I first land, to Nepal. This will give me time to find my travelling legs and get used to it all. The tour leader does not know yet that he/she will have to help me find a Net café every week. This tour ends on December 24, so it is going to be Christmas in Kathmandu.

I have spent the last decade making a lot of changes in my life and getting to know more about myself. The past year or two I have been restless and frustrated by not having the time or money to travel. Turning 50 did not help. It all no longer matters.

This trip and its timing feel so right. I would love to share my luck and this adventure and hope you will join me on the Net!

The Netjetters' tickets have been organised by Bridge The World, specialists in around the world travel. Tel: 0870 4447474 (www.bridgetheworld.com).

fields.headline: Salt of the Earth
fields.trailText: Lucy Elliott samples the treatments available at the Dead Sea's Zara Spa.
fields.body:
Nothing had prepared me for the view from my hotel by the Dead Sea - the serene, glittering blue that stretched horizontally before me, or the immense canyon wall slowly emerging from the white heat haze beyond. Nothing can be as elemental as this landscape.

This is the lowest place on earth, the Valley of Salt, where the Bible meets the Koran and the Dead Sea separates Israel from Jordan. And it is here, in the desert, just along from where John baptised Jesus, that the Sanctuary of London has opened its Zara Spa, in association with the Swiss hotel chain Mövenpick. They have endless supplies of water, as well as copious amounts of salt and mud from the Dead Sea.

It is so hot here that flagstone or fabric will burn naked skin; so hot that it seems when you walk into the cool of the spa reception this is the only possible place to be. You are surrounded by pools, themselves surrounded by canopied terraces. The thalassotherapy pool, like the main pool of the resort, is built so the rim overlaps the sea behind, creating the illusion that you could swim into infinity (or at least Israel). It is 3% saline and pumps water through various jets so it pummels each part of your body.

The Kneipp foot massage and two Dead Sea pools inside are a quarter pumped from the sea and so have all its mineral and saline properties, softening and antiseptic. "If you have any problem," a high-powered American woman from Cairo assured me, "anything growing," she said mysteriously, looking at her feet, "it's gone." Many people come here from Egypt, Israel and the Gulf for the low humidity and the rich concentration of oxygen in the air.

Should you desire more heat, the "thermarium" contains a steam room and "caldarium" - an elegant green-tiled room with heated benches, each with less invasive heat than a sauna, and plenty of loungers to cool off on afterwards.

Then come the treatments. Beginning with a salt rub, in which coarse Dead Sea salt is mixed with almond oil and scrubbed all over the body to rid you of dead skin and stimulate circulation. Each morning, in a diamond-shaped room, I was smeared in the famed mud - camphor and aloe added to its 22 minerals and lavender-scented for relaxation - and left there, wrapped in my slimey envelope, a mummy in her tomb. Then, after a shower, the aromatherapy massage: scents and rhythmic touch combine to induce a state of dreamy euphoria, after which you wander out to the corridor in a daze, joining the other white-robed zombies doing the same. By now, your skin is so soft, your body so supple it feels elastic.

Of course, you can always stumble the few yards down to the sea and cake yourself with mud. People sit half-camouflaged like birds on the rocks, their limbs covered in black mud which the sun bakes to green, or bob in the sea.

There are delicious buffet banquets to start and end the day, cafés and bars, as well as restaurants offering the world's cuisines. After eating, you can smoke apple or strawberry-scented tobacco through elaborate hubbly-bubblies, the coals replaced with tongs throughout the night, as you relax to the strains of Lady in Red, Feelings or Imagine alternating with Jordanian traditional music, all delivered by the in-house crooner. Or you can watch a be-tasselled bellydancer, the more alluring for her intense shyness.

Leaving the table, you can flop straight into the huge outside pool, float belly-up and stare at the stars all night. But as the shadows gather in the crevices of the great rock behind, giving slant to the mountain, a restless twitch drives you out of its confines and into the desert or towards Amman...

Huge gorges and scorched gulleys run beside you or beneath, streaked pink and red, rising higher and higher until your ears pop and the landscape becomes lunar.

Houses ranging from simple bunkers of rough breeze block or concrete squares to ultramodern apartment blocks match the wan colours of the land. The nearer you are to Amman, the more palatial the homes - stucco turquoise paintwork or extravaganzas in marble. Arm in arm, the late King Hussein and his son, the more liberal King Abdullah, grin from signposts.

White taxis can take you on set routes back and forth from the city, whereas yellow taxis will take you where you please. The ancient King's Highway winds over desert and mountain, south from Amman into Arabia, with Petra along the way. Mount Nebo is 800m above sea level, the place where Moses was laid to rest. From its summit, the mountains you have just passed look like mere dimples. The roads are good and the tarmac stripes on towards Madaba, a modern town of 65% Christian population with its thriving Bedouin markets.

Up here atop the rock, all that's visible are the giant electricity pylons and telegraph poles; in the distance a train with its long straight line of phosphate cargo. Mosques of very modern design stud all roads, next to their domes the green neon-ringed minarets stand new and high, like rockets.

Suddenly the road winds downwards and, echoing the jagged cliff edge, is the jutting architecture of a very modern hotel nestling at the bottom of a huge chasm: the Ma'in hot springs. Jordan has many natural hot springs, but none have been exploited to such spectacular effect in such magnificent surroundings. The volcanic springs gush fast on to smooth rust-red rock before falling to shallow streams far below, which are so boiling hot you leap the stones yelping to reach a clearing that lets the spring power down over you. The French-owned hotel is spacious and elegant, Arab chic and state-of-the-art treatments, more medical than beautifying.

On the way home, to break the monotony of the road, lone neon tubes in all colours hang in the dark, heralding stops for Bedouin coffee from glinting pewter pots. Sudden caves of light appear, big tents below which men in flowing robes are briefly displayed, wedged comfortably on sofas around a fire, drinking and chatting in the warm night, in the middle of nowhere.

You cannot, of course, leave without visiting the stone of Petra, the great city where the smears, creases and holes in the walls of sandstone rock have been fashioned into a neoclassical living wonder. But nothing can prepare you for that - unless it's the feeling of complete surrender induced by the great desert and sea of Jordan itself.

Beginner's guide to treatments

Sauna - the Swedes' favourite. You sit with others in a room filled with dry-heat to warm and detoxify your body.

Steam room - like a sauna but with "wet" heat, ie steam. The effects are the same, it's just a matter of preference.

Steam cabinet - the cliché of the health spa. Your body is shut in asteamy cabin while your head pokes out of a hole at the top. Your pores are opened so your body can better absorb theraputic creams and oils.

La stone - hot volcanic stones are placed on various points of the body. A natural therapy for relaxing rebalancing and destressing.

Full body wax - all hair from the neck downwards is removed with the aid of hot wax which is ripped off when it hardens. Yes, it is as painful as it sounds.

Seaweed wrap - you are covered in seaweed then wrapped in a hot towel. This detoxifying therapy is also said to reduce cellulite and aid weight loss.

Collagen facial - the 21st-century version of the traditional facial. A mask soaked in collagen (the stuff used in face lifts) is applied to your face which is then cleansed and toned. Thus, your face can absorb collagen without having to go under the knife.

Reiki - a therapist holds parts of your body looking for problem areas and energy blockages.

Body exfoliation - an exfoliating cream containing tiny granules, is smothered over your body to remove dead skin cells and give you a more polished appearance.

Lymphatic drainage - your skin is brushed abrasively before being massaged with a special oil. Said to promote weight-loss and improve energy levels and circulation.

The practicals

Thermalia Travel (020-7586 7725)offers seven-night stays at the Movenpick resort and Sanctuary Zara Spa in Jordan for £1,180 departing in November. The price is based on two sharing half-board accommodation and includes return flights to Amman, transfers and the following package: one spa consultation on arrival; seven spa experiences; one Sanctuary Zara Dead Sea Salt scrub; one Sanctuary Zara Spa facial; three Dead Sea mud wraps with herbal essences; three full body aroma massages; choice of dry float with facial massage or underwater massage; one manicure; one pedicure.

All spa packages include unlimited use of the Hydro-pool, Dead Sea pool, Kneipp foot massage pool, Thermarius (inc Caldarium, Laconium, Tropical Rain shower, indoor and outdoor rest areas), gym, tranquillity lounge, swimming pool and beach area.

www.movenpick-deadsea.com Contact the Jordan Tourist Board on 0207 3716496

webTitle: Jonathan Rendell: Anti-jerk tablets | Mobile phones | A blue plastic bracelet

fields.headline: Jonathan Rendell never travels without...
fields.trailText: Anti-jerk tablets | Mobile phones | A blue plastic bracelet
fields.body:
A necessity: My Oxazapan 10mg anti-jerk tablets. I suffer from involuntary movement, especially on trains and planes, so I need them on my travels.

A luxury: No "largers" - people who push their way around brandishing mobile phones. The numbers seem to have grown enormously. You can spot them by their walk, the way they continually glance down at their phones. They don't respect anyone and push their personalities on to others.

A memento: A blue plastic bracelet I shop-lifted by accident in Las Vegas. It was a genuine mistake. I had to get some shoes early in the morn ing and at the checkout I must have brushed inadvertently against a stand and after I'd left I found this $1.99 bracelet in my bag. Once I had it, my luck changed. My last bet won.

If only: A stand-up mahagony bar full of entertaining people on every plane. It would be much more interesting than watching the film.

The Gambler, a three-part series following Jonathan Rendell's fortunes as he gambles £12,000 will begin on Channel 4 on Wednesday at 10.30pm. His book Twelve Grand, The Gambler As Hero is published by Yellow Jersey Press at £7 .

fields.standfirst: From Steve Lockett
fields.trailText: If you want a cheap taste experience in Mumbai, try a cafe called Vithal's. The dining room is upstairs, and for less than a pound you could try one of the Bels with a pot of tea.
fields.body: If you want a cheap taste experience in Mumbai, stand outside V.T. station and look right, where you will see MacDonalds (not finished yet!). The street behind the aforementioned culinary palace has a cafe called Vithal's (5, AK Naik Marg). The dining room is upstairs, and for less than a pound you could try one of the Bels with a pot of tea. This is a very tasty snack with mung beans and curd available in a range of styles; ask the waiters for advice. Hope you enjoy my favourite city.

fields.headline: Powder Blues Gloves
fields.trailText: A glove designed specifically to prevent snow finding its way into your gloves and jacket.
fields.body:
This winter I am determined to try snowboarding in powder but is there any way to stop the snow finding its way into my gloves and jacket? There is a glove designed specifically to prevent that. It works by a three-part process; an inner glove, your jacket and an outer glove.

Sounds a bit complicated, how does it work? First you put on an insulated fingerless glove that has a solid plastic cuff stitched into it above the wrist. Next the jacket is worn over the inner glove with the cuff wrapping around it. Then you pull on the outer glove, and align its plastic quick-release strap with the cuff on the inner glove. The two form a seal that guarantees snow won't get in.

Does this mean you have to have a special jacket as well? No, but the jacket has to have an adjustable cuff to fit over the glove.

Is the glove warm and waterproof as well? Yes. The inner glove has a breathable liner and the outer has Kevlar on the palm, so it is protective as well as fully waterproof.

How much does it cost? It's not cheap at £69.95. For stockists tel: 020-7434 1113. www.powderblues.com

webTitle: Travel agents lose patience with window shoppers

fields.headline: Agents to charge
fields.standfirst: Would you pay £25 to see your travel agent?  Roger Bray reports on a backlash to the Net
fields.trailText: Would you pay £25 to see your travel agent? Roger Bray reports on a backlash to the Net.
fields.body:
Travel agents are beginning to get tough with customers who pick their brains but then fail to follow up or simply bypass them, using their advice to book direct. Enquirers seeking complicated itineraries, involving multiple flights, hotels and car hire, may be required to pay a deposit. One agent is already charging £25 an hour, which is returned if the traveller completes the booking, and another is considering following suit, though at a lower rate.

Underlying the move is the increasing importance of the Internet, which is tempting some customers to book transport and accommodation independently and is allowing airlines, which incur lower costs if they sell tickets online, to pressure agents into accepting less commission. As agents watch their income drain away, they are having to redefine the way they do business.

Leading the movement to charge a deposit is Edwin Doran, who has two agencies in Twickenham and is chairman of the Campaign for Real Travel Agents, which was set up by the Association of Independent Tour Operators - the country's leading group of specialist firms - whose members argue that the big chains do little or nothing to sell their holidays. "We are assessing people as to whether they are likely to be time-wasters or genuine clients," says Doran. "Sometimes, if we spend a lot of time researching, we have to protect ourselves by charging £25 an hour, but they get it back if they then book with us."

Michael Phillips of Cadogan Travel says: "We haven't decided to start charging yet but we think the time has come. All you need is a deterrent and I think £10 would make people think twice." Estimates of how much the Internet is affecting bookings are vague. John Bennett, managing director of Osprey Holidays, told AITO delegates at its annual conference in Mexico last week that he suspected city break operators were worst hit, with business down 8% last winter and a further 1% this winter. "Because of the high commission agents are demanding, city break sales are being prised further and further away from their domain. It is hard to compete with a £19 return fare on a low-cost airline when people can book accommodation on the Internet too." AITO, meanwhile, is launching a website of its own. Scheduled to be up and running on January 6 at www.aito.co.uk, it will make last-minute deals from its 155 members widely accessible for the first time. Potential customers will also be able to tailor the holiday they want, entering requests for activities and asking to be contacted by up to five operators that can match their requirements.

AITO plans to use information gleaned via the site to establish a database of customer preferences which should lead, perhaps as early as next summer, to the creation of a loyalty scheme aimed at persuading people to book again - if not with the same operator then with another member firm. As yet, few members offer Internet reservations and some remain extremely reluctant to offer late deals, pointing to the fact that the big operators bump up their initial prices only so they can discount them later. However, if the site proves successful it seems destined to encourage more of them to do both. This will only exacerbate the problem for travel agents but ultimately it should benefit consumers. As Bennett observes, those who survive will have to be good. "They will have to offer expert, thoughtful advice - and there will always be a place for agents who do that."

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: Peter
fields.trailText: If you have the time and money, consider taking a tour through the desert parks of Southern California; Death Valley is still warm (25C) this time of year, though the approach roads may be snow-covered.
fields.body:
Welcome to the world's most powerful banana republic! My condolences at arriving here in the US just as we're providing conclusive proof (as if any were needed) that our political system is a complete joke. You've chosen a good itinerary; had you opted for the land route from NY to SF (or anywhere else), you'd have been hard-pressed, after a day or two, to come up with original or apposite responses to rabid supporters of the Bush Putsch who are, so they say, the majority in "fly-over country".

But never mind. You're probably not too keen on politics anyway. If you have the time and money, consider taking a tour through the desert parks of Southern California; Death Valley is still warm (25C) this time of year, though the approach roads may be snow-covered. And if you're so inclined, consider renting a motorbike while you're in S.F. There are fantastic roads in every direction, especially up the northern coast into Mendocino County (where it's likely to be rainy, though).

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: International festival of Christmas | Hidden Art | British Museum | Alexandra Palace | Framlingham Castle | Hadrian's Wall | Covent Garden | Deal Castle
fields.body:
Rock the boat

The traditional European Christmas comes to Portsmouth in Britain's first international festival of Christmas. Nearly 50 stalls will be selling hot chestnuts, rocking horses, dolls, ceramics, glassware and wine.

Sat/Sun, 10am-8pm. £6/£4 including entry to ships and attractions. The Historic Dockyard, Portsmouth (023-9286 1512).

Hidden art

Now in its seventh year, Hidden Art is Britain's leading open studios event. Buy or commission direct from designers, for work ranging from furniture to fine art.

Prices from 20p to £750,000. Sat Dec 2 (10am-6pm). Sun 3 (12pm-6pm). Mazorca Projects, Charity House, 14/15 Perseverance Works, 38 Kingsland Road, London E2 (020-7729 3301).

Court in the act

When the Queen Elizabeth II Great Court opens at the British Museum, the restored 19th-century Reading Room will be open to the public for the first time. The Great Court will house a new education centre, new galleries and visitor services.

Open daily 10am-5pm (Sun 12pm-6pm). Great Court opens Dec 7. Free. Great Russell St, London WC1 (020-7636 1555).

Palatial shopping

The season of retail therapy gets underway at the Christmas craft fair at Alexandra Palace. Around 350 craftsmen will display and sell crafts alongside London's largest pre-Christmas food and drink show.

Sat/Sun 10am-5.30pm. £7/£3, under 12s free. Alexandra Palace Way, London N22 (01273 833884).

Christ's mass

Children can take part in scenes from the story of St Nicholas or join the nativity cast at Framlingham Castle, while adults examine the roots of ceremonies like mumming plays and Yule logs.

Sat/Sun from 11am. £3.70/£1.80. Framlingham, Suffolk (01728 724189).

Wall power

Hadrian's Wall - A Winter Guide puts together a selection of days out around the World Heritage site, with details of walks, bus links and interpretive displays.

Details from local tourist information centres or phone 01434 322 002.

Just dessert

Covent Garden's 20th Great Christmas pudding relay race involves celebrities and others in fancy dress dodging obstacles while carrying a Christmas pudding, all for cancer research.

Sat Dec 2. Fancy dress parade and activities from 11.30am, race 12.30pm. East Piazza, Covent Garden, London.

Seeing Santa

Father Christmas is taking orders from children, who can also enjoy storytelling and make Christmas decorations.

Dec 2/3, 9/10, 16/17; 12pm-4pm. £3/£1.50. Deal Castle, Deal, Kent (01304 372762).

fields.headline: China in your hands
fields.standfirst: www.discoverhongkong.com
fields.trailText: www.discoverhongkong.com
fields.body:
Isn't Hong Kong under Chinese rule these days?
It is, but thanks to the special relationship Britain enjoyed with the country until the transfer of power, visiting from the UK is very easy. Indeed, HK is touted here as the "gateway to China" to encourage you to take an excursion over the border, although you will need to arrange a visa in advance.

China the easy way?
Yes - the site encourages you to stick to such cities as Xian and Shanghai and provides flight details: no unsupervised backpacking or hitch-hiking in sight.

So how is HK reinventing itself as a tourist spot?
This vast site lurches from the banal and determinedly Western - the EuroChristmas experience, for example - to the solidly Eastern, such as this month's winter solstice festival and the world's tallest seated Buddha statue.

What if I want to leave the city?
Around three-quarters of Hong Kong is countryside. Fourteen national parks have been established and the endangered pink dolphin lives just off Lantau Island. But conservationists might want to avoid some of HK's winter "tonic foods", which include deer antlers and snake. None the less, this is a brilliantly executed site that leaves few questions unanswered.

fields.headline: And when you're not skiing...
fields.standfirst: Anna Rockall forsakes the planks to climb, float and skid about the mountainside
fields.trailText: Anna Rockall forsakes the planks to climb, float and skid about the mountainside.
fields.body:
Scale a frozen waterfall this winter. Ski off the side of the mountain into thin air. Buzz over moguls like a pro on nippy snow blades. The mountains offer so many exciting things that it seems a waste to spend every single day skiing. You probably wouldn't make a whole holiday out of any of these activities, but taking half a day to try something different could end up being the highlight of your week.

Ice climbing

A frozen waterfall is a formidable sight: a suspended curtain of frozen water hanging hundreds of feet down the mountainside. If you peer through the deep cracks in the ice, you can see the water still running. Scaling the huge, slippery vertical wall is a totally different way of experiencing the mountain.

Fitted with unwieldy climbing boots, vicious-looking crampons, harness, crash helmet and ice axes, I drove with my guide, Jean-Phillipe, to a little valley free of pistes and crowds a few miles from Val d'Isère. We struggled along it (or I did - JP skipped like a mountain goat) until we reached the shining wall of ice I was to climb. The water freezes in rough bumps, so that some parts of the "ice fall" give you a favourable lean into the mountain and you feel like you've got it under control; others curve out, forcing you to climb what looks like a gentle overhang but leaves you clinging on.

With ice axes in each hand and crampons on each foot, I was fully spiked up. Once JP had attached me to a safety line and shown me how it is meant to be done, it was my turn. I managed to plant my first axe after several strikes - it wasn't simply a matter of popping it; I had to strike with all my force as high as I could reach, often twice, for the pick to sink in securely. The same went for the crampons. Particularly where the ice was hard, I had to really kick to get a foothold. This made the whole activity aerobic, so I was soon panting. Every movement took a massive effort even though with feet planted properly I could stand fairly easily.

It was difficult because it was exhausting and because crampons and ice axes don't always stick in easily. But in other ways it wasn't too hard. It was obvious what you were meant to do and, unlike rock climbing, you could make a handhold where you wanted. I managed to fall off twice when my ice axes slipped out, and swung pathetically from my harness until I managed to get some purchase again.

When I finally got to the top, I was as happy to stop as I was to have accomplished the climb. But after a few minutes' rest, I remembered the romantic notion that had made me want to climb a frozen waterfall. The valley was quiet, JP out of sight behind a bump in the ice, and all around were the Alps, the snow and the icy waterfall.

Putting my weight and my trust in JP, I leaned against my safety rope and walked backwards down the waterfall in easy, bouncing strides. After the trauma of climbing up, it didn't even occur to me to be nervous about abseiling down.

Paragliding

On a clear day, I had enviously watched the multi-coloured canopies of paragliders soar above the snowy peaks, twirling and rising and putting us skiers to shame. Such a beautiful-looking sport had to be tried. So, firmly strapped to my guide, Serge, his skis either side of mine and the silk canopy neatly laid out behind, I prepared to float into space.

The slope we were on, at the top of the Col de la Loze in Courchevel, was gently skiable for about 50 yards, and then plummeted away into a death-defying couloir. I prayed we would take off before we ended up sliding down it. No fear of that - when Serge gave the word, we let ourselves start moving down the slope for about five feet before we met with resistance from the canopy, which had immediately filled with air and stood puffed up behind us in a billowing wall of silk. Slowly we skied on until suddenly we seemed to be airborne. Then we weren't, and then we'd made it and were floating gently away from the mountainside.

I was expecting to be terrified, but the fear was all in the anticipation. Although we were miles above the valley floor - and rising - peering down between our skis at a huge quantity of nothing, I felt quite safe on my makeshift seat jammed in between Serge's legs.

Serge used strings to control the angle of the canopy, and before we knew it we were circling higher than the surrounding mountains. The views, of course, were special, though once I started to relax my death grip on Serge's legs I became more aware of the biting cold.

The other unexpected problem was air sickness. The gentle swaying motion, compounded with the odd bumpy bit when we hit a thermal, added up to a worrying bout of nausea. Concerned at the prospect of me throwing up over his equipment, Serge brought us down after just five minutes (the normal flight time being 10). As we descended, all worries about high-altitude vomiting faded at the prospect of trying to land in one piece. The cables of the chairlift looked threateningly in the way, and I had to close my eyes as we swooped just above them.

We landed with an ungainly thump. I promptly fell over backwards and struggled to my feet with the grace of a pregnant duck. But despite the fear, the sickness and the cold, once safely down I couldn't wait to be swooping above the peaks again.

Snowblading

If you've ever cursed your skis as you lumbered up the road with them slung over your shoulder, poles in hand, or if you've ever fallen having crossed your skis and ended up stuck in a snowdrift in a tangle of metal and fibreglass, you'll appreciate snowblades. Scarcely longer than boots, and not requiring poles, these are the minimalist approach to skiing.

I thought I'd give them a quick try on the nursery slopes initally before attempting anything I'd regret. I shuffled to the top of the slope, and tipped myself over the edge. And it was easy! I thundered down, doubtless looking totally unco-ordinated with my feet wide apart and my hands everywhere, but feeling as safe as if I was on my own feet.

The whole experience is much more instinctive than proper skis; it is more reminiscent of skidding on patches of ice in the school playground. With less thinking required to control your skis (at about 70cm long, you'd have to try hard to cross them) the sense of balance comes more naturally. I found myself crouching to lower my centre of gravity, and automatically shifting weight from foot to foot. In less than an hour, I was tackling difficult runs with no problem.

The shortness of snowblades makes them useless for off-piste, and not terribly fast, though you feel like you are moving like snow off a shovel. But they come into their own on moguls. They turn on a sixpence, they are easy to jump with, a piece of cake to control and if you do bury them in a deep bit of snow, you simply step out of it. Even an intermediate skier like myself can confidently go down icy, bumpy, slushy black runs, something I would be nervous to attempt on regular skis.

It feels great having your hands free, although I was a bit at a loss as to what to do with them; I ended up waving at everybody and clicking my fingers in time to any tune going through my head as I grooved down the slope, jumping and turning and whizzing about.

I loved snowblades so much, for the convenience and ease and fun of them, that I considered not bothering going back to normal skis again; my only qualm was that while skiing feels like a proper sport, snowblades feel like a toy. But after all, what are the slopes but an enormous playground?

The practicals

All these activities are available in any major ski resort. Snow blades can be hired from any ski-hire shop for around FFr50 for half a day, and can be worn with ski boots.

Anna Rockall paraglided from the Col de la Loze, Courchevel 1850, France, and booked it through Chardon Loisirs, 04 79 08 39 60. Price FFr450 for 10-15 minutes.

She went ice-climbing in Val d'Isère, France, for FF250 for an hour, which can be split between several people. A minimum of two hours is needed. Contact the Val d'Isère Mountain Guides' Office to arrange a guide (04 79 06 94 03).

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Meat-free Paris | Long-range golf | Cruises for all | Top ski resorts | Inter-capital rail | Christmas holidays | Holidays in France
fields.body:
Meat-free Paris

A guide to meat-free eating in France, timely considering the latest BSE crisis there, has been published by Travelscene, the city breaks specialist. Meat Free Paris, available to clients booking a short break to the French capital, includes a broad selection of restaurants, ranging from the chic, celebrity-chef restaurants like Alain Ducasse's Spoon (14, rue de Marignan 75008 tel: 01 40 76 34 44) to cheap and cheerful eateries. Travelscene 0870 7774445.

Long-range golf

Hong Kong's disused Kai Tak airport runway is now home to Oriental Golf City, what is thought to be the world's largest driving range with 500 bays. Fees start at HK$70 (£6.30) an hour midweek. Tel: 00 852 2522 2111. Hong Kong Tourist Association: 020-7533 7100.

www.discoverhongkong.com

Cruises for all

Holidaymakers with special needs now have access to tailored information on holidays at sea. The Cruise Information Service has launched a free factsheet on cruise holidays for the disabled and those with special needs. Tel: 020-7436 2449.

www.cruiseinformationservice.co.uk

Ski to the top

The top 10 resorts being booked for skiing by Neilson so far this season are 1 Meribel, 2 Val Thorens, 3 Banff, 4 Pas de la Casa, Andorra, 5 Soldeu, Andorra, 6 Sauz d'Oulx, Italy, 7 La Thuile, Italy, 8 Kitzbuhel, 9 Soll, 10 Borovets, Bulgaria. Tel: 08705 141414

www.neilson.co.uk

The fastest run

The world's fastest inter-capital rail service is the Thalys-run link between Paris and Brussels, covering the 312km in 1hr 25mins. Thalys is a joint venture between the French, Belgian, Dutch and German railways. Rail Europe Direct 08705 848848.

Tinsel to go

Some 32% of Britons travelling abroad for Christmas say they will pack tinsel and a Christmas stocking, according to a Thomas Cook survey. More than half of those questioned say they will eat a traditional turkey dinner, while 89% say they will phone home on December 25. An estimated 290,000 will go abroad.

French source

An exhibition highlighting holidays in France, Vive La France, is being held at Olympia, London from January 19 - 21. A highlight is recipe demonstrations from cordon bleu chefs. Tickets cost £10 in advance. Tel: 0870 1200164

www.vivelafrance.co.uk

fields.headline: Married to the mob
fields.standfirst: A modest start to her acting career helped prepare Edie Falco for her role in Judy Berlin, but nothing could have prepared her for life as Mrs Soprano
fields.trailText: A modest start to her acting career helped prepare Edie Falco for her role in Judy Berlin, but nothing could have prepared her for life as Mrs Soprano
fields.body:
One day, you're a semi-anonymous jobbing actress from Long Island working with Hal Hartley and Abel Ferrara. The next thing you know, you've garnered worldwide critical praise as the long-suffering mobster's wife in hit TV show The Sopranos. Not that 36-year-old Edie Falco has let it go to her head, as her latest movie, Judy Berlin, proves. It took the director's prize for her long-time friend Eric Mendelsohn at Sundance last year, and sees Falco in the title role; a semi-anonymous jobbing actress from Long Island. And who said truth was stranger than fiction?

Did you recognise Judy's plight as a struggling actress?

Yes. God knows I was a struggling actress for a long time, but our approaches were very different. It seems clear that Judy has known that this is what she wants to do. I almost fell into this, rather than aiming towards it. I've been acting since I was 18. My mom was an actress in community theatre when I was growing up. I've always done it, but I'd always figured that I'd do it at weekends, and have a real job also. Judy is on more of a ballistic mission than I was.

Did you ever have the desire to do the LA thing like Judy?

Nah. My family's in New York, my life is there, my house is there and my friends all live within a few blocks in the West Village. Every year my actor friends do the exodus in January, for pilot season, and I say goodbye to them until July. They all come back looking like they've been hit by a truck.

You stayed in New York to work with, among others, Abel Ferrara. How was he?

He's a kook. A first-class kook. And he's brilliant. So bright and so respectful of actors. He makes you feel important. Then he would disappear for hours, and nobody would know where he was, and he'd be in the park talking to a tree.

Were you surprised how successful The Sopranos has been?

webTitle: From trailer park to Central Park

fields.headline: From trailer park to Central Park
fields.standfirst: Don't believe what anyone says about America being a classless society. Woody Allen's Small Time Crooks shows that snobbery is just as rife across the Atlantic. John Patterson reports
fields.trailText: Don't believe what anyone says about America being a classless society. Woody Allen's Small Time Crooks shows that snobbery is just as rife across the Atlantic. John Patterson reports
fields.body:
When it comes to class distinctions and serious snobbery, we British tend to believe we're top dogs. We have royalty in Buckingham Palace. We have aristocrats in the House of Lords. We have an extremely snooty middle class, a vociferous, boisterous working class and a nearly invisible underclass. Each is separated from its nearest neighbour by layers of well-nuanced resentment, smugness, irrational fear and mutual contempt. And whenever two or more Englishmen gather in foreign parts, they will spend several minutes circling each other warily until they decide whether the other is someone they'd ever be caught dead talking to back home. It's a sickness.

Americans would have us believe that they're past all this. They had a revolution, after all, and the Declaration of Independence enshrined social equality as a right shared by all men. But as any slave or woman could have told you in 1776, America had a class system the moment the citizenry briefly tried to make George Washington king.

Though they're loath to admit it, Americans have a class system that in its own pseudo-egalitarian way is just as visible and divisive as the British one. We're used to decoding all the social signals that separate, say, Lucinda Lambton from Ricky Tomlinson, but unlike us, Americans don't spend much time attempting to locate precisely and minutely the dodgy social origins and non-U accents of their neighbours and co-workers.

It's almost impossible to imagine America breeding an indigenous Mike Leigh to chronicle acute moments of social embarrassment and class awkwardness. Which is not to say these things don't exist. Cultural distance means that we're less adept at analysing those signals in a roomful of Americans, but they're still legible if you know how. Class masquerades as wealth at the top of the scale and is often displaced into race at the bottom end, but in the broad middle there are a zillion finely calibrated distinctions.

Look at Woody Allen's Small Time Crooks, in which Brooklyn manicurist Frenchy Winkler (Tracey Ullman) suddenly finds she and her husband Ray (Allen) are rich beyond their wildest dreams and able to hobnob with a better class of person. Frenchy lusts after "the finer things" and hooks up with Hugh Grant's crooked art dealer, who has the very thing that guarantees class and style to many Americans: he's English. Thus he can aid her in her quest for "quality" and good taste, that indefinable je ne sais quoi allegedly imparted by close association with European culture and cuisine, and with British nobs (he finds her "unspeakably vulgar" , of course). So it is that ex-stripper Frenchy (formerly known as "Frenchy, The Topless Wonder" ) and ex-con and hapless thief Ray find themselves ineptly serving snails to the kind of people who, unlike them, actually know how to eat them. "Snails leave a scum trail when they walk," whines Ray. "Not in France," snaps Frenchy.

The chance to express themselves through expenditure and acquisition is what brings the couple out in all their tacky glory. Money may well be the root of all evil, it may well buy you happiness, but if you have rotten cheap tastes then the one thing you can guarantee is money will find you out.

If money can do one thing, many Americans theorise, it can go some way towards erasing the stain of one's origins. The fear that others might discover you have one foot in the trailer-park is a great motivator. Just as the British know precisely what separates South Kensington from, say, Droitwich, Americans are highly alert to the differences between Beverly Hills and Catfish Junction, Alabama - and will move heaven and earth to erase any stigma based on origin.

Just look at the Kennedys, America's "Royal Family" . There wouldn't have been a President Kennedy or any senators had not their father Joseph Kennedy spent his entire life attempting to break away from his Boston Irish roots and ingratiate himself with the landed American aristocrats of Boston and New York. "Tell me," Rose Kennedy is said to have asked an aristocratic schoolfriend of JFK's in 1939, when her family was already rich but beset by the wildest forms of social insecurity, "when are the good people of Boston going to accept us Irish?" In the end they had to accept them, if only because of the sheer force of Kennedy Sr's social ambitions. But it will take generations before the aristocracy Joe wanted his sons to join will let the Kennedys forget that their real roots are in the Irish ghetto and their past is deeply tainted by Joe Kennedy's extensive activities as a bootlegger during Prohibition.

Similarly the moguls of young Hollywood. They feared anti-Semitism above all else and skirted it by utterly suppressing their Jewish origins both in their public lives and in the movies they oversaw down to the last detail. Having been kept out of "respectable" business activities by anti-Semitism on the part of the kind of people Joe Kennedy aspired to be like, they got their sweet revenge when the "disreputable" nickelodeons they'd bought up suddenly began to make them the richest men alive. As movies came of age in the 1930s, the moguls constructed a notion of "class" or classiness through the decor, the repartee, the costumes and the social attitude of their productions that came to be seen as uniquely expressive of "The American Dream" . Thus all of America came to dream in the terms laid out by a group of socially awkward insecure Jewish immigrants, which must have been supremely gratifying to them, even as they were kept out of gentile neighbourhoods and country clubs till well into the 60s.

And at the top of the heap, of course, is the class that kept those country clubs "restricted", the class that sneered at the Kennedys' nouveau-riche aspirations, and which still largely owns and runs the United States. America's Wasp aristocracy (of which George W Bush is a Texicanised scion) is based around the Groton and Harvard-educated owners of the great banking and investment houses on Wall Street and the ancient law firms that do their bidding. This is the class Edith Wharton wrote about in The Age Of Innocence and The House Of Mirth. They're the people painted by John Singer Sargent: the Roosevelts, the Vanderbilts, the Rockefellers, the Aldriches and so on. They'd like us to believe that they're all descended from the pilgrims who arrived on the Mayflower in 1620, though any fool can tell you that if everyone who claimed to be descended from the Pilgrim Fathers actually was, then the Mayflower must have been a jumbo-supertanker. In fact it was the size of a double-decker bus.

Their tailoring is echt-British aristocracy (Savile Row, LL Bean and Brooks Brothers), as were many of their accents until the turn of the century (Scorcese cast English actors as Yankee aristos in The Age Of Innocence) and their ghastly social isolationism. There's a distinct element of the cultural cringe in the way this class associates Englishness with high style and good taste, while apparently remaining blithely unaware that England is no longer a hellhole of Merchant-Ivory literary adaptations, eccentric toffs, smiling butlers and singing chimney sweeps. Above all there is a determination to reassociate themselves with the very Brits the pilgrims sought to get away from. All of which leads one to speculate that when it comes to moronic social minutiae and divisive class differences, we British really are the top dogs.

 Small Time Crooks is on general release

fields.headline: Terrorist acts
fields.standfirst: The guerrilla film-makers in John Waters' latest movie recall the most inept and hedonistic terror groups of the 70s. David Eimer explores the legacy of the Weathermen and the SLA
fields.trailText: The guerrilla film-makers in John Waters' latest movie recall the most inept and hedonistic terror groups of the 70s. David Eimer explores the legacy of the Weathermen and the SLA
fields.body:
Film-makers have been biting the hand that feeds them ever since the silent days, but only John Waters would send up his trade by creating a misfit crew of cinematic revolutionaries who are so intent on cleansing the world of bad films that they'll kill anyone who gets in their way. Cecil B Demented, Waters' 12th feature, is as inspired as its title, a satire that gleefully pokes fun at Hollywood while offering an alternative history lesson on the radical organisations of late 60s and early 70s America.

Waters' would-be auteurs, the Sprocket Holes, are led by Sinclair Stevens, a Baltimore cinema manager by day, who at night becomes Cecil B Demented, guerrilla film-maker and art terrorist. As played by a manic Stephen Dorff, he's so determined to make his first film that he kidnaps A-list star Honey Whitlock, a valiant Melanie Griffith, and forces her at gunpoint to take the lead in his no-budget epic.

From then it's an increasingly frenzied ride as the Sprockets shut down multiplexes showing the director's cut of Patch Adams, attack a Hollywood movie that's shooting locally and become cult heroes via a willing media, while all the time making their own film.

But if Waters' targets are predictable - the rampant sentimentality and commerciality of most studio product - then his masterstroke is the way the Sprockets mimic the rhetoric and actions of now-forgotten terrorist groups like the Weathermen and the Symbionese Liberation Army (SLA).

Emerging out of the anti-Vietnam war student protests of 1968 and 1969, the Weathermen, who took their name from a line in Bob Dylan's Subterranean Homesick Blues ("You don't need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows" ), were middle-class, mostly white Marxists who in 1970 called for "an armed struggle against the state" and immediately went underground to do just that. Unfortunately, though, they weren't very good at the terrorist game. In fact, despite planting bombs at the Pentagon and other defence installations, the only casualties from their campaign were three of their own, who blew up themselves and their swanky Greenwich Village apartment in 1971. This is hardly surprising, given that their real talent lay in winding up middle America with outrageous slogans and a lifestyle that put the "h" into hedonism.

Loading up on any drug they could lay their hands on, sleeping with each other in rotation and occasionally bounding on stage at rallies to announce, "We're about being crazy motherfuckers and scaring the shit out of honky America", the spirit of the Weathermen lives on in the Sprockets.

No sex before a mission, the compulsory tattooing of their favourite directors, Preminger, Warhol, Castle and Fassbinder among them, on their arms and the endless chanting of their slogan, "Demented Forever", makes for a nicely paranoid and twisted group of daydreaming cine-revolutionaries. But if the Weathermen were more farcical than fanatical, the SLA were sinister. Led by Donald "Cinque" DeFreeze, their most famous action was the kidnapping of newspaper heiress Patricia Hearst in 1974. Locked in a cupboard for 50 days and hectored constantly by DeFreeze and his cohorts, Hearst subsequently emerged as a fully fledged urban guerrilla who took a new name, Tania, started denouncing her family as "corporate liars" and was photographed robbing a bank while toting a machine gun and sporting a Che-chic beret.

Waters didn't have to look too far when he reproduced this in Cecil, with Melanie Griffith's character representing Hearst and Dorff as the mysterious DeFreeze, because Patricia Hearst has been appearing in his movies since 1990's Cry-Baby. Pardoned by President Carter for her role in the SLA, she went on to marry her bodyguard and to launch an acting career that's been confined to cameos in Waters' films, including Cecil, and the Pauly Shore vehicle Bio-Dome.

Given his long-standing interest in all things deviant, it's no shock that the 54 year-old Waters should have been aware of the Weathermen and the SLA. What is surprising, though, is the way those groups have mostly been erased from history so soon after they flourished.

But Americans are notoriously squeamish when it comes to re-visiting the less palatable parts of their past and so while there are plenty of harmless hippies in American popular culture, the radical left gets short shrift.

Perhaps unsurprisingly, the conspiracy-driven X Files has picked up on the phenomenon. The April 2000 Hollywood AD episode, written and directed by David Duchovny, saw Garry Shandling playing an ageing Weatherman.

Before that, you have to go back to 1988 when two very different films revisited the era. The least interesting was Paul Schrader's Patty Hearst, which featured a young Ving Rhames as DeFreeze and our own Natasha Richardson as Hearst. Adapted from Hearst's own book, it's singularly uninvolving, even if it is an improvement on the 1979 TV movie The Ordeal Of Patty Hearst, which starred a 20-year-old Rosanna Arquette.

Far better is Running On Empty, which is also notable for containing River Phoenix's finest performance. An oblique look at the Weathermen, it sees him playing the teenage son of parents who have been on the run from the FBI since they bombed a napalm lab in 1971. It's a masterly look at the consequences of misplaced, youthful idealism and what it's like to spend your life permanently looking over your shoulder. It must have been compulsory viewing for all those ex-radicals who quietly disappeared back into ordinary American life, once the Weathermen and SLA imploded through indifference and informers in the mid-70s.

But Running On Empty was more than just a nostalgia trip, as Sara Jane Olsen discovered on June 16, 1999. Pulled over by police in St Paul, Minnesota, the doctor's wife, soccer mom, avid cook and keen amateur actress was revealed to be one Kathleen Ann Soliah, a former SLA member who had been on the lam for 23 years after being charged in her absence with a 1976 attempt to bomb an LAPD patrol car.

In typical, incompetent SLA fashion the device didn't even go off, but that hasn't stopped the on-going trial of Soliah, who swiftly published the Serving Time Cookbook to help finance her high-profile defence. But being able to bake a decent cookie doesn't cut any ice with the Feds, even if many people are wondering exactly what is the point of prosecuting the affable Soliah, especially as she's been a law-abiding citizen for so long. The answer is that the late 60s and early 70s remains one of the most turbulent periods in US history and there are still plenty of people alive who resent the fact that Nixon fell, Vietnam was lost and that all those freaky longhairs didn't get what was coming to them. As Soliah faces the prospect of a long jail term, her only consolation is that a movie deal must be round the corner.

 Cecil B Demented is out on Friday

But being able to bake a decent cookie doesn't cut any ice with the Feds, even if many people are wondering exactly what is the point of prosecuting the affable Soliah, especially as she's been a law-abiding citizen for so long. The answer is that the late 60s and early 70s remains one of the most turbulent periods in US history and there are still plenty of people alive who resent the fact that Nixon fell, Vietnam was lost and that all those freaky longhairs didn't get what was coming to them. As Soliah faces the prospect of a long jail term, her only consolation is that a movie deal must be round the corner.  Cecil B Demented is out on Friday

fields.headline: Set your mind at rest
fields.standfirst: There's a wealth of difference in insurance policies.  Roger Bray wades through the fine print
fields.trailText: There's a wealth of difference in insurance policies. Roger Bray wades through the fine print.
fields.body:
Winter sports insurance often defies logic. Assessment of what represents an acceptable risk will always vary between underwriters. But skiers and snowboarders comparing policies closely will discover ludicrous anomalies.

Why does one company regard heliskiing as an extreme sport while another covers it at no additional cost? Why should one policy allow off-piste skiing without a guide, while another excludes it? And why should you get compensation when there is too little snow to ski on, but not if there is too much?

Sometimes these absurdities appear to stem from ignorance. Ask your insurers if you are covered to go snowcat skiing. Unless you are insured by a skiing specialist, it is unlikely they will have a clue what you are talking about.

Snowcat skiing is an option in many US and Canadian resorts. It involves travelling off piste to untracked snow by a converted piste machine and is usually cheaper than going by helicopter - but the risks are surely much the same. Yet at least one firm, which covers customers taking the cat, demands extra if they fly.

Even between firms with acknowledged expertise there can be contradictions. Hamilton Barr, for example, will not cover heliskiing if it is booked before you travel, because of the potentially high cancellation cost. Inghams, however, will only provide cover if you pre-book, to ensure you have booked with a reputable operator.

About two things there can be no argument. First, it would be foolish to take no insurance at all. Though many basic medical costs in Europe are covered if you take an E1-11 form, it will not pay for a mountain rescue, which could set you back around £1,000 if a helicopter is needed, and it does not cover additional repatriation costs. Nor does it stretch to North America, where even a relatively minor injury can cost several hundred pounds and the average bill for torn ligaments is around £2,500.

And second, it pays to read the small print. If you plan to stick to piste skiing, there are fewer pitfalls. However, there are certain essentials you should check. Does the policy provide a decent level of liability cover - against the risk that you injure someone who then sues you? You ought to have at least £1 million-worth in North America. Will it cover the hire of skis, boots or clothes if your bags go AWOL? Insurance organised by the Ski Club of Great Britain, for example, pays up to £150 if luggage is delayed - but only if it is more than 24 hours late.

Will you get compensation if you are unable to ski? Until recently, most policies coughed up only if customers were frustrated by too little snow.

The spate of avalanches two seasons ago caused a rethink. Some insurers now pay out if such hazards force the closure of pistes. One example is the cover organised by tour operator Inghams. It pays compensation of £30 a day if all lifts are closed for any reason - provided it is not possible to transport you to alternative slopes. With admirable precision, it says baby drag lifts or those used to carry non-skiers around resorts do not count.

It would also be wise to check whether you are covered for fringe activities, such as racing around on a snowmobile.

For those intent on heading off piste, things become trickier. How do you define a piste? Must you stay strictly on groomed snow - or is it safe to take a few turns in the powder alongside? Insurers apply what they call the "test of reasonableness". Thus, if a boarder with a policy excluding off-piste skiing was injured on a jump within sight of a prepared run, it might pay out. But if the same customer strayed deep into unpatrolled territory, it probably would not.

For regular travellers and families, an annual policy, which covers trips other than winter sports holidays, can be economic. American Express Centurion, for example, covers your children on a school trip. But never renew such policies without checking for changes. Some years ago I dis covered that off-piste skiing had been excluded from mine. The company insisted it had informed policy holders but I could not recall receiving any communication.

Insurers often offer two levels of cover with different premiums. Sometimes it is worth paying the extra. Sometimes it is not. Whether you need more than £2m worth of medical cover, for example, is debatable. Who knows of a claim for a higher amount?

One example of souped-up cover that would be worth paying for is Hamilton Barr's Excel. At £33.77 for up to 10 days in Europe or £55.86 worldwide it costs only £3.47 or £8.33 more than the firm's respective standard policies. But it pays out up to £800 if your ski equipment is lost, damaged or stolen - double the amount covered by the cheaper policy.

If you are stuck in hospital as the result of an accident, it will pay £30 a day "inconvenience" cover, for expenses such as taxis to get friends to your bedside - double the standard figure. And it covers up to £600 worth of physiotherapy when you get home - which is also not included under the cheaper deal.

fields.headline: Open society
fields.standfirst: Roly Smith steps back in to the middle ages in the Midlands
fields.trailText: Roly Smith steps back in to the middle ages in the Midlands.
fields.body:
Even after several visits, it still comes as a bit of a surprise to happen upon the broad, open fields of Laxton to the east of Ollerton in north Nottinghamshire. All around are the the hawthorn-hedged, tightly-enclosed fields so typical of the Midlands shires, punctuated here and there by copses which often provide the last refuges for wildlife.

But as you climb up from the flood plain of the Trent to reach Laxton, which stands at just under 300ft (90m), it feels as if you have been suddenly transported from the East Midlands to the prairies of East Anglia. Horizons broaden, the hedges disappear and the sky opens up as you step back 1,000 years into a unique little bit of Old England.

Laxton is the only village in England that still practises the open-field system of agriculture, common throughout the country during the middle ages. This amazing survival is thought to be due to the fact that the two major landowners, Earl Manvers and the Earl of Scarborough, could not reach agreement on how and where the enclosures should take place during the early 19th century.

Although some partial enclosure did happen, by the start of the 20th century, Laxton's importance as a unique historical landscape was recognised, and the emphasis changed to the preservation of the old system, encouraged by the county council and the Countryside Agency.

Laxton, (or Laxintune or Lexington as it has also been known) was already a well-established village by the time of the Norman conquest. Roman remains have been found at Fiddler's Balk in the West Field, and many of the names still in use, such as toft, flatt, gate and syke, are of Danish origin, showing that Scandinavian invaders also left their mark on this ancient landscape. The name comes from the Anglo-Saxon and means "the settlement of Leaxa's people".

In William the Conqueror's great land register, the Domesday Book of 1086, "Laxintune" is already shown to be a cultivated and populous village, consisting of an adult population of around 35 villiens, bordars and serfs (including, unusually, one female serf or ancilla), supporting a total population of perhaps 100-120 people. The Domesday entry also shows that the people of Laxton were cultivating about 720 acres of arable land, with about 40 acres of pasture for mowing, and woodland providing pannage (acorns and beechmast) for pigs, and for fuel and building timber.

The well-preserved earthworks of the Norman motte and bailey castle on the northern edge of the village date from the late 11th century, and feature an unusual extra cone on the summit of the "motte," the mound on which the original timber tower was built. It was from here that King John enjoyed many weeks of good hunting in the royal Forest of Sherwood, which was then stocked with herds of deer and wild boar, packs of wolves and possibly outlaws.

The castle proved to be a popular lodge for a succession of medieval monarchs including Henry II and Edward I. It fell into decay in the 14th century, but the Roos family built a three-gabled manor house, now also disappeared, to the south of the site in the 17th century. Today, there are spectacular views from the tree-topped motte across the marching pylons towards the great billowing cauldrons of the power stations of the Trent Valley to the east, and over the village of Laxton and its West Field.

The village's open-field system was probably already in place by the time of Domesday. Basically, it relies on a three-field rotation system, where in any one year, one field is sown with winter wheat; the second, a spring-sown crop such as barley, and the third is left fallow. All village farmers have the right to use the land in strips or furlongs in the three great open fields of Laxton: the West Field, the Mill Field and the South Field.

Uniquely, Laxton's open-field system is still administered by the Court Leet, a form of manorial government surviving from medieval times. On Jury Day, usually held at about this time of the year, an inspection is made of the open fields, checking that everything is in order. This is followed a week later by the Court Leet held in the Dovecote Inn, where officials and a new jury are appointed and fines are imposed.

Our walk starts from the village car park, near the visitor centre. Turn left on to the road past the Dovecote Inn, passing the site of the walled pinfold (for impounding stray animals) in Kneesall Road. Bear right at the junction with the Moorhouse Road and, after about 200 yards, turn right by the second wooden footpath sign on to the broad, muddy trackway known as the Langsyke.

This leads up through a gate and an avenue of young beeches into a holloway and out on to Mill Field, the largest of the three great open fields of Laxton. In the summer, if the field is in arable use, you will be able to see different crops growing in the different strips, and there are fine views right back towards the village and the church tower.

Ascend the broad green headland for about 500 yards (550m), towards a prominent interpretive sign from which views extend, on a clear day, as far as the triple towers of Lincoln Cathedral, 17 miles away to the east. Turn sharp right at this junction on to a metalled farm track which leads out to the Ollerton Road. This is crossed and you follow a grassy, often wet holloway, turning right at the junction with another towards the end of the main street of the village, with the church tower ahead.

Just before reaching the street, turn left on to a farm track. After about 150 yards, leave the track, turning left over a stile by a footpath sign partly hidden by the hedge. Cross another stile which leads across the West Field via Hall Lane, a wet, deeply- hedged green track. Follow the lane for about 500 yards, where a gate and sign leads left across a field towards the earthworks of the castle, surrounded by ageing hawthorn trees.

Retrace your steps back to the lane, where you go straight ahead to arrive back into the village nearly opposite the church. The beautiful, mainly 13th-century parish church of St Michael the Archangel had, like the castle, fallen into disuse and "impious neglect" until it was remodelled by Earl Manvers in 1854. Note the grotesque gargoyles on the battlements of the nave, and the remains of a medieval preaching cross in the churchyard.

From here, it is a short walk down the Main Street and back to the Dovecote Inn.

The practicals

The walk is a combination of routes suggested in the Laxton village guide, published by the trustees and obtainable from the visitor centre, and will feature in the forthcoming Walks Through Britain's History, published by the AA. It is about four miles (6.5km) in length, mainly on field paths and holloway lanes which can be very wet and muddy, especially after rain. The best map covering the area is the Ordnance Survey's 1:25,000 Explorer No 271, Newark-on-Trent and Retford. Good pub food can be obtained at the Dovecote Inn (01777 871586). The nearest railway station is Mansfield, about five miles away. National rail enquiries 0345 484950. For accommodation, contact the tourist information centre at Sherwood Heath, Ollerton Roundabout (01623 824545).
