webTitle: Alternative therapies from around the world

fields.headline: Alternative therapies around the world
fields.trailText: Five completely different ways to relax and detox.
fields.body:
Osho Commune meditation commune, Poona, India

If you are looking for a completely different experience without leaving the planet, this resort could be it. Meditation is the main draw but there's also the creativity caravan for pottery, painting and sculpture. For the more sporty there's "zennis" - zen tennis - which is like tennis but without the ball. Having to wear red robes and take an "on-the-spot" Aids test to gain entry may be offputting to many. A range of hotels and apartments are within walking distance.

Prices: Entry and day meditation pass £2. Programmes from around £30.

Tel : 00 91 20 613 6655.

Getting there: Fly to Bombay or Delhi then to Poona. Return flight from London to Bombay or Delhi with British Airways from £500.

The Spa Resort & Health Center, Koh Samui, Thailand

The "clean-me-out" fasting programme attracts devotees from all over. Described as "the ultimate in cleansing and rejuvenation of your entire system", it involves specially prepared intestinal cleansers and herbal tablets, plus a twice-daily enema colon cleansing over a seven-day period. Instruction is given on how to use the "enema boards", which regular visitors swear by.

Prices: Start from £160 plus, chalets from £4-£9 a night.

Tel: 00 6677 230 855.

Getting there: Return flights to Koh Samui from London Heathrow via Bangkok with Qantas Airways from £500.

Somatheeram Ayurvedic Rejuvenation Centre, Kerala, India

Ayurvedic is the most fashionable spa treatment but the Indian centres offering this are quite stark. Somatheeram is a mix of beach resort and ayurvedic medicine. Surrounded by 15 acres of greenery, it has a dedicated ayurvedic centre, where an individual programme will be prescribed for you.

Prices: Around £30 for cottages, £175 for a deluxe suite during high season, room only.

Tel: 00 91 471 481600, www.somatheeram.com

Getting there: Return flights from London Heathrow to Trivandrum from £425 with Qatar Airways.

Blue Lagoon, Iceland

This geothermal spa 40 minutes' drive from Reykjavik has undergone a revamp, including man-made "beaches" and a restuarant. But the setting is still impressive. The lagoon is a pool of mineral-loaded seawater in the middle of a lava field with a power plant in the background. Its milky aquamarine hue comes from the blue-green algae and white silica mud on the bottom. It is open every day of the year. There is no accommodation at the lagoon but there are regular buses from Reykjavik and Keflavik.

Price: Half-day around £6, full day around £11.

Tel: 00 354 420 8800.

Getting there: Return flights from Heathrow to Reykjavik start at £300 with Icelandair.

Skyros Centre

An alternative centre on the Greek island. Courses intended to boost creativity and spirituality include the predictable - yoga, massage, shiatsu - to the more offbeat (stand-up comedy, clowning and baking bread). The day begins with either swimming in the Aegean, meditation or yoga.

Prices: From £625 two weeks' half-board not including flights.

Tel: 020-7267 4424.

Getting there: Flights can be arranged through Griffin Aviation (020-7814 9977). Return to Athens from £239 and transfers to Skyros from £95 (inc one nights' accommodation in Athens).

fields.headline: The Griffin, Powys
fields.trailText:
Address: Llyswen, Brecon, Powys, Wales LD3 OUR.
Tel: 01874 754241.
Web address: www.griffin-inn.co.uk
fields.body:
Address: Llyswen, Brecon, Powys, Wales LD3 OUR.
Tel: 01874 754241.
Web address: www.griffin-inn.co.uk

First impressions: Cosy, classic-looking country inn with rooms above. In the summer it is covered with virginia creeper. Stone-flagged main bar, with real fire, used by locals and visitors. Run by the Stockton family for generations and they have friendly, low-key, good service down to a tee. Well-kept beer including Flowers IPA. Companions said the Guinness was in good nick too.

What are the rooms like? Straight, unfussy, with everything you need, including en-suite, TV, radio-clock. They would not win any design awards but that misses the point.

The bed test: No problems.

webTitle: The world's only wine spa near Bordeaux

fields.headline: Roll in the barrel
fields.standfirst: The world's only wine spa has been uncorked near Bordeaux.  Gillian Rhys  takes the plunge
fields.trailText: The world's only wine spa has been uncorked near Bordeaux. Gillian Rhys takes the plunge.
fields.body:
The waitress is so shocked she can hardly contain herself: I'm not having wine with my lunch? After a few seconds of stunned silence, she adds with further disbelief: "And I suppose you're not having pudding either?"

Okay, so I'm in France, where not partaking in the finer things in life is practically sacrilegous, but I am in a health spa. Then again, this is the world's only vinotherapy centre and it is dedicated to beauty treatments derived from grapes. Denial is definitely not on the agenda here - as well as a cellar of 13,000 wines, there's a Michelin-starred restaurant and a cigar room. You're even encouraged to join a wine-tasting session at the nearby chateau.

The name of this unique spa is Les Sources de Caudalie, and beauticians at the centre, 15 minutes' drive from Bordeaux, believe that as well as imbibing a couple of glasses of wine a day, we should be bathed and massaged in it, too. The theory is that the humble grape pip is highly effective at countering skin damage caused by free radicals (smoking, pollution and sunlight).

Which is why, later that afternoon, I find myself lying on a plastic sheet being slathered with wine and honey. The sheet is wrapped around me, then covered with what looks like a thermal blanket and I'm left to doze in a gloopy cocoon for 20 minutes. Not only is this baccanalian-sounding process strangely relaxing, it is meant to render me lithe, toned and youthful to boot.

Vinotherapy is the brainchild of Mathilde Cathiard, whose parents own the Chateau Smith Haut Lafitte wine estate. With the help of dermatologists at Bordeaux university, Mathilde launched a line of skincare a few years ago, using the byproducts from her parents' wine-making business. Last year, she opened the spa and diminutive four-star hotel among the vineyards.

Think of it as haute rustic - the appearance seems effortlessly country casual, but you can bet your life that every detail has been agonised over. The 23 bedrooms and six suites are each decorated in variations of boho chic. There's one room in a cabinesque building next to a small lake complete with a pair of swans.

The Maison de Lievre restaurant is out here, too, in this ridiculously romantic setting. But if a seven-course dinner is too much on a health break, there's the Table du Lavoir. Described as a "country inn", it is a casual eaterie with such hearty fare as rabbit stew, but it is still slickly stylish. Non-residents pour in to both places and, of course, since you're not a prisoner of this particular spa, you are free to explore the culinary delights of Bordeaux.

The spa itself is in a wooden outhouse, just a short trot from the hotel. Inside, the series of relaxation areas and beauty rooms exude a Zen-like calm - all large, airy spaces, pale wood and stone. While you're left in no doubt that vinotherapy is a serious business - the hushed silence of the spa suggests it is almost a temple to wine - the treatments themselves reveal a sense of humour. They read like a wine list - Sauvignon massage, crushed Cabernet body scrub, Merlot wrap, Premier Grand Cru facial . . .

And although you are not exactly frolicking in wine - any chance of a Kate Moss/Johnny Depp-style champange bath is out - the vino references are very much in your face. The barrel bath, for example, is a Jacuzzi clad in wood à la wine barrel. Powdered grape extract is added to the spa water so it is frothy and warm, but it is more like soaking in a barrel of British beer than vintage vin. From every treatment tub and table, you look out on to the 163 acres of vines through wooden-slatted windows - you can see out but no one can see in.

Alas, the invitingly sounding red vine bath turns out to be a big white tub unnervingly similar to the tubs for the elderly and infirm you see in small ads. But it is quite a treat none the less. Once submerged, jets start up everywhere, resulting in a sort of turbo-charged Jacuzzi. As with all the treatments here, extracts to "relax", "refine" and "slim" are added so all you have to do is lie there, no effort required. Definitely my kind of exercise.

My fellow guests were mainly professional couples of middle youth - impeccably preserved French women with bobbed hair and JP Todd driving shoes with their pot-bellied, expensive watch-wearing husbands. Many had children with them. Apparently this is the norm in French spas but it did seem a bit odd. Singletons such as myself were such a rarity that I felt distinctly awkward dining en seule. There is no chatty banter between guests and I even began to miss the enforced table-sharing of British health farms, which means that no one eats alone.

Nevertheless, I embraced the vinotherapy ethos wholeheartedly - in the spa, restaurant and bar. While you're not going to get fit here, you can't beat it for pure, unashamed relaxation. One thing still puzzles me, though. Over the few days of my stay it was scorchingly hot. All the guests, while paying a fortune to preserve their skin, were all too happy to roast in the sunshine in between beauty slots. I guess it is all wrapped up in the French paradox.

The practicals

Les Sources de Caudalie, Chateau Smith Haut Lafitte, Martillac (00 33 557 83 82 82, www.sources-caudalie.com). Prices start at £258 for a two-night weekend package, half board, including four treatments. Buzz (0870 2407070 www.buzzaway.com) flies to Bordeaux from Stansted from £95 return.

fields.headline: Bewildered in Bombay
fields.standfirst: Barely 24 hours after landing in India, Sue attempts to gets to grips with Bombay's traffic, beggars and tourist traps
fields.trailText: 'Tired, bewildered and in sensory overload just about sums up how I am feeling... but I have survived my first day and am getting into the swing of it slowly.' Barely 24 hours after landing in India, Sue gets to grips with Bombay
fields.body:
Wow, I am off!
Tired, bewildered and in sensory overload just about sums up how I am feeling. The flight and journey was all pretty uneventful, but then I hit India.

Thank goodness there was someone from the hotel to meet me, even if we could not communicate. What followed was the maddest car/van ride you probably could not even imagine - I thought many times that the first day of my adventure was going to be my last. How everyone misses each other I don't know - the sounding of horns is compulsory, even though it is totally ignored. I arrived at 2am, sank a beer and fell into bed.

Today I did not know what to do. I just scraped into breakfast at 10, changed some money, sorted the bag and decided that I must be brave and venture outside.

The taxi ride was even more hairy than last night's, as the volume of traffic and decibels of horns was even greater. I had been warned about beggars, but limbless children banging on the car window is still a shock. I arrived at the Gateway of India, bought the most expensive map ever, got anointed by some holy man who probably has put a curse on me for not giving him the 100 rupees he wanted, and jumped onto a boat to Elephant Island to escape the vendors and guides.

I began to relax a bit then and to enjoy myself. The caves were a disappointment as it cost the equivalent of 60p for Indians but $10 for all others. I declined to go in, but it was good to wander about in the sunshine. I met a young couple from Devon who were also a few days into a six-month world trip. They showed me a net cafe next to Leopalds, where I will shortly go for my first meal.

It certainly is a culture shock to come to Bombay as the first stop on my trip, but I have survived my first day and am getting into the swing of it slowly. A good night's sleep and the arrival of the tour guide tomorrow will transform things.

It is great to read the emails. I hope to respond to some when I have settled down a bit. Is it still raining back there? I am hungry - time to test out my constitution. Bye for a week!
Sue

fields.headline: Steamed up in Turkey
fields.trailText: It was after about three-quarters of an hour of being pummelled and washed and scrubbed like a baby by my middle-aged Turkish masseur that he leaned over and whispered: "You like?"
fields.body:
It was after about three-quarters of an hour of being pummelled and washed and scrubbed like a baby by my middle-aged Turkish masseur that he leaned over and whispered: "You like?"

Naked, sitting on the marble floor, I could only agree. He smiled. His next words were: "You give beeg teep." The transaction was quickly agreed and I promised that once he returned my trousers he could trouser 5 million lira.

And it was worth every lira.

The 300-year-old Turkish baths, Cagaloglu Hamami, in Istanbul are a must. The main bath rooms (one for men and one for women) are beautiful, all marble with big slabs in the middle where you lay down to relax with a little towel for cover.

After 10 minutes, a poke in the shoulder meant that my man had arrived. He started with an all-over massage. Then he gestured to the side where I sat on the marble floor beside a basin that looked like a font. He poured warm water over me and washed me from head to toe.

Then I lay down on the floor where there was more massaging and, just as I began to nod off, I thought: "That man is walking up and down my back, a back which has had lavish Harley Street treatment this past year." And he was. It was the highlight and soon, minus tip, I was taking tea in the delightful courtyard.

The trip to Istanbul had been on the 836-passenger Olympic Voyager, the world's fastest cruise ship, which made the journey from Athens, charging through the Dardanelles, overnight. The point about this stylish ship is that it can zip from one Mediterranean port to the next at 27 knots,so giving more time at each stop. It had a spa on board and that evening, feeling as clean as clean could be, I had a relaxing mudwrap and cranial massage.

A large gin and tonic was needed. After a double detox it was time for a tox.

The Practicals

The Olympic Voyager 's seven-day/three continent Grand Cruises run between May 5 and November 17, round trip from Piraeus, with prices from £1,173 (plus £146 port/air charges). Ports of call include Santorini, Alexandria, Port Said, Ashdod, Rhodes, Istanbul, Kusadasi and Mykonos.Tel: 0800 3583535. www.royalolympiccruises.com Cagaloglu Hamami , Cagaloglu, Istanbul. Basic bath US$10. Full works $30. Open 8am - 8pm. Tel: 0090 (0)212 522 2424, www.cagalogluhamami.com.tr

webTitle: Who lost their heart in Port Antonio, Jamaica?

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Port Antonio, Jamaica
fields.standfirst: Chris Salewicz
fields.trailText: Chris Salewicz
fields.body:
Why: In the 40s and 50s, Port Antonio was a society place: Errol Flynn lived there, as did Tallulah Bankhead. The Aga Khan had an island with one hotel, Frenchman's Cove, once the most luxurious in the world. Now the place is run-down but you can walk through its gardens to a perfect beach. When I went there in the 70s the roads were pot-holed, there was nothing in the shops and there were no tourists.

It is in the north-east with the Blue Mountains behind the town, which is where the rebels who fought the British came from. The people have kept that spirit. I once went into the mountains to see a healer who practised in a church and had a bucket full of mice skeletons, Jamaican dollars and wire wool she claimed to have taken from inside people to cure them.

What's the best thing: Visually, sensually and spiritually, Jamaica is magic realism made real.

My perfect day: Getting up early and going for a swim. Drinking bush tea, made from herbs, and eating peanut porridge. Strolling to the market to buy some fish, sweet potatoes and honey, sold in rum bottles, then home to cook it. There is still the sense that you can only do one big thing a day.

My advice: Talk to people of Jamaican origin and you may get a contact you can trust. Jamaica can be dangerous. You should dress down, behave modestly and watch your possessions. If you are careful, you will be all right.

How do I get there: Air Jamaica (020-8570 7999) flies to Kingstown for £457 plus taxes between December 25 and April 30.

Rude Boy, Once Upon A Time In Jamaica by Chris Salewicz is published by Victor Gollancz at £10.99

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: • Sarah Gardner is planning a holiday in the interior of Jamaica where ticks are a problem. She wants to find an effective repellent that can be used safely on small children.
fields.body:
 Sarah Gardner is planning a holiday in the interior of Jamaica where ticks are a problem. She wants to find an effective repellent that can be used safely on small children.

I camped on Rathlin Island in County Antrim, which has a lot of ticks. I was part of a camp of about 50 people, including very young children. The most used repellent was lemongrass essential oil. After applying sun protection, the lemongrass can be used diluted in carrier oil such as almond and rubbed on the legs, arms and torso.Take tweezers to remove any ticks that do take hold in the skin. Lavender oil can be safely applied neat after removal to help skin heal and stop infection.

Joanna Fursman

 Hilary Matthews is a teacher limited to travelling in high season. She wants advice on how to go on holiday without spending a fortune.

fields.headline: Making rail connections
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor journeys along the broken rails of British rail websites.
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor journeys along the broken rails of British rail websites.
fields.body:
This week's journey along the broken rails of British rail websites starts with Railtrack, the company all the others want to blame for this winter's chaos.

Railtrack
Saying sorry for the current inconvenience, according to Railtrack, just isn't enough. Hard to disagree with that one. The good news is that the re-railing programme is now one-third complete, and Railtrack has posted a detailed FAQ page which explains exactly what "gauge corner cracking" is and why speed restrictions were introduced as a result. Indeed, so thorough is the coverage here that you find out exactly what the restrictions are on every stretch of British track - although some of the figures have a question mark next to them. Happily, the entire timetable is online at 212.87.65.227/bin/query.exe/en. For details of the emergency timetable, however, we must move on to...

National Rail
A summary of each company's changes can be found in the "today's train running information" section. In better times, the train company promotions section is worth a visit - it lists all the special offers each company is running. These include offers such as WAGN's Mum2B special, under which pregnant season ticket holders are entitled to an upgrade to first class if there are no seats in standard carriages. However, as National Rail points out, "this site does not sell tickets, but provides links to sites that can sell tickets". Such as...

The Trainline.com
This is by no means the only online source of tickets. GNER and other companies are happy to sell them on their own sites. But the great advantage of the trainline.com is that it allows you to compare prices before buying, and thus track down the cheapest time to travel - which is not to say that companies may not offer their own exclusive deals. Next stop . . .

GNER
More emergency timetables and special offers.

Connex Download a speed restrictions map for your journey and claim compensation for the disruption.

First Great Western
Have just launched traindirect.com, which offers "exclusive savings" on some tickets. Not to be confused with thetrainline.com.

Anglia Railways
Anglia would like to be able to offer online booking, too, but unfortunately the company has been trying to upload its winter timetable since September 24.

webTitle: Top Tory admits election is lost

fields.headline: Top Tory admits election is lost
fields.trailText: December 12 2000: Party needs more time to find itself, says Gary Streeter
fields.body:
William Hague's troubles deepened yesterday when a shadow cabinet colleague admitted it was obvious his party had not yet found its voice and was unlikely to do so before the next election.

Effectively admitting that the party was likely to lose next spring's election, Gary Streeter , the shadow international development minister, said it might take the Conservatives a few more years to complete its rehabilitation.

"I think it is obvious that we have not yet found our voice. We have not yet perhaps fully grounded what 21st century Conservatism looks like. We've got five months to do it before the next general election. OK, maybe we won't quite complete the task in time, but we have got to do that task within the next few years."

He also praised the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, for personally struggling with the dilemma of how the Conservatives needed to move on.

Mr Streeter, a Christian, said he longed for the Tories to be thought of as the party of the poor. He was speaking the day after the Tories deserted the first government inspired Commons debate on poverty in Britain, leaving Labour and Liberal Democrats to debate the issue alone.

The Labour MP Caroline Flint said the absence of any Tory MPs for more than two hours spoke volumes about the priorities of the Conservatives. The party's front bench spokesman, Eric Pickles, left after making a brief speech.

Mr Streeter said in an interview with GMTV's The Review programme, to be shown on Sunday, that many of the party's new leading figures are largely unknown to the public.

His comments came as both published and private polls yesterday showed the Tories trailing badly and on course for a 100-seat defeat.

A poll in the London Evening Standard put Labour on 50 points in the capital, 19 ahead of the Conservatives. The Tories lost three-quarters of their seats in the capital in the 1997 election and would be likely to fare no better if they continue to trail by such a margin. Private polls suggest the Tories are also doing poorly in vital marginal seats.

Mr Streeter said there was "a third limb to 21st century Conservatism and it's about dealing with some of the social problems of the poor".

"I long for us to be thought of now as the party of the poor, that we are the voice for the people who have nothing because we are going to come up with radical policies to penetrate some of our inner city problems ... we've got to find much more radical ways drawing on the voluntary and faith based charitable sector to find solutions to people's misery in some of our inner cities."

Although he said the party had a strong team and he was confident of Mr Hague's leadership, Mr Streeter said: "I think one of the problems is we're in a period of transition. Some of our big beasts are retiring and a lot of older people are retiring and lot of younger people are coming through, but people have not heard of them yet, so that will take a while."

Similar refrains have been heard about the Conservative front bench for three years.

In recent weeks, the Tories have been concentrating their fire on the issue of Europe, but a massive bombardment on the issue of the European rapid reaction force, backed by close supporting fire from the Eurosceptic press, had no impact.

Polls in both the Daily Telegraph and the Mail on Sunday by separate polling organisations showed most voters thought Britain should contribute forces. The Mail on Sunday poll backed British involvement by 55% to 38%. The Telegraph poll showed 48% to 34% support.

fields.headline: The full treatments
fields.standfirst: From Baden-Baden to Budapest, and Henlow to Hua Hin,  Joanna Israelsohn picks 20 of the best places to pamper yourself around the world
fields.trailText: From Baden-Baden to Budapest, and Henlow to Hua Hin, Joanna Israelsohn picks 20 of the best places to pamper yourself around the world.
fields.body:
If health spas conjure up images of sulphurous pools and torturous diets, think again. No longer so concerned with curing ailments as preventing them, the modern spa focuses on promoting health through a range of luxurious treatments designed to pamper the body and relax the mind.

From Baden-Baden to Budapest, and Henlow to Hua Hin, take your pick from 20 of the best spas around the world.

Champneys

The grande dame of UK spa resorts puts the emphasis on alternative therapies. The food is great, as is the programme of free activities including pilates, total body stretch, fitness walks and beauty workshops. A weekend escape costs £400 including all meals, a daily massage and the use of facilities. Shiatsu (£70) and reiki (£75) are particularly good.

Champneys, Chesham Rd, Wigginton, Tring, Hertfordshire (01442 291111).

Stobo Castle

A fairy tale Gothic castle set on a 3,000-acre estate near Peebles, Stobo's lavish bedrooms look out on to sheep-filled fields and forests of Scots pine. A two-night health and beauty programme costs £165 including all meals, two body massages, facial massage, manicure and the use of facilities.

Added extras include hydrotherapy baths (£12.50), Dead Sea flotarium sessions (£28) and aromatherapy facials (£38).

Stobo Castle, Stobo, Peebleshire, Scotland (01721 760 600).

Chewton Glen

Set in a Relais & Chateaux Michelin-star hotel by the New Forest, it is a 20-minute walk from the sea. If you can't get to grips with doing nothing, the hotel has a nine-hole golf course, tennis courts and riding, sailing and fishing nearby. A three-day, half-board relax, unwind and detox break costs from £675 and includes the use of all facilities, two body treatments, one facial, a manicure or pedicure and a fitness consultation.

Want more? Try reflexology (£45), Indian head massage (£25) or shiatsu (£45).

Chewton Glen, New Milton, Hampshire (01425 275341).

Lucknam Park

A Palladian manor set in a 500-acre Wiltshire park, Lucknam Manor is an upmarket country house hotel with attached spa, rather than a health farm.

Popular with executive couples and TV celebrities, this is Noel Edmonds' favourite hideaway. Daily rates from £270 half-board (minimum stay two nights) including the use of all facilities. Choose such spa treatments as an algae wrap with full-body massage (£52), Clarins facials (£50) or Jessica manicures (£22).

Lucknam Park, Colerne, Wiltshire (01225 742777).

Ragdale Hall

A Victorian redbrick building set in landscaped gardens near Leicester, Ragdale Hall is incredibly friendly and relaxed. Food is delicious and healthy, and you are allowed vast amounts. A three-night total pampering package costs £321 and includes all meals, use of facilities, a facial, a mud envelopment treatment, a back, shoulder and neck massage and a conditioning foot and hand treatment. Choose from a daunting range of treatments including the Kanebo bathing ceremony (£70) and the Dead Sea discovery inch wrap weight-loss treatment (£61).

Ragdale Hall, Ragdale, nr Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire (01664 434 831).

The Dorchester

This is the ultimate in inner-city indulgence and great for star spotting. Cindy Crawford, Tom Cruise and George Bush are regulars at the Park Lane hotel's spa. Daily rate is from £305, including the use of all facilities. Extras include a 90-minute Eve Lom facial for £105, full-body massage (£65), Thai massage (£70) and a luxurious prenatal treatment (£120) for spoilt mums-to-be.

The Dorchester, Park Lane, London (020-7629 8888).

Grayshott Hall

A handsome Victorian house with rooms ranging from luxury suites to comfy singles. Mobiles are banned and guests pad around the hotel in dressing gowns and tracksuits. Daily rate is from £160 based on two sharing and includes all meals, a massage and use of facilities. A range of add-ons include facials and body wraps from £35.

Headley Rd, Grayshott, nr Hindhead, Surrey (01428 604 331).

Henlow Grange Health Farm

Set in 100 acres of parkland, Henlow Grange is relaxed and friendly with the emphasis on having a good time (healthily). One of the few health farms where coffee, cigarettes and alcohol are allowed and you are not made to feel guilty for doing nothing. A two-night, mid-week break costs £289.95 and includes all meals, two body massages, one facial, one scalp massage and use of facilities. More problem-specific treatments include sports massage (£27) and cellulite treatments from £42.

Henlow Grange Health Farm, Henlow, Bedforshire (01462 811111)

The Sanctuary Spa, Oasis Forest Village

Set in 400 acres on the edge of the Lake District National Park, the Oasis Forest Village offers great value spa breaks, with accommodation in lodges and self-contained apartments. A weekend break costs from £160 for two people and treatments include detoxifying algae wraps (£44), Jessica manicures (£32) and E'spa facials from £39.

The Sanctuary Spa at Oasis Lakeland Forest Village, Temple Sowerby, Penrith, Cumbria (08705 086000).

St David's Hotel and Spa

The super-stylish St David's Hotel on Cardiff Bay is one of the few spa hotels in Wales. The antithesis of the country house hotel, St David's is built like a slick cruise ship and all the minimalist rooms have private balconies with a sea view. A detoxifying two-night break costs £265 and includes all meals, a jet blitz, marine hydrotherapy bath, detoxifying algae wrap and a facial. Extras include full body massage (£35), mud wraps (£45) and manicures (£20).

St David's Hotel and Spa, Havana St, Cardiff Bay, Wales (02920 454045).

Germany

The 125-year-old Brenner's Park Hotel and Spa (recent guests: Yasser Arafat and Jacques Chirac) is situated on the edge of the historic spa town Baden-Baden. Past guests have included Queen Victoria and Napoleon III. A two-night Brenner's body-revival break with Erna Low (020-7584 2841) costs £685 and includes flights, half-board accommodation, a jet-lag treatment, a body treatment and a personal training session.

Cyprus

Le Meridien Limassol Spa & Resort, which opened this year, is set in a complex surrounded by waterfalls and grottos, with four sea-water pools. Treatments include sea-mud body wraps and algaeo-therapy detoxification.

Seven nights at Le Meridien with Argo Holidays (020-7331 7070) costs from £405 including flights and transfers. A seven-day spa package costs £430 and includes a medical evaluation, personalised exercise program and daily thalassotherapy treatments.

Hungary

With more than 1,000 medicinal hot springs, Hungarian spas are recommended for rheumatism and circulatory disorders. The approach is medicinal and prices are suitably sober. A seven-night break at the four-star Danubias Thermal Hotel Helia in Budapest with Thermalia Travel (020-7483 1898) costs from £541 including flights, half board, and a basic Balneotherapy package including consultation, six treatments and the use of thermal baths and other facilities.

Italy

Abano, in the hills near Venice, is famous for its mud treatments for muscular, rheumatic and arthritic pain. A seven-night, anti-stress spa break at the five star Grand Hotel Terme in Abano with Thermalia Travel (020-7483 1898) costs from £1,312 including flights, transfers and full-board accommodation. The anti-stress package includes six underwater massages, three anti-stress massages, two reflexology sessions, three scalp massages, two shiatsu sessions, plus the use of facilities.

France

France's speciality is thalassotherapy, and Les Thermes Marins de Monte Carlo spa, connected to the turn-of-the-century Hotel Hermitage, has 6,600sq metres dedicated to it. A three-night Discover Thalassotherapy break with Erna Low (020-7584 2841) costs from £1,265 and includes flights, helicopter transfers, half-board accommodation, a medical check-up and four treatments a day including hydromassage, algae baths, mud packs and aquagym sessions.

At sea

Most cruise ships now have onboard spas, and the 25,000sq ft Aquaspa on the newly launched Millenium is one of the largest and most sophisticated at sea. Seven nights on the western Mediterranean with Celebrity Cruises (0800 0182525) costs from £899, including flights, transfers, accommodation and all meals. Book your treatments individually or go for one of the spa packages; the AquaSpa gold package costs £289 and includes aromatherapy massages, seaweed treatments, deep-cleansing facials and more.

Strawberry Hill, Blue Mountains, Jamaica

Situated 3,100ft above sea level in Jamaica's Blue Mountains, Strawberry Hill is a haven of chic, colonial-style villas complete with an Aveda concept salon. A seven-night break with Caribbean Connection (01244 355 500) costs £1,309 based on two sharing and includes flights, transfers and accommodation. Treatments can be booked either as a package or individually - try the essential back treatment (£30) or a Himalayan rejuvenation session (£114).

Canyon Ranch,Tuscon, Arizona

The US is known for the most innovative, if expensive, spas, and Canyon Ranch, complete with counsellors, nutritionists and pyschologists, is the best for a full mind and body makeover. A four-night break costs $2,050 (approx £1,470) and includes airport transfers, full-board accommodation, activities ranging from ballet to boxercise, health and healing services and four spa treatments. Book direct on 001 520 749 9000 or visit www.canyonranch.com.

Chiva Som, Hua Hin, Thailand

The $16.8m Chiva Som is the ultimate spa experience. Surrounded by lush greenery, tropical lakes and breathtaking views, the emphasis is on east meets west and holistic healing. Seven nights with Magic of the Orient (01293 537700) costs £1,638 including flights, accommodation, all meals, medical consultation, facial treatments, body treatments and choice of daily massage.

Rajvilas, Rajasthan, India

The luxury spa at the Rajvilas hotel, set in a converted Rajasthani mansion, uses the ancient holistic healing technique of Ayurveda to treat the mind, body and soul. An eight- day break costs from £1,899 with Greaves Travel (020-7487 9111) including flights, transfers and accommodation.

Treatments include Ayurvedic massage from £24, marma point Ayurvedic facials from £20 and Indian head massage from £13.

fields.headline: Avoiding ticks in Jamaica
fields.standfirst:
I'm planning a holiday in the interior of Jamaica. We will be staying in very basic accommodation and ticks are a big problem. Does anyone know of an effective tick repellant that can be used on my child, who is one year old?
Sarah Gardner
fields.trailText: I'm planning a holiday in the interior of Jamaica. We will be staying in very basic accommodation and ticks are a big problem. Does anyone know of an effective tick repellant that can be used on my child, who is one year old?
fields.body:
 I camped on Rathlin Island in County Antrim, which has a lot of ticks. I was part of a camp of about 50 people, including very young children. The most used repellent was lemongrass essential oil. After applying sun protection, the lemongrass can be used diluted in carrier oil such as almond and rubbed on the legs, arms and torso.Take tweezers to remove any ticks that do take hold in the skin. Lavender oil can be safely applied neat after removal to help skin heal and stop infection.
Joanna Fursman

 The network's first national above-the-line brand campaign

Buy the book at BOL
Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free
fields.trailText: Russell jabs you into unrestrained laughter, and makes you angry at the unresponsible power of the mob
fields.body: Russell gloriously shatters the maxim that authors of fiction should not record their own stuff. It's no easy read, this first-person narrative by Raymond, a poor, lonely lad driven crazy after being falsely accused of a sexual assault on a toddler and banished by his local community. Russell has made his first novel epistolary - a series of letters from Raymond to his idol, the singer Morrissey. Russell jabs you into unrestrained laughter, and makes you angry at the unresponsible power of the mob. Somebody should give it for Christmas to the editor of the News of the World.

fields.trailText: Hurrah for the true champion of the lower-middle-upper-working-class!
fields.body: Bennett claims to have a poor memory and then disproves it utterly with these beautiful, sherbert-lemon portraits from his Leeds childhood. Bennett's adolescent fears of catching syphilis off the communion chalice will make everybody laugh. But only those of us who come from the English lower-middle-upper-working-class will really know how spot on he is about that quiet, unpretentious stratum, baffled by the antics of the classes on either side and perpetually on the brink of embarrassment. Hurrah for their true champion!

webTitle: Extract: All Dressed Up And Nowhere To Go by Malcolm Bradbury

fields.headline: Wonders of the New World
fields.standfirst:
When Malcolm Bradbury went to New York in the 50s, it was the start of a lifelong passion for US culture. Here he reflects on his first awestruck encounter with the land of plenty.

Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: When Malcolm Bradbury went to New York in the 50s, it was the start of a lifelong passion for US culture. Here he reflects on his first awestruck encounter with the land of plenty.
fields.body:
I was not an angry young man, perhaps, since to me the angry young men were all old, 10 years or so older than I was. But I was a niggling one, an uneasy figure struggling in my Englishness, fighting to get out. The British provinces had been swallowing me like an eiderdown; America seemed the great, good place. I left, a young Nottingham intellectual with five published articles to his credit, all in journals of absolutely no importance, and sailed to Florida on a freighter. From there, I took the bus to New York, and rode in the endless elevator up to the top of the Empire State building; below was the great metropolis, looking like a gigantic waffle-iron.

Excitement grew; I took the ferry and sailed out to the Statue of Liberty, while fireboats sprayed me with jets of water; I wandered Macy's and bought nylon shirts, then a new invention that made you ping with static electricity when you put them on and off. The Beat Generation was riding high: I went to poetry readings in gloomy bagel shops in Greenwich Village, where poets in dark glasses would look up to the ceiling and cry "Come, little bird of poetry, fly down to me" (actually it rarely did). I talked to deviants on benches outside New York Public Library, while dapper secretaries went by, carrying plastic Lord and Taylor's bags. It was different, exciting; yet I still didn't feel I knew what America was.

Then one day the revelation came. I was staying with the parents of a Jewish friend in their small apartment in the Bronx. It was not a notable apartment but it did have a notable American kitchen: a shining bulbous icebox, a glinting split-level cooker, Formica worktops, a whirring blender and mixer, a toaster that threw bread in the air as if in sport, and in the middle of the sink, an object called a Dispose-All which consumed the kitchen refuse and sent it all straight to the sewage company. Commonplace now, it was a wonder of the 50s; I used to wander in there frequently, just to experience it all. One day my host came and found me there, staring down the Dispose-All's magnificent orifice, as if seeking the meaning of life. Not speaking, he opened the door of the ice-box, took out an entire uncooked chicken, thrust the chicken into the grinder, and switched on. Standing there, watching the machine consume an entire bird. I knew at last that I had seen the New World, and it worked.

I stayed on in the States for a long time, in the American heartland, teaching freshman composition - better known as Readin' Writin', Speakin' and List'nin' - at a university in a cornfield in the midwest. Here I taught coeds in tight sweaters, cantilevered bras and Elizabeth Arden make-up, and seven-foot-tall footballers with crew cuts and huge ears, who could sit in the third row and still put up their feet on my desk ("Duh, I didn't doe dey was mine," said one of them when, after five weeks, I complained).

I taught them the simple things of life: how to use human language, how to write on pieces of paper from left to right, how to open books without splitting the spine, how to put in verbs to give a sentence the completeness of a sentence. I taught a lot, but I learned more. My students called for me in cars and took me out on dates, teaching me how to drink milkshakes; they showed me the way to the Doosie Duds, where I washed my socks, and the Piggly Wiggly, where I bought comestibles and acquired free Melamine tableware on food orders of five dollars or more.

I thought I was growing American, though the students never quite agreed. "Pip-pip, old chap," they said as they came into a class, "Bin shootin? How's the Queen?" Indeed, as time went by, a certain excess of Englishness crept into my character.

Though by origin a good deal closer to Jimmy Porter than the Duke of Windsor, I acquired a degree of bearing. My old cheap Harris tweed sports jacket with plastic patches on the elbow (only Oxbridge undergraduates could afford leather) acquired a fine old glow, as if it had been carefully smoked over a peat fire by willing peasants, and then systematically stained with claret by family butlers. I became an expert in politeness, rank, the royal family, hunting, and warm beer.

At the same time my literary ambitions were proceeding apace. For in addition to haunting the coffee bars of Nottingham, shouting about Sartre and nibbling the ears of leggy girls named Ernestine, I had spent three years being a student at a certain nameless English provincial university. A strange youth, who wore pink intellectual shirts and clip-on bow ties that kept falling off suddenly into cups of black coffee, and spent most of those three years writing a novel, about, of course, an English provincial university. I used to sit for hours in the university entrance hall, ostentatiously correcting a large sheet of proofs: "He's a writer," my two or three friends would explain to any passing visitor who happened to stumble in, usually under the impression that they had found the public library. I had once seen TS Eliot, or someone very like him, emerge from the offices of Faber and Faber in Russell Square, so I felt alert to everything that was happening in the literary scene; I had even been discovered - by a college friend, the editor of the literary magazine, a man named Michael Orsler, an impressive figure who used to stand naked at the window of his room, shouting "Sex rules the world" to occasional passing suburban shoppers.

Everyone assured me that a book about an English provincial university would never sell, and this confirmed me in my integrity. It was to these talents that I now turned in my office in the midwestern heartland; passing strangers, wandering close to the English department late at night, would hear the tapping of typewriter keys as I wrote down for posterity the benefits of my Anglo-American experience in articles that went to Vogue and Harper's and Punch and somehow managed to appear in print.

It all came to an end, of course. My contract ceased after a year. I posted the final grades on the door of my office and locked myself in, while disappointed students shouted through the keyhole in fury. I said goodbye to my friends, who explained that they had not understood a word I had said all year, because of my foreign accent. I knew, with a kind of dread in my heart, that it was time to go home to England. I knew that going home was always an agony, if not a disaster; that I would miss what I had enjoyed.

I had learned much about America, in the Doosie Duds and the Piggly Wiggly and the long car and bus journeys I had taken right across the nation, there to find more Doosie Duds, more Piggly Wigglies, more and more and more. In a dark, or at any rate decidedly ill-lit, night of the soul, I put all my Melamine tableware into my great foot-locker, heaved it lightly under one shoulder, and set off to New York City and the Cunard pier, on that most ancient of quests, the tale of return. Great liners with big red funnels still ran in those days, though plane travel was becoming fashionable in some quarters.

Looking forward to six days of leisure, I climbed aboard the great vessel, a haven of Englishness, smelling of marchionesses, carbolic soap, and good old kippers. The freighter I had come on, all those lifetimes ago, would have made one of its lifeboats; "Directions for Adjustment" said the notices on the wall of the underwater tourist cabin in which I found myself, showing a picture of a very well-developed girl strapping herself into some apparatus that made her look more well developed still.

And adjustment, after a long spell of America, was exactly what I needed. For I looked around at my fellow passengers, and the severe guardians who formed the crew. They appeared to me odd, until I realised that they were simply English. I would need to learn England all over again.

This is an edited extract from Malcolm Bradbury's introduction to his book All Dressed Up And Nowhere To Go, his satirical look at Britain at the end of the 1950s. It was republished last month by Picador. His last novel, To The Hermitage, is also published by Picador.

webTitle: Extract: Malcolm Bradbury's introduction to Herzog by Saul Bellow

fields.headline: 'He is the most superb recorder of America in its age of closure and mindless plushness'
fields.standfirst: In one of the last pieces he wrote before his death this week, Malcolm Bradbury celebrates the work of Saul Bellow as the great chronicler of the American century
fields.trailText: In one of the last pieces he wrote before his death this week, Malcolm Bradbury celebrates the work of Saul Bellow as the great chronicler of the American century.
fields.body:
As I write these words, Saul Bellow, America's greatest living novelist, is in his 85th year. He has lately published his 13th novel, Ravelstein, an exuberant tale about grand political ideas and our human mortality - not least the author's own, for in the book he discloses he has been recently faced with a life-threatening illness, for which the completion of his novel is a recompense. His central character, Abe Ravelstein, famous gay high-spending Jewish academic and political philosopher, belongs in a long line of Bellovian heroes. He is the suffering joker, a source of huge ideas and serious political wisdom, who is also a figure of clownish excess.

Following the advice of the book's narrator, an older writer who is clearly Bellow, Ravelstein has put his inspired academic ideas into print, and suddenly made a fortune. Now he can stay in a suite at the Hotel Crillon in Paris, where the crowds outside are calling for Michael Jackson, and buy priceless jackets from Lanvin over which, in his grand carelessness, he promptly spills his espresso coffee. Ravelstein is dying of Aids, and wants to see a memoir written.

RAVELSTEIN, the chattering philosopher who points to silence, the dying man who gives life, a figure of mind, mortality and the lush vulgar wonder of our age of glossy late modernity, is a natural figure in the great gallery of Bellow's fiction, which has always been strong in thinking heroes and the climate of the times. For over 60 years Bellow has sustained the late 20th century, postmodern American record. In careful detail, every phase of a remarkable cultural growth has been recorded.

A fiction that started out in the climate of 30s naturalism has boomed and expanded and grown extravagant to keep pace with the amazing strangeness of modern America itself. There was the dark time of Depression, the search for work, food and the right politics; then there was the mental hiatus of wartime. There was the suddenly booming postwar world, when ideological conflict grew, and America became a superpower. There was the youthful buoyancy of the age of Kennedy, then the cultural revolution of the 60s, the venture into space, the accumulation, the struggles of the mind in the "terrific posthistorical enterprise of the 60s and 70s", then the wealth, the mile-high apartment block, the great mall of postmodern abundance, and the era when Abe Ravelstein the philosopher shares a world and a hotel lobby with Michael Jackson. Bellow has over this time offered us various styles of fiction, yet the voice throughout has been complete and consistent, the style a distinctive tone, vernacular and metaphysical, comic and scrupulous, meditative yet narrative, euphoric yet studied.

Bellow is a humanist, and his attempt to sustain the humanism that has always been associated with the classic seriousness and worth of fiction is one part of his power. But he is also the writer writing of a post-humanist world: the world of survivors, after Auschwitz; the world where human beings are dwarfed by the cities they live in, by the scale of their urban masses and their lower depths, by the power of science and the new cosmos, by the earth-departure sensations of a genera tion and a nation leaving the earth-mass and heading for the moon.

Of all Bellow's novels, Herzog (first published in 1964), has the most complicated and labyrinthine structure. The book is multi-layered, mirroring the mixture of contemplation and frenzy which is the stuff of Herzog's own mind. The story offers to tell us of a few days in Herzog's life as he summers at his house in the Berkshires, an old American literary landscape, beloved of Melville and the transcendentalists, where he has settled down trying to explain, justify, make amends.

Herzog lives in a materialist, a narcissistic, a Freudianised and a litigious modern America, where everyone seems to be administering the common medicine now known as Reality or the Truth. Herzog confronts the City of Modern Desolation, with its certainties, its indifferences, its lost futile lives, its crimes. Meanwhile he offers to fight the battles of world historical thought, searching his way beween the lessons of Tolstoy ("To Tolstoy, freedom is entirely personal. That man is free whose condition is simple, truthful - real") and that of Hegel ("History, memory - that is what makes us human, that, and the knowledge of death").

Herzog, for all his intellect and heart, does not of course resolve the question of the modern condition, or come to a clear philosophical conclusion. The multiplicity of realities, the irreconcilable energies of mind and sexuality, lead to no clear outcome or 10-cent synthesis. "I go after reality in language," Herzog tells us, "I put my whole heart into these constructions, but they are constructions." Like Ravelstein drowned in the chatter of parrots, his ideas subsumed into feeling, Herzog must make his peace. Beyond the insistent self there is also a world: beyond language there is silence and even transparency.

HERZOG is the first of Bellow's big comedians of mental strife, the heroes of heartbreak, for whom the encounter with big America is crucial. Thinking in contemporary America, as Bellow has observed, has its own problems. A writer's task, he says, is to make thought into something else, so that it comes alive as art. "What makes that project singularly difficult is the disheartening expansion of trained ignorance and bad thought. For, to put the matter at its baldest, we live in a thought-world, and thinking has gone very bad indeed."

Bellow has made it his business to tell the story. "Awareness was his work, extended consciousness was his line, his business, vigilance": what Bellow says of Herzog becomes a custom, as he tells stories of the vigilant in book after book. The result is, in a sense, a spectacular comedy as the American intellectual tries, like Humboldt in Bellow's novel Humboldt's Gift, to "fit queer American bodies . . . into art's garments". So Humboldt "behaved like an eccentric and a comic subject. But occasionally there was a break in his eccentricity when he stopped and thought."

No modern writer has better constructed this anxious and very serious comedy, more clearly defined the encounter between thought and the labyrinth, more exactly captured the strange, Byzantine, parrot-filled meeting places of modern thought, modern heart, and modern silence.

This is an edited extract from Malcolm Bradbury's introduction to a new edition of Herzog by Saul Bellow. It will be published by Penguin in April.

fields.headline: Gimme that new-time religion
fields.trailText: "You are the potter, I am the clay", or is it the other way round? Many Christians like myself know only too well the shudder of embarrassment that accompanies those modern hymns about little birdies flying into the sunset, and the ones which involve clapping or other actions.
fields.body:
"You are the potter, I am the clay", or is it the other way round? Many Christians like myself know only too well the shudder of embarrassment that accompanies those modern hymns about little birdies flying into the sunset, and the ones which involve clapping or other actions.

Yes, A N Wilson, there are things about the modern liturgy which are enough to make anyone run screaming to a Quaker meeting. But to say that these aesthetic atrocities have destroyed Christian faith in Britain - well, steady on.

In last week's Saturday Guardian, Wilson argued that the abolition by the Roman Catholics of the Tridentine Mass, and the modernising by the church of England of the Book Of Common Prayer, had, in some way, destroyed our faith. He lamented the loss of the "old words, the tried and trusted words, the words which, worn and smooth like old, well-trodden stones, had been heard so often before".

A couple of weeks ago, I attended an evensong conducted according to the Book Of Common Prayer. As a Catholic, I relished the chance to hear some beautiful old language - and so I did. But as the liturgy wore on, I realised that I was copping out. This language was not the language I speak, and so it did not need to challenge me. It sounded lovely, as does the Tridentine Mass, but failed to penetrate through the head and the heart to the uncomfortable bits of the gut which any religion needs to reach if it is to change things.

Many people would not agree. For them, the Tridentine Mass and the Book Of Common Prayer are channels of inspiration - and, for these people, those forms of liturgy should be available. But many other Christians want to worship and hear the word of God in the language they speak every day; only in those everyday words can it be a part of their everyday world.

According to Wilson, those people hardly exist. "We," he says grandly, no longer believe that Jesus was born in a stable in Bethlehem. Only a minority of seminarians and theological students really believe that Christ became man and lived (sorry, dwelt) among us.

Well, I don't know where Wilson has been doing his research, but the Christians I meet every day would say different. Many of us believe the lot, thank you, and we are not a minority of fanatics. A quick trawl through my address book yields a leading physicist and a top botanist who are unabashed to declare themselves Christian.

Wilson laments that the churches "squabble about miracles", rather than give "serious responses" to the philosophical challenges of the last 200 years. What has he been reading? These issues are debated every day in universities, on Radio 4 and in the pages of my newspaper. What does he think the Vatican Observatory is up to?

To say that Christian leaders are cowards, who dare to question concepts such as the Resurrection and the Virgin Birth, is again to miss the point of what the modern church is about. Perhaps they simply believe these things.

Or even if they do not, perhaps they think it is more important to rock the boat over things like the relief of international debt, capital punishment and the ravages of human greed and materialism. Would Wilson rather they spent their time polishing up their Latin?

Yes, the modern liturgy can feel like a teddy-bears' picnic, with music borrowed from Play School. Yes, the rightful attention which the church now pays to community-building and social work can lead us to forget the awesome nature of God. In our proper quest to do good for those around us, we can lose touch with that amazing force which defines goodness. And if we stop listening to God, away from the clamour of the modern Sunday service, we will lose any sense of direction. Neither approach - the worldly nor the cerebral - will work. Christianity needs both.

To suggest, as Wilson does, that modern liturgy and the retention in the modern creeds of the Virgin Birth and the Resurrection, have killed off modern Christianity is simply untrue. For many people, the love they see in their modern, friendly priest or vicar is their key to the gentle, forgiving love of Christ.

The stories of the Virgin Birth and the Resurrection, irrational as they may sound, complement the whole audacious, amazing business of there being a God at all. And if we lost all the Christian music which has been composed around those doctrines, Wilson's glorious liturgy might be a little quiet.

His analysis of the impending extinction of Christianity gives the strong impression that, when it comes to faith, he just does not get it. The late Cardinal Hume used to say that the best way to know God was to sit quietly and listen. Having done that, the debate over Latin, or estuary English, in the liturgy really ceases to matter that much.

Annabel Miller is executive editor of the Tablet

webTitle: 'Cambridge Two' can stay free, say appeal court judges

fields.headline: 'Cambridge Two' can stay free, say appeal court judges
fields.standfirst: More about the Cambridge Two
fields.trailText: Two charity workers jailed in a landmark case for "knowingly permitting" drug dealing at a hostel were yesterday told they could go free.
fields.body:
Two charity workers jailed in a landmark case for "knowingly permitting" drug dealing at a hostel were yesterday told they could go free.

But Ruth Wyner and John Brock will have to wait until next year before they find out whether their convictions will be quashed.

Wyner and Brock - dubbed the Cambridge Two - were sentenced to five and four years respectively after an undercover police operation revealed that heroin was being widely dealt at The Bus day centre in Cambridge.

Although they conceded they knew that some dealing had gone on, the pair were shocked by the extent of the problem. At the trial they were criticised for not sharing what they believed was confidential information about their clients with the police.

In July, after spending 207 days in prison, the pair were given leave to appeal against the convictions and sentences. They were freed on bail but told they might have to return to prison if their convictions were not overturned.

Yesterday three appeal court judges decided to reserve final judgment but Lord Justice Rose said they considered the sentences "far too long".

He said: "We are not minded to send the appellants back to prison". If the convictions are quashed the Crown will not demand a retrial.

The pair walked from court cheered by supporters who had packed the public gallery.

Wyner said: "That's just the best Christmas present anyone could have really."

"The whole thing has cost an enormous amount of public money - well over £1m. I feel things could be done differently. We've been dragged through the courts and prison over the last two and a half years and the effect on my family has been appalling.

"The case is very important to the whole homeless sector - it involves our ability to work safely with drug addicts."

At the trial last year a raft of the centre's policies came under scrutiny. The charity had drawn up a policy banning illegal drugs. But it believed that a policy of confidentiality was necessary to forge an atmosphere of trust. An "open door" policy - allowing visitors to walk in off the street without being checked or searched - was thought to be another vital feature of the centre.

The prosecution argued that the pair were not doing everything in their power to stop dealing. It suggested they could have halted the open door policy and shared information about users with the police.

William Clegg QC, for the Crown, repeated yesterday that the pair must have had a very good idea that "trading in heroin was widespread and epidemic through the entire building".

And he argued that the refusal to give police the names of those selling heroin was "unreasonable".

He added: "You can't, we submit, escape criminal liability by reliance on a code of confidentiality."

Michael Mansfield QC, for Wyner and Brock, argued that the trial judge, Jonathan Haworth, erred in not allowing the jurors to consider whether, in the light of their policies, the pair acted reasonably in not telling the police what they knew about drug dealing.

He told the appeal judges that the case was of "considerable public importance" because the charity was run on similar lines to many other such organisations.

Mr Mansfield said that though Wyner and Brock had been told by police that heroin dealing was going on, they were unaware of the scale. "They felt they had done as much as they could to control the problem."

fields.headline: The Water-Seller of Seville, Velazquez (c1620)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Diego Rodriguez da Silva Velazquez (1599-1660), born to a family of the minor nobility in Seville, who set up his own studio at the age of 18. Soon afterwards, already revered, Velazquez set off for Madrid, where he was appointed court painter to Philip IV in 1623. He held the position for the rest of his life, making portraits regarded ever since as among the greatest European paintings.

Subject: A street water-seller nicknamed the Corsican of Seville who, according to accounts from the end of the 17th century, wore a smock with holes in it to show his scabs and sores to potential customers.

Distinguishing features: The vendor's face is downcast, expecting nothing, not looking at the boy to whom he gives water in a clean, fine glass with a black fig to freshen the taste. In the shadows another customer drinks. The water-seller seems unaware of either; as if in deference to his sorrow, the boy looks down. He respects the poverty and age of the street-seller, as does Velazquez, who gives the man an immense dignity.

The water-seller's body is as monumental as the round container on which he places his left hand. His robe is torn like a saint's, his face lined with experience, the scarred, creased antithesis of the boy's white, smooth features. This is the face of a man who has spent a lot of time in the sun, standing on dusty street corners.

This painting crackles with Seville's scorching heat. The water-seller's robe has a flaky, crisp texture. His face, around his mouth, is marked by deep canyons like dried-up river beds. His beard is desert grass, his hair shaved short, in contrast to the boy's lively locks. He touches the water jar, on the surface of which three drops of water glisten, shining globules of life.

The paintings in which Velazquez specialised during his early career were known as "bodegones", from bodegon, a cheap eating-house. They are scenes of lowlife, but with a sombre, static quality that is the opposite of contemporary Dutch genre scenes with their cheerful peasants. In The Water-Seller the simplicity of the clothes and ceramics, and the ritual of pouring and drinking water, gives the painting the feeling of a fable or parable.

Years later, Velazquez was to paint an old man impersonating the ancient storyteller Aesop. In early 17th-century Spain Cervantes and other writers gave voice to outsiders, the destitute, the mad; Cervantes even wrote a conversation between two dogs about Seville's street life.

Part of the Spanish royal collection, The Water-Seller was seized by Joseph Bonaparte in the Napoleonic wars, taken back from him by the Duke of Wellington at the battle of Vittoria, then given by the restored Spanish royal family to the Iron Duke as a token of gratitude for defeating the French. Today it seems a little forlorn among Wellington's trophies, but this only adds to its status as a memorial to the overlooked and despised. The water-seller emerges forever from history's shadows, the light touching his face.

Inspirations and influences: The most important influence on Velazquez was Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio (1571-1610), the Italian baroque painter of saints with the faces of street people. Caravaggio's use of dramatic light sources to illuminate staged scenes with the rawness of real life is directly emulated in The Water-Seller - in particular the boy's face, lit up and youthful.

Velazquez's imitators were numerous.His fellow Sevillian Bartolome Esteban Murillo made the city's streets his own in imaginative lowlife scenes, such as Invitation to a Game of Pelota (c1670) and The Flower Girl (c1670). But compared with the reality and compassion of The Water-Seller, these are soft fantasies of street urchins.

Where is it? Apsley House, Hyde Park Corner, London W1 (020-7499 5676).
fields.bodyText: · View the work online Artist: Diego Rodriguez da Silva Velazquez (1599-1660), born to a family of the minor nobility in Seville, who set up his own studio at the age of 18. Soon afterwards, already revered, Velazquez set off for Madrid, where he was appointed court painter to Philip IV in 1623. He held the position for the rest of his life, making portraits regarded ever since as among the greatest European paintings. Subject: A street water-seller nicknamed the Corsican of Seville who, according to accounts from the end of the 17th century, wore a smock with holes in it to show his scabs and sores to potential customers. Distinguishing features: The vendor's face is downcast, expecting nothing, not looking at the boy to whom he gives water in a clean, fine glass with a black fig to freshen the taste. In the shadows another customer drinks. The water-seller seems unaware of either; as if in deference to his sorrow, the boy looks down. He respects the poverty and age of the street-seller, as does Velazquez, who gives the man an immense dignity. The water-seller's body is as monumental as the round container on which he places his left hand. His robe is torn like a saint's, his face lined with experience, the scarred, creased antithesis of the boy's white, smooth features. This is the face of a man who has spent a lot of time in the sun, standing on dusty street corners. This painting crackles with Seville's scorching heat. The water-seller's robe has a flaky, crisp texture. His face, around his mouth, is marked by deep canyons like dried-up river beds. His beard is desert grass, his hair shaved short, in contrast to the boy's lively locks. He touches the water jar, on the surface of which three drops of water glisten, shining globules of life. The paintings in which Velazquez specialised during his early career were known as "bodegones", from bodegon, a cheap eating-house. They are scenes of lowlife, but with a sombre, static quality that is the opposite of contemporary Dutch genre scenes with their cheerful peasants. In The Water-Seller the simplicity of the clothes and ceramics, and the ritual of pouring and drinking water, gives the painting the feeling of a fable or parable. Years later, Velazquez was to paint an old man impersonating the ancient storyteller Aesop. In early 17th-century Spain Cervantes and other writers gave voice to outsiders, the destitute, the mad; Cervantes even wrote a conversation between two dogs about Seville's street life. Part of the Spanish royal collection, The Water-Seller was seized by Joseph Bonaparte in the Napoleonic wars, taken back from him by the Duke of Wellington at the battle of Vittoria, then given by the restored Spanish royal family to the Iron Duke as a token of gratitude for defeating the French. Today it seems a little forlorn among Wellington's trophies, but this only adds to its status as a memorial to the overlooked and despised. The water-seller emerges forever from history's shadows, the light touching his face. Inspirations and influences: The most important influence on Velazquez was Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio (1571-1610), the Italian baroque painter of saints with the faces of street people. Caravaggio's use of dramatic light sources to illuminate staged scenes with the rawness of real life is directly emulated in The Water-Seller - in particular the boy's face, lit up and youthful. Velazquez's imitators were numerous.His fellow Sevillian Bartolome Esteban Murillo made the city's streets his own in imaginative lowlife scenes, such as Invitation to a Game of Pelota (c1670) and The Flower Girl (c1670). But compared with the reality and compassion of The Water-Seller, these are soft fantasies of street urchins. Where is it? Apsley House, Hyde Park Corner, London W1 (020-7499 5676).

webTitle: Witnesses who turn a blind eye

fields.headline: Witnesses who turn a blind eye
fields.standfirst:
After Damilola Taylor's murder, Jack Straw condemned what he called a 'walk on by culture'. So what makes people decline to help?

More about the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: After Damilola Taylor's murder, Jack Straw condemned what he called a 'walk on by culture'.
fields.body:
Mike Thornton was on the top deck of a number 86 bus when the three boys boarded and started making trouble. It was a hot day in Manchester and the boys - "beefy lads" he says - ran the length of the bus slamming shut windows, before turning their attention to Mr Thornton. "What's your problem?" one demanded and 10 minutes later, the 55-year-old's nose was broken in two places and a bone in his eye socket chipped. "No one stepped in to help," he says. "The other passengers told me afterwards 'we didn't see anything, we didn't hear anything' and I couldn't believe it. I was covered in blood."

This is an instance of what Jack Straw condemned this this week as "walk on by culture", the public's reluctance to answer pleas for help, which is being indicted in the wake of the murder of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor. The home secretary, who has made three citizen's arrests to date, upbraided the public for its failure to respond adequately when witnessing crime. While warning them not to take risks, he said: "People do have a responsibility to help the police in their work."

Last year the audit commission calculated that for every police officer on patrol there were 18,000 people, 77 miles of road, 7,500 houses, nine schools and 23 pubs. Civic responsibility, says Mr Straw, must play its part in lessening the shortfall.

The deterrent for intervening in street crime has always been the ease with which apparently trivial situations can turn into life-threatening ones mid-flow. This week, a 34-year-old man from Glasgow was taken to hospital after trying to stop a gang of youths stoning a bus in the city's Pollock area. He is believed to have been stabbed in the chest.

"There's an awareness that you're liable to suffer if you're going to interfere," says Anthony Black, a criminal psychologist who was for 27 years head of psychological services at Broadmoor hospital.

Fear

"Criminals will plan a crime with the general awareness that people are not going to get involved because they fear the consequences, the violence, the fact that nowadays people will be carrying some sort of a weapon."

It is not only fear but embarrassment that psychologists detect in people whose conduct they refer to as "bystander apathy". Dr Norah Hart teaches on this subject at the centre for applied psychology at Liverpool John Moores University. "There is the fear that they have not read the situation right and that they will may make fools of themselves," she says.

"When people aren't sure what's going on, they tend to think, maybe there's a simple explanation, maybe it's just kids larking about. This is what happened with the James Bulger case. People thought, the two boys have said he's their brother, so it must be all right."

Embarrassment

This attitude, says Dr Hart, is dangerously contagious. "If an incident is taking place in a crowded area, people see that no one else is doing anything and deduce from that that there is nothing wrong, that the situation doesn't merit intervention."

"You are worried that your actions will be misinterpreted," says Anthony Black. "The other day a child ran out of a shop crying 'Mummy, Mummy' and my initial reaction was to comfort her. But then I thought no, I'm going to be thought to be trying to abduct the child, so I quickly got the help of two other women."

When Mike Thornton finally pulled away from his assailants and appealed to the bus driver for help, he was informed that the bus company observed a strict policy of non-confrontation. The thugs were allowed to leave the bus unchallenged.

"I was shocked," he says. "There was a gentleman sitting further along the bus who was quite elderly but fit looking. I'm no youngster, but if it had been him getting attacked, of course I would have stepped in. Instead, this man did nothing, and after it was all over came up to me and said, 'Oh, what happened to you?' as if seeing my blood-stained shirt for the first time.

"There was a girl at the back of the bus and when she left she apologised to me and handed me my sunglasses. She said, 'I'm sorry, but you'll appreciate I go to the same school as the boys and didn't see anything.' I could understand her attitude, but not his. It is one thing not to intervene, but another to deny you even saw anything." Mr Thornton's attackers were never convicted.

Frank Levy, a 53-year-old taxi driver from Peckham in south London, is a rare example of a man who did get involved. While driving through Holborn he passed a bank robbery in full swing in which a security guard was being held with two guns to his head. When the guard fell to the ground, Mr Levy leapt into action.

"Maybe I'm stupid," he says, "but I saw the two gunmen and thought, why is no one doing anything? Next thing I knew, I was in."

He stopped the car, chased the robbers down the street and in the ensuing scuffle was shot in the foot. "People kept saying to me afterwards, 'You must be bloody mad, doing what you did.' But my parents were very moral, upright citizens.

"Without me knowing they might have instilled values in me which made me take that course of action without thinking." In the aftermath, it transpired that the security guard had merely fainted, but Mr Levy does not regret his actions.

Nonetheless he disapproves of Jack Straw's latest appeal to the public conscience. "I think Jack Straw's got it wrong. I don't think it's up to the public to behave like that.

"People don't mind stepping in if all they're going to get is a a punch on the nose. But so many kids carry weapons these days. People don't want a knife in the stomach for their trouble."

webTitle: 'Cambridge Two' can stay free, say appeal court judges

fields.headline: 'Cambridge Two' can stay free, say appeal court judges
fields.trailText: Two charity workers jailed in a landmark case for "knowingly permitting" drug dealing at a hostel were yesterday told they could go free.
fields.body:
Two charity workers jailed in a landmark case for "knowingly permitting" drug dealing at a hostel were yesterday told they could go free.

But Ruth Wyner and John Brock will have to wait until next year before they find out whether their convictions will be quashed.

Wyner and Brock - dubbed the Cambridge Two - were sentenced to five and four years respectively after an undercover police operation revealed that heroin was being widely dealt at The Bus day centre in Cambridge.

Although they conceded they knew that some dealing had gone on, the pair were shocked by the extent of the problem. At the trial they were criticised for not sharing what they believed was confidential information about their clients with the police.

In July, after spending 207 days in prison, the pair were given leave to appeal against the convictions and sentences. They were freed on bail but told they might have to return to prison if their convictions were not overturned.

Yesterday three appeal court judges decided to reserve final judgment but Lord Justice Rose said they considered the sentences "far too long".

He said: "We are not minded to send the appellants back to prison". If the convictions are quashed the Crown will not demand a retrial.

The pair walked from court cheered by supporters who had packed the public gallery.

Wyner said: "That's just the best Christmas present anyone could have really."

"The whole thing has cost an enormous amount of public money - well over £1m. I feel things could be done differently. We've been dragged through the courts and prison over the last two and a half years and the effect on my family has been appalling.

"The case is very important to the whole homeless sector - it involves our ability to work safely with drug addicts."

At the trial last year a raft of the centre's policies came under scrutiny. The charity had drawn up a policy banning illegal drugs. But it believed that a policy of confidentiality was necessary to forge an atmosphere of trust. An "open door" policy - allowing visitors to walk in off the street without being checked or searched - was thought to be another vital feature of the centre.

The prosecution argued that the pair were not doing everything in their power to stop dealing. It suggested they could have halted the open door policy and shared information about users with the police.

William Clegg QC, for the Crown, repeated yesterday that the pair must have had a very good idea that "trading in heroin was widespread and epidemic through the entire building".

And he argued that the refusal to give police the names of those selling heroin was "unreasonable".

He added: "You can't, we submit, escape criminal liability by reliance on a code of confidentiality."

Michael Mansfield QC, for Wyner and Brock, argued that the trial judge, Jonathan Haworth, erred in not allowing the jurors to consider whether, in the light of their policies, the pair acted reasonably in not telling the police what they knew about drug dealing.

He told the appeal judges that the case was of "considerable public importance" because the charity was run on similar lines to many other such organisations.

Mr Mansfield said that though Wyner and Brock had been told by police that heroin dealing was going on, they were unaware of the scale. "They felt they had done as much as they could to control the problem."
