fields.headline: When your lender won't loosen its tie
fields.standfirst: Linking household insurance to a mortgage deal has been decried as a scam. Yet, promises to outlaw the practice have come to nothing
fields.trailText: Linking household insurance to a mortgage deal has been decried as a scam. Yet, promises to outlaw the practice have come to nothing.
fields.body:
It looks like many homebuyers will continue to fall foul of what's been dubbed a mortgage "scam" for some time to come, despite a government pledge 12 months ago to outlaw the practice.

During the past couple of years, there has been a growing outcry about the fact that some mortgage lenders force customers to take out expensive home insurance as a condition of signing up for their cheapest home loans.

Studies suggest that tying compulsory insurance to mortgage deals costs borrowers millions of pounds a year. Borrowers can end up forking out thousands of pounds more than necessary over their lifetime. Research has shown that insurance arranged through your mortgage provider can cost up to a third more than cover offered by a direct insurer. In fact, the extra cost can end up cancelling out the amount you're saving by taking the cheaper mortgage deal.

In December last year, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said legislation to ban compulsory insurance tie-ins would be brought in "at the earliest possible opportunity", probably by the end of 2000. He said: "It is important for consumers to have a genuine choice and that they are not forced into accepting an insurance policy which may not be the best deal available to them."

But 12 months on and there's still no sign of a ban. The rumours are that Mr Byers's bill on consumer rights, which includes the ban, has failed to secure a slot in the Queen's Speech to parliament this coming Wednesday, which would mean the chances of new legislation appearing before the next election are slim, unless an MP can rescue it by pushing it through as a private members' bill.

While many of the biggest lenders have scrapped the practice, there are at least 16 that still insist you buy one or more of their insurance policies if you want one of their lowest rate mortgage deals.

Direct Line has estimated that this so-called "bundling" of insurance with mortgages costs the UK public around £400m a year. "For the average homeowner this can mean needlessly paying around £4,000 more for home insurance over a lifetime," says the company.

Even if you are able to look around for cheaper buildings or contents cover, some lenders charge their customers a fee - typically around £25-£30 - if they have the temerity to arrange their insurance with another company. This tactic is clearly aimed at deterring people from shopping around for their insurance - though the lenders of course deny this, and say the fee covers the cost of checking that a policy you arrange yourself offers adequate cover.

The DTI this week said it could not confirm or deny whether the legislation would be included in the Queen's Speech, but worryingly it appears to be backtracking on its original commitment. A spokeswoman says the situation has changed greatly over the past year in that many banks and building societies have abandoned compulsory insurance. "There are a lot less lenders offering [insurance] tie-ins now, especially among the major players. The consumer now definitely does have a choice," says the DTI.

If it does transpire that the ban has been delayed, or even dropped, the government is likely to come under fire from consumer groups and others. It could be argued it is ridiculous that while travel agents and tour operators are now forbidden from forcing people to buy travel insurance if they want to take advantage of discount holiday deals, mortgage lenders are free to insist that people buy their home insurance as a condition of obtaining their most attractive home loans.

The Consumers' Association - which has described tying compulsory insurance to mortgages as "a scam" - says that sometimes borrowers are forced to buy the lender's buildings or contents cover for several years, so there is no way of knowing at the outset whether the premiums you're being charged over this period will be competitive.

The 16 lenders still offering home loans with compulsory insurance, according to the latest issue of financial data magazine Moneyfacts, are: Clay Cross building society; Clydesdale Bank; Darlington building society; Earl Shilton building society; Leeds & Holbeck building society; Leek United building society; Marsden building society; Newcastle building society; Paragon Mortgages; Principality building society; Progressive building society; Skipton building society; Teachers building society; Universal building society; Wesleyan Home Loans; and West Bromwich building society.

Most of the big lenders have ditched this practice: the Halifax did so seven years ago.

Lenders that have mortgages with compulsory insurance tend to argue this enables them to offer more attractive deals because of the commission they earn. The West Bromwich spoke for many when it said: "We find customers are happy to take up compulsory insurance in exchange for a lower rate. For those customers who don't wish to take up this offer, we offer an equivalent deal without insurance at a slightly higher rate of interest."

Finally, one reason why a ban could still prove problematic is that it would clash with the idea that mortgage payment protection insurance should be made compulsory. This type of insurance, also known as accident, sickness and unemployment (ASU), covers your mortgage payments if you become unemployed or are unable to work, due to an accident or illness.

The government wants more of us to take this out because it is concerned about how many people would pay their mortgage if they lost their job, and the House of Commons social security committee recently indicated it favours forcing lenders to provide payment protection insurance as part of all mortgages.

Ask the right questions and you could save a fortune

When you're choosing a mortgage, be sure to check with the lender or adviser whether their loans come with compulsory insurance.

The government says this is one of the 10 key questions, listed at the end, which everyone considering taking out a mortgage should ask.

If the loan you're particularly interested in does require you to buy the lender's insurance, make sure it is clear exactly how much you would have to pay and how long you would have to take it for. It's advisable to do some homework to find out how the cost of the policy they're offering compares with what you could get by shopping around. Ring round a couple of companies or, if you have access to the internet, try one of the online insurance broking services run by companies such as Screentrade or the AA.

You enter your basic details and the sites will fire back a selection of quotes from leading insurers. Screentrade has a panel of 19 insurers offering buildings and contents insurance, while the AA has 14 insurers on its site.

If there is a big difference between what your lender is charging and what you could get by doing it yourself, you may find this cancels out much of what you would save by taking this mortgage deal.

Screentrade says its own research has suggested that on average, lenders are charging 40% more for their buildings and contents insurance than you would pay by obtaining quotes from several insurers and going for the best one. "You can save yourself hundreds of pounds by shopping around," says a spokesman.

If you want to be completely sure you're getting a mortgage with no hidden costs or catches you may want to consider a so-called "CAT" mortgage offered by Abbey National, Britannia building society, Egg, Halifax, HSBC, Woolwich and Yorkshire building society among others. CAT mortgages must meet a range of government-imposed minimum standards on charges and terms, one of which is that the lender cannot insist you buy its buildings, contents or mortgage payment protection insurance.

Other requirements are that interest must be calculated daily, not annually; with variable rate mortgages, the interest rate cannot be any higher than 2% above the Bank of England base rate; and with fixed, discounted and capped mortgages, there must be no "lock-in" early redemption penalties after the end of the fixed/discounted/capped period.

But the downside of CAT-marked mortgages is that they will often not offer the most competitive rate - meeting all those requirements inevitably means they will tend to be more expensive.

Meanwhile, the advice about shopping around for your home insurance also applies to the millions of borrowers who may have been unwittingly forking out over the odds for years by sticking with their lender's buildings or contents cover. A few minutes on the net or the phone looking at what deals are on offer from other companies could enable people to make significant savings, and in the vast majority of cases you are going to be free to sign up with another insurer.

Research issued by the Department of Trade and Industry last week found that at least one in four people initially sign up with their mortgage lender for insurance. It also revealed just how many people have never got round to changing their insurance provider - less than a third of homeowners (30%) have switched their home insurance in the past five years

The DTI says there are 10 questions everyone taking out a mortgage should ask to help them make an informed choice and avoid hidden traps.

1 How much can I realistically afford to borrow? (Make sure you're clear about what you will have to pay out each month, and don't forget there are other fees and costs involved in buying a home.)

2 How can I tell which mortgage rate is best for me? (What is the rate now and what will happen to it when the special offer period ends?)

3 What is the best type of mortgage for me? (Ask what the jargon means, and whether the mortgage you're being offered will suit your circumstances both now and in the future.)

4 How should I repay it? (You can go for a repayment or an interest-only mortgage, or one that's a mixture of the two.)

5 Can I make lump sum payments to reduce the size of the loan? (Some mortgage deals are a lot more flexible than others.)

6 Are there any redemption penalties? (How much would you have to fork out if you wanted to switch to another lender's better deal?)

7 Does this mortgage come with compulsory insurance?

8 What other charges will I have to pay? (Check if you'll have to pay for mortgage indemnity guarantee insurance - also known as "MIG" fee.)

9 What happens if I can't pay? (Some lenders charge very high fees if you fall behind with your mortgage payments.)

10 What about the small print? (Ask about any terms you're unsure of.)

For full details log on to the special website, the Consumer Gateway.

A case: Joe Hogg

Joe Hogg took out the lender's buildings insurance when he got his mortgage with Bank of Scotland around 15 years ago.

Several years passed and then in 1998, when the bank sent him a renewal quote of £124 for just buildings cover, Mr Hogg, 42, of Edinburgh, decided to shop around to see if he could get a better deal.

He signed up with Tesco Personal Finance after they gave him a quote for buildings and contents cover of £98.80. "I just wish we had done it earlier," he says.

The amount Bank of Scotland charged him had "gradually climbed up" each year, he adds. "We have stuck with Tesco."

Research has shown that insurance arranged through your mortgage provider can cost up to a third more than cover offered by a direct insurer. In fact, the extra cost can end up cancelling out the amount you're saving by taking the cheaper mortgage deal. In December last year, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said legislation to ban compulsory insurance tie-ins would be brought in "at the earliest possible opportunity", probably by the end of 2000. He said: "It is important for consumers to have a genuine choice and that they are not forced into accepting an insurance policy which may not be the best deal available to them." But 12 months on and there's still no sign of a ban. The rumours are that Mr Byers's bill on consumer rights, which includes the ban, has failed to secure a slot in the Queen's Speech to parliament this coming Wednesday, which would mean the chances of new legislation appearing before the next election are slim, unless an MP can rescue it by pushing it through as a private members' bill. While many of the biggest lenders have scrapped the practice, there are at least 16 that still insist you buy one or more of their insurance policies if you want one of their lowest rate mortgage deals. Direct Line has estimated that this so-called "bundling" of insurance with mortgages costs the UK public around £400m a year. "For the average homeowner this can mean needlessly paying around £4,000 more for home insurance over a lifetime," says the company. Even if you are able to look around for cheaper buildings or contents cover, some lenders charge their customers a fee - typically around £25-£30 - if they have the temerity to arrange their insurance with another company. This tactic is clearly aimed at deterring people from shopping around for their insurance - though the lenders of course deny this, and say the fee covers the cost of checking that a policy you arrange yourself offers adequate cover. The DTI this week said it could not confirm or deny whether the legislation would be included in the Queen's Speech, but worryingly it appears to be backtracking on its original commitment. A spokeswoman says the situation has changed greatly over the past year in that many banks and building societies have abandoned compulsory insurance. "There are a lot less lenders offering [insurance] tie-ins now, especially among the major players. The consumer now definitely does have a choice," says the DTI. If it does transpire that the ban has been delayed, or even dropped, the government is likely to come under fire from consumer groups and others. It could be argued it is ridiculous that while travel agents and tour operators are now forbidden from forcing people to buy travel insurance if they want to take advantage of discount holiday deals, mortgage lenders are free to insist that people buy their home insurance as a condition of obtaining their most attractive home loans. The Consumers' Association - which has described tying compulsory insurance to mortgages as "a scam" - says that sometimes borrowers are forced to buy the lender's buildings or contents cover for several years, so there is no way of knowing at the outset whether the premiums you're being charged over this period will be competitive. The 16 lenders still offering home loans with compulsory insurance, according to the latest issue of financial data magazine Moneyfacts, are: Clay Cross building society; Clydesdale Bank; Darlington building society; Earl Shilton building society; Leeds & Holbeck building society; Leek United building society; Marsden building society; Newcastle building society; Paragon Mortgages; Principality building society; Progressive building society; Skipton building society; Teachers building society; Universal building society; Wesleyan Home Loans; and West Bromwich building society. Most of the big lenders have ditched this practice: the Halifax did so seven years ago. Lenders that have mortgages with compulsory insurance tend to argue this enables them to offer more attractive deals because of the commission they earn. The West Bromwich spoke for many when it said: "We find customers are happy to take up compulsory insurance in exchange for a lower rate. For those customers who don't wish to take up this offer, we offer an equivalent deal without insurance at a slightly higher rate of interest." Finally, one reason why a ban could still prove problematic is that it would clash with the idea that mortgage payment protection insurance should be made compulsory. This type of insurance, also known as accident, sickness and unemployment (ASU), covers your mortgage payments if you become unemployed or are unable to work, due to an accident or illness. The government wants more of us to take this out because it is concerned about how many people would pay their mortgage if they lost their job, and the House of Commons social security committee recently indicated it favours forcing lenders to provide payment protection insurance as part of all mortgages. Ask the right questions and you could save a fortune When you're choosing a mortgage, be sure to check with the lender or adviser whether their loans come with compulsory insurance. The government says this is one of the 10 key questions, listed at the end, which everyone considering taking out a mortgage should ask. If the loan you're particularly interested in does require you to buy the lender's insurance, make sure it is clear exactly how much you would have to pay and how long you would have to take it for. It's advisable to do some homework to find out how the cost of the policy they're offering compares with what you could get by shopping around. Ring round a couple of companies or, if you have access to the internet, try one of the online insurance broking services run by companies such as Screentrade or the AA. You enter your basic details and the sites will fire back a selection of quotes from leading insurers. Screentrade has a panel of 19 insurers offering buildings and contents insurance, while the AA has 14 insurers on its site. If there is a big difference between what your lender is charging and what you could get by doing it yourself, you may find this cancels out much of what you would save by taking this mortgage deal. Screentrade says its own research has suggested that on average, lenders are charging 40% more for their buildings and contents insurance than you would pay by obtaining quotes from several insurers and going for the best one. "You can save yourself hundreds of pounds by shopping around," says a spokesman. If you want to be completely sure you're getting a mortgage with no hidden costs or catches you may want to consider a so-called "CAT" mortgage offered by Abbey National, Britannia building society, Egg, Halifax, HSBC, Woolwich and Yorkshire building society among others. CAT mortgages must meet a range of government-imposed minimum standards on charges and terms, one of which is that the lender cannot insist you buy its buildings, contents or mortgage payment protection insurance. Other requirements are that interest must be calculated daily, not annually; with variable rate mortgages, the interest rate cannot be any higher than 2% above the Bank of England base rate; and with fixed, discounted and capped mortgages, there must be no "lock-in" early redemption penalties after the end of the fixed/discounted/capped period. But the downside of CAT-marked mortgages is that they will often not offer the most competitive rate - meeting all those requirements inevitably means they will tend to be more expensive. Meanwhile, the advice about shopping around for your home insurance also applies to the millions of borrowers who may have been unwittingly forking out over the odds for years by sticking with their lender's buildings or contents cover. A few minutes on the net or the phone looking at what deals are on offer from other companies could enable people to make significant savings, and in the vast majority of cases you are going to be free to sign up with another insurer. Research issued by the Department of Trade and Industry last week found that at least one in four people initially sign up with their mortgage lender for insurance. It also revealed just how many people have never got round to changing their insurance provider - less than a third of homeowners (30%) have switched their home insurance in the past five years The DTI says there are 10 questions everyone taking out a mortgage should ask to help them make an informed choice and avoid hidden traps. 1 How much can I realistically afford to borrow? (Make sure you're clear about what you will have to pay out each month, and don't forget there are other fees and costs involved in buying a home.) 2 How can I tell which mortgage rate is best for me? (What is the rate now and what will happen to it when the special offer period ends?) 3 What is the best type of mortgage for me? (Ask what the jargon means, and whether the mortgage you're being offered will suit your circumstances both now and in the future.) 4 How should I repay it? (You can go for a repayment or an interest-only mortgage, or one that's a mixture of the two.) 5 Can I make lump sum payments to reduce the size of the loan? (Some mortgage deals are a lot more flexible than others.) 6 Are there any redemption penalties? (How much would you have to fork out if you wanted to switch to another lender's better deal?) 7 Does this mortgage come with compulsory insurance? 8 What other charges will I have to pay? (Check if you'll have to pay for mortgage indemnity guarantee insurance - also known as "MIG" fee.) 9 What happens if I can't pay? (Some lenders charge very high fees if you fall behind with your mortgage payments.) 10 What about the small print? (Ask about any terms you're unsure of.) For full details log on to the special website, the Consumer Gateway. A case: Joe Hogg Joe Hogg took out the lender's buildings insurance when he got his mortgage with Bank of Scotland around 15 years ago. Several years passed and then in 1998, when the bank sent him a renewal quote of £124 for just buildings cover, Mr Hogg, 42, of Edinburgh, decided to shop around to see if he could get a better deal. He signed up with Tesco Personal Finance after they gave him a quote for buildings and contents cover of £98.80. "I just wish we had done it earlier," he says. The amount Bank of Scotland charged him had "gradually climbed up" each year, he adds. "We have stuck with Tesco."

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Government's homebuying plan flawed

fields.headline: Flawed to the foundations
fields.standfirst: The government's sellers' pack idea is not good enough, there needs to be a massive shake-up of a rotten house sale system
fields.trailText: The government's sellers' pack idea is not good enough, there needs to be a massive shake-up of a rotten house sale system.
fields.body:
The government is right to say house buying needs reform. But in its enthusiasm for the seller's pack it is overlooking how fundamentally rotten the system is. A massive shake-up is needed, not tentative tinkering.

Local authorities, estate agents, surveyors (and solicitors) all expect their cut from the substantial amounts of money floating around and, with the connivance of mortgage lenders, will continue to get it until there are meaningful reforms.

The seller's pack may speed up the process but there is no reason why it should prevent gazumping. Sellers who have paid for the pack may be even more tempted to raise the price after accepting an offer, knowing that the new prospective buyer will be able to make a quicker decision on whether to proceed.

Little thought seems to have been put into how to make unwilling sellers use the pack. It has been suggested that selling a property without it could be a criminal offence enforced by trading standards officers. This would not be politically acceptable. There is no precedent for legislation making it illegal to draw up a contract in a way that fails to meet with government approval, yet is not dishonest, and if introduced it could fall foul of the Human Rights Act.

That there must be a local authority search is one of the unquestionable assumptions of conveyancing. Most councils charge more than £100 for these. The search amounts to three sheets of answers, stating, say, that there are no plans to build roads within 200 metres of the property and it is connected to the main drains. Compiling the information takes about 15 minutes.

The process can cause delays while councils get around to replying. The long-winded forms of questions give a misleading impression that both the authority and the solicitor making the inquiries are doing some work.

Legislation could require councils to quickly and cheaply answer a single question: Are there any adverse factors known to you affecting this property? "Adverse factors" will mean the matter currently referred to in the inquiries. If the special circumstances of a property call for extra inquiries, then they should be dealt with and charged for separately.

An even bigger bind for those involved in property transactions are fees charged by estate agents. Traditionally, these are expressed as a percentage of the selling price, not a specific amount. One would expect the percentage to fall as the house becomes more expensive, but the reverse applies. Agents in the provinces rarely charge much more than 1%. In the smarter parts of London rates can rise to 2.5%. Fees for selling a £50,000 house in Newcastle might be £500; if the same size property sold in Kensington for £500,000 they could be £12,500.

Overheads are higher in London, but not by a factor of 25. It is hard to see how a truly competitive market would allow such disproportionately high prices in some areas. There has to be a suspicion that agents have an informal understanding with each other that keeps commission rates up. This cries out for investigation by the Competition Commission and Office of Fair Trading, but so far neither have shown much interest.

Surveyors - or at least valuers - are another group who might not welcome too close a scrutiny of their role in the house buying process. "Survey" can cover vastly varied types of report. More often than not buyers rely just on the valuation that their mortgage lenders require. Although this may be prepared by a chartered surveyor, the work involved is neither skilful nor time consuming. A knowledge of the local market will give an idea of value, and a cursory inspection of the premises will disclose whether or not it has any obvious defects. But this is not the way to find out if the seller has been plastering over the cracks.

A structural survey doesn't deal with value, but should tell buyers all they could want to know. Although chartered surveyors can do this, the skills of a structural engineer are better fitted to the task.

On a personal note, when we bought our home we did have such a survey done. It was worth it. The engineer spotted obscure, though potentially serious, defects and we were able to renegotiate the price of the house on the basis of the report. Our mortgage lender, however, insisted that we have a valuation done by a valuer on its "panel". He looked at the property, pointed out the glaringly obvious, that it needed modernisation, wrote a 200-word report and said it was worth the price we were paying - no more than we could have done ourselves.

For that he charged the same as the engineer. It was only the monopoly in the area his position on the panel gave him that enabled him to charge such an uncompetitive rate. It would probably take political pressure, rather than legislation, to persuade lenders to abolish such panels, and accept valuations from anyone suitably qualified.

It has taken nearly three years to get even this far with the sellers' pack project. That delay makes it hard to take seriously claims that the government has the will to really tackle the mess that passes for English house buying.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

Fight is on to save conveyancing reforms
Phillip Inman

Housing minister Nick Raynsford spent the week battling with estate agents and other critics to save his plans to overhaul home buying and selling. Despite general dislike of the current system, the government has found it hard to gain support for its reforms.

Official figures show that 69% of households in England own their own homes. However, few are satisfied with the stress and uncertainty of house buying and selling .

The proposals are expected to speed up the process and increase its transparency by shifting much of the responsibility for gathering information from buyer to seller.

When the new rules are implemented, homeowners who want to put their house on the market will need to prepare a seller's pack. This must contain title documents, answers to pre-contract inquiries, replies to local searches, planning and building regulations consents, warranties and guarantees for any work car ried out, a draft sale contract and a surveyor's report on the condition of the property.

Packs for leasehold properties will also have to include information about the lease, service charges, insurance and management arrangements.

The changes are driven by concerns that under the present system a high number of transactions fall through after an offer has been accepted.

But not everyone shares the government's enthusiasm for the new rules, despite the claimed success of a pilot in Bristol. Critics say the changes will kill the property market in a single blow by chasing out sellers who are in two minds about whether or not to move.

Some agencies already offer a seller's pack as part of an overall service to sellers, either swallowing the cost of the pack in the overall fee, or deferring the fee until completion. The government expects more agents to join in.

fields.headline: Pug and Gravy, Chiswick
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort chews over the relative merits of two near neighbours in Chiswick, Pug and Gravy
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort chews over the relative merits of two near neighbours in Chiswick, Pug and Gravy.
fields.body:
Address: Pug and Gravy, Chiswick

Does anyone pay any attention to what critics write? I popped into Gravy, a new Brit-style pastiche bistro in Chiswick for lunch, shortly after Fay Maschler had given it a fearsome pasting in her column in the Evening Standard, deriding in particular its version of modern British cooking.

As I sat over my snack, Gravy filled up, until people were practically slopping over into the street outside. Were they, like myself, there out of curiosity, to see if a restaurant could be as bad as Ms Maschler had written? Or could it be that they were truly indifferent to scrappy, if anxious-to-please, service, dire food (ill-assorted seared salmon with salad, gherkins, caperberries and shallots; chewy calf's liver with anonymous parsley mash and burnt-tasting thyme gravy) and cud green walls?

I was completely baffled. They appeared to be having a whale of a time, so perhaps it's true that we don't really care about the basic decencies of eating when two courses for lunch costs £9.50.

But Chiswick's gastronomic reputation is in safer hands at Pug, further along the High Street. This is an altogether different item, and evidently it has not been put together on a shoestring budget. The dining room is what you'd call contemporary smart; that is, large and classless, in that crisp, bright, shiny way, with pale Granny Smith-green walls, corn-coloured wooden floor and brown leather chairs, nice, bright waitresses in classic apron, shirt and trouser gear, and plenty of noise bounding off the hard surfaces to build up the buzz. There's a big bar and a lounge ,where you can eat as well as drink, and a semi-open-plan kitchen. It runs with steady confidence, even though it was scarcely unwrapped when I went there for a solitary supper.

Every so often, I like a solitary supper, if you can be solitary with the teeming pages of Moby Dick open before you on the table. It may limit the number of courses that I can try, but - and this may come as a surprise to some of you - I don't really like making a complete pig of myself on every occasion. So it was the poached duck's egg salad with crispy chorizo and Parmesan croutons, followed by grilled chicken with roasted pumpkin, pumpkin seeds and gravy, followed by a bitter chocolate pot with Charbelli biscuits.

This is the kind of food that goes under the general heading of modern European, I suppose, as opposed to modern British, although the difference between them is a how-many-angels-can-you-get- on-the-head-of-a-pin kind of debate. Sometimes I have trouble with the fluid nature of some so-called modern cooking, because too often it doesn't seem to be rooted in any discernible culture, and the taste of the chef is so dubious as to render all ingredients to a kind of indeterminate mish-mash.

Brian Baker, the chef/proprietor of Pug, is a man who has been round the block a few times (Hambleton Hall, The Criterion, The Abingdon, The Depot, and two years as Sir Elton John's private chef), and he has a fair idea of what works and what doesn't. The kitchen has its feet firmly on mainland Europe, even if occasionally the menu strays into the Middle East, as with Moroccan-spiced lamb with herb and lime couscous, or even as far afield as the Far East with a honey and soy dressing for a mushroom and goat's cheese salad.

Each dish had a clear sense of identity based on sound technical skill and sensible gastronomic ambitions. In other words, it tasted good. The salad base was a fine mix of good quality leaves complemented by a fine dressing. The emollient egg and the saucy chorizo performed a bit of a ying and yang act to add interest, while the challengingly sized Parmesan croutons added a touch of ballast.

The grilled chicken and roasted pumpkin was more thought- provoking, but not what you would call seriously novel. The meat was from a bird of good breeding, and it had been expertly cooked to give nice burnt bits on the outside and nice succulent bits on the inside.

Pumpkin in the roasted form has a mild earthiness that sits well with burnt chicken. In addition, there were a couple of slivers of crisp pancetta, which served to introduce a salty note, and a good gravy to round things off. It would be a mistake to over-analyse a dish of this kind, but it is right to appreciate the intelligence that goes into devising it.

The bitter chocolate pot finished off the theme of warm comfort very nicely, the chocolate having just enough bitterness and concentration to take the edge off the richness. There was a sensible wine list, and my bill came to £25, which included a couple of glasses of wine, water and coffee.

There is a set lunch, two courses for £9.95 - not far off the price for the same offering at Gravy, but with the cooking and service in a different league. There's also a three-course dinner currently available for £14.95, which shows a worrying upward price trend - the press release at opening quoted three courses for £13.50, but it had reached £14.50 on the night I went there, and has continued to rise since.

In spite of this, Pug represents both a handsome and intelligent addition to the eating scene. Just in case anyone wants to know.

fields.headline: Branch Line
fields.standfirst: You want to plant a tree, but which kind? Christopher Lloyd names some of his favourites
fields.trailText: You want to plant a tree, but which kind? Christopher Lloyd names some of his favourites
fields.body:
If you intend to buy an unusual tree, or one likely to sell out before you have made a move, act quickly. Even if the ground is not currently suitable for planting, you can easily keep your purchase happy until it is.

A bare-root tree can be kept wrapped and damp in a cold shed until things improve. But if you are planting in turf, the soil beneath is usually friable and in reasonable condition, so long as you complete both the preparation and planting all in one go. Don't let the site become soaked between exposing the soil and putting in your tree. To find the tree you want, turn for sources to the RHS Plant Finder. Here are some of my favourites . . .

A black mulberry, Morus nigra . Fruit is produced from quite an early age and ripens in August-September. Don't make the mistake of buying the useless white mulberry, and do remember that the berries make a terrible stain - no matter if it's lawn beneath them, but a nuisance if you wanted to sit there.

The false acacia, Robinia pseudoacacia , is grumbled at for dropping spiny branches. Also, if its roots are damaged, for suckering. But it becomes a lovely, light-textured tree with a beautifully fissured trunk, while its pendant racemes of white blossom, late May or early June, are most deliciously fragrant on the air. Particularly beautiful is the variety Rozynskiana, its pinnate leaves long and drooping. In early June, that flowers as well as any.

With so great a preponderance of blossom in the spring, late flowerers are especially valuable. The Indian horse chestnut, Aesculus indica , flowers in late June or July. Its growth is similar to the ordinary chestnut's, so it'll need space, but its blush white flowering candles make a great display.

Koelreuteria paniculata , sometimes called Golden Rain, carries its panicles of small, yellow flowers late in July. It makes a charming small tree and is at its best in London, appreciating the extra summer heat. Its elegant pinnate leaves are shrimp-pink in spring and change to apricot orange before falling.

A tree doesn't have to flower to be good company. With so many flowering cherries, crabs and prunuses all around us, we might do well to try something different. Years ago, I fell in love with an oak, Quercus pyrenaica Pendula, which was growing in Holland Park, and I'm very glad I planted one soon after. It makes a beautifully shaped tree, upright in habit but with drooping branches. The long, deckle-edged leaves are quite pale on their undersides. Late in spring, it is briefly covered with long catkins among the unfolding leaves.

A not over-large but spreading tree is made by the deciduous conifer, Pseudolarix amabilis . In spring, its young foliage is the freshest green, long retained, but warm yellow in autumn. Cones, exactly the shape of tiny globe artichokes, are borne on the upper sides of some branches, not on others. It keeps you guessing. I killed my young one, I think, by planting it in dense turf where it was starved. But a weeping silver lime, Tilia Petiolaris, has done extremely well in such a position.

Next to my lime, I have an Italian alder, Alnus cordata (nowadays often planted as a windbreak along the boundaries of commercial fruit orchards). It has very large, handsome catkins in March, being one of the latest alders in flower. The foliage is healthy, glossy deep green.

Certain evergreen conifers are tempting - Sciadopitys verticillata , for instance, sometimes called umbrella pine because its leaves radiate from a central axis like the spokes of an umbrella. It does not usually make a big tree but is one of the freshest, and at its best if allowed to carry its branches right down to ground level throughout its life.

That goes for many conifers, too, and it is not an unpractical treatment in many private gardens. The Korean silver fir, for example, Abies koreana . If it does its stuff as expected, it carries upright cones like short purplish candles on the top of its horizontal branches. I use it as a mixed border plant. When it grows too large for its position, I start again with another youngster, but first use the top of my old one as a Christmas tree.

Fastigiate trees are often useful for taking up little lateral space, but many of them have a stiff and gawky branch system. One of the worst, in this respect, is the far too popular semi-double pink cherry, Prunus Amanogawa. It is only tolerable as a baby, becoming increasingly ugly year by year from then on. In a key position, I was recommended to plant the fastigiate version of the white pine, Pinus strobus Fastigiata, and I have not regretted it. Its fine needles, five to a cluster, are glaucous blue. The tree has remained well furnished right to its base, and when it shows a slight inclination to obesity around its waist, we lightly prune the young terminal shoots with secateurs

webTitle: Review: A Clue to the Exit by Edward St Aubyn

fields.headline: The thought gang
fields.standfirst: Justine Jordan on morbid meaning in A Clue to the Exit by Edward St Aubyn
fields.trailText: Justine Jordan on morbid meaning in A Clue to the Exit by Edward St Aubyn
fields.body:
A Clue to the Exit
by Edward St Aubyn
196pp, Chatto & Windus,
£12.99

This small novel boasts a big project: the quest for "the authentic ground of being", what Henry James called a clue to the exit from the human maze. Nested within it is an even slimmer novella that proposes to solve the related conundrum of human consciousness. The whole takes the form of a philosophical parlour game: what would you do if you had just six months to live - if the trivia of daily life, past regret and future planning melted away, bringing into focus the suddenly pressing problem of the meaning of life?

Schlock screenwriter Charlie has just had this life-changing news and determines, much to his agent's disgust, to write something honest and meaningful before he dies. His On the Train is a terrible pitch, worthy of Adrian Mole's stifled ambitions or Alain de Botton on a bad day: three people stuck in a railway carriage outside Didcot run through potted abstracts of different theories of consciousness.

As they rattle through dualism, Buddhism, linguistic philosophy, evolutionary psychology and the other usual suspects, Charlie experiences an equally speedy gamut of emotions and attitudes in his search for "the heart of the matter", significance in the face of death. Like Candide, he tries everything; embracing chance in a Monte Carlo casino and sexual obsession with an inscrutable stranger, flirting with fatherly feeling, staring at sunsets in the desert. And like Candide, of course, he comes home.

While his characters think about thinking, Charlie writes about writing: these circular musings mimic both the mind-bending tautologies of investigations into the human awareness of being aware and the endlessly forestalling effects of the effortful search for happiness. St Aubyn lends Charlie his characters from his own back catalogue: Patrick from the trilogy of abuse and addiction among the aristocracy that made his name, and Jean-Paul and Crystal from his last novel, On the Edge . Set among the New Age community, it also catalogued an eminently mockable search for meaning, yet aimed for visionary moments.

This swirl of satire and sincerity has become St Aubyn's speciality, but here the constant conflict between the grand gesture and the subversive side swipe has a jarring effect. Despite the elegant ease of his absurd set pieces and his stylish summaries of the most convoluted ideas, he is prepared to be as careless with his style as he is with his characters. His mockery of the clichés surrounding death, sex, philosophy and literature extends to the very fabric of the novel, leading to passages of parodically bad writing ("we thrashed like marlin caught on the hooks of each other's unforgiving genitals" - it's no surprise that A Clue to the Exit was shortlisted for a Bad Sex Prize). When a fleeting moment of comprehension is glimpsed, it comes not through language but through visual art.

Charlie is eventually swamped again by life's trivia and the "bathos of survival", while On the Train judders to a halt when a guest appearance from philosopher of mind Colin McGinn leads Patrick to accept with a sigh of relief that the nature of consciousness can never be fully understood. Both narratives, then, are set up to fail, and achieve this splendidly, leaving the strange phenomenon of a novel that fatally undermines itself.

webTitle: After Big Brother, reality TV goes pop

fields.headline: After Big Brother, reality TV goes pop
fields.standfirst:
ITV drive to create a music chart success

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: ITV drive to create a music chart success
fields.body:
One day, predicted the New Musical Express, pop will eat itself. That day could come next month when ITV reveals the true level of manipulation, deceit and subterfuge behind the creation of a pop band - with the complicity of the performers, a record company and, it is hoped, the viewers.

In an extraordinary exercise in counter-intuition, the network will screen Popstars, a 13-part series charting the creation of a teen band, from auditions, through rehearsals, to the release of a single. If all goes to plan and fiction turns into reality, the new stars should have a number one hit by the end of the run.

The format has already been a hit in Australia, where it was shown earlier this year. The programme was extended, and the all-girl band, Bardot, became a sensation. Their single and album shot to the top of the charts, the group was the talk of television shows and featured on the cover of magazines and newspapers.

ITV is investing heavily in the British version of the show, which it believes will become an equally talked-about success. Network chiefs have identified Popstars as one of their three priority projects next year and the hype is about to start. David Liddiment, the ITV director of programmes, says it is part of his strategy to promote "event-TV".

The initial episodes of the series follow the thousands of hopefuls who audition for the programme. Viewers will see executives from the record company Polydor, marketeers and television producers agonise over which characters to choose; while the trauma of rejection and joy of success are minutely exposed.

Then, the focus narrows on the band itself as a name is chosen and an image created. Cameras track the rehearsals, fitness routines and daily lives of the performers, who by this time will be living together. Finally, reality takes over as a CD is released and Polydor's promotion starts. The band will break out of the confines of the programme and, ITV hopes, become a musical sensation in their own right.

Conrad Green, the series producer for LWT, which is making the programme for ITV, believes the show exposes the reality behind the creation of modern pop music. "I would argue that it is more real than most bands, because you see everything that goes on. We don't pretend that they are like John, Paul and Ringo who happened to meet each other. Instead, we give these people the opportunity to meet each other when they might never have met anyone else in their town who can sing, or dance, or write songs."

Mr Green, who was series editor of the reality TV sensation Big Brother, for Channel 4, said he had no idea whether the new show would have the same impact that it had in Australia. "Hopefully it will grip people, because human stories are gripping. Showbusiness is something that fascinates people."

More than 2,000 people have already been auditioned and the first part of the series is already in production. It is expected that Britain's Popstars band will feature a mixture of young men and women, but the final selection has yet to be made.

Jason Volbeda, the publicist who hyped the show for the Seven network in Australia, said it was an instant hit. "It was down to a range of elements: on one level it is pure voyeurism, in the sense that anyone who has stood in front of a mirror with a hairbrush can relate to.

"There are also excruciating moments - it's 'train-wreck TV' that you're compelled to watch. And you see the tantrums and egos, you get involved with the finalists and get emotionally attached to them. We open the door to the music world, and viewers see how much really is manufactured."

Ones we made earlier

The Monkees Created out of Beatlemania in the 1960s, the clones had their own children's TV show from which they launched a series of hits.

PJ and Duncan The short-lived pop career of Ant and Dec grew out of their characters in the BBC children's drama Byker Grove.

The Banned Even shorter-lived spawn of EastEnders. Best not to go there.

S Club 7 A revamped version of the Monkees, this time with four girls and three boys. Started with a TV show, now the band is a hit in its own right. Made the cover of FHM magazine this month.

fields.headline: Express staff get £40,000 bonuses
fields.trailText: Lord Hollick, who sold Express Newspapers last week, has caused deep divisions among his former staff by giving away £1m in bonuses to a selected group of journalists and executives.
fields.body:
Lord Hollick, who sold Express Newspapers last week, has caused deep divisions among his former staff by giving away £1m in bonuses to a selected group of journalists and executives.

The Labour peer is sending cheques of up to £40,000 apiece to around 25 staff thought to include the Daily Express editor, Rosie Boycott, the columnist Peter Hitchens and the departing political editor, Anthony Bevins.

Meanwhile the sale of the newspapers 10 days ago to Richard Desmond, owner of OK! magazine and a range of soft porn titles, continues to stir controversy. It emerged yesterday that 10 MPs led by Labour's Brian Sedgemore have laid an early day motion expressing their "grave concerns and regrets that national newspapers within the Express Group should have fallen under the ownership of a publisher of pornography".

Other Express staff to benefit from Lord Hollick's largesse included the diarist John McEntee, football writer Rob Shepherd, columnist Martin Samuel and political journalist Peter Oborne.

One senior journalist at the Daily Express said staff were furious that the bonuses had been paid on what appears to have been an arbitrary basis.

"It's quite the most divisive thing he could have done - as if things weren't bad enough here," he said. "Nobody from production has got one - no one from the magazines. These are basically the people that Lord Hollick knows and has had some dealings with."

Chief City correspondent David Hellier and City editor Patrick Hosking are also among the recipients, as are comment editor John Price and Michael Pilgrim, editor of the Sunday paper.

"There's obviously some bitterness about," said another senior Express journalist. "I simply can't understand it. This is a man who while he owned the papers was very keen on scrutinising the smallest of expenses and here he is giving this money away. Is it conscience money? Did he feel guilty? I don't know. If I was a shareholder though I think I'd want to know what was going on."

A spokesman for United News & Media said the payments "are in recognition of their significant contribution to the success of the group over a number of years."

The others are said to include Chris Williams, the paper's number three, deputy editor Chris Blackhurst, David Robson, three senior Daily Star staff including editor Peter Hill and the directors of Express Newspapers.

Meanwhile the staff exodus has continued with the latest departure columnist Stephen Pollard. He said the paper's new owners treated its readers like "imbeciles who want to live on a diet of pap."

Mr Sedgemore is calling on trade secretary Stephen Byers to open an inquiry into the sale of the Express group. The ten MPs who have signed the motion are all Labour.

David Taylor, MP for north west Leicestershire who signed the motion said: "It seems to be heading for the newspaper graveyard and it will be a great shame if there is nothing in that market to compete with the trenchant often disturbed views of the Daily Mail."

webTitle: TV actor stabbed at home as he fights off attacker

fields.headline: TV actor stabbed at home as he fights off attacker
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: John Savident, the Coronation Street actor, was able to leave hospital last night after he was stabbed in the neck in his flat in central Manchester.
fields.body:
John Savident, the Coronation Street actor, was able to leave hospital last night after he was stabbed in the neck in his flat in central Manchester.

Savident, 62, who plays butcher Fred Elliott, was attacked at 3:30am yesterday at his one-bedroom flat 100 metres from Granada studios, where the soap opera is filmed. He was stabbed twice in the neck before fighting off his attacker, who fled.

Police have not revealed a motive for the attack but the inquiry has not ruled out the theory that Savident disturbed a burglar. Other lines of inquiry include the possibility of a stalker.

Police said a 28-year-old man from Ashton-under-Lyne was arrested in a nearby street just before 4am and was being questioned. It was unclear how an intruder could have gained access to Savident's flat. Entry to the apartments is through security doors with intercom system. Several Coronation Street actors and production staff live in the area.

Savident, a former Manchester police officer who has appeared in the series for six years, was treated at Manchester royal infirmary but his injuries were not life threatening.

A neighbour, David Przepiora, 56, who lives on the floor below, said he saw Savident stagger into the street in the early hours of yesterday morning.

"I came out of the flat and saw John naked and covered in blood shouting, 'I don't know why he did it.' He looked dreadful, really pale, and blood was pouring from the back of his neck."

Mr Przepiora, an artist, said he was woken at 3am by the sound of someone opening Savident's ground floor garage, where the actor keeps a sports car.

"I looked out of the window and saw a man outside holding the remote control for the garage and making the door go up and down. He did this two or three times and it was making quite a lot of noise. He seemed agitated and ran back into the flat."

He said Savident, who appeared in A Clockwork Orange and Gandhi in an acting career spanning 30 years, was an affable, quiet neighbour who kept to himself. He lived alone while his wife lived in London.

It is understood that Savident attended a charity event for national Aids week at Via Fossa bar in Canal Street before the attack.

Yesterday, Savident's street, where Coronation Street actors Sue Nicholls and Jacque line Pirie also have homes, was cordoned off while forensic experts searched the flat and plain clothes police removed items in a black bin liner. There was a splattering of blood near the door.

A spokeswoman for Granada said: "Everyone is really, really shocked that anything like this could happen. It was a terrible ordeal to have gone through and the cast have all been ringing in and wishing him a speedy recovery."

Granada said that although the incident would not affect next week's live, hour-long 40th birthday episode of Coronation Street, Savident could be written out if he was too ill to perform.

"As one of the most popular characters in the cast, John has an active role in the live episode," a spokesman said. "It depends on how serious his injuries are as to whether he will be in it."

Granada refused to comment on safety issues for the Coronation Street cast until they knew the reason for the attack on Savident.

Three female members of the cast, Tracey Shaw, Jennifer James and Pirie, recently complained of five years of harassment from a stalker. He was stabbed twice in the neck before fighting off his attacker, who fled. fields.headline: BBC apologises for 'rigged' Millionaire claim
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: The BBC was yesterday forced to apologise for suggesting that ITV had rigged an edition of its hit game show Who Wants to be a Millionaire?
fields.body:
The BBC was yesterday forced to apologise for suggesting that ITV had rigged an edition of its hit game show Who Wants to be a Millionaire?

In an embarrassing climbdown, the corporation withdrew comments made by a number of its "overzealous" press officers after ITV showed Judith Keppel winning £1m on the night the BBC transmitted the last-ever episode of One Foot in the Grave. The BBC said steps had been taken to ensure such a claim is never repeated.

ITV was furious at the coverage that followed the Millionaire win last week. Many newspapers ran the BBC "fix" claim, despite firm denials by the commercial network. It is understood that a phone poll in the Mirror, showing that most readers believed the BBC claim, prompted the ITV chairman, Leslie Hill, to make a formal complaint to his BBC opposite number, Sir Christopher Bland.

In a statement yesterday, the BBC distanced itself from employees who made the comments and said it did not believe there was any "manipulation or fixing" of the quiz.

"The BBC should simply have acknowledged, as a point of fact, that ITV's first million-pound winner coincided with the final episode of One Foot in the Grave. We should also have given more emphasis to the fact that Monday's schedule on both channels was a fantastic night for viewers.

"An overzealous press briefing went further and commented that Millionaire had previously had big winners against other high-profile BBC programmes, inviting some journalists to draw the inference that this might be more than a coincidence. This was wrong."

The apology is embarrassing for the BBC because the press briefing was conducted by senior members of the corporation's publicity team.

Yesterday, an ITV spokeswoman said: "We said at the time these suggestions were completely unfounded and so are grateful to the BBC for setting the record straight."

The press briefing was the culmination of a war of words that has waged between the BBC and ITV this autumn. BBC1 moved its main news programme to 10pm and embarked on an aggressive scheduling strategy of placing high-profile shows against ITV's best offerings.

While the BBC has been criticised for the tactic, the director general Greg Dyke has said the corporation is not in the business of "managing decline". The BBC fears that if ratings for its flagship channel fall below a critical mass, the argument for the licence fee will be undermined.

fields.headline: Is this your licence to print money?
fields.standfirst:
Don't let the big guns deter you: there is still plenty of room for would-be Citizen Kanes in the tough world of magazines. Sandra Deeble goes to press

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Don't let the big guns deter you: there is still plenty of room for would-be Citizen Kanes in the tough world of magazines. Sandra Deeble goes to press.
fields.body:
Whatever you're into, there's a magazine for you out there. Check out the shelves in WH Smith: snappy new titles appear every day. The glossies which help you create the ultimate minimalist temple - in your body, home, garden or mind - sit cheek by jowl with Practical Caravan and Dog World.

The internet has far from put the kibosh on weighty tomes; it has spawned its own wave of techie mags. And the era of slow commuting recently put in place by Railtrack means that many more words are being read per journey. Surely the market is ripe for would-be Citizen Kanes?

Yet the reality is that while 200 magazines start up each month, a high proportion fail after only two issues. This chilling warning sets the scene at the beginning of a two-day course called Introduction to Magazine Publishing run by the London School of Printing. The course costs £249 and promises to get you all Quark-ed up before launching your own home-spun version of Conde Nast.

So who would be maverick enough to start their own publication when even the most powerful and established of magazine publishers are struggling to increase market share? Producers of high-profile women's mags such as Red and Marie Claire are quaking in their Sergio Rossis as they square up to the imminent arrival of established US titles.

Nevertheless, if you look hard enough, there are still gaps in the market, and novice, spare bedroom publishers continue to dip a toe into the water in the hope that what they've been plotting will strike a chord.

And "boldness has genius", said Goethe, a view doubtlessly shared by Paul Morrison, publisher of Wanderlust. "If someone tells you that something won't work when you know there's a gap in the market, that's an incentive to do it. What it means is that they haven't been able to make it work."

He and his partner, Lyn Hughes launched their specialist travel magazine "something between a Lonely Planet guide and National Geographic" seven years ago. Its initial print run of 5,000 has grown to 45,000 since its launch.

"We were consumers frustrated by the fact that there wasn't a magazine for us," explains Mr Morrison. "We were working in IT, doing contract work, and were able to take long breaks and travel a lot. At the time, there was nothing giving you information about more unusual travel: there was this gaping hole in the market."

This hole is being filled rapidly as Wanderlust has been joined by the likes of Conde Nast's Traveller and Escape Routes, produced by EMAP. "I'm not going to say it's not tough," says editor Lyn Hughes. "We see other magazines come along where the circulation is no bigger than ours but because they've got a major publishing house behind them it eases their way into the shops."

Yet it is possible to spread the word without big budget advertising - it just takes longer, admits Mr Morrison. He and Ms Hughes learned about publishing the hard way through attending an evening class and going to the library. "We bought an Apple Mac and converted the spare bedroom and then got someone to teach us Quark. Looking back at it now, we cringe, although the first issue is now a collector's item."

"When we started, people in our street worked with us," says Ms Hughes. "Our next door neighbour made up the ads and a lady down the road did the typing." And although Wanderlust now has a team of 10 people, Ms Hughes is adamant that by remaining hands-on, the fun continues, which is why they choose to remain independent.

Dreams of fun jobs in publishing are often inspired at school, when a "print your own newspaper" project can elicit enthusiastic sessions of cutting, pasting and editorial battles over Bugles and Clarions. Teacher Hayley Hobbs used to struggle when trying to use newspapers in the classroom as directed by the National Curriculum. "There was nothing really suitable," she explains. "It wasn't just the vocab, it was the content as well."

Ms Hobbs, together with fellow teacher Buffy Whiting, started producing The Newspaper earlier this year, although it was officially launched in September. Some 500,000 copies of the latest issue are hot off the press and there is a now a waiting list of 200,000 more eager recipients. It's a free publication funded entirely by strictly monitored advertising and distributed to schools. Ms Hobbs sent out "a tatty piece of paper" to head teachers as her market research. "We had a 50% re sponse," she says. "If you speak to teachers, it's something that has been lacking for years." Interviews with the likes of All Saints and Arsenal defender Matthew Upson provide reading comprehensions with cred, and Ms Hobbs produces notes for teachers that are posted on the website so that materials can be used immediately.

The success of The Newspaper, according to Ms Hobbs, is that it isn't: "a worthy tome"; it has links with websites such as Pop World, and it's keen to encourage children to contribute articles and air their views.

While new publishers have to be assiduous when truffling out untapped niches, opportunities often arise when existing publications fail to hit the spot.

So it was for Mslexia, a magazine for "women who write", launched in 1998 by Debbie Taylor. There were already a couple of magazines for writers on the market but Mslexia has won followers for its critical look at both published and unpublished writers.

Now, with 6,500 subscribers, Mslexia has been welcomed with a heartfelt "at last" sigh of gratitude by women hungry for practical, humorous advice about tackling the publishing powers that be. But after nearly two years of producing stirring stuff, Debbie Taylor is often a victim of what she preaches in the magazine.

"Pester, pester pester", is the advice meted out to people with dreams of getting their poems out of their notebooks and on to the tables of Waterstones. Breeding a persistent, never-give-up attitude means that subscribers are quick to pick up the phone to try out their selling techniques. "The more we advise people, the more we're on the receiving end of it," says Ms Taylor philosophi cally. "And every subscriber is a potential contributor."

With 10% funding from Northern Arts, Mslexia will soon be on newsstands and in bookshops, in addition to subscriptions. "Although we've been described in other publications as a membership organisation," explains Ms Taylor. "I think that's how people feel."

This resonates with Lyn Hughes at Wanderlust. "People often say: 'I'm calling to renew my membership. And it has got that club feel; as we grow, one of the challenges will be keeping that feeling."

The fact that readers can call the owner, editor and publisher may create a special feeling of intimacy for the reader; for the publisher, it provides vital and valuable feedback. Wanderlust has regular reader evenings all around the country; Debbie Taylor often picks up the phone in the offices of Mslexia and at The Newspaper, Hayley Hobbs goes into schools where teachers and children tell her what they think of the publication. It's essential information which enables independent publishers to hone their content so that they're consistently producing something that's hard to put down.

So small really can be beautiful, according to Paul Morrison at Wanderlust. "You can have people in a big publishing company having brainstorming sessions to find out where to position their next title. Yet when you're small, you take risks and spot gaps."

webTitle: Comment: Truth stranger than fiction in US elections

fields.headline: Stranger than fiction - ain't that the truth
fields.standfirst:
A revived 1960 Gore Vidal play has proved uncannily prescient

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: It is generally said that jokes don't age well but time has been astonishingly kind to a line Gore Vidal wrote 40 years ago. At the Virginia Theatre on Broadway on Wednesday afternoon, during a revival of Vidal's 1960 hit The Best Man, the words brought gasps and applause.
fields.body:
It is generally said that jokes don't age well but time has been astonishingly kind to a line Gore Vidal wrote 40 years ago. At the Virginia Theatre on Broadway on Wednesday afternoon, during a revival of Vidal's 1960 hit The Best Man, the words brought gasps and applause.

The play is set during the deadlocked presidential convention of an unspecified party. As a winner refuses to emerge, one contender exasperatedly warns: "The way we're going, we'll never nominate anyone." A nothing line when written has become an accidental show-stopper. Gore Vidal has often mocked his distant politician cousin Albert Jr, but the vice- president who is so desperate to give up the vice has allowed his relative the biggest laugh of his writing career.

The humourist's constitution mandates that events such as the current American election mess are cited as proof that truth is stranger than fiction. In New York this week, I have been testing this contention by immersing myself in presidential fiction.

Three White House stories were produced to coincide with the 2000 election. Apart from the comeback of Vidal's play, they were Rob Lurie's movie The Contender, with Joan Allen as a Democrat senator attempting to become vice-president against Republican hostility; and a political-legal thriller, Protect and Defend, by the bestselling Richard North Patterson. Watched or read against a background of events which you couldn't make up, these campaign tales now face an unusually severe test for political fiction. Have the novelists and playwrights been out-plotted by reality?

Vidal's The Best Man would seem as certain to date as Bill Clinton on a Saturday night. But, if the roar which now greets the line about the possibility of never nominating anyone is a result of luck, the writer deserves it for his general far-sightedness. Much other dialogue - including one about Americans feeling more comfortable when being led by someone stupid - now take on the kick of topicality. Scenes detailing a loveless marriage of political convenience produced an uneasy stirring in a theatre a few blocks from a bookshop where the new senator from New York, Hillary Rodham Clinton, was about to make an appearance. All political fiction fears being overtaken by events. The Best Man had the happier feel that events had taken it over.

A few hours later, at a 25-screen multiplex on several levels above 42nd Street, there was a sense of heightened expectation in the audience before a screening of the presidential thriller, The Contender. The present electoral no-win situation has had on political fiction an effect similar to recreational drugs. Each speech seems more significant, every irony bigger.

The Contender (released in Britain next year) is, like Al Gore, caught between two administrations. Joan Allen's would-be vice-president is almost destroyed by Gary Oldman's McCarthyite Republican, waving faded stains on her sheets. The message - that sex should not be relevant to a politician's career - is a parting gift to Bill Clinton from the producer, his friend Steven Spielberg. But the image of politics as a dirty fight between parties more interested in victory than principles is helped by the Florida context and a reference to a vice-president's sudden death in office produced Cheney-inspired titters.

The film, though, is essentially a Clintonian fiction. Better adapted to the new unled America is Protect and Defend. With triple luck, Richard North Patterson's book has a title from the constitution, an illustration of the supreme court pillars on its cover and is published on December 12 - now the final legal deadline for the Florida arithmetic to cease. Inclining to the view that the White House is increasingly a frat-room for the nation's lawyers, the book follows a president attempting to appoint the next chief justice, but feels perfectly timed for a period in which the chief justice may appoint the next president.

There was a startling example in Britain a decade ago of a real politician helping the career of a fictional one: Andrew Davies's BBC adaptation of the Michael Dobbs novel House Of Cards, with Ian Richardson as a Tory schemer plotting the succession to a resigning prime minister, had the enormous good fortune to be broadcast in the week of Margaret Thatcher's fall.

Any American fiction writer who came up with such a neat plot coincidence on this occasion would have to be interrogated at once for close connections with God or the governor of Florida. But, competing with occurrences which could not have been foreseen, America's political fiction writers have proved surprisingly prescient. Broadway producers may have been knowingly cheeky in staging a play this autumn by a member of the Gore clan and casting an actor (Chris Noth from Sex and the City) who shares the current vice-president's bulky solemnity. But how odd that Vidal's play should depict deadlocked contenders.

And The Contender's portrayal of main parties' hatred of each other as the driving motivation of American politics draws on the Clinton impeachment, as did North Patterson's contention that American politicians are merely surrogates for the lawyers who truly run the country. But the 2000 election - being decided posthumously by animosity and attorneys - has shown in these writers an ability to predict the future issues which would make any focus group envious. None of these political narratives needed to be differently recounted.

fields.headline: Power cuts at -30C for Russians
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Five thousand miles from Moscow in sub-zero temperatures, hundreds of women and children in Russia's far east blocked the main Pacific roads yesterday to protest at the impact of a regional energy crisis.
fields.body:
Five thousand miles from Moscow in sub-zero temperatures, hundreds of women and children in Russia's far east blocked the main Pacific roads yesterday to protest at the impact of a regional energy crisis.

With children dying as a result of power cuts and temperatures sinking below -30C (-22F), around 500 protesters blockaded the main routes linking the regional capital, Vladivostok, to other towns.

Energy crises have become an annual fixture in the region, as a result of embezzlement, unpaid bills, fuel shortages, collapsing infrastructure, and misrule. But the crisis is worse this year, with some 60% of the power supply infrastructure said to be in ruins.

The regional governor, Yevgeny Nazdratenko, has long been at odds with the Kremlin. His administration and local councils loyal to him have failed to lay in enough coal and fuel for the winter, nor have they carried out repairs.

But with the governor well entrenched, the crisis has become a major test of authority for President Vladimir Putin.

fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText: Separatists in the Indonesian province of Irian Jaya yesterday held muted ceremonies to mark the 39th anniversary of their unilateral declaration of independence after officials threatened repressive measures against anyone calling for secession.
fields.body:
Muted protests in Irian Jaya

Separatists in the Indonesian province of Irian Jaya yesterday held muted ceremonies to mark the 39th anniversary of their unilateral declaration of independence after officials threatened repressive measures against anyone calling for secession.

Surrounded by troops, several thousand West Papuans, as they call themselves, saw their movement's flag raised in the provincial capital, Jayapura. Similar events were held across the province.

Police in Jakarta used tear gas to disperse several hundred Papuans after protesters refused to lower their flag.
John Aglionby
Jakarta

Mystery over fate of minister

China's struggle against corruption has reached the heart of power in Beijing, with the mysterious removal of the minister of justice, Gao Changli.

Officials said Mr Gao, who disappeared from his ministry last weekend, had left his post "for health reasons". But other sources claim he has been caught up in the drive against high-level corruption.

His downfall is thought to be connected with the alleged corrupt activities of his family and associates in Shandong province.
John Gittings
Hong Kong

Fujimori to stay away from Peru

Disgraced ex-president Alberto Fujimori said yesterday that he would not return to Peru from Japan even if his presence was demanded by investigators probing circumstances surrounding his resignation.

A Peruvian state attorney investigating corruption allegations against the country's ex-spy chief said on Monday he was looking into evidence that could link Mr Fujimori to money-laundering.
Reuters
Tokyo

webTitle: Supreme court hears Bush and Gore arguments on election recount

fields.headline: Supreme court hears Bush and Gore arguments on election recount
fields.standfirst:
Washington and the world watch

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: There are days in the history of a nation when the sheer drama of the moment transcends even the great issues at stake. Yesterday, when the highest court in the United States debated the outcome of the presidential election, was one of them, and the whole of Washington wanted to make sure of its ticket.
fields.body:
There are days in the history of a nation when the sheer drama of the moment transcends even the great issues at stake. Yesterday, when the highest court in the United States debated the outcome of the presidential election, was one of them, and the whole of Washington wanted to make sure of its ticket.

The nine gowned justices of the US supreme court took their seats just before 10am to hear legal arguments in a case that could decide who will be the next leader of the republic.

John Fucetola had arrived at just before 4am on Thursday and queued for more than 30 hours to be first in line to get one of the court's 50 public seats. Others huddled in sleeping bags on the pavement on Capitol Hill

"Money can't buy this. Money can't buy history," he told a scrum of reporters. "This is something we'll be telling our grandchildren."

Senator Edward Kennedy, the closest thing that America has to a hereditary peer, made sure of his place, along with other senior Republican and Democrat figures.

Outside on Capitol Hill, there were large, noisy crowds, some drawn there by their political passions. Gore supporters waved placards saying "We've been Bushwhacked". Republicans hit back with "Winners not whiners".

But many came simply because this was one of those days where you want to say "I was there when"

"God save the United States and this honourable court," the high court's marshal intoned. Then Chief Justice William Rehnquist announced: "We'll hear argument this morning on number 00-836, George W Bush versus the Palm Beach Canvassing Board," and called Mr Bush's lawyer, Ted Olson, to begin his pleadings.

Mr Olson had been on his feet for little more than half a minute when Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, the first female supreme court member, interrupted him with a question.

That set the pattern for the morning, as Mr Olson and Mr Gore's lawyer, Laurence Tribe, were peppered with questions.

Each lawyer had 35 minutes to put his case. Lawyers for Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state, and her arch-enemy, Bob Butterworth, the Florida attorney general, then each got ten minutes.

In accordance with the court's brisk traditions, the hearings were time limited and cameras were excluded. A request from the C-Span channel for television cameras to be allowed in had been rejected earlier in the week.

But, in a break with convention, the court allowed an audio tape of its proceedings to be broadcast after the hearing.

The case hinges on whether the supreme court, which interprets the US constitution, decides it has any reason to step in and override the Florida state courts.

All remarks were noted, as hints of the way the unpredictable justices are thinking were eagerly sought by lawyers on both sides.

Early reports suggested that Mr Olson was having a difficult time persuading the judges that this was a case in which they should intervene.

"I do not know of any case where we have impugned a state supreme court the way you are doing in this case," said Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, normally a liberal.

"In case after case we have said we owe the highest respect to what the state supreme court says is the state's law."

"This is a very unusual situation, Justice Ginsburg," Mr Olson replied, "because it is in the contest of a presidential election."

"Why should the federal judiciary be interfering in what seems to be a carefully thought out scheme?" asked Justice David Souter, another liberal member of the bench.

Mr Tribe found himself facing a grilling too. " You now say this court has no role. That means the supreme court of Florida is it," said Justice Anthony Kennedy.

And then, after just one and a half hours, it came to an end and the judges withdrew to consider their verdict, expected early next week. History stood adjourned.
