webTitle: Glaxo stops Africans buying cheap Aids drugs

fields.headline: Glaxo stops Africans buying cheap Aids drugs
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Aids crisis
fields.trailText: The arguments over affordable life-saving medicines for the developing world intensified yesterday when it was revealed that the multinational pharmaceutical company Glaxo-Wellcome has blocked imports of cheap copies of one of its Aids drugs into Ghana.
fields.body:
The arguments over affordable life-saving medicines for the developing world intensified yesterday when it was revealed that the multinational pharmaceutical company Glaxo-Wellcome has blocked imports of cheap copies of one of its Aids drugs into Ghana.

The revelation came as South Africa announced it had done a deal with a second company, Pfizer, over supplies of the drug Fluconazole to treat infections such as meningitis that often kill people whose immune systems are wrecked by the Aids virus HIV.

Under pressure from campaigners, who began bringing a cheaper version of the patent-protected branded drug into South Africa which massively undercut the usual Pfizer price, the company has agreed to supply Fluconazole free.

But although aid organisations such as the charity Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) hailed the deal as an example of what can be achieved if countries show a willingness to turn their back on the pharmaceutical giants and buy copies, Britain made it clear yesterday that it was not in favour of such tactics.

Trade minister Richard Caborn told activists from the London-based organisation Action for Southern Africa (Actsa) that such measures "are not the answer here".

Campaigners insist that developing countries must use every possible means to get hold of affordable drugs that can stop people dying. But western governments say the companies have a right to protection for the drugs they sell at high prices in order, the companies argue, to recoup research and development costs.

The west says the right approach is for countries to negotiate discounts with the companies. But African nations say they cannot afford the drugs even at the discount prices offered in May this year by five multinationals. Only Senegal has so far taken up the invitation to negotiate a deal.

The giants take very seriously the threat of competition. Glaxo-Wellcome has blocked the import into Ghana of a version of its Aids therapy Combivir made in India by Cipla.

It is argued by campaigners that impoverished countries faced with a health emergency have a right under international trade legislation to buy generic drugs. The African Regional Industrial Property Organisation was quoted yesterday as saying that if Glaxo went to court, it believed it would lose. But poor countries fear confrontation will upset relations with the west.

Glaxo's spokesman said the company had offered Ghana its own drugs under its "preferential pricing" scheme.

The price for the generic version of Combivir has not been revealed, but generics sell for a fraction of the branded price. MSF has gathered data showing that Cipla sells Fluconazole for $0.64 (45p) in India, compared with Pfizer's price in South Africa of $8.25 and in Kenya of $10.56.

MSF pointed out yesterday that AZT and 3TC, the two drugs in Combivir, are both old and that they were developed with the help of public funds in the United States. Glaxo Wellcome has already made many millions out of them. "It cannot argue it needs to recoup its investment," said a spokesman.

Actsa says that the threat of generic competition made Pfizer lift restrictions it wanted to impose on the Fluconazole it is donating to South Africa. "At first it was going to be only for meningitis and not for thrush, which affects more people. The company was dictating how the drug was to be used," said a spokesman.

The Pfizer deal was announced the day after South Africa's medicines control council said it would allow generic Fluconazole to be used in the country.

fields.headline: Writ over Shayler dropped
fields.standfirst: Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: Government lawyers yesterday abandoned their writ against the Mail on Sunday for allegedly breaching its duty of confidence by publishing disclosures by the former MI5 officer David Shayler.
fields.body:
Government lawyers yesterday abandoned their writ against the Mail on Sunday for allegedly breaching its duty of confidence by publishing disclosures by the former MI5 officer David Shayler.

The writ, which had serious implications for the media, also claimed damages from Associated Newspapers, publishers of the Mail on Sunday, for causing "injury to the national interest".

Government lawyers claimed the media was bound by the same duty of confidence and copyright rules as any former crown servant, including spies.

The Mail on Sunday was the first newspaper to publish revelations by Mr Shayler - including how MI5 kept files on politicians and rock musicians - in August 1997.

The treasury solicitor said in its statement of claim that the newspaper paid £40,000 for the information as well as Mr Shayler's legal fees and accommodation in France. It also demanded the return of all MI5 documents Mr Shayler gave to the newspaper.

The decision to abandon the writ was announced in the high court during a hearing of arguments relating to Mr Shayler's secrets trial, which has been set down for next April.

webTitle: Space station will brighten night sky

fields.headline: Space station will brighten night sky
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: The space shuttle Endeavour, which blasted off from the Kennedy space centre yesterday, is due to dock with a floating hotel 200 miles up in the sky at 7.57pm GMT tonight, and deliver a $600m set of solar panels bigger than a jumbo jet.
fields.body:
The space shuttle Endeavour, which blasted off from the Kennedy space centre yesterday, is due to dock with a floating hotel 200 miles up in the sky at 7.57pm GMT tonight, and deliver a $600m set of solar panels bigger than a jumbo jet.

When the panels are installed, the unfinished structure will gleam in reflected sunlight to become the brightest thing in the night sky, after the moon and the star Sirius.

People in Britain will not see the $60bn International Space Station (ISS) until September 13 2001, when it reaches an altitude of about 17 in the southern sky at around 18.04 GMT. But by then, an electrifying drama will have been played out in orbit at 18,500 mph, as astronauts begin the highest construction job of all time.

They will have to fit the 240ft-wide high-voltage arrays of the solar panels to a structure already 13 storeys high - while working in freefall.

Each wing of the panels weighs a ton, and together they will generate 64kw of current - enough to power 30 homes.

During construction, the arrays will have to be moved so they cannot generate electricity, or the 80-ton space station tilted away from the sun, to make conditions safe.

"We don't want to be the lightning rod, as it were, for the discharge between any potential energy difference between the structure and space," astronaut Joe Tanner said. "If they say we ought to take certain precautions, then by golly, we ought to take those precautions."

webTitle: Why that joke email could get you the sack

fields.headline: Why that joke email could get you the sack
fields.standfirst:
Your in-box is not as private as you thought

Net news
fields.trailText: Your in-box is not as private as you thought.
fields.body:
They were not even very good jokes. Certainly not the sort of thing you would send to your mother, but exactly the same as thousands of other smutty emails that whizz their way round the computers of Britain's offices every day.

But for Rupert Beverley and David Pennington, who worked for an engineering company in Huddersfield, forwarding the messages to colleagues was the worst mistake they ever made. Earlier this month an industrial tribunal unanimously rejected their claim for unfair dismissal. It found the company was perfectly within its rights to sack them not only for sending the emails - but more worryingly for the thousands of workers whose in-boxes are filled with personal mail - for the amount of time wasted in the process.

A string of similar sackings in other companies has set alarm bells ringing among civil liberties groups and trade unions, who believe the current regulations could be used as a licence for bullying bosses to build up dossiers and then fire people they do not like.

The emails ranged from a cartoon frog in a blender to smutty drawings and jokes. They had been circulating among a group of 40 willing employees at the company, but unfortunately one of them went astray and landed in the in-box of a colleague who did not share their sense of humour. He complained, an investigation and surveillance operation were launched and Mr Beverley and Mr Pennington were sacked for being the ring leaders and forwarding more emails than anybody else.

In their case the company had a clear policy stating precisely what was ac ceptable material for inclusion in emails. But the plethora of rules and regulations governing exactly how, when and why bosses can access the in-boxes of their staff is both contradictory and confusing, and has led more and more companies to the conclusion that they can carry out blanket trawls of emails. Others have banned emails altogether rather than end up in acrimonious disputes with their staff.

The farrago has led some commentators to suggest it could have ramifications for Tony Blair's vision of London as the e-commerce capital of the world. "The laws are riddled with contradictions," said John Browning, co-founder of First Tuesday, the main network for dot.com entrepreneurs. "Why would companies come to Britain when they don't face these kinds of problems in other countries."

Under pressure from employers the government acted. The Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act, which came into force on October 24, allows employers to snoop on staff without their knowledge according to specific circumstances. But the six categories listed are widely considered to include nearly all the circumstances in which an employer might want to snoop.

But the RIP Act contradicts both a 60 page draft code of conduct drawn up by the data protection commissioner, Elizabeth France, and article 8 of the Human Rights Act. Ms France insists that email is private and has refused to water down the draft code that effectively bars employers from opening personal messages received at work. She also believes workers should have the power to delete emails, a move that would prevent firms retrieving old messages from an individual's hard disk.

However, the Department of Trade and Industry has made it clear that the RIP Act takes precedence. The only crumb of comfort for employees can be found in the regulations, which a spokesman said employees can use to pursue a civil action against an employer who has not told its staff that emails "may or will be intercepted".

A spokesman for the civil rights group Liberty said: "Our view is that employers should be obliged to justify each occasion when they monitor an employee's emails or telephone calls and show why it was necessary and proportionate in that case. They should also provide facilities for employees to phone and even send emails from their workplace secure in the knowledge that their calls or emails won't be intercepted."

A spokeswoman for the TUC also criticised the current confusion."At the moment the regulations encourage employers to think blanket monitoring of all emails is allowed without thinking how that will affect the workforce."

One of the most worrying recent examples is that of eight sales staff at the telecoms company Cable & Wireless who were suspended after a complaint about a smutty email. Six of them were sacked last week and two others are understood to have resigned. All eight had worked for the company for less than a year and so will be prevented from appealing to an industrial tribunal.

One of the six sacked workers said the first time he saw the company policy on emails was in a letter after he was suspended. Even then he felt safe after he read that staff might only be dismissed for downloading pornography. He said he deleted the email. Yet this failed to appease the company and it trawled through his in-box.

"They went through my entire system and found an email with the word 'fuck' in it, which they said was offensive," the employee said.

Cable & Wireless said the emails were clearly in breach of its policy, but admitted the guidelines were not published on the internal computer noticeboard. When the Guardian asked for a copy of the policy a spokeswoman said it was private and confidential.

If the Cable & Wireless staff had been at the company for more than a year they might have claimed that the policy was unclear or that Cable & Wireless had failed to communicate it to staff. They could also claim the company had been draconian if other staff on the email circulation list had been let off, as one of the victims alleges.

It looks more and more as though the UK is set to follow the American model where more than 40% of companies regularly examine their staff's email. One multinational company in Germany - where the rules governing spying on employees personal emails are much stricter - is understood to have already taken advantage of the more relaxed laws in the UK by sending all the emails sent and received by staff from its offices in Germany to London where they are monitored.

It would seem likely that there will be many more court cases before employees know for sure just what words are acceptable for use in private emails and how much time they can spend sending private messages and surfing the internet. But one thing is for sure: that ill thought out missive questioning the parentage of the boss could well land more employees in hot water.

He complained, an investigation and surveillance operation were launched and Mr Beverley and Mr Pennington were sacked for being the ring leaders and forwarding more emails than anybody else. In their case the company had a clear policy stating precisely what was ac ceptable material for inclusion in emails. But the plethora of rules and regulations governing exactly how, when and why bosses can access the in-boxes of their staff is both contradictory and confusing, and has led more and more companies to the conclusion that they can carry out blanket trawls of emails. Others have banned emails altogether rather than end up in acrimonious disputes with their staff. The farrago has led some commentators to suggest it could have ramifications for Tony Blair's vision of London as the e-commerce capital of the world. "The laws are riddled with contradictions," said John Browning, co-founder of First Tuesday, the main network for dot.com entrepreneurs. "Why would companies come to Britain when they don't face these kinds of problems in other countries." Under pressure from employers the government acted. The Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act, which came into force on October 24, allows employers to snoop on staff without their knowledge according to specific circumstances. But the six categories listed are widely considered to include nearly all the circumstances in which an employer might want to snoop. But the RIP Act contradicts both a 60 page draft code of conduct drawn up by the data protection commissioner, Elizabeth France, and article 8 of the Human Rights Act. Ms France insists that email is private and has refused to water down the draft code that effectively bars employers from opening personal messages received at work. She also believes workers should have the power to delete emails, a move that would prevent firms retrieving old messages from an individual's hard disk. However, the Department of Trade and Industry has made it clear that the RIP Act takes precedence. The only crumb of comfort for employees can be found in the regulations, which a spokesman said employees can use to pursue a civil action against an employer who has not told its staff that emails "may or will be intercepted". A spokesman for the civil rights group Liberty said: "Our view is that employers should be obliged to justify each occasion when they monitor an employee's emails or telephone calls and show why it was necessary and proportionate in that case. They should also provide facilities for employees to phone and even send emails from their workplace secure in the knowledge that their calls or emails won't be intercepted." A spokeswoman for the TUC also criticised the current confusion."At the moment the regulations encourage employers to think blanket monitoring of all emails is allowed without thinking how that will affect the workforce." One of the most worrying recent examples is that of eight sales staff at the telecoms company Cable & Wireless who were suspended after a complaint about a smutty email. Six of them were sacked last week and two others are understood to have resigned. All eight had worked for the company for less than a year and so will be prevented from appealing to an industrial tribunal. One of the six sacked workers said the first time he saw the company policy on emails was in a letter after he was suspended. Even then he felt safe after he read that staff might only be dismissed for downloading pornography. He said he deleted the email. Yet this failed to appease the company and it trawled through his in-box. "They went through my entire system and found an email with the word 'fuck' in it, which they said was offensive," the employee said. Cable & Wireless said the emails were clearly in breach of its policy, but admitted the guidelines were not published on the internal computer noticeboard. When the Guardian asked for a copy of the policy a spokeswoman said it was private and confidential. If the Cable & Wireless staff had been at the company for more than a year they might have claimed that the policy was unclear or that Cable & Wireless had failed to communicate it to staff. They could also claim the company had been draconian if other staff on the email circulation list had been let off, as one of the victims alleges. It looks more and more as though the UK is set to follow the American model where more than 40% of companies regularly examine their staff's email. One multinational company in Germany - where the rules governing spying on employees personal emails are much stricter - is understood to have already taken advantage of the more relaxed laws in the UK by sending all the emails sent and received by staff from its offices in Germany to London where they are monitored. It would seem likely that there will be many more court cases before employees know for sure just what words are acceptable for use in private emails and how much time they can spend sending private messages and surfing the internet. But one thing is for sure: that ill thought out missive questioning the parentage of the boss could well land more employees in hot water.

webTitle: Mob burns young killers to death

fields.headline: Mob burns young killers to death
fields.trailText: Five teenagers accused of murder have been burned to death by a mob of 500 people in a Guatemalan village. The incident comes as the government is struggling to rebuild its international image following the stoning to death of a Japanese tourist and a tour driver by a mob in another village earlier this year.
fields.body:
Five teenagers accused of murder have been burned to death by a mob of 500 people in a Guatemalan village. The incident comes as the government is struggling to rebuild its international image following the stoning to death of a Japanese tourist and a tour driver by a mob in another village earlier this year.

The five youths, aged 16 to 18, had come to Las Conchas, in the mountainous central Guatemala region, 200 miles to the north-east of the capital, apparently planning to rob. On Tuesday, according to the police, they ambushed a local man and his eight-year-old son, shot the man dead and stole about £35 from him before fleeing.

Villagers discovered them hiding in a nearby forest. They disarmed them of two pistols and replica guns and carried out an impromptu trial, in which the teenagers blamed each other for the killing.

The crowd, by now around 500-strong, including men, women and children, decided all five were guilty. They were doused in petrol and set alight, one by one. Their charred remains are in the local morgue.

The deaths took the total of people killed by village lynchings this year to 28. This is a drop from the 48 last year but still high enough to provoke the government into new attempts to halt public killings, which it says damage the country's international image.

At the heart of the killings is a belief by many Indian villagers that the government and police do little to protect them and they have to enforce their own rough justice. During the civil war, the army killed tens of thousands of villagers who were believed to be sympathetic to leftwing guerillas, and there has since been deep suspicion of the police and military.

"If they are going to kill my husband, they should be killed," Elena Cajon Yat, widow of the man murdered by the five youths, told the Associated Press news agency. "If not, someone else will be killed tomorrow by that same group."

Earlier this year, in the village of Dos Santos, a Japanese tourist and a tour driver were stoned to death after a rumour spread that they were satanists who were planning to steal the village's children for ritual sacrifice.

The government has sought to reassure would-be tourists that such incidents are isolated.

But the belief that foreigners may sometimes be planning to steal children has a strong hold in some remote villages, and tourists are warned not to touch children or to take their photographs without permission.

Lynchings for murders, rapes and even thefts are not just a problem of remote villages, however. Concern about the breakdown of law and order in the capital, Guatemala City, led earlier in the year to the army being drafted in to assist the police.

fields.headline: Failure unthinkable for EU leaders
fields.standfirst:
As national interests conflict with cooperation, the battle over power is likely to end in a fudge

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and his fellow European Union leaders gather in Nice next week for a summit whose outcome is vital for the future of Europe. Looking out over palm-fringed promenades, they will spend three, perhaps four difficult days and probably nights putting the finishing touches to a new treaty which will shape the union for decades to come. No dramatic changes are planned, certainly nothing to compare with the single currency, agreed at Maastricht in 1991.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and his fellow European Union leaders gather in Nice next week for a summit whose outcome is vital for the future of Europe. Looking out over palm-fringed promenades, they will spend three, perhaps four difficult days and probably nights putting the finishing touches to a new treaty which will shape the union for decades to come. No dramatic changes are planned, certainly nothing to compare with the single currency, agreed at Maastricht in 1991.

But several long-overdue reforms have to be agreed to prevent creaking institutional and decision-making machinery, first created for the six founding members in 1957, from seizing up when the union expands: 13 countries, from Poland to Turkey and Malta to Estonia, are queueing up to join the 15 states. Without these changes, enlargement cannot proceed.

Most of the issues are highly technical. But shorn of detail they are about raw power: who decides, and how. Big players such as French president Jacques Chirac and Germany's Gerhard Schröder have to take on board the worries of smaller ones such as Denmark, Portugal and Finland, resentful at being bullied.

Two or three countries are happy to pool sovereignty and integrate further. But each is fighting its national corner too. Each leader has impassable red lines. The outcome is likely to be a carefully-packaged fudge. Failure is unthinkable.

Vote re-weighting

The big four - Germany, Britain, France, and Italy - agree on the need to re-weight votes in the council of ministers - where the 15 governments cooperate - to avoid being outvoted by smaller states when the doors open to admit the enlargement candidates. Currently 62 votes out of a total of 87 are required to block a proposal. Chancellor Schröder wants more votes to reflect the fact that with a post-reunification population of 82m Germany has 20m more people than the other big three. All now have 10 votes. Luxembourg, population 400,000, has two. Spain, a famously tough negotiator, wants more to reflect its medium size. The Netherlands with 15.8m people wants more than Belgium, Portugal and Greece (each 10m). Most states support a double majority voting system where decisions would require both a majority of weighted votes and a majority of the EU's population. Sweden wants to use the square root of a country's population: this would give Germany nine votes, France seven.

"Our formula has the advantage of being easy to understand by public opinion and practical to use in an enlarged Europe," said prime minister Goran Persson. "It is transparent, logical and loyal. Maybe that is why it does not please everybody."

Compromise could lie in a proposal to treble each country's existing votes, then readjust them in favour of Germany, Spain and the Netherlands. That way, every leader could claim to have increased his country's vote. But the 14, and most importantly, France, would have to accept Germany has most votes. The only alternative is for Germany to accept parity with France in return for a favourable share out of seats in the European parliament. The toughest item on the agenda.

Commission size

Difficult talks are also expected over the size of the 20-strong European Commission, the "supranational" executive of the EU, which initiates legislation and applies community rules.

The four big boys, plus Spain, have two commissioners each (Neil Kinnock and Chris Patten are Britain's); the others one each. The bigs say they will give up their second commissioner in return for a greater weight in decision-making, or surrender the right altogether in favour of a system of egalitarian rotation. But the smalls, backed by the enlargement candidates, insist on retaining their one commissioner - vital, they argue, to maintain a link between Brussels and their publics at home. National prestige is a key element of this argument.

The likely solution is the so-called "deferred ceiling" under which every member state will still have one commissioner for now, and an internal hierarchy of de facto deputy commissioners created to keep the place working. The total number would then be capped at a later date. Probably much later.

Enhanced cooperation

Euro-jargon for a two-speed Europe in which more integrationist-minded countries can forge ahead without being held back by laggards. France, Italy and Germany are all keen on this, but most small countries are unhappy, fearing domination by bigs. Britain has now reluctantly accepted that this can happen, but fought hard to impose tough conditions on what is allowed under this treaty provision. Blair's key concern is to prevent the informal Euro-group of the 12 members of euroland from acquiring a formal status and starting to make economic policy. "Two speeds, but not two tiers," Britain now says. Formalises existing reality of different groups such as Schengen for border controls and immigration (all except Britain and Ireland). The key question is how flexibility will be applied in sensitive areas such as foreign policy.

QMV

Qualified majority voting (QMV) is Tony Blair's biggest problem. But no less than 12 member states object to French proposals for moving from unanimity to majority voting, already used for 80% of community business. The commission, and governments such as Belgium and Italy, say majority voting should be the norm, to make the working of the union, and especially the single market, more efficient. France has tabled about 50 treaty articles for moving to QMV. About one third to a half could be agreed. Mr Blair refuses to budge on indirect taxation and social security, fearing a slippery slope towards more integration. Britain's position is distorted because it already has opt-outs on highly sensitive matters such as immigration and asylum, where France and Germany oppose surrendering their vetoes. President Chirac also insists on keeping his veto to protect French cinema from the steamroller of global competition, preventing majority voting in the vital field of trade in services. "Our trade partners... rub their hands with glee because they can count on 15 possible vetoes," said Romano Prodi, president of the commission. Messiest item.

Charter of fundamental rights

The summiteers will "solemnly proclaim" the EU's new charter of fundamental rights. But after a bitterly-fought battle spearheaded by Britain, it will not become part of the new treaty. The charter's 53 articles are designed to make existing rights more visible to ordinary EU citizens and to give a moral dimension to a body which has never given prominence to human rights. Some experts believe the charter could eventually affect the jurisprudence of the European Court of Justice, which interprets and enforces EU law.

British opposition watered down or removed references to the right to strike and protection against unjustified dismissal. The document itself states explicitly: "This charter does not establish any new power or task for the community or the union, or modify powers and tasks defined by the treaties." Europhiles had seen the document as the basis for an embryonic EU constitution. Enthusiasts such as France, Germany and Italy will demand it be written into a future treaty.

Defence

Not part of the treaty, but a high prestige item, especially for the French presidency. Nice will review progress made on developing EU defence capabilities.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: From the top

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: While most of the world's attention was focused on the courtrooms of Florida, a case in Atlanta, Georgia produced a settlement with massive implications for management. Coca-Cola paid almost $200m to settle a racial discrimination case taken out by four African-American employees. Part of the criticism of Coca-Cola was that the company's board had not received an equal opportunity report for almost 10 years.
fields.body:
While most of the world's attention was focused on the courtrooms of Florida, a case in Atlanta, Georgia produced a settlement with massive implications for management. Coca-Cola paid almost $200m to settle a racial discrimination case taken out by four African-American employees. Part of the criticism of Coca-Cola was that the company's board had not received an equal opportunity report for almost 10 years.

The re-launch of the Commission for Racial Equality's Leadership Challenge last week showed that, for leaders of many UK organisations, the very idea of an equal opportunity report would be a novelty. The re-launch vividly illustrated the problem. Around 80% of managers signing up to the challenge fitted the white male stereotype. Little progress has been made in convincing those at the top that they must change if they expect their organisations to change.

Some of the worst exam ples occur in the public sector. Organisational charts and photographs of the senior teams at the main government departments of state show serried ranks of white males.

Lack of change is rooted in three deeper problems. The first is personal. Many managers think that because they are not personally prejudiced, the actions of the organisation they lead cannot be prejudiced. In practice, virtual colour bars can grow up in companies led by seemingly liberal people. Management and information systems are needed to convert aspiration to action.

The second problem in many enterprises is the failure to create these processes for managing diversity. Equal employment opportunity reporting is rare in Britain. This is partly because the tools do not exist. The government's Qualifications and Curriculum Authority recently refused even to consider management standards in this area.

The real difficulty probably lies at a third, even deeper level. Many organisations fail to develop a strategic and integrated approach to their corporate social and environmental policies. Action against discrimination is not an optional add-on to be confined to some corporate ghetto. Policies in this area have implications for the organisation's work in communities, employee policies, approaches to learning, relations with its different stake holders, even its position in the market.

Liverpool learned this lesson years ago. Members of minority communities in Liverpool did not shop in the city centre because no people of colour were employed in the stores there. Racism in the workplace had a direct impact on sales.

In her book, No Logo, Naomi Klein says growing anti-corporate attitudes are rooted in the failure of business to link brands, global markets and increasing affluence to the reality of sweatshop labour, environmental destruction and deteriorating living conditions.

An integrated approach to social and environmental policy accepts that workplace practices are inseparable from community policies, which are in turn linked to environmental policies. This requires a new mind-set.

When the CEO has a passion for the environment this becomes the top priority. Change the top person and priorities shift. This approach is hard to sustain as those organisations with a strategic approach reap increased benefits while the rest face growing costs.

The costs of failure are high. Coca-Cola's support for sport and the arts, its work in its local community and its corporate reputation have been severely undermined by its failure to end discrimination.

 Professor Tom Cannon is chief executive of RespectLondon.

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Mike Heap, Chief executive, Entertainment Rights
fields.trailText: Mike Heap Chief executive, Entertainment Rights
fields.body:
What was your first career aspiration?

To be a professional footballer.

What has been your best moment in management?

There has been no one single moment, but the best have been developing bright people into top managers.

And your greatest mistake?

Not developing enough bright people.

How would you describe your management style?

Questioning, open and focused.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

It's a waste of time dwelling on things that one would like to have done.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

Not listening, but pretending to understand.

Does your organisation have a glass ceiling?

The managing director of our sales, distribution and co- production division is Jane Smith. With good management, she'll have my job.

What management wisdom is most over-rated?

It will work itself out.

What is the biggest challenge facing your industry?

The harnessing of the digital explosion into a profit centre that satisfies both the consumer and the creator.

What single lesson would you pass on to budding managers?

Make the best of every day. You'll never see it again. Work hard, work smart.

Which management guru do you believe in?

God. He laid down some basic but brilliant commandments for success.

Who is your management hero?

Alex Ferguson of Manchester United.

Who is your favourite politician?

Favourite and politician - the two are not compatible, although I think Churchill was the right man at the right time.

If you could change one aspect of British business, what would it be?

Negative attitude.

What phrase or saying do you most overuse?

Persistence pays, and it does.

Apart from quality time with your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

Helping others to achieve more than they thought possible.

What annoys you most?

The "it can't be done" syndrome.

How do you relax?

Long walks with Kizzie, my Wheaton terrier, and dinner with my family.

What is your favourite city?

New York.

Do you have a favourite website?

Basil Brush, which is still in development.

What is your greatest regret?

I have no regrets as far as business is concerned. Personally, I regret that my father didn't live to see my wife and children.

What is your biggest fear?

Wasting time. Not making the best of each day.

What would you really like to have been?

No more than what I am - happy.

What single lesson would you pass on to budding managers? Make the best of every day. You'll never see it again. Work hard, work smart. Which management guru do you believe in? God. He laid down some basic but brilliant commandments for success. Who is your management hero? Alex Ferguson of Manchester United. Who is your favourite politician? Favourite and politician - the two are not compatible, although I think Churchill was the right man at the right time. If you could change one aspect of British business, what would it be? Negative attitude. What phrase or saying do you most overuse? Persistence pays, and it does. Apart from quality time with your family, what else makes you happiest in life? Helping others to achieve more than they thought possible. What annoys you most? The "it can't be done" syndrome. How do you relax? Long walks with Kizzie, my Wheaton terrier, and dinner with my family. What is your favourite city? New York. Do you have a favourite website? Basil Brush, which is still in development. What is your greatest regret? I have no regrets as far as business is concerned. Personally, I regret that my father didn't live to see my wife and children. What is your biggest fear? Wasting time. Not making the best of each day. What would you really like to have been? No more than what I am - happy.

webTitle: Norway's crown prince defies critics to marry his unconventional girlfriend

fields.headline: Norway's crown prince defies critics to marry his unconventional girlfriend
fields.standfirst: A right royal rumpus
fields.trailText: A right royal rumpus
fields.body:
Queen Victoria's great-great-great grandson, Crown Prince Haakon of Norway, yesterday announced his engagement to his live-in girlfriend - a single mother whose former lover had multiple convictions for violence, drink-driving and possession of cocaine.

Prince Haakon, a trainee diplomat at the Norwegian foreign ministry, said he had proposed to Mette-Marit Tjessem Hoiby, a student known as "the Cinderella from Kristiansand", yesterday morning, that she had accepted his diamond ring - the one used by his father and grandfather - and that the wedding was planned for August 25 next year.

"It was not an easy choice," Ms Tjessem Hoiby said of her decision to become Norway's best-known young wife. "But I look forward to marrying Haakon and I look forward to entering that role. I just hope people will accept me for the person I am."

The crown prince had already become the first European royal to live with a partner without first marrying. He moved into an Oslo flat with Ms Tjessem Hoiby, 27, last September, prompting a barrage of criticism from conservatives and churchmen.

Haakon admitted he had thought of giving up his claim to the throne as a result of the sniping. "It would have been strange if the thought hadn't entered my mind," he said. "But I've never seriously considered it. We believe in the monarchy."

The prince's critics, mainly strict Protestants, say he should set a moral example to his 4.5m subjects, but opinion polls showed that most Norwegians are unflustered at the prospect of a future queen who has admitted hanging out at ecstasy- and cocaine-fuelled house parties in the 1990s.

Ms Tjessem Hoiby has since refused to talk further about her partying past, and a CV issued by the royal palace noted only anodyne details such as the would-be queen's past job as a strawberry picker and her year at a high school in Wangaratta, Australia.

The bright and articulate prince, who has often declared that nothing in his girlfriend's background would stand in the way of marriage, is a hugely popular representative of a royal family that is markedly less stuffy than many others - and is allowed a lot more privacy.

Haakon's father, King Harald, has supported his son's choice, perhaps because he himself had to battle for almost a decade to persuade his father, King Olav, to allow him to marry a commoner, his childhood sweetheart Sonja Haraldsen, who is now Queen.

But many Norwegians fear Ms Tjessem Hoiby's son, Marius, three, has drawn the short straw. The constitution allows only children born within royal wedlock to accede to the throne, and the boy is likely to grow up in the shadow of the monarchy, with princes and princesses fas half-sisters and -brothers.

webTitle: Swiss sent Gypsies back to Nazi killers

fields.headline: Swiss sent Gypsies back to Nazi killers
fields.standfirst: Historians expose decades of discrimination whose victims included legendary jazz guitarist Django Reinhardt
fields.trailText: Historians expose decades of discrimination whose victims included legendary jazz guitarist Django Reinhardt
fields.body:
The legendary jazz guitarist, Django Reinhardt, was among an unknown number of Gypsies who were systematically turned back from Switzerland during the second world war, even though the authorities knew they faced extermination in Nazi Germany, according to an independent commission of historians.

The study, part of officially-backed investigations into Swiss wartime history, says the authorities failed to lift a decades-old policy of discrimination against Gypsies. It says they were aware in 1942 that Gypsies were being sent to Nazi death camps. For years, Swiss border guards had witnessed Gypsies being beaten and shot at before they were expelled by Italian fascists.

Official Swiss restrictions on Gypsies were only lifted fully in 1972.

Reinhardt, who was born to Gypsy parents in Belgium, was 33 and already the star of swing jazz at the Hot Club in Paris when he was turned away by Swiss border guards near Geneva in 1943. He is said to have survived the war in Paris partly thanks to the help of a German officer taken by his music. He died in 1953.

His fate contrasts with that of another, unrelated, Reinhardt, according to the 102-page study. Anton Reinhardt, a 17 year-old German Gypsy with a Swiss mother, swam the Rhine in 1944 and tried to claim asylum in Switzerland as a conscientious objector. He was expelled and later shot while trying to escape from a Nazi concentration camp.

The international panel, led by a Swiss historian, Jean-François Bergier, was unable to estimate how many travellers had tried to flee to Switzerland and how many had later died. An estimated 100,000 Gypsies were killed by the Nazis.

The Bergier commission found that Swiss border guards did not identify Roma, Sinti or Jenisch as ethnic groups in official records. But it says that, apart from a few exceptions, there was no evidence that Gypsies of foreign origin were granted asylum, while there were plenty of cases to indicate the opposite.

"Switzerland belonged at the beginning of the 20th century to the first countries that restricted the freedom of movement of Gypsies," it says.

The restrictions, first implemented in 1906, were largely followed throughout the continent, and the study raises harsh questions about the treatment of Gypsies in many European countries during the pre-war years. Discrimination was encouraged by Interpol's predecessor, the International Criminal Police Commission, set up in 1923, which treated Gypsies as criminals and a threat to public order. It backed the policy with racist theories advanced by its German and Austrian creators.

The Swiss government yesterday expressed "deep empathy" with the Roma, Jenisch, and Sinti communities, and the "severe discrimination" they faced. Compensation payments have been made to Gypsy communities in eastern Europe, part of a wider second world war restitution effort. A foundation to support travellers was set up three years ago after it was revealed that hundreds of Gypsy children had been snatched from their families and adopted in Switzerland from 1926 to 1972.

The Bergier commission has also criticised the Swiss authorities for shutting out Jewish refugees in 1942 and 1943. Switzerland admitted 27,000 Jewish refugees during the Nazi era, but turned back a similar number.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: The Hanover Foundation

fields.headline: Give them skills and they can do the jobs
fields.standfirst: Serena Standing describes the work of the Hanover Foundation in helping young people
fields.trailText: Serena Standing describes the work of the Hanover Foundation in helping young people.
fields.body:
"Our order book is full, but I am short of 10 people to do fairly simple, but responsible and well-paid jobs. We train on the job, of course, but new people need basic skills which they just don't seem to have. I just can't find the people."

Alan Watkins' dilemma is a typical one. Director of a specialised Midlands-based manufacturer, he tells us that his problem can be multiplied dozens of times over, just in the industrial estate where his business is to be found.

Across Britain, the skills gap yawns like a chasm between success and failure as a manufacturing nation, a nation with its eye on an IT future, or a world centre of excellence in the financial and banking sectors. "Unless something changes," Watkins says, "we will start to lose our competitive edge in the export market, and what is even worse, will start to see our imports growing at a furious rate to satisfy demand for products and services which we just can't supply."

But what are the missing skills. Why are they missing in so many young people in particular? The gaps are at their widest in the most basic of skills, with too many job candidates unable to do simple mathematics, unable to spell or write and unable to communicate. Above that level, far too few have acquired any technical skills involving the use of machinery, IT software, or even the most basic sales and marketing knowledge.

It isn't a question of a system failure, or the lack of availability of teachers and courses. The problem is that too many young school-leavers are seemingly content to stop learning the moment they walk away from the classrooms for the last time. At that point, their lack of learned skills often means they are not even good enough to get onto the bottom rung of the ladder.

The key component in the solution to this problem is motivation. It is demonstrably wrong to blame the skills gap on lack of intelligence or innate ability - teachers everywhere will confirm that most of their students are bright enough to take on whatever is thrown at them.

What too many of them do not have, is the one thing they need most urgently - life skills, the ability to self-grow their own personal development, and a world view which is upbeat and forward looking.

This is where professional schools coaching comes in, and if the two-year experiment conducted by the Hanover Foundation is anything to go by, it works and works well.

The cornerstone of Foundation coaching philosophy is that the seed for a fulfilling and continually developing life lies within every individual, irrespective of his or her background, life circumstances or intellectual ability.

The challenge is to germinate and nurture that seed - to stimulate individuals to take control of their lives and see a future that suits their ambitions. The crucial requirement is that clients be put into a position where they can learn to think for themselves and be encouraged to set their own goals, identify and repeat success and devise alternative strategies to deal with failure.

Over a period of a year, we offer students confidential one-to-one sessions with a coach in which they can explore their lives - away from the pressure cooker of personal relationships with friends, peer-group members or families.

Our practices are built on 20 years of coaching senior executives and managers in strategy and personal devel opment. Today, employing a coach is an accepted part of business practice. Hanover coaches apply the same techniques and strategies to the next generation. Our coaching is results-orientated and we expect positive outcomes.

How does the Foundation deliver? Our coaching is free to students in state education and concentrates on GCSE level. Latterly, we have trained and paid our coaches and covered supervision and administration costs by raising donations from generous individuals and companies. Now we are offering business partnerships to socially responsible community minded companies which seek to benefit from association with our programme, our schools and our students. It works for them and it works for us.

So, where is the connection between the work of the Foundation and trying to close the skills gap? If we can succeed in helping students into the world of work with a tool-bag of life skills and a "go for it" attitude, then they will go looking for ways to acquire the technical skills that businesses need.

The Foundation is a small operation at the moment, working with 360 students in inner London, but our aim is to offer a service throughout the country over the next five years. I would like to talk to companies who want in on the ground floor and can help us extend our programmes to more comprehensive and other schools.

Please contact me on 0207-262-3732 or by email StandingUK@aol.com.

 Serena Standing is director of the Hanover Foundation - a charity raising career ambitions among school leavers.

webTitle: Become a mamma? You must be kidding

fields.headline: Become a mamma? You must be kidding
fields.trailText: Ambling downtown for an ice cream, walking the dog in the park, window-shopping in the high street, you suddenly notice something about the children of Rome. There aren't any.
fields.body:
Ambling downtown for an ice cream, walking the dog in the park, window-shopping in the high street, you suddenly notice something about the children of Rome. There aren't any.

Famed for being venerable Rome may be, but it comes as a shock to realise that here ageing elegance describes people as well as buildings.

Little faces flicker from passing cars and youngsters occasionally bound into a fast food restaurant but at times it can seem nobody under 13 exists. Go south, to Naples and Sicily, and it's another story, but from Rome upwards couples are no longer having children. A country renowned for its love of large, close families now has the lowest birth rate in the developed world.

At less than 1.2 children per woman, it has become unusual to reproduce. Discount the relatively higher rate among immigrants and the figure is even lower. Within 50 years, according to the government's estimates, Italy's 57m population will have fallen by a third. By the end of the century there may be just 10m Italians.

Empty desks are beginning to appear in what used to be overcrowded schools. A play area near Castel Sant'Angelo has been sealed off, and it is not alone.

A friend, mother of a young daughter, complains that the lack of facilities for children is not an effect but a cause of the trend. "Kids have nowhere to go and then they wonder why couples don't have kids."

Policy-makers, commentators and the Pope are agonising over the causes of the phenomenon.

One candidate is selfishness. Couples busy with work are asking if a messy, expensive, time-consuming addition is really what they want. Aspirational grandparents may pine for the pitter-patter of tiny feet, but to announce a pregnancy is often to invite the concern of friends and relatives. Congratulations, but can you afford it?

Women entering the workforce, poor childcare facilities, marrying too late, all are blamed. The Pope has begged (married) couples: "Make more babies."

For Italy, the implications are huge. The pension system could collapse and firms are crying out for labour.

Lurk in my local chemist, close to the Vatican, and the call seems doomed. A procession of customers order condoms without a trace of embarrassment. The tradition of losing your nerve and asking for razor blades is long gone.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: My big break

fields.headline: The ads ambassador
fields.trailText: When David Kester was first approached about heading up the professional association for the design and advertising industry, it was a bankrupt organisation with just a couple of hundred diehard members, a skeleton staff and a filing cabinet. Mr Kester was just married, just 30 and a new dad.
fields.body:
When David Kester was first approached about heading up the professional association for the design and advertising industry, it was a bankrupt organisation with just a couple of hundred diehard members, a skeleton staff and a filing cabinet. Mr Kester was just married, just 30 and a new dad.

Why should he put his time and effort into a body with the not very catchy title of British Design and Art Direction (D&AD). He thought about the financial risks, looked at the remnants of the staff, talked to people in the industry, thought again - and took the job.

"I said to myself, here is an organisation in tatters, but it has a great brand, a great heritage and an award scheme revered by its industry. I didn't believe the industry would let it go bust."

Now, six years on, Mr Kester rules as chief executive over a successful, inter nationally recognised organisation with a turnover that has trebled in the past five years to £3m and a 2,000-strong membership list. And, yes, he thinks he made the right decision.

Passion and people are the two essential ingredients that Kester attributes to his meteoric rise, rather than years of experience and "relevant" qualifications. He doesn't wish to sound like a beauty contestant, but nevertheless tells you that he has always enjoyed meeting people and hearing about what they do.

The ability to listen and apply creative ideas with a unique brand of chutzpah has clearly got him where he is today.

Armed with a degree in English and Drama, he took his first "proper" job at 28 after what he jokingly calls his "wilderness years" in fringe theatre and further education. Mr Kester will be the first to admit that his organisational, promotional and marketing skills have been very much learned on the job. But the boundless energy he puts into his work is innate. Much of his role within D&AD involves seeking out opportunities for sponsorship.

Today, the organisation has £1m worth of support from 100 different major companies, from British Steel and the Co-operative Bank to Apple Computer and Getty Im ages Worldwide. D&AD holds public lectures and has an extensive education programme to help those starting out in the industry.

It recently introduced Blood Bank, an online facility for sourcing young creative talent. But the organisation is best known for the D&AD Awards, the the Oscars of the industry, known as the Yel low Pencils. This year, out of 18,000 design and advertising entries judged by a team of 200 practitioners, just three pieces of work struck gold, the supreme accolade for the bow-tie brigade.

The son of high achievers - a designer mother and an actor-cum-businessman father - Mr Kester rebelled at school and continued in much the same vein at university, taking home an unremarkable pass degree. After graduating, he dabbled for a time in fringe theatre, designing and directing and running arts projects. One of his many jobs was teaching A-level theatre studies by day in Oxford and running a rain forest festival by night for Friends of the Earth.

His work on the festival got him noticed. Friends of the Earth asked him in for an interview as director of arts and he won the job. His total inexperience prompted his boss to suggest that in order to garner information he should phone all his counterparts in other charities and ask them for opinions and advice. The strategy worked.

One evening, while throwing ideas around, he clicked on to the membership database for a browse. Leaping out of the L section came the name Yasmin Le Bon. "I thought, interesting," says Mr Kester, who contacted her and asked her to help. "She was fantastic and that meeting led to two years of running all sorts of events with her." Yasmin went off to a rain forest and appeared in TV programmes to highlight the issues.

"Duran Duran even recorded one of their tracks for the cause. It was the big break. "What I learned was how to manage people and how to come up with a creative solution to a problem."

Today he describes his D&AD role as that of an ambassador, strategist, analyst and presenter. "I like big ideas and I develop a sense of enthusiasm and passion about them. But once you have come up with them, you have to deliver," he says.

After graduating, he dabbled for a time in fringe theatre, designing and directing and running arts projects. One of his many jobs was teaching A-level theatre studies by day in Oxford and running a rain forest festival by night for Friends of the Earth. His work on the festival got him noticed. Friends of the Earth asked him in for an interview as director of arts and he won the job. His total inexperience prompted his boss to suggest that in order to garner information he should phone all his counterparts in other charities and ask them for opinions and advice. The strategy worked. One evening, while throwing ideas around, he clicked on to the membership database for a browse. Leaping out of the L section came the name Yasmin Le Bon. "I thought, interesting," says Mr Kester, who contacted her and asked her to help. "She was fantastic and that meeting led to two years of running all sorts of events with her." Yasmin went off to a rain forest and appeared in TV programmes to highlight the issues. "Duran Duran even recorded one of their tracks for the cause. It was the big break. "I like big ideas and I develop a sense of enthusiasm and passion about them. But once you have come up with them, you have to deliver," he says.

webTitle: FBI hunts through Los Alamos rubbish dump for US nuclear data

fields.headline: FBI hunts through Los Alamos rubbish dump for US nuclear data
fields.trailText: Clad in white body suits and pink face masks, they hunt through 50-acres-worth of rubbish discarded by the people of New Mexico.
fields.body:
Clad in white body suits and pink face masks, they hunt through 50-acres-worth of rubbish discarded by the people of New Mexico.

But this is no ordinary team of sanitation workers, they are FBI agents. They are rummaging by hand through a snow-covered mountain of waste at the Los Alamos county landfill in the hope of finding up to ten pocket-sized plastic data storage tapes thrown away more than a year ago.

They allegedly contain secrets of the American nuclear weapons programme.

The tapes, believed to be buried in around 5,000 tonnes of landfill, are a vital part of the three-year investigation into allegations that the Taiwanese-born American nuclear physicist, Wen Ho Lee, was spying for the Chinese.

Mr Lee, who will be 61 this month, was suspended from his job at the laboratory in 1998 and accused of passing secrets about the W-88 warhead to China.

He has always protested his innocence. In September prosecutors dropped 58 of the 59 charges against him in exchange for his cooperation. He pleaded guilty to one charge of mishandling classified information.

After initially denying that he knew anything about the whereabouts of missing tapes containing ignition test data and design information on US nuclear weapons, Mr Lee is understood have told the FBI several weeks ago that he threw the tapes into a public rubbish bin.

A source familiar with the case, said on Wednesday that Mr Lee claimed he had disposed of the tapes in a large metal trash bin inside the laboratory's fence in January 1999.

An FBI spokesman said teams could be working on the site for several weeks until the tapes are found. The manufacturers of the tapes, IBM, say that only a strong magnetic force or a fire is likely to have destroyed the data.

Mr Lee became a rallying point for Asian-American protests during a nine-month stint in solitary confinement before his release in September. Since then, Mr Lee has sold his story to television and has begun writing a book about his experiences.

fields.headline: Collecting: it's a tribal thing
fields.standfirst: No longer just the province of anthropologists, artists from regions such as West Africa are attracting serious attention, and prices, says Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: No longer just the province of anthropologists, artists from regions such as West Africa are attracting serious attention, and prices, says Stewart Dalby.
fields.body:
A rare North American Indian Pictographic Treaty, 1873-1877, is one of the highlights of Phillips' sale of antiquities and tribal art on Monday.

Executed in pencil on paper, rather than the more usual bark, the first page depicts two men in European dress offering gifts. The opposite page itemises gifts offered to the Cree Indian chief in the North West Territory of Canada.

The piece is estimated to fetch between £3,000 and £5,000.

At Bonhams & Brooks' tribal art sale last Thursday, the most expensive item was a Baule male, a woodcarving from the Ivory Coast, which had once been in the Patricia Whithoss collection. This was estimated at £20,000 to £25,000 but it didn't get away.

A large Kuba ancestor post, from the Democratic Republic of the Congo, was another highlight of the sale. It originally formed part of the Prince Saddrudin Aga Khan Collection, which was sold at Sotheby's New York in 1999 and was estimated at £4,000 to £6,000. It sold for £4,600. The large pillar is carved in two sections with incised geometric decoration around the outside and a double Janus head at the top.

The Bonhams sale also included a finely carved Tsonga headrest, estimated at £1,000 to £1,500. In fact it sold for £10,350. From Zimbabwe, this 19th-century piece was used by men to keep their oiled hair out of the dust when sleeping. Given heirloom status, these were carried around the neck and were sometimes used in burials.

Men with more than one wife would also use them to indicate whose bed they would share that night by placing it at the opening of their intended's hut.

With tribal art there is an awful lot to choose from. There are thousands of tribes, most with very long histories. While two-dimensional pieces with their heavy symbolism are not to everyone's tastes, there are many other objects to collect - sculptures, carvings, blankets, jewellery, pottery, basketwork and, not least, weaponry.

Ten years ago, tribal art collecting was very much a minority interest, only of value to anthropologists, museum curators, ethnographers and eccentric travellers. At their modestly priced levels, tribal art was subject to fads. Australian bark paintings were once much sought after, but are less so now.

A decade ago, Aboriginal weaponry, particularly boomerangs, sold for a few pounds. Now they fetch anything from £50 to £150. South African tribal art, particularly Zulu weapons, have also become fashionable and can sell for hundreds of pounds.

Anthropologists and curators have been joined by serious collectors, particularly from the US and Europe, as well as by interior designers. Siobhan Quin, the specialist at Phillips, says: "The sales are always packed and there are usually a number of young people, photographers and designers."

As the prices indicate, the most sought after items are usually from West Africa. Ms Quin continues: "There are Americans with money and they are very interested in their past. Anything that is genuinely anthropological or functional can fetch thousands, like the Pictographic Treat Record."

Interest is not confined to North American artefacts. A highlight of a Bonhams sale three years ago was a rare Alaskan Inuit mask painted in pale green, with red eye and lip outlines. It fetched more than £12,000.

West African tribal art also attracts historians as collectors. According to Ms Quin, Britons are not great ones for chasing artefacts from their former colonies, but the opposite is true of the Belgians and French.

Philip Keith, the specialist at Bonhams & Brooks, feels there is great artistic merit in West African art. He says: "West African pieces are characterised by a high level of workmanship. They are the most traditional form of travelling art." He points out that modern artists such as Picasso, Braque and Modigliani have been influenced by African art. Good pieces from the Fang or Yoruba tribes can make tens of thousands of pounds.

According to Mr Keith, for the more expensive pieces people like to be sure of the provenance since, like antiquities, the market is inflated with fakes. "People like to know who owned the pieces, which collections or museums they were in."

He also says the market is polarising. "Like most areas of antiques, the increasingly rare and fine pieces are fetching ever better prices, while at the bottom end prices are drifting."

For further information:

Bonhams & Brooks 020 7393 3900, Bonhams;
Phillips 020 7629 6602, Phillips

webTitle: Italy's corrupt elite are reborn as victims in rewriting of 90s scandal

fields.headline: Italy's corrupt elite are reborn as victims in rewriting of 90s scandal
fields.standfirst: Tangentopoli:  A tale of bribes, ruination, failed court cases and redemption
fields.trailText: Tangentopoli:  A tale of bribes, ruination, failed court cases and redemption
fields.body:
As dusk seeps over Milan, Sergio Cusani checks his watch and paces to the window. Illuminated towers of concrete, steel and glass dissolve into blackness as workers stream from offices into bars, restaurants and theatres.

Cusani is in his fifth-floor apartment, surrounded by paintings, mahogany furniture and books. The cat is teasing the puppy, dinner is being prepared, and the ex-financier is not planning to go anywhere. By night he is a prisoner, the last captive of Tangentopoli.

To be outside his door between 9pm and 7am is to book a ticket back to his cell in San Vittore prison, his home for five and a half years. The curfew will end in March, when his debt to society will officially have been paid.

For nine months he has been allowed out only by day. He tends to avoid the banks, party offices and city hall, but people recognise him just the same.

Cusani was the public face of a corruption scandal that swept away Italy's ruling class in the early 90s. His televised trial attracted huge audiences. Systematic bribes and kickbacks were revealed to a fascinated, horrified electorate.

Most shocking of all was that it happened not in the sunbaked, mafia-ridden south but in the acme of northern thrift and innovation: Milan. The capital of Lombardy was renamed Tangentopoli, or Bribesville. But in reality the entire country was infected.

Cusani's sentencing marked a watershed. An establishment entrenched for half a century collapsed. Ministers were arrested, premiers fled, bankers committed suicide. Jails filled up as prosecutors swooped. It was an earthquake. The radical changes which followed amounted to a second Italian republic built on the rubble of the first.

Turning his back on the rush-hour traffic, Cusani, 52, returns to his couch, overlooked by a painting of the Death of Adonis. "Yes, I admit my share of responsibility. There was a bacterium. It was not a good time. But I am out now, I am rebuilding a life." He fell in love with his lawyer, married her and they have a young son.

Voluntary work, including setting up a non-profit-making bank, takes up much of his time. Money is not a problem as he comes from a wealthy family.

Another project is penal reform. Cusani has urged the government to relieve overcrowding and despair in jails by granting an amnesty, as the Vatican has suggested.

Does he believe in the second republic? He stares. "The second republic does not exist. We are all tired of this phenomenon. It represented only a hope of change."

These days even the hope is ebbing. Italy's brave new world has not turned out as expected. Everything has changed but only, say some, so that things could remain the same.

Next month the prime minister, Giuliano Amato, and the head of the European commission, Romano Prodi, will be called to the witness stand to testify in a bribery case against the opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi.

It is probably the last gasp of the at tack on Tangentopoli, because this case, like all the others against Mr Berlusconi, will almost certainly fail. He is surging ahead in the polls and is expected to romp back to power in elections next spring.

He is sweeping along on a tide of revisionism. A parliamentary commission is re-evaluating Tangentopoli. Once-reviled public figures are being rehabilitated on chat shows.

Corruption is creeping back, but now it is history on trial. Italians are being invited to take a closer look at the prosecutors. Were they really heroes, or were they leftwing hatchet men? The time is coming when it will be their turn to be chopped down, says Mr Berlusconi.

What started in March 1992 as an investigation into a cleaning contractor's bribe to a Socialist party official, Mario Chiesa, snowballed into an exposé of a nation-wide system of illegal party funding so brazen Machiavelli would have blushed.

Codenamed mani pulite (clean hands), it implicated the dominant Christian Democratic-Socialist axis. Businesses seeking public contracts covertly funded election and management costs. Around $1.5bn changed hands.

The financier Raul Gardini shot himself. Giulio Andreotti, seven times prime minister, was charged with mafia collaboration and denied his dream of becoming president. Bettino Craxi, another ex-prime minister, was surrounded by a mob and pelted with coins. He was sentenced to nine and a half years and fled to Tunisia, where he died last January, aged 65.

Today the Socialists and Christian Democrats are destroyed. The systemic corruption they pioneered is gone. The relatively untainted centre-left is in power.

Yet as the smoke of battle has lifted, Tangentopoli has been shown to be no triumph. Cusani is the last of only a few prisoners. Prosecutors requested 3,165 trials. Judges granted around a third, resulting in 582 convictions. But appeals, deals and the expiry of the statute of limitations whittled the number in jail down to less than 10.

Gerardo D'Ambrosio, Milan's chief prosecutor, told Corriere della Sera that Tangentopoli never finished. "All the signs are of an increase in corruption. Experience has created antibodies: today the corrupt know how to cover their tracks. Inquiries are ever more difficult, while reforms continue to lengthen the time of trials. Now, for certain crimes, one can think of having enough power for impunity."

In September Massimo Guarischi, the chairman of Lombardy's regional assembly budget committee, and eight businessmen were charged with rigging public contracts. Mr Guarischi was with Craxi's Socialists before starting a television career with Mr Berlusconi's Milan-based media empire.

According to the commentator Angelo Panebianco, politicians are reflecting a society-wide negation of the common good. The latest corruption perceptions index, published by the anti-graft group Transparency International, ranked Italy 39th out of the 60 countries surveyed - firmly in the zone of developing countries.

"Companies still pay bribes but it might be in a less direct way. There is a lot of political lobbying, a lot of grey areas," said Fabio Poletti, a journalist with La Stampa. "But in the media there is a sense of boredom, that it's the same story and we've heard it all before. People are sick of it. They are no longer taking to the streets to support prosecutors."

Inside Milan's cavernous courthouse the ramshackle lifts still wheeze with files of pending prosecutions but, according to Gherardo Colombo, a deputy prosecutor, the will to fight is waning. "I sense less enthusiasm. People want to bury these cases. I think these things go in cycles, there has to be a lull before things explode again."

The legacy of Tangentopoli appeared to crackle in October when the government said its leader in the coming general election would be the Rome mayor, Francesco Rutelli, rather than the prime minister, Mr Amato, who is tarnished by association with Craxi. In reality, the problem is his lack of charisma.

After almost nine years of crime and punishment, redemption is in. Claudio Martelli, a disgraced former justice minister, was elected to the European parliament and cheered when he triumphed in a television spoof of the Survivor show.

Mr Andreotti has been cleared in two trials and is now a chat show regular with a dry wit. Stefania and Bobo Craxi are gathering support to name a giant fountain in front of Milan's Castello Sforzesco after their father.

In the town of Aulla, a 3.8-metre obelisk, with wings symbolising freedom, has been raised to "commemorate those imprisoned, impoverished, scorned, insulted" by the Tangentopoli affair.

A parliamentary commission to investigate party funding came close to becoming an inquiry into prosecutors' methods, and may yet do so.

Leading the charge is Mr Berlusconi. The 64-year-old billionaire wants payback. In 1994 he was prime minister, presiding over a law enforcement summit, when he was charged with bribery. His government collapsed and he has spent six years fighting - and gradually winning - myriad court battles, often on technicalities. Only minor charges are outstanding.

His mantra, echoed by his media empire and political allies, is that he was the victim of a plot by prosecutors acting as the left's "armed wing". Privately, some foes concede that a minority of cases were politically motivated.

The strategy of a calculated assault on judicial legitimacy appears to be succeeding. Polls suggest Mr Berlusconi will hammer the government.

Hence the sudden sympathy of supposedly independent judges, said commentator Giorgio Bocca, "as always happens in the Belpaese when the winds change".

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Risk and return

fields.headline: Health is sound, but T-folk suffer
fields.standfirst: Investors, reeling under the slump in technology shares, now face more difficulties brought by a slowing UK economy, says Robin Stoddart
fields.trailText: Investors, reeling under the slump in technology shares, now face more difficulties brought by a slowing UK economy, says Robin Stoddart.
fields.body:
Few big winners remain in the stock market lists after the savage shakeout in technology issues due to the spate of profit warnings on both sides of the Atlantic.

Economic slowdown seems to be a fact of life in recent months in most developed countries, apart from those with a high minerals content. It can hardly come as a surprise in the UK, in the wake of the disasters afflicting so many important areas. The remaining strong suits need to remain healthy if predictions of steady overall growth are to remain credible.

Health, in the shape of the top pharmaceutical companies, stands out as the soundest. Ulcers and depression are being fought with considerable success and, although large-scale breakthroughs in main diseases remain apparently just round the corner, clinical treatment is usually achieving far more cures than only a few years ago.

The optimism in this area is reflected in the high-level stability of AstraZeneca, Glaxo Wellcome and impending new partner SmithKline Beecham. Celltech and Shire have moved up close to the premier league of profit earners with the help of acquisitions, including all-important US links.

Another bastion of wealth is house prices and the financing activity that goes with it. Housebuilders have been one of the best investments to have held this year. Their recent strength owes something to the fewer numbers that remain listed on the stock market, as well as buoyant results and reports. The gap between market capitalisations and asset valuations became so pronounced that repurchase and return to private status became a highly attractive option.

But on all past experience, high lending in the property sector, along with financial excesses in consumption, stock market dealing and City-led affluence as a whole, ends in tears for the less well-off. Financial engineering continues, though most conglomerates have been dismembered with hardly a whimper on this side of the Channel.

The problems of manufacturing industry have gone on so long, without reversing the rising trend of employment in a rapidly rising population, that cutbacks in textiles and the motor, chemical and mechanical engineering sectors, that were once the locomotives of progress, have become largely of only local concern. In engineering, the worst may even be over as the pound falls back towards a more realistic level where export profits may be earned. At a fraction of their former peaks, shares in specialists with a worldwide reach may be worth buying. Dividend yields are among the best available.

Enterprise is alive and kicking as venture capital providers are showing. For the most part, only a few million pounds, rather than billions, are involved. But 3i, Europe's leading development capital provider, with nearly £10bn invested, gained £1bn in the latest half year to September.

Bookham Technology contributed over £100m and TeleCity, the software business, £300m, including profit realised on their flotations and part of the gain on holdings retained, though that may be threatened by the current weak market. Already the three-year-old policy of investing in new technology issues has been triumphantly vindicated.

Although 3i shares have suffered in the latest setback, so that they are around a fifth below their £18 peak, they are still nearly three times their low point of a year ago.

Other investment trusts specialising in development capital have sometimes held up still better, thanks usually to long-standing stakes in buy-outs. Schroder Ventures, with large stakes in German, Swiss and other continental growth companies and only a few in the UK, after the sale of Tetley Tea, has been a particularly steady holding, consolidating gains earlier this year.

Corporate activity in the former Leica empire has helped the private equity group as a whole. As with 3i and several others, including Candover, the UK buy-out backer, the shares stand at a premium to assets, though recent acquisitions, including Memec, the Oxford-based semiconductors distributor and an Austrian holding designing microcircuits, are valued at cost.

Previously there were large cash holdings, following realisations of the Swiss fashion group Vogele and others. Caution on the part of managers in other investment trusts, including British Empire and some of the funds in the Baillie Gifford group, have now also paid off.
