fields.headline: Cash
fields.standfirst:
In the clinic: Celia Bell
Age: 27
Occupation: Local government officer
fields.trailText:
In the clinic: Celia Bell
Age: 27
Occupation: Local government officer
fields.body:
The facts
Celia Bell has recently moved to Nottingham from Cambridge, where house prices were double those of her new home town. "There a two-bedroom house was £120,000 but here it's around £60,000. It's great and I would really like to take advantage of this," she says.

But even though her cost of living is now lower, the 27-year-old local government arts officer has a problem: she has no savings.

"So, help! I need to save fast and I need some independent financial advice, and although I have a good relationship with my bank, I suspect they may not be the best people to give it. I do not want to be forced to take out an 100% mortgage, although I think my bank would give me one." She banks with HSBC.

"I have just paid off a £6,000 graduate loan and although I earn £23,000, I have no money saved. But I am suddenly at least £200 a month better off and need advice about what best to do with it."

She has a steady employment record - she was in her previous job for four years, and was head of department before leaving for Nottingham - and now works in middle management. "I expect my salary to rise incrementally; in other words, I expect to be earning quite a lot more in a few years but in the arts you never know."

She would be happy to invest in an Isa, but would not like "anything too risky". She is also happy to tie up some of that money for five years: "In fact, in my case I think it's best tied up.

"Oh, and my car is in a state of terminal decline and I need to get a newer one," she adds.

The solution
Paul Fuller

Celia is in a quandary: she has so much she wants to do but so little with which to do it. Although she accepts that she cannot do everything at once and is prepared to wait five years for the house, the car may be needed sooner.

She really needs to sit down and prioritise. If the car is of immediate import, then she needs to put the majority of the £200 into a building society account and may need to top this up with a car loan. I would normally advise a client to get a quote for a loan from their bank and then to try some of the specialist lenders: often if you go to them with an existing quote, they will try to undercut it.

The best account at the moment for short-term savings is the Nationwide Building Society e-savings account which is paying 7% gross. This is a no-notice account which allows instant access, but is only available to those who have a current account with Nationwide.

But if she decides that the house is a higher priority, then it would make sense to invest in a stock market fund via an Individual Savings Account (Isa). I agree that it would be better not to take an 100% mortgage: if you can save just 5% of the asking price you will have access to a far better range of mortgage rate deals.

This type of investment allows your money to grow in a completely tax-free environment - it will not be subject to income or capital gains tax. Celia appears to have a "medium" attitude to risk (she does not just want to sit on her money, nor is she willing to invest in,say, an emerging market fund, which could rocket but which could also bomb) and so I would suggest a good, actively managed fund such as Exeter Managed Growth, which is currently the top performing fund in its sector over five and 10 years.

This type of fund should provide good growth over the medium term (five years) but could also provide access to capital in the event of an emergency.

 Paul Fuller is a director of Baronworth Investment Services.

 If you are 18-30, working and want advice on managing your money, email jobs.and.money@theguardian.com

webTitle: Jobs and Money: The Rathbone company

fields.headline: A bright star if you can spot it
fields.standfirst: Tony Levene turns the spotlight on Rathbones, which has a had a social conscience  from the day it was founded back in 1742
fields.trailText: Tony Levene turns the spotlight on Rathbones, which has a had a social conscience from the day it was founded back in 1742.
fields.body:
Some 258 years old and still going - a mistake, surely?

Absolutely not. It was founded in 1742 as a trading company in Liverpool by Wiliam Rathbone. It set up a bank shortly afterwards and still has a banking licence.

Is "trading" a euphemism for slave trading?

No. Rathbones, now a stock market quoted company, has always been socially responsible - its stockbroking arm in Bristol specialises in ethical investments.

When did it get involved in unit trusts?

Either 247 or 257 years after it was founded. The oldest trust dates from 1989 but the Rathbones name was only flagged up last year - previously they had used the Laurence Keen name.

Who has heard of it?

Hardly anybody. It does not advertise to the public or deal with mass market advisers. Only 250 IFAs sell its wares.

What do those in the know think?

It's a bright star within its limits - most investments are in the UK. Over the past year or so, money under management has doubled to £200m.

And what about the legions of IFAs who ignore it?

They reckon it's either too much effort to explain a new name to clients; that you can't be sacked for specifying Fidelity or Jupiter (the IBMs of the unit trust world) or that until Rathbones forks out £100,000 for inclusion in a mailing, they don't want to know.

Thousands of non-believing IFAs will be targeted with chocolate Santas next month.

How should clients react?

With sorrowful anger. They will have missed out on one of the better investment tales.

What does it offer?

A range of six unit trusts - income, income and growth, smaller companies, special situations, capital growth and technology.

Are there plans for more?

Not immediately. But there are distant plans for a global fund sometime next year.

What's the investment style?

Back to basics or old fash ioned, depending on your viewpoint. You can forget investment committees, barbells, active-passive strategies, closet indexing or risk-adjusted parameters.

Instead, they look for an information flow from stockbrokers. The better brokers are rewarded with share orders - the flops get very little for their troubles.

That's the process?

Not quite. The managers themselves then add their value to the broker tips. And once a stock is in a fund, they use two very time tested formulations - "run with the winners and cut the losers" and "sell on the first profits downgrade." They're not guaranteed, but they help avoid Marks & Spencer. They also look for companies with a proven record and precise market position and good earnings history.

Has it worked?

Broadly yes. They weren't involved in the dot.com debacle. All their funds have been in the top division over five, three and one years with the exception of the Technology fund, launched last year, which has been close to average.

Does it sell on past performance?

It recognises the regulators' current concern on statistics plucked from history. But they use it as an entry card with advisers - then they know they have to do some heavy explaining on how they got there.

Which fund do the staff buy?

The top people at Rathbones buy them all, but rate technology their long-term future favourite.

Is size a help?

Yes. With just £200m under management and a deliber ate policy of diversifying widely, Rathbones can take positions in shares without scaring the stock market horses. Growing further or faster could prove to be more difficult.

Are there star managers?

There are just three managers overall - one more will join shortly. Hugh Priestley and Patrick Evershed are well known from previous incarnations and have more than 65 years' experience between them. Carl Stick is much younger - but has a good record with the income fund.

What's the market view?

Long-term belief in equities, thanks to demographics. But nearer to now, Rathbones reckon the market is struggling to find a level, though there could be a year-end rally in the UK stock market.

Is there an internet site?

Click on to rathbones.co.uk There's plenty of information - and a portrait of the original Rathbone in his 18th century finery. You'll be able to buy online next spring.

What's the unique selling proposition?

Wise heads on old shoulders.

fields.headline: Rudeness and grime signal end of the line
fields.standfirst:
Yorkshire commuter Richard Culf concludes his account of his week of rail travel

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: "You'll have to hurry up mate," the conductor shouted as another flustered passenger fought his way through the crowds on the narrow platform. "We're going, we've got the signal to leave." The conductor's shrill voice punctured the air as the man struggled on to the packed train.
fields.body:
"You'll have to hurry up mate," the conductor shouted as another flustered passenger fought his way through the crowds on the narrow platform. "We're going, we've got the signal to leave." The conductor's shrill voice punctured the air as the man struggled on to the packed train.

Near the end of another week of delayed and inadequate services, this all struck me as a touch ironic. I could not decide which was more astonishing: the idea that, for once, there should be some degree of concern about a train's punctual departure or the rude and abrasive manner of the conductor.

While waiting for the early train on Friday morning I paused to reflect on the strange priorities adopted for customer announcements. It is like buses - when you want some information there is none; when you've no need of any, a stream of meaningless announcements flood in.

This morning's announce ment that "the train approaching platform one terminates here" seemed superfluous; given that it is also where the line ends, it was scarcely surprising.

Having come to a halt at the Burley-in-Wharfedale stop we were belatedly told: "We are now arriving at Burley-in-Wharfedale" - an indisputable fact also confirmed by the large sign on the platform. I am told these seemingly obvious statements of fact are now made, following complaints from a number of passengers who missed their stops, having been unable to see through the thick layer of grime on the windows.

While we waited I noticed one of the large penalty fare notices which Northern Spirit have posted at stations along the route. "Haven't we been penalised enough already?" observed the man next to me.

As I braced myself for the last journey before the weekend, a friend inquired, "Do you want a lift home?" Suddenly the appeal of hanging about on a dingy platform for a delayed rusty old train was lost on me and I succumbed to the allure of the automobile - certain in the knowledge that more railway antics await in the coming weeks.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Abbey National makes toy appeal | Royal Scottish Assurance payout | B&B share sale stirs rivals
fields.body:
Abbey National makes toy appeal

Abbey National calculates that unloved toys at the back of cupboards are worth a massive £3.18bn - £254 per household.

Now it is hoping to collect some of those playthings - or their cash value - for charity. It wants children to donate any new, unwanted toys to its Toy Appeal, to be passed on to more needy children around the country. It will be collecting new toys and games at 64 of its branches until mid-January.

It would like adults to follow the youngsters' lead by popping an extra gift into the collection boxes.

The Portman Building Society is also feeling charitable. It is selling calendars at its branches in aid of British Red Cross and 11 good causes in the south of England.

Royal Scottish Assurance payout

Endowment mortgage customers of Royal Scottish Assurance - fined £2m by regulators earlier this week - can phone 0808 100 4010 to see if their policy is one of the 30,000 that will share out £50m in compensation. The payout also takes in customers who may have surrendered policies.

B&B share sale stirs rivals

Bradford & Bingley shares go live on Monday following the demutualisation - and rivals are after a slice of the action.

Norwich & Peterborough building society is offering a free "B&B" branch-based competition for members. If they can correctly answer "which building society converts to a bank in December 2000" they stand the chance of winning up to £500 worth of bed and breakfast weekend breaks.

Yorkshire building society has a remortgage product targeted at Bradford & Bingley, which guarantees to stay 1% below the B&B standard variable rate for two years. Details: 0845 1 200 888.

NatWest is offering an instant share dealing service in 375 main branches. Sales require a share certificate - expected in mid-December. Commission costs from £20.

Nationwide cuts rates to savers

Nationwide has cut rates paid to savers by 0.15 to 0.3% to fund lower mortgage rates. And now that saving is less attractive, it is easier to take money out. It has raised the cash machine or branch over-the-counter withdrawal limits from £250 to £500 a day.

Wesleyan launches personal pension

Wesleyan Assurance has introduced a new personal pension with lower charges. But the scheme is still more expensive than stakeholder for customers, with funds below £50,000 with a starter 1.25% annual management charge. The insurer justifies the gap because it provides "personal financial advice".

Fairer credit for shoppers

Interest free credit customers are to get a better deal from Finance & Leasing Association lenders following adverse publicity.

Shoppers found themselves paying sky high penalty rates if they were just one day late with final payments. Now the FLA says members will allow a "grace period" at the end of the loan and make clear any restrictions on the method of final payment at the outset.

Skipton unveils fixed rate bond

Skipton building society has a new fixed rate bond paying 6.1% before tax until January 31, 2002. The minimum investment is £3,000.

Free endowment guides

Pre-owned endowment dealer, Policy Portfolio, has two free guides - one for those thinking of selling and a second for potential investors: 020 8343 4567.

Nottingham offers discount deal

Nottingham building society has a new flexible mortgage with a 1.75% discount for six months. The society's standard flexible rate is 6.95%. There are no arrangement fees, free valuations and no mortgage indemnity premium as the maximum loan is 90% of the property's value.

webTitle: Cod quota could be cut by 40%

fields.headline: Cod quota could be cut by 40%
fields.standfirst: Fishing in crisis
fields.trailText: The European commission proposed its biggest cuts in North Sea cod quotas last night and warned that stocks were on the verge of extinction.
fields.body:
The European commission proposed its biggest cuts in North Sea cod quotas last night and warned that stocks were on the verge of extinction.

In a move which the British fishing industry fears will cost hundreds of jobs, Brussels called for next year's quota to be slashed by 40% to 48,600 tonnes. This year's figure of 81,000 tonnes was already a historic low.

North Sea cod stocks have dwindled to their lowest levels since records began in 1963 and the commission argued that it had no choice but to go for what one official described as "the nuclear option".

There are an estimated 70,000 tonnes of adult cod in the North Sea - the larder on which fish and chip shops depend - compared with 250,000 tonnes in the 1960s. The minimum stock level to guarantee the species' survival is 150,000 tonnes.

The commission also demanded a reduction of 56% for cod catches west of Scotland.

The proposals will be passed to EU fisheries ministers who meet in Brussels this month.

Hamish Morrison, chief executive of the Scottish Fishermen's Federation, said the negotiations were likely to be fraught. "There will be blood on the carpet," he said. "These proposals will displace several hundred fishermen from the industry."

The government yesterday refused to comment on the quota, but the fisheries minister, Elliot Morley, signalled that drastic action was needed. "The UK fleet has only been able to catch around 60% of its quota this year - simply because the boats have been unable to find the fish."

The commission said its proposals were inevitable. The commissioner with responsibility for fisheries, Franz Fischler, said: "There is no way round it: to have a fishing industry we need fish. Fishermen have acknowledged that they cannot catch their cod quotas and that stocks need to be rebuilt."

The industry last night admitted that many fishermen should now think about getting out and called for government compensation. "Boats will have to come out of the water," Mr Morrison said.

fields.headline: Downs parents lose heart claim
fields.trailText: A couple who claimed that doctors advised against heart surgery for their baby because he had Down's syndrome lost their bid for compensation yesterday.
fields.body:
A couple who claimed that doctors advised against heart surgery for their baby because he had Down's syndrome lost their bid for compensation yesterday.

The high court upheld doctors' advice to Maralyn and Alvin Adey of Idle, Bradford, and rejected suggestions that the parents had been told to take their son home "and enjoy him while you can".

Mr Justice Bennett ruled that consultants in Leeds and London had given "full and proper" advice to the couple in 1985 when their baby, Kristian, was a few months old. Mr and Mrs Adey had complained that they were told by consultant David Dickinson of the specialist heart unit at Killingbeck hospital in Leeds, which has since closed, that the child's hole-in-the-heart condition was inoperable

They also alleged, in an action followed closely by other families with Down's syndrome members, that there had been no proper discussion of the future of Kristian, who is now 15 and suffers from severe pulmonary vascular disease. He is not expected to live beyond 30.

Judge Bennett told the couple, who were in court in London to hear the judgment, that they were "the most devoted of parents" who had been caught up in a tragic case. But the couple had failed to convince him they would have agreed to surgery on Kristian at such a young age.

He ruled that Dr Dickinson, and another consultant at Hammersmith hospital in London had advised that the mortality rate for a hole-in-the-heart operation was one in three or four, which all the experts had agreed was correct. The facts negated the idea of any policy which discriminated against Down's syndrome babies where surgery was an option.

Mrs Adey said after the ruling: "We are very disappointed. We still believe that Kristian was discriminated against."

webTitle: Yard's new approach faces first test

fields.headline: Yard's new approach faces first test
fields.standfirst: More about the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: The investigation into the death of Damilola is one of the first big tests of Scotland Yard's new approach to the handling of critical incidents in the capital.
fields.body:
The investigation into the death of Damilola is one of the first big tests of Scotland Yard's new approach to the handling of critical incidents in the capital.

With 40 officers working on the case and the Metropolitan police's full range of back-up services at their disposal, including intelligence analysts, it is already the biggest murder inquiry since the death of the TV presenter Jill Dando in April 1999.

Scotland Yard, though, has three other essential considerations; supporting Damilola's family and ensuring they are kept fully briefed, keeping in contact with and referring to community leaders for advice, and handling the media.

The man who is running the investigative side of the inquiry has been shielded from the press. Working from the incident room in Clapham, south London, Detective Chief Inspector Trevor Shepheard has been told to concentrate on catching the killers.

Detective Superintendent David Dillnutt is officially supervising the investigation. He is briefed about developments and referred to for advice, and has been fronting press conferences.

Peckham's MP, Harriet Harman, called on the home secretary, Jack Straw, to do more to increase the numbers of police in Peckham, saying recruitment would be difficult unless more was done to ease housing costs for police.

She also called for the police "to mount a real crackdown against knives in the street and schools".

Mike Tomlinson, the new chief inspector of schools in England, said yesterday that one of his priorities was to help schools stamp out bullying.

"I think it is important that we, through inspections, identify whether schools are being effective at preventing it from happening or indeed, dealing with it effectively when it does happen," he said.

fields.headline: On a siding to nothing
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: This week the Guardian asked readers of Richard Culf's commuter diary to email their own examples of rail horror stories. The following are just three of the hundreds of responses.
fields.body:
This week the Guardian asked readers of Richard Culf's commuter diary to email their own examples of rail horror stories. The following are just three of the hundreds of responses.

David Ross
Penzance

On Monday I left Troon, Ayrshire, on the 07:23. Twenty hours later I arrived at my destination - Penzance, in Cornwall. My first train arrived on time in Newcastle at 10.54am. Then it was on to the 11:15 to Liverpool. I was expecting to take this to York where I would have to wait three hours for a connection. I asked the train manager if there would be a quicker connection if I changed trains elsewhere. He told me to stay on the train until Manchester, get on the 15:17 from there to Plymouth, where I could catch a train to arrive in Penzance shortly after 11pm.

I got off in Manchester to find the 15:17 had been cancelled. I was advised to catch the 15:07 to Crewe. This trundled to Sandbach - the last stop before Crewe - at 4.15pm. There we were told to leave the train and wait for another. Eventually I caught the 18:01 to Birmingham to catch the 19:35 Virgin service to Plymouth, scheduled to arrive there at 11.30pm. Once under way I was told the train would terminate at Bristol. From there I caught two more trains to Plymouth then a taxi to Penzance, arriving at 3am.

Anne Thomas
Crawley

The 08:43 Virgin service to Wolverhampton should arrive in Coventry at 9.52am. Just after 9am the guard explained that trains were taking 40 minutes longer than usual to reach Coventry.

At 9.52am we stopped short of Bletchley and had to wait for a replacement engine as ours had broken down. By 10.45am we were on our way again, reaching Coventry at 11.24am - 92 minutes late.

And so to the journey home - hopefully in time to reach my father-in-law's birthday party. The 16:07 pulled in at Coventry and the announcement was almost incomprehensible. I tried to find a member of staff to confirm the train was London-bound. By the time I had, the train doors were locked.

I eventually caught a stopping service which arrived at Euston at 6.45pm. I headed for Victoria to get the 19:03 to Three Bridges. This left just after 7.25pm. I rang my husband to tell him I could not make it to the party. I arrived at Three Bridges at 8.30pm.

Chris Jones
Macclesfield

On Sunday, I tried to leave Cardiff Central on the 18:15 direct train to Stockport. It never turned up. At 7.25pm a replacement train arrived. We stopped outside Shrewsbury at about 10pm - and were still there three hours later. Our train had broken down. The heating was off.

At 1.30am we arrived at Shrewsbury, where the train terminated. Eventually a coach was organised to take us to Crewe, Stockport and Manchester, where taxis would be available. We arrived at Stockport at 4.15am. I took a taxi and arrived home in Macclesfield at 5.15am.

webTitle: Teachers win praise of Ofsted's new chief

fields.headline: Teachers win praise of Ofsted's new chief
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The new chief inspector of schools in England took charge yesterday and immediately offered teachers the prospect of a much smoother ride than they got from his predecessor.
fields.body:
The new chief inspector of schools in England took charge yesterday and immediately offered teachers the prospect of a much smoother ride than they got from his predecessor.

Mike Tomlinson, 58, adopted a notably more emollient tone than the former head of the office for standards in education, Chris Woodhead, who in his first week demanded that incompetent teachers be sacked.

At a press conference at his headquarters at the Aldwych, central London, Mr Tomlinson, until yesterday head of inspection at Ofsted, went out of his way to praise the "hard work and dedication" of teachers which had cut the number of lessons identified as unsatisfactory from 30% to 6% over the past decade.

He emphasised Ofsted's role in encouraging the spread of good ideas adopted by individual schools on a range of issues, including bullying, ethnic minority education and lesson-planning time for teachers.

"I'm not Chris Woodhead, I'm my own person and I shall handle matters in my own way," Mr Tomlinson said.

"I share his absolute passion for wanting the highest possible standards within our schools and wanting every child to receive the best possible education that they need and deserve in order to give them the best start in life.

"I shall pursue that passion with the same vigour. I shall want to be stating quite categorically where things are not as they should be. But I will equally want to give the same force to those areas of work which are improving, and where teachers and all those associated with schools are bringing about the necessary improvements."

He added: "I have grandchildren in the system and I want the very best education for them. Therefore it's important to me personally as well as professionally." He said two members of his family taught in state schools.

In the wake of the murder of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor in Peckham, south-east London, Mr Tomlinson said he wanted Ofsted to play a part in helping schools stamp out bullying.

He wanted to encourage schools and local education authorities to collect data on ethnic minority pupil performance, and he recognised "the importance and contributions that different cultures can bring to the teaching situation". The commission for racial equality accused Mr Woodhead of ignoring race issues.

Like the government, Mr Tomlinson would focus on the dip in performance in the early years of secondary school, at key stage three.

Other areas of concern include weaknesses in writing skills, the underperformance of boys, bureaucracy and the recruitment and retention of teachers. He intended to work "effectively and constructively with all our partners in education where they share a concern to improve standards all round".

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, urged the new chief inspector to order a review of the inspection system. "Mike Tomlinson starts off in an enviable position. He can repair the damage created by his predecessor. I wish him well in that task. I look forward to working with Mr Tomlinson to ensure that school inspection becomes a process which is recognised as valuable, not feared."

In contrast to Mr Woodhead, who recently criticised "vacuous" degree subjects, Mr Tomlinson said higher education, other than teacher training, was not part of his remit. And he apologised again - twice - for his remark a few years ago that he didn't "give a monkey's toss for teachers". Ofsted officials are anxious for the media to stop quoting that remark.

Mr Tomlinson, a chemistry graduate from Durham university, was a teacher in Nottinghamshire and Leicestershire from 1965 to 1977. He joined the Inspectorate of Schools in 1978 and became director of inspection at Ofsted in 1995.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, offered him the chief inspector's job after Mr Woodhead resigned to join the Daily Telegraph.

"You'll all appreciate that recent events resulting in me becoming the chief inspector have been both rapid and rather surprising," Mr Tomlinson said. "I'm only slowly coming to terms with the change. I do regard holding this post as an honour and at the same time for me its a very humbling experience."

fields.headline: Pooh artist's pin-up surprise
fields.standfirst: Show reveals there was more to EH Shepard than Piglet and friends
fields.trailText: Show reveals there was more to EH Shepard than Piglet and friends
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
An exhibition due to open at the Dulwich Picture Gallery on Tuesday reveals that the man who created the childhood icons of Winnie the Pooh and Mole of The Wind in the Willows also drew risque illustrations of a young woman in her underwear.

Arthur Chandler, curator of The Man Who Drew Pooh, an exhibition of the life of EH Shepard, London, dived into 70 years of the artist's diaries wondering if he would find scandal - especially since Shepard's will said no biography was to be written until 30 years after his death.

After five years work in the Shepard archive at Surrey University, Mr Chandler, author of a new book on the artist, has concluded that the truth is indeed startling - he was a truly happy man, who loved his children, his life and his work.

Unlike the author of the Pooh books, AA Milne, and his son, the model for Christopher Robin, who came to feel menaced by them, Shepard also loved his creations.

The archive contains 1,400 drawings, many never published. The last of them had never been seen since the artist shut his sketch book in November 1970, aged 90. It shows Eeyore, engulfed by a tuba, and Piglet, drumming wildly on a kettle drum.

His life had much tragedy. His mother, an amateur artist, died when he was a boy, his brother in the first world war, his son Graham in the second, and his first wife, Florence, in 1927, under anaesthetic while having routine surgery.

Despite this, the impression Mr Chandler took from the thousands of pages of drawings, diaries and letters was of the sunny Edwardian world of Shepard's books. In the 1960s the artist was working on his two illustrated autobiographies, still drawing that world and not the new England of Mini cars and mini skirts.

Shepard lived most of his life near Guildford, and the Surrey landscape of hills, beeches and pan-tiled cottages, can be seen in his work again and again.

In 1974 Shepard left his entire archive to Surrey University. The university, devoted to science, was at a loss to know what to do with it. The archive sat in boxes in the library for 20 years, until Mr Chandler was asked to take a look at it.

After reading the diaries - accounts of drives in the country, lunches, parties - it came as no surprise to Mr Chandler that the voluptuous pin-up is Shepard's wife, Florence.

Shepard was in the trenches in France, a soldier who fought at the Somme, Arras and Ypres. He won the MC.

In that nightmare he was still sending back a stream of cartoons to Punch about shell holes and ruined villages. One shows two Tommies, standing alone in a superbly drawn devastated landscape, a smoking shell crater yards away. One soldier mutters: "Faster! No, I ain't goin' no faster, young 'igh velocity, I ain't got but two speeds, slow and stop."

Into this hell Florence sent a letter about some new underwear she had bought. Shepard sent back an illustrated letter visualising the effect: the drawing is captioned: "Is this rather a nice young person?"

fields.headline: Bookshop discounts 'threat to publishing'
fields.trailText: Some 635 small and medium-size publishers applied yesterday to the office of fair trading for an inquiry into a demand by Waterstone's which they say will cause wholesale bankruptcies and either raise book prices steeply or "vastly" reduce the public's choice.
fields.body:
Some 635 small and medium-size publishers applied yesterday to the office of fair trading for an inquiry into a demand by Waterstone's which they say will cause wholesale bankruptcies and either raise book prices steeply or "vastly" reduce the public's choice.

The unprecedented complaints, from many of the most active smaller presses in Britain, are in reaction to an ultimatum requiring price discounts of 50% in the books they sell through the country's biggest specialist high street bookseller.

The small presses tabled a formal complaint that Waterstone's has broken the 1998 Competition Act by abusing its dominant position in some sectors of the book trade. If the complaint is upheld, the company could be fined up to 10% of its UK turnover.

The new discounts, a rise of up to 15% for many publishers, are aimed at increasing Waterstone's revenue and cutting its stocks of unsold quality books. An editorial in the Bookseller magazine yesterday forecast the policy would mean a substantial drop in the range of titles available in bookshops.

webTitle: Railtrack eases speed limits but delays could last till May

fields.headline: Railtrack eases speed limits but delays could last till May
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack yesterday announced the lifting of some speed restrictions on its battered network, but refused to commit itself to returning the railway to normal before May.
fields.body:
Railtrack yesterday announced the lifting of some speed restrictions on its battered network, but refused to commit itself to returning the railway to normal before May.

The date could be significant for the government if it calls an election, but Railtrack's new chief executive, Steve Marshall, said that he would be "more comfortable" in dealing with the question on a return to normality in a few weeks.

Over the next fortnight, Railtrack will start lifting 340 of the 572 speed restrictions currently in use, of which 200 are on sites where the speed limit will be raised from 20 mph to 40mph, and 140 are in places where the limit is to be increased from 40 to 60 mph.

A big push has been started to get the railway in some sort of shape before Christmas, but there will be inevitable closures over the holiday period as Railtrack engineers work on maintenance work already scheduled.

Railtrack now faces the threat that Labour will seek to take greater control of the railway in its election manifesto if the company fails to deliver the improvements which ministers are seeking.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, has told Railtrack that the network must be returned to its state pre-Hatfield or he will impose further controls over the company. In the wings will be further legislation setting an independent safety body for the industry and tougher delivery objectives for the company, falling short of re-nationalisation.

Mr Marshall yesterday attended the first meeting of industry leaders, chaired by Lord Macdonald, transport minister. It was described by the government as helpful and positive, but it was made clear afterwards that ministers will soon be asking for a guaranteed date on when the railway will be returned to normal.

Mr Marshall denied that the government was directly interfering in the running of the industry, while acknowledging that it was entitled to be heard, since it was pouring £2 bn a year into the business and rightly reflected the public interest.

But he insisted that Railtrack was responsible for the infrastructure and had the final decision on the operation of the railway. "The buck stops with us," he said.

Railtrack gave no specific locations for the easing of speed restrictions, but highlighted the Midland main line, the east coast main line, and the the west coast and great eastern lines, as areas where it was laying special emphasis.

Mr Marshall said: "I know it is a dreadful time for many travellers. Relaxing the speed limits will help things run more smoothly. The speed restrictions were appropriate and necesssary following the accident at Hatfield, but the huge effort by our engineers to check the tracks for gauge corner cracking means that we are now in a position where we can safely raise the limits at some sites."

Richard Middleton, Railtrack, technical director, said that the company had not over-reacted after Hatfield, and that a nationwide check had to be put in place. He described it as a sensible engineering response.

Since Hatfield, Railtrack has checked more than 3,000 sites which have shown evidence of gauge corner cracking. As re-railing takes place, the length of the track affected by the problem is falling, even though five new potential danger sites are discovered each day.

Mr Middleton said that in some cases steel plate is being placed on the track to support it until a permanent job is completed. So far 117 miles of track has been relayed and 70 per cent of the network checked. Another 300 miles of new track still has to be laid at the rate of 20 miles a week.

webTitle: Convicted killer bailed amid fresh doubt over guilt

fields.headline: Convicted killer bailed amid fresh doubt over guilt
fields.trailText: A former soldier who served 17 years in prison for a double murder was freed on bail yesterday after doubts emerged about his conviction.
fields.body:
A former soldier who served 17 years in prison for a double murder was freed on bail yesterday after doubts emerged about his conviction.

Peter Fell, 39, who came from a deprived family background, was known to police as a fantasist and had even confessed to being the Yorkshire Ripper, his solicitor said.

He was released pending a full appeal hearing in January, but prosecution lawyers yesterday conceded that his confession had been unreliable.

Fell was convicted of the murders of Ann Lee, 44, and Margaret "Peggy" Johnson, 65, who were exercising their dogs on Aldershot common in May 1982 when they were stabbed several times. There was no forensic evidence nor any apparent motive.

Fell made a series of anonymous telephone calls to police, the day after the murders, giving the name and address of the killer as Peter Fell of York Road, Aldershot.

Thirteen months later he rang again, giving his new address in Bournemouth, where he worked as a hospital porter and had married.

At Fell's trial in 1984, the jury was told that he had admitted attacking the women, but did not remember stabbing them.

His solicitor, James Nichol, said the partial confession was made after he had been held in solitary confinement for 72 hours, denied access to a solicitor, and refused food.

Fell later claimed that he was not on the common at the time of the murder.

He said yesterday: "I am very relieved and naturally happy and I have always believed that one day I would be proved innocent."

Prison had been an ordeal, but he had became a Christian and his faith had helped him.

Asked why he had confessed to the murders, he said: "I used to say a lot of silly things, but did not realise that they would be used against me at the trial."

His solicitor said: "He has been in prison for 17 years too long. He is innocent and will be shown to be innocent, because he could not have been at the crime scene at the time of the killings."

Patrick O'Connor QC, representing Fell at the bail hearing, said new evidence would show that Fell was "unusually vulnerable" to suggestion and that his psychological condition was not understood at the time.

Fell was "a serial confessor" and prone to fantasy, who would admit to things he had not done.

While on bail, Fell, who was at the category C prison The Verne in Portland, Dorset, will stay with a prison visitor who has taken an interest in his case.

webTitle: Mallon weighs move into local politics

fields.headline: Mallon weighs move into local politics
fields.trailText: The suspended detective Ray Mallon hinted yesterday at a new career in politics, as mayor of Hartlepool.
fields.body:
The suspended detective Ray Mallon hinted yesterday at a new career in politics, as mayor of Hartlepool.

The officer courted by politicians at the last election for his "zero tolerance" policing experiment started his fourth year of suspension by speculating on a career at the port's town hall.

Mr Mallon, 45, made it clear that he would not give up his long struggle with Cleveland police, who sent him home on full pay on December 1 1997 while corruption and neglect of duty charges were investigated. The £5m inquiry, which was formally completed yesterday, found earlier this year that there was no criminal case to answer, but Mr Mallon still faces 14 disciplinary charges.

Yesterday he signalled growing doubts that he could return to active police work, and repeated a pledge to retire in 2003, when he would have spent 30 years in uniform. That would be the time, he said, when a shift to local government was a possibility, if Hartlepool decided to elect a mayor directly.

"After I am exonerated I would ideally wish to continue to serve the public in some way," Mr Mallon said. He has recently turned down media offers, including a proposal to present a Roger Cook style investigative programme on TV.

"I would consider standing as mayor of Hartlepool. Although I am Stockton-born and bred I used to work in Hartlepool and have a great affinity for the people there."

Mr Mallon made a name for himself as the head of crime prevention in Hartlepool, where the British version of American zero tolerance - cracking down on small offences and monitoring suspected criminals intensively - was first tried.

The town is considering a move to a mayoral system. A poll of the 90,000 residents produced a 7-4 majority for a directly elected mayor, as opposed to a system of a council leader and "cabinet". The council is now moving into the second stage of consultation, canvassing the views of businesses, the voluntary sector and other organisations.

Mr Mallon, who becomes eligible for a police pension in three years, would almost certainly have to move house to Hartlepool if he decided to make a career in politics. He lives in neighbouring Stockton-on-Tees.

webTitle: Wild tales of Beckett, Pinter and hot coconuts

fields.headline: Wild tales of Beckett, Pinter and hot coconuts
fields.trailText: Director's diary
fields.body:
December 7 1999. Dublin

It's swaggering with Euro enterprise, with barely fewer cranes on the skyline than in Berlin, and a feeling that this is no longer a dependency: they've shaken off the British. We film by the canal where Beckett paced and looked up at the window of the nursing home where his mother was dying. Our driver tells me he's a cousin of a cousin of Beckett. Their mutual cousin had a wooden leg, which she used to take off for swimming, he says. He adds that Beckett was once so hard up and desperate for a cigarette in Paris in the middle of the night that he went out and sold the sheets off his bed.

Off to the Wicklow hills, where Beckett walked with his father - a continent of heather and peat and little mountain peaks in the background, wild and desolate. Standing here in the biting wind facing a camera talking about the theatre of Brecht and Beckett seems more than usually absurd. And no less so, the mournful walk on the long pier at Dun Laoghaire past a public lavatory that appears to be a popular cottaging spot. The pier features in Krapp's Last Tape; the lavatory doesn't.

December 8

Interviews with Alan Ayckbourn and Harold Pinter. Alan has written more plays than Shakespeare, and a few years ago, a poll revealed that his plays were joint second in the world to Shakespeare in popularity (along with Brecht). Like Shakespeare, Alan has a company (in Scarborough) and has to provide a play for them every year. He speaks admiringly of Beckett, but confesses that he once fell asleep onstage during Lucky's speech, while playing one of the tramps. He describes Shakespeare as a big, sandy beach - every new generation comes down and scrawls furiously on it with a piece of stick, and then the tide comes in and the whole thing is as it was.

Harold talks openly, vividly and amusingly for about an hour and a half: about his own work, about Coward, Wilde, and Brecht (who he admires greatly), and Beckett, who, he said, loved gossip: "What's the latest?," he'd say to Harold - the immeasurable tenderness of the man set against the despair. And we talk about politics. Our generation, ostentatiously cocky in the 1970s, used to think that Harold came late to politics, but he points out that he was a conscientious objector against national service in 1948, and was prepared to go to prison - taking his toothbrush along to the trial - which is a rather more thorough act of political engagement than I or any of my contemporaries made. He recommends me a poem of his - "it's pretty good, actually" - called Requiem for 1945, about the death of post-war hope.

Like Alan, Harold was (and still is) an actor, and talks about the tension between actor and audience that "has to be addressed: you can't let them win."

He deplores the way that the audience nowadays is part of the action, and the actors part of the audience: "I remember once when I went to see a production of Nicholas Nickleby at the Aldwych, and an actor I had actually directed was prancing around before the show, pretending to sell hot coconuts or something, and he came up to me, and waved a hot coconut in my face, and I said, 'Bugger off.' And he went away and then just as the curtain rose - the whole thing was about to start - he danced down the aisle and thrust a hot coconut in my lap..."

December 16

I interview Steven Berkoff, and feel it's a shame that he can't appear in three dimensions. As if to argue his case for the body as his instrument, he uses his hands with sculptural expressiveness. He has a reputation (not entirely earned) for being a theatrical Rottweiler, but he's genial, eloquent, even witty, about the theatre he admires and has tried to create. After we've finished, the studio technicians talk about theatre. "It's dead, isn't it?" says one genially. I slink away, not for the first time wondering who this series will be addressing.

December 21

I interview Alan Bennett in my kitchen. I should have used Alan's adage on the studio technician: "I don't think people should be made to go to the theatre if they don't want to. It makes it such hard work for the actors." There's no playwright in the country who's better known or better liked by the public; he's one of the - quintessentially English - family, a familiar face, a national institution, adjectival: "Very Alan Bennett," people say.

Alan isn't at his happiest when talking about his own work: he reveals a "self" in his plays and diaries but when he's sitting in my kitchen facing an interrogation, the "self" is undeniably himself. But he rallies generously, and answers my questions with a practised ease, aware, from his countless TV appearances, of the virtues of pithiness and brevity.

Of The Importance of Being Earnest, he says: "Most plays are nearly completed circles and the production completes the circle; The Importance of Being Earnest is completed there on the page. It was a perfect play and I think Wilde knew it."

January 5 2000. New York

I interview Liam Neeson about Irish theatre. Liam is a veteran of 1,000 promotional interviews for films, so it's a comparative novelty for him to do an interview where he doesn't know the questions and has to consider the answers. He speaks feelingly and fluently of Irish theatre and being a voluntary exile and wishing he'd been in Dublin for the first performances of O'Casey's plays, and of Wilde's folie d'amour and his elocution lessons and his out-Englishing the English.

"I remember when I decided to come over and live in England I was very, very, very conscious of being Irish. I was aware especially when the Queen's cavalry were blown up in Hyde Park. If I was in a shop or something like that I'd put on this faux English accent."

Then to the Village - to Wooster Street - to interview actor Willem Dafoe about his involvement with the Wooster Group. Acting in movies underwrites his work with this avant-garde group, and he lives the enviable life of man unencumbered by ambition, liberated from the market, pursuing his passion. He's very charming and engaging about working with the group, creating theatre-like collages. I ask him what the special properties of theatre are. "Well," he says, "where else can you get spat on by an actor?"

 Richard Eyre's TV series Changing Stages continues on BBC2 tomorrow at 7.05pm

"I remember when I decided to come over and live in England I was very, very, very conscious of being Irish. I was aware especially when the Queen's cavalry were blown up in Hyde Park. If I was in a shop or something like that I'd put on this faux English accent." Then to the Village - to Wooster Street - to interview actor Willem Dafoe about his involvement with the Wooster Group. Acting in movies underwrites his work with this avant-garde group, and he lives the enviable life of man unencumbered by ambition, liberated from the market, pursuing his passion. He's very charming and engaging about working with the group, creating theatre-like collages. I ask him what the special properties of theatre are. "Well," he says, "where else can you get spat on by an actor?"  Richard Eyre's TV series Changing Stages continues on BBC2 tomorrow at 7.05pm

fields.headline: The last word on   Patriotism
fields.standfirst: Patriotism is a kind of religion; it is the egg from which wars are hatched -   Guy de Maupassant
fields.trailText: Patriotism is a kind of religion; it is the egg from which wars are hatched - Guy de Maupassant
fields.body:
This week's publication by the National Centre for Social Research of its annual survey of attitudes in Britain paints a disturbing picture. Xenophobia, racism and nationalism are on the rise, especially among the so-called "working classes" who outweigh the "middle classes" by as much as two to one in their distrust of foreigners, Europe, the Euro, immigrants, homosexuals, and non-white Britons. Devolution in Scotland and Wales has made the English more indifferent or even hostile to those countries, and certainly more nationalistic and inward-looking.

One of the chief things to be deplored in this hardening of attitudes is the recrudescence of patriotism. Patriotism is so potent a concept that to oppose it seems obviously wrong. England's flag, the St George's Cross, was until recently not much seen, but is frequently flown now, and not just by football supporters. To describe it - as one would describe the patriotic devices of an enemy - as a menacing symbol seems bizarre. How can one not love one's country? How could one not wish to defend it against invaders, to uphold its honour on the playing field, to see it succeed in the world and win the admiration of other peoples?

These apparently unanswerable challenges beg the question. The right response is to say that one wishes to see human beings flourish everywhere, living in peace and freedom, benefiting from education and sound health, and enjoying all the good things that the world at its best has to offer. But to achieve anything approaching these utopian possibilities, the world's human family has to stop dividing against itself.

The world is a wasteland of separate groups jostling for advantage, trying to buy cheap and sell dear to each other, clambering on each other's shoulders for a larger share of the light and air above. Competition eventually breeds conflict, and patriotism has always been the tool by which kings and elites have persuaded their people to take arms against a sea of foreigners, and to risk death by attempting to kill them - thinking, with Addison's Cato, "What a pity it is that we can die but once for our country!"

The strangest thing about patriotism is that it is an emotion directed only outwards, towards the foreigner in his foreign land. It is not an emotion that makes us love our own people better, in any but the most abstract and reflex way. Do we hasten, because of patriotism, to succour our own poor, to pay more tax to boost the health service and help pensioners? We do not. We find that what we mean by our love for our country is that we are prepared in its interests to drop bombs on other countries, not that we are willing to strive and sacrifice to make our plot of earth a paradise for our own fellows, who are putatively the flesh of our flesh.

Mark Twain pungently remarked, "Talking of patriotism, what humbug it is; it always commemorates a robbery. There isn't a foot of land in the world which doesn't represent the ousting and re-ousting of a long line of successive owners." English xenophobes should reflect on the relative lateness of their ancestors' arrival on these green and pleasant shores, in waves of invaders - Celts, Romans, Angles, Saxons, Jutes, Danes, Normans, Huguenots, wave after wave of peoples, who have given the people of this island their sturdy mongrel blood, and always brought more with them than they ever displaced.

The cant of patriotism typically arises when a sense of threat is felt. What is the threat to present-day England? Tabloids and Tories demonise Europe to manufacture one; but the real threat is division and separation, pushing others away, making them strangers so that one can despise or fear them more easily. To contest the unhealthy drift of opinion revealed by this week's survey, the point to be urged is that one's nation is humankind, and although doing one's best by its local portion is a duty, it is only part of our larger duty to be patriots of the whole world.

fields.headline: Rouse yourselves from complacent slumber
fields.trailText: Wake up, o people of England! Yes, people of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland - that goes for you too, but "wake up, people of the UK" does not quite have the same ring about it. The lot of you, anyway, ought to rouse yourselves from complacent slumber and recognise the danger at your door. Take that Tony Blair. Nice enough chap, on the face of it. Pretty moderate. Not giving much obvious aid and comfort to socialism...
fields.body:
Wake up, o people of England! Yes, people of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland - that goes for you too, but "wake up, people of the UK" does not quite have the same ring about it. The lot of you, anyway, ought to rouse yourselves from complacent slumber and recognise the danger at your door. Take that Tony Blair. Nice enough chap, on the face of it. Pretty moderate. Not giving much obvious aid and comfort to socialism...

Don't you believe a word of it. The man's an extremist. You have probably seen photographs of him, long-haired and cuddly, in his Oxford University days, when his chief delights were supposed to have been religion and his guitar. All a front. The fellow was an extremist. We know he was an extremist because it said so in last week's Mail on Sunday. Two proofs of this incurable condition: he took part in demonstrations against the National Front! And he once attended a lecture on the Marxist theory of alienation!! He was even, the MoS says, "involved with a band of firebrands"!!! Once a firebrand, always a firebrand, I say, don't you? I have to make that a question, because I seem to have run out of exclamation marks. I must send the boy out for more.

But this is only the half of it. What about this sinister fellow Jonathan Powell, who sits at Blair's right hand? The revelations about him on page one of the Sunday Times must have made many readers ask themselves: "What kind of a land are we living in?" and then answer themselves: "Not the kind of country that I, and my spouse and our children, grandchildren and labrador dogs, and my lovely young mistress Lorraine (or my hunky young toyboy Jason: delete as applicable), and that nice chap down at the butcher's, want to be living in, I can tell you."

Apparently, confidential documents from the "stressed and secretive" hand of this Powell have come to the newspaper and, as you'd expect, they project a veritable laser beam right into the very heart of this government. For instance: "What shines through," the paper tells us, "is the informality of government, with Powell referring to key figures in Downing Street by their initials". TB, it can be revealed, is Tony Blair, and AC, Alastair Campbell!

One entry reads: "Express... Hollick... Lab", thus lifting the lid on government concern that the Daily Express might turn against the Labour party! Another reads: "Arsenal Dome - what say CS?", which the Sunday Times conjectures could be a reference to Chris Smith! Some entries are even more startling. Campbell, we learn, is mentioned in connection with "Q's sph" - an apparent reference, the paper daringly suggests, to the Queen's speech. There are also references to RW, JC and SW: "RW may be Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, but the others remain a mystery." The source of all this extraordinary stuff is not revealed, but some have suggested it came from a dustbin; which makes sense to me, because that is where you expect to find rubbish.

Y et even the Sunday Times Insight team has missed the most alarming information of all - exactly the kind of thing the nation needs to wake up. One entry reads: "Irish - not sound health MM." Naively, the Sunday Times thinks this refers to Mo Mowlam. Smallweed knows better.

This entry, I believe, reflects information recently forwarded by the security services to number 10 about a woman using the alias Molly Malone, whom MI6's informants suggest was until recently wheeling a barrow round Dublin purporting to sell cockles and mussels. With a vigilance born of years of experience, observers deduced that Malone was not a fit woman, a view now confirmed by reports in the past few days that she died of a fever and no one could save her.

On the other hand, JC, RW and SW are probably only Powell's favourite actresses (Joan Collins, Raquel Welch, Sigourney Weaver), composers (John Cage, Richard Wagner, Samuel Wesley) or entertainers (Johnny Cash, Robbie Williams, Stevie Wonder). They have nothing to do with attempts by extremists to subvert the constitution. Wake it up, Sunday Times!!!!!

People may wonder how it is that Smallweed, with his meagre resources, is able to garner so much more from these documents than the whole Sunday Times Insight team put together. I attribute that to taking regular journeys to and from Acton Green on the number 94 bus. Nor am I alone in finding inspiration on that grand, scenic journey from Piccadilly by way of Marble Arch and Shepherd's Bush to this delectable suburb. The controller of Radio 4, Helen Boaden, told the Guardian on Thursday that initially she had doubts about how to transmit Stephen Fry's recording of Harry Potter And The Philosopher's Stone, by JK Rowling. "But when I was coming back on the 94 bus I thought: 'I know how we'll do it.'"

It is no rare thing, as travellers on this route will tell you, to find the whole top deck (downstairs is different) crammed with philosophers, poets and other writers and intellectuals in search of a whizzy notion. Bertrand Russell had most of his best ideas on route 94, and I myself, while using it on Wednesday, spotted among the passengers Simon Schama, AN Wilson, Jeremy Clarkson, Thomas Adès and the late Ludwig Wittgenstein. In the old London transport rubric: route 43 for remembrance, route 94 for creative thinking, route 189 for a fine old time, and route 306 for a matchless view of Acton's rhubarb fields.

My reminiscences of the weeping judge of Gresley have reminded Dr Eames of Cambridge of the case of St Ambrose of Milan (d 937), the volume of whose tears, occasioned by sins confessed to him, necessitated the construction of a stone overflow channel. Though this can no longer be seen, the saint remains visible in the crypt: "He is in no danger of rehydration," says my informant, "being roughly 4ft long and the colour (after 16 centuries) of a superior brand of digestive biscuit." He adds the subsequent suggestions: (1) that his holy tears irrigated a sizeable plot of the saint's favourite vegetable (globe artichokes), or (2) that being only 4ft tall in life, he was in danger of drowning unless environmentally drained, have been discounted by Vatican omniscienti. And there was I, happy to believe them both. Wake up, Smallweed.

fields.headline: Press charges
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... newspapers and accountability
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... newspapers and accountability
fields.body:
Here are two questions which have cropped up rather more often than usual in the past week. Why are newspapers, which are constantly calling for accountability in others, generally so reluctant to be accountable themselves? What possible reason could a newspaper, or a newspaper's website, have for declining to correct some significant thing it had got wrong?

As a matter of fact, I have been putting these questions myself in reply to questions put to me as I have gone round publicising the first collection of these Saturday columns and the Guardian's (funnier) corrections (details below).

The questions I have been asked most frequently are, "Why does the Guardian run daily corrections?", usually coupled with "Is it because it makes more mistakes than anyone else?"; and "Why don't the other papers carry regular corrections?" This last question is usually coupled with another, "Is it because they never, or hardly ever, make mistakes?"

I cannot answer for other papers and we have no way of knowing whether the Guardian makes more mistakes than others, but I would certainly look more than a little sceptically at a journalist who stood up to declare, "We never make mistakes". You may take it as read that they all do.

The editor of the Guardian, writing a diary in this week's New Statesman, notes the advent of a readers' editor, modelled on the Guardian system, at Politiken, the Danish newspaper, then adds, "But so far, one has to confess, the idea has not spread like a bushfire through the British press.

"Do other editors really believe their readers will trust them less if they keep admitting they got things wrong? Can't they see that the reverse is true..."

It certainly is true to say that an increasing number of journalists on other papers are making it clear that they would welcome a franker relationship of this kind with their readers. The Express, for example (although things have changed there somewhat in the past few days), in mentioning the book, said that, "Since its introduction as 'a forum for accountability' in 1997, [the Guardian's corrections system] has been an unqualified success." A senior journalist on the Express, in a radio discussion a week ago, said, "... it is utterly proper that if you get something wrong, you should correct it at the first possible opportunity and not try and squabble".

In the same programme (Radio 5 Live's Paper Talk, presented by Brian Hayes on November 24), a senior journalist from the Telegraph said - and we must take it that he was speaking generally and not with specific reference to his own paper - "I think one of the most disgraceful things about our business is our refusal actually to admit when we get things wrong. And as newspaper journalists we're brought up - and it certainly happened to me - to do everything we can to avoid apologising or issuing a correction...

"We spend hours trying to persuade people who have every reason to expect a correction, will they accept a letter from us saying 'I'm sorry we got this wrong'? And when they say 'Well, no, we want a correction in the paper', [we say] 'Well would you write a letter to the paper?'

"I don't know why we do it, because the Guardian, I think, is doing brilliantly with this system."

Clive Soley, the chairman of the Parliamentary Labour party and joint author of Regulating The Press (published this month by Pluto), lamented in a recent article in the Times, "The press is very reluctant either to say sorry - most don't even have a correction column - or to admit that they got it wrong."

A senior journalist on the Times, reviewing the Guardian's Corrections book, shares some of our best or worst moments with his readers but points out, "The truth is that similar cock-ups appear in most newspapers most days... If a newspaper is prepared to admit to error... it establishes a relationship of trust with readers for being honest enough to admit mistakes."

When I talked to postgraduate journalism students at the City University in London this week, I fancied I detected a flicker of surprise and dismay when I said that society at large did not hold the journalist in high esteem. A more open and mature relationship is in everyone's interest, and maybe the students from the City, and others just entering the profession, will do something to foster it.

A willingness to correct things when you know they are wrong does not seem too much to ask. Why, perhaps we shall soon be asking, did it take us all so long to get round to it?

 The Guardian book of Corrections & Clarifications, which includes more than 50 of these Open Door columns, with a large selection of our funnier corrections, is published by Guardian Newspapers Limited at £6.99. You can get it from bookshops or direct from Guardian Books on 0870 727 4155 (p&p free). fields.headline: Beyond the clouds
fields.standfirst: Turner painted more than storms and sunsets. There's politics in there too, says  Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: Turner painted more than storms and sunsets. There's politics in there too, says Jonathan Jones
fields.body:
No one ever said JMW Turner's strong point was the human figure. His people are heroic lumps, dwarfed by cosmic explosions of light and weather that they either contemplate in static wonder or try desperately to survive. In his work Caernarvon Castle, under a golden sky and in a lattice of shadows, a Celtic bard sings to a pious conclave sitting under an oak tree. And did those feet in ancient time_ now, who does that remind you of?

Turner: the Great Watercolours, a beautiful display in the Royal Academy's Sackler Galleries, has been put on by the RA for no better reason than the 250th anniversary of Turner's death. Chance, however, has given it a more interesting context: it coincides with the Blake show at Tate Britain. Blake (1757-1827) and Turner (1775-1851) both paint people not realistically or according to academic drawing rules, but as robed ancients, muscular vessels of spiritual revelation. And they are both political artists.

Sometimes we talk about the world's favourite British artist as if he were an honest chronicler of nature, like Constable; he's anything but. Like Blake, he paints the world transfigured. His light is not just a depiction of nature, but nature with the volume cranked up very loud. The objections to his work by Victorian critics should remind us that no one ever looked at Folkestone From the Sea, a glory of this exhibition, and said, "Ah yes - that's what Folkestone looks like." Folkestone? It's a city on the shores of a lake in hell. The sky burns pink, the moon is a white lantern blazing through lowering clouds, the sea is evil, as a gang of smugglers realise they're about to be caught. This is a million miles from homely British self-images.

Caernarvon Castle is a clue to Turner's politics. As the son of a Covent Garden barber who was elected to the Royal Academy, Turner seems to have known when to keep his mouth shut, so his ideas are a mystery. But he grew up in a dramatic era and his paintings participate in it. Turner always tried to record his times, rushing to paint the battle-scarred HMS Victory after Trafalgar. Later he painted the Houses of Parliament in flames. Turner's champion John Ruskin simply didn't see the moral anger in his work, praising Turner's masterpiece Slaver Throwing Overboard the Dead and Dying - Typhon Coming On as a perfect depiction of the sea in a storm, without mentioning its subject matter, except in a footnote, or that Turner intended it as his contribution to the campaign against the slave trade.

Turner painted Caernarvon Castle when he was about 25. The French Revolution and subsequent wars convulsed Europe; at home, half-underground groups campaigned for political reform. Turner's inclusion of a Welsh bard is not accidental. The bards were romanticised in this period as icons of primitive freedom. This wasn't a nationalist image but a radical one.

Of course it would be mad to deny Turner's patriotic love of the British landscape and coast, not to mention the British navy. His painting of a man o' war rising out of the sea, its bulk apparently as stable as a rock, in First-Rate Taking in Stores, is a tribute to the ships that sank Napoleon's ambitions. Yet when this watercolour was still drying at the home of patron Walter Fawkes, Turner painted a pendant showing a merchant ship shattered, going under for the last time in a boiling maelstrom of foam, people clinging to each other - some in soldier's uniforms. It records a real incident, the loss of an East Indiaman off Purbeck in 1786 in which 166 people died.

History runs through Turner's art, however much Ruskin ignored it, and however much we want to see it through the filter of modernist abstraction. When he travelled to Europe he didn't just see mountains; he imagined them as settings for terrible battles, for Hannibal's hordes and Napoleon's Grande Armée. This exhibition includes two watercolours of the same alpine castle. One is a sweet scene of tourists contemplating the gorge below the battlements. The other imagines a fictional battle, with Napoleon's army in hand-to-hand combat with the fort's defenders.

This exhibition reveals Turner's watercolours as romantic topographies with absolute precision of perspective - Turner was, after all, professor of perspective at the Royal Academy. A study such as Kilchern Castle is a consummate exercise in creating a real space on paper. Viewed from close to the ground, across a flat plain with mountains to the right, the earth recedes from us almost diagrammatically. Shadows fall on the fields; behind them is a streak of light, and behind that the tiny castle and distant peaks. The more of these landscapes you look at, the more a pattern emerges.

Whether he is painting Conway Castle or the Rhine, Turner sees a hierarchy of receding phenomena: people in the foreground, a town behind them, a castle, mountains, sky, then finally the moon or sun. It amounts to a cosmology as hermetic as Blake's. Modern people - you and I - are in the foreground, with things becoming more ancient as they recede, until we see the origins of the earth, the universe, light. In Richmond Hill a group of picnickers sit and stand on England's green and pleasant land. They are sampling the picturesque. They get more than they bargained for. The sky that lights the woods and river in the distance is a divine gold, an apocalyptic window on heaven. Some of them look; some don't. It's as if Turner is urging them to look again, to see what he sees, to see the grandeur of existence, to respond, to get up.

fields.headline: Lulu and the dead floozie
fields.standfirst: Tim Ashley  is thrilled by a celebration of radio's golden age
fields.trailText: Tim Ashley is thrilled by a celebration of radio's golden age
fields.body:
If you came across a woman got up in a gumshoe's mac and trilby and a bloke in high heels, you'd probably assume they'd strayed from a cross-dressing party. Not on this occasion, however. The woman is Lulu Pinkerton, female detective, in a fictional 1930s American radio series. The chap is a sound-effects guy, clattering his feet on planks as our intrepid heroine totters through San Francisco. They both feature in a quirky show called Radio Rhapsody, the brainchild of writer Denise Lanctot and conductor (and Bernstein pupil) Marin Alsop.

Performed by the City of London Sinfonia at London's Barbican, Radio Rhapsody is one of the most entertaining evenings I've ever spent in a concert hall. An evocation of the great age of radio, it is billed as a tribute to the bandleader Paul Whiteman, whose live broadcasts from Times Square's Biltmore Ballroom in the years between the wars had millions tuning in.

The show is a dramatisation of an imaginary radio show of the time. The Sinfonia mutates into the Syncopated Sinfonians, producing an ideal big-band sound under Alsop, the "swing-time gal with the syncopated baton". Kim Criswell, sporting a series of outlandish outfits, plays a sequence of ditsy divas with names like Violet McDade and Jeanette L'Amour. Much of the music, arranged by Garry Fagin, consists of jazz versions of classics (such as Liszt's Lebestraum), which was one of Whiteman's specialities. The concert/broadcast is interrupted for a series of spoof advertising jingles: Criswell, adopting the gravelly tone of Marlene Dietrich, praises Dromedary cigarettes, which must be smoked two at a time. It is all held together by "the tasteful Dirk Hennesy" (the actor Henry Goodman), a slimy Maitre d' with a fine line in malapropisms.

Lulu Pinkerton's preposterous adventures in solving the murder of a floozie are basically a showcase for the percussionist Glyn Matthews as the sound-effects guy, producing every noise imaginable from gunshots to cars backfiring.

Watching him sprint through his routine is mesmeric, though it points up the show's main flaw: an excessive visual emphasis in the depiction of something that was primarily intended to be heard rather than seen.

fields.headline: Searching for reason amid Euro-hysteria
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Media analysis: It is so much easier to handle personalities than issues, and the stories are so much more accessible, readable, even interesting.
fields.body:
It is so much easier to handle personalities than issues, and the stories are so much more accessible, readable, even interesting. Ask yourself, yes even Guardian readers ask yourselves, would you rather read about qualified majority voting or John Prescott being branded a male chauvinist by a woman French environment minister? He had accused Dominique Voynet of torpedoing his attempts to broker an international deal on global warming because she was "too tired" to concentrate. The French minister, not used to the ways and idioms of Two Jags, did not take kindly to such remarks, and told the world so.

It is so much easier to indulge in schadenfreude than to wrestle with enlargement. BSE in Germany and France had the press, and not just the Eurosceptic press, very close to a state of gloating. It was as though the serious European issues of the previous week had been erased from media memory. We were back at the usual point on the dial, where Europe was another country that we did not trust. And the Nice summit grows ever closer.

The Eurosceptic press was in full cry. "How dare you preach to us about patriotism," wrote Frederick Forsyth in the Mail, ranting at the prime minister. "Memories of 1066 mean we cannot trust our neighbours from hell," the Express billed a piece reflecting on the Prescott Voynet spat.

We are looking in this column each week at the way the press reflects the most important issue of our time, the one that destroys prime ministers and unseats governments, the one that fuels xenophobia and nostalgia alike. Europe. And as another crunch summit approaches, we are asking if sensible debate exists in our newspapers, if reason can exist amid the hysteria.

So we turn to the Sun. Here is the newspaper so often accused of ignoring or trivialising serious issues giving nearly a page to the "battlegrounds of EU summit". The hardest thing is to explain issues as arcane as constitutional change in the EU to a Sun audience. Yet, admittedly from its known Euro-sceptic position, the Sun took its readers through the major Nice issues.

For those who hold dear John Birt's famous "mission to explain" dictum it was The Times which this week served the European debate well. In a three-day, six page preview to the Nice summit, it explained in great and accessible detail the issues. Qualified majority voting and the veto, enlargement and the size of the commission, the voting strengths of individual member states, were all laid out. Issues not personalities, description not propaganda. Was it read?

One of the more significant stories of the week was the latest social attitudes survey, which found large class divides in support for Europe. The survey, as reported in the Financial Times, found only 8% of the working class supported the single currency, compared with 28% of the middle class.

Another was the entry into the pre-summit argument of the governor of the bank of England, Eddie George, which provided a classic illustration of how the Euro-agenda of different papers can influence the way they report the same event.

"Euro will hurt on pay and tax says bank boss" was the Mail's headline over a story that started: "Britain faces a return to the stark 1970s policies of high taxes and pay restraint if we join the Euro, Sir Eddie George warned yesterday." The Financial Times said of the same speech: "He said the use of fiscal policy instead of interest rates would involve recognition by people that their behaviour would have to be driven by the need to control inflation. Employees, for example, would be under pressure to moderate wage demands to avoid punishing tax rises."

But after all the scare stories about the European rapid reaction force, the assault on British sovereignty, and the embarrassment of John Prescott's altercation in the Hague, came the public's response. A Mori poll in the Times put the Labour lead over the Tories two points up at 15%. Europe in the spotlight, and Labour's co-ordinated offensive provoking a strong sceptic response has not damaged Labour at all. Will that be the case after next week's summit?

Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University
