fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Anoushka Shankar
fields.trailText: Anoushka Shankar
fields.body:
Anoushka Shankar, 19, is the daughter of sitar master Ravi Shankar. She grew up in London, New Delhi and California, and became her father's student aged nine. Still the only sitarist trained solely by Ravi, she made her performing debut at 13. She recently released her second album, Anourag.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?

Lots of travel and performing, lots of close friends and pets, and a wonderful man to go home to - that last part is a bit down the road.

What is your greatest fear?

Being lonely.

Which living person do you most admire?

My father - aside from being an incredible musician, he's also the most caring, loving, humorous man.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?

I lose my temper when I'm stressed.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?

It's difficult to have relationships with people who can't compromise.

What is your most unappealing habit?

People get really annoyed at how often I crack my fingers and my neck.

What makes you depressed?

Because of how much I travel, it's easy to make friends, but difficult to make close friends. So it hurts me when I grow away from people I've been close to, even though I know how natural that is - I never really get over it.

What is your favourite smell?

I love to smell the few people that I'm very close to. It's incredibly comforting.

What is your favourite fantasy?

I have dreams about flying really often. It took me until I was nine or 10 to realise that I couldn't actually fly! It still disappoints me, because I know the feeling so clearly.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?

Never, but I hate that sometimes I feel pressured to say, 'I love you, too'.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?

A driver's licence!

What would your motto be?

Live in the moment, love without holding back, and have a job you enjoy.

What keeps you awake at night?

Things I said that I didn't mean; things I should've said and didn't.

How would you like to be remembered?

I would hate for people to say that I didn't live up to my father's name. And, aside from music, I want people to look back and say they were happy to have known me.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?

You don't get away with hurting people: somehow or other it comes back to you.

webTitle: How to get a maggot excited

fields.headline: How to get a maggot excited
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
I'd never thought of the Spanish as mean before. After all, they make rioja (delicious), they invented tapas (yummy) and they advocate sleeping in the middle of the day (a great idea). Sherry and paella aside, Spanish equalled nice. But no longer. After watching Conquistadors (BBC2), I have come to a conclusion that no amount of finger food and fine wine can obscure: the Spanish are no better than the English.

That such emotions were triggered by Michael Wood retracing the bloody footsteps of Pizarro is testament to the programme's intelligent and lucid storytelling, its sense of spectacle, and detail and its simple drama.

Wood was a perfect guide, too: enthusiastic and sensitive, knowledgeable and entertaining. On a bewitching journey he traipsed from an island on the Pacific coast of South America where Pizarro rallied his supporters, through the peaks and valleys of Peru where the conquistadors first lulled the Incas then slaughtered them, to deep in Amazonia where the last of the Incan royals absconded to rebuild their civilisation.

Telling of empires risen and fallen, of conquerors and civilian casualties, of gods and monsters and men, Conquistadors was epic, sweeping and captivating. It carried us with the momentum of history while simultaneously instilling the hope that somehow history could be rewritten and that the victorious Spanish could become the vanquished and the Incas could claim back their land. This hope was folly but it remained nonetheless, buoyed by the news that the Spanish started fighting among themselves and that, deep in the jungle, the Incas who hadn't been enslaved or slaughtered built magnificent temples and palaces.

Their renaissance was not to be and nature, as she always does in the end, claimed their new settlement for herself.

Conquistadors' closing observation that Peruvians today still remember their ancestors in celebrations and ceremonies was both heartening and melancholy. Of an ancient civilisation, all that's left is funny brass bands, spangly hats and people kissing glaciers. But then, what else is there to do? Mourn the conquered of history forever? Wanting happy endings all the time is a real bugger. I blame fairy tales.

Part magic show, part nature programme and - for one week only - part cheer for the monarchy, The Animal Magic Show (BBC1) told the kids that "the royal family are really magic". As if to prove their point, Billy Nibbles (I bet he does) and Dominic Wood took us on a tour of the more regal of the animal kingdom in between rather rubbish tricks, even by the standards of a six-year-old.

There were the obvious lions whose attack of a zebra was described by Billy, himself a rabbit, with blase offhandness.

"The zebra's a goner. Oh well," he shrugged as children across the country shrieked in horror. "Bad luck for the zebra. At least the cubs won't go hungry."

He moved on to the queen scallop, which looked a bit like a battery-powered custard cream, leaping along the ocean floor to escape predators, followed by the king crab, which, Billy informed us, had been king of the sea for 65m years. Cue pictures of the helmet-like crab writhing in panic on its back, legs in the air, trying to right itself. It didn't look very regal. You'd think in all that time, evolution might have devised it a couple of springy appendages on its shell to help it when it was upside down.

Like humanity, nature is, for the most part, cruel. Testament to that, wolves have yet to devour Clarissa and the Countryman (BBC2). That means there is still one reason to watch this missed opportunity of a programme. That's if you don't have anything better to do with your time - such as lick the floor of an abattoir, or watch Barbara (ITV), which, amazingly, took five people to write.

This week, Clarissa and Posh Johnny were in Northern Ireland fiddling with maggots and meeting with priests. The priest had a passion for eels (which beats most priests' passion for altar boys) and the gruesome twosome were getting maggots excited "the traditional way", which promised some lurid vision but never delivered. Another unhappy ending.

As if to prove their point, Billy Nibbles (I bet he does) and Dominic Wood took us on a tour of the more regal of the animal kingdom in between rather rubbish tricks, even by the standards of a six-year-old. There were the obvious lions whose attack of a zebra was described by Billy, himself a rabbit, with blase offhandness. "The zebra's a goner. Oh well," he shrugged as children across the country shrieked in horror. "Bad luck for the zebra. At least the cubs won't go hungry." He moved on to the queen scallop, which looked a bit like a battery-powered custard cream, leaping along the ocean floor to escape predators, followed by the king crab, which, Billy informed us, had been king of the sea for 65m years. Cue pictures of the helmet-like crab writhing in panic on its back, legs in the air, trying to right itself. It didn't look very regal. You'd think in all that time, evolution might have devised it a couple of springy appendages on its shell to help it when it was upside down. Like humanity, nature is, for the most part, cruel. Testament to that, wolves have yet to devour Clarissa and the Countryman (BBC2). That means there is still one reason to watch this missed opportunity of a programme. That's if you don't have anything better to do with your time - such as lick the floor of an abattoir, or watch Barbara (ITV), which, amazingly, took five people to write. This week, Clarissa and Posh Johnny were in Northern Ireland fiddling with maggots and meeting with priests. The priest had a passion for eels (which beats most priests' passion for altar boys) and the gruesome twosome were getting maggots excited "the traditional way", which promised some lurid vision but never delivered. Another unhappy ending.

fields.headline: Snowdonia
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
One of the great unsung glories of Snowdonia is the meeting place of the Machno with the Conwy, deep in a rock chasm hidden from the general gaze by beech, oak and a scattering of introduced conifers, now magnificently mature. The other day we came down by Pandy Woollen Mill beside the thundering Machno. The river was swollen and brown with peat stain after heavy rain, but the mill is closed and awaiting a new owner, its looms silent until at least next spring.

We stood on the "new" bridge over the rebellious child of the sodden Conwy moors and looked downstream at the "Roman" bridge immediately downstream, now a slender arch of stone where pack horses once crossed. More than a century ago a grumpy farmer, sick of painters and sightseers trespassing to see the old bridge, attempted to demolish it. He removed the parapets, but the actual arch of this medieval relic defeated him - he abandoned his malicious scheme and what we see today is quaint, moss-covered and fern-hunt. There are plans to restore it.

A further 400 yards down the lane towards Betws-y-coed, a path to the right near an old flour mill leads to the very brink of the Machno Falls. They were white and foaming, plunging to a chocolate-coloured pool where no sensible dipper would be paddling now. But the finest is yet to come. A couple of hundred yards downstream the Machno gives up its identity as it is caught up by the Conwy and carried on for a short distance to be flung over the great rock step that creates the Conwy Falls. Here the combined waters, draining such a huge area of upland between Blaenau Ffestiniog and Ysbyty Ifan, crash below great trees and so down towards the narrow chasm that our Victorian forefathers christened Fairy Glen.

All this turbulent section of the Conwy and its tributaries, Machno and Lledr, were favourite subjects for some of the best 19th-century landscape artists, such as BW Leader and William mellor. To see the actual Fairy Glen, though, you must approach from the other, eastern bank and pay 50p at a stile. Woe betide anyone attempting to pass by without paying this wretched toll because one's offering is recorded automatically in a nearby outbuilding! Not all God's gifts come free, it seems.

fields.headline: How to...
fields.standfirst: win at sports day
fields.trailText: Children, the time to start training for the school sports day is now. Winning is everything. Your parents may have taken a day off work to see you run, and they don't want to see you limping in at the back of the field. Remember, mummy or daddy may have sacrificed an important meeting that would've helped pay off the mortgage on the house in which your bedroom and toys are.
fields.body:
Children, the time to start training for the school sports day is now. Winning is everything. Your parents may have taken a day off work to see you run, and they don't want to see you limping in at the back of the field. Remember, mummy or daddy may have sacrificed an important meeting that would've helped pay off the mortgage on the house in which your bedroom and toys are.

In the sprint, you can't just run really fast anywhere - you have to run in between those white lines. Why? Because the International Olympic Committee says so, that's why. If, halfway up the course, all the other children are in front of you, it really doesn't matter where you run, because mummy and daddy won't be hanging around at the finish line to see you humiliated.

In the egg-and-spoon race, the object is to get to the finishing post with your egg still on your spoon, not to see how many times you can drop it and pick it up. Other parents may find this cute and funny, but yours won't, and they're the ones with the keys to the front door.

Refereeing is often lax, even non-existent, in this event. So, even though you won't have time to glue your egg to your spoon, you can pick a spoon with greater concavity than others. Ask your mother for a soup ladle, if possible. When you find yourself neck and neck with other kids, simply put your thumb on your egg and run a bit faster. After all, no one's going to ask for a steward's enquiry because you're only a kid.

Children who are not naturally athletic are advised to focus on the three-legged race. Avoid teaming up with your best friend; he may have great toys, but in the co-ordination department he's a bit of a dork. Pick someone with the same leg-length as you and then walk quickly to school with him for the rest of term until lockstep becomes second nature.

If you're the big porky boy in the class, pick the weediest boy in your class to run with. Don't worry about his stride pattern or anything else. Just drag him along as fast as you can go. If you've tied your knots right, he will still be there at the finishing line.

School sports days often have a parents' race, too. This is different from kids' races and is not competitive. When your daddy finishes seventh or eighth, that is good. But console him with the fact that the other adults are in too much of a hurry and are probably showing off. If you have won your race and your daddy hasn't, don't mention sports day for a few weeks.

fields.headline: 'Hello, Yoko here...'
fields.trailText: A week in radio
fields.body:
Yes, yes, yes, Oscar Wilde did have a way with one-liners. Hard to miss that fact this week, with everyone irritatingly wheeling out their favourite Wildean epigrams to mark the centenary of his death. But what about the Ken Bruce show on Radio 2? Forget Oscar: Bruce was witty in Cleveland on Wednesday, a place so miserable - so the old joke goes - that you should head there if you are given only three months to live, as it will feel like five years.

Still, Bruce was a model of perkiness, despite the fact that the show was going out live at 4.30am local time. Coming from the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, which had opened specially for him in the middle of the night, it was a strange audio experience: Bruce, alone with lots of waxwork figures of people like Clappo and Chuck "Ding-a-Ling" Berry, surrounded by cases of memorabilia. Bruce stopped to do "a little air work" before the guitar used on the Eagles' Hotel California. "If nobody's looking, you could join me," he said with admirable flirtiness given the circumstances. It was hard not to.

It felt as if Bruce had been let loose in a toy cupboard at night, when the dollies and teddies of the world of rock might suddenly come to life. And so they did, at least by telephone. Duane Eddy called, burbling on about how he used a water tank to make music. Then, while Bruce inspected the controversial John Lennon exhibits (including the smashed and bloodstained glasses he was wearing the night he was shot), Yoko Ono called via the white telephone that sits in the museum. She calls once a fortnight, talks to whoever picks up the phone. "People are thrilled when I call," she said by way of an ice-breaker.

That may have something to do with the fact that she sounds on the howling-at-the-moon side of crackers. Ono does this curious little laugh, not unlike Michael Crawford as Frank Spencer, after each of her weird interjections. The phone, she begins, is "a talking sculpture". (Small strange laugh.) It's good to exhibit Lennon's things, she continues. "It's my new work! It's conceptual!" (Big strange laugh.) Bruce was bewildered and clearly hungered for some more air relief.

Pam Ayres has been out on the road, too, these past few weeks, as you might gather from the title of her series Pam Ayres Open Road (Radio 2). In the spirit of Thelma and Louise, almost, Ayres has roamed the land, stopping at places that are "special" to her. This week, it was the Welsh Valleys, with which she clearly has a complex love-hate relationship. Her first impression of the place at 16 was of "big black slagheaps" (and she has a winning way of saying "slagheaps"), but now it's green and lovely "like the Alps".

A chap explained that women were stopped from working the mines because there "was too much fornication" down below. Ayres changed the subject to the humiliation she met with on her last Welsh trip. She mentioned it several times in fact, so deeply has it scarred her. Invited to the Ebbw Vale Garden Festival in 1994, Ayres thought she might be opening proceedings, or doing the raffle at least. "I took my two boys," she said, ladling on the pathos. "Because of my accent they said, 'Stand in this pigsty and smile winsomely.'" One can only wonder what they might have asked of Yoko Ono.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: A drop of the hard stuff
fields.trailText: A drop of the hard stuff.
fields.body:
The subject The demon drink, C2H5OH, as applied in the kitchen.
The basics Alcohol is an optional extra in many dishes, an essential component in many others. When you need it, you really, really need it - for flavour, that is, not for its ability to fry your brains.
The details The Knowledge Alco-Cook Most Wanted list begins, naturally, with table wine. Whatever you're serving as a beverage will do, unless it's second-mortgage material. Where white wine is wanted, vermouth will do. Where red is read, remember that white can often step in with no loss other than colour. Second Most Wanted: something with a bit of sweetness. The Knowledge leans heavily on crème de cassis, young Madeira, and cheapissimo ruby port. Third MW: brandy. You don't need it often, but when you do need it, nothing else will do. Fourth: fino sherry in half-bottles; good sherry vinegar is sometimes a reasonable replacement. The Knowledge number-one rule of cooking with alcohol: if you find a recipe calling for a drink you've never drunk, turn the page. You'll never use the stuff again, and chances are it tastes like the stair carpet after kitty's been sick on it. Rule number two: don't cook with anything you wouldn't want to sip. It needn't be colossally costly, but neither should it stimulate the gagging reflex. This applies especially, of course, in those rare dishes (mostly sweet) where the alcohol forgoes heat treatment. Rule number three: after the booze has barged in, cook it until the taste of alcohol goes bye-bye. That's not why it's there. Interesting debate: the received wisdom holds that all alcohol burns off if you cook food long enough, but some say that it doesn't. This is only a problem if you're cooking for a recovering alcoholic - but then it matters a lot.
The easy way out Eh?
Where to buy Huh?

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: Auntie's eccentricities
fields.standfirst: Why should I give Gordon anything, anyway, after the way he has behaved'
fields.trailText: Why should I give Gordon anything, anyway, after the way he has behaved'
fields.body:
"Listen, Dulcie, that money your aunt gave you is yours - not his." Alice is delivering pep-talk. "Don't weaken! I know you. I'm doing the tarot for you as we speak, and I've never seen so many swords in my life. Ah! The Devil. You know what that means: you're your own worst enemy."

Distracted from Alice's insights by a sword-like pain originating between my shoulder blades and stabbing upwards to the roof of my mouth. Suspect it may be caused by traffic jam of pills I swallowed 10 minutes ago: Red Clover for the menopause, evening primrose for that primness that arrives in the evenings, magnesium and zinc to show solidarity with the metalworkers of southern Africa, and calcium to keep the azaleas at bay.

Ex-spouse has requested a meeting to discuss the aunt's eccentricities, though he is not yet aware of the most eccentric thing she has done recently - ie, slip me a cheque for £50,000. While I was away in St Ives, he was obliged to keep an eye on her and noticed her putting her purse in the fridge. When he pointed it out, she got quite ratty and called him Donald instead of Gordon. Donald was her elder brother, a bit of a bully, buried near Bannockburn. Though this is madness, yet there's method in it.

Elspeth is reading RSPB magazine and exclaiming alternately in joy and sorrow. "The Indian vulturrre is in crrrisis !" she cries in dismay. The British vulture, however, her nephew, is roosting in an adjacent armchair, biding his time. "I'm rrreassurrred about the crrrakes , dearrr ," aunt confides, "but worrrrrried about the twites." Suppose this is an ornithological aside, although it may refer to geriatric ailments.

Harriet walks in dressed from head to foot in black. She is scowling and wearing so much metal that she appears to embody the Industrial Revolution, only without the smoke. So far. "Where's my black lipstick, Mum?" she growls accusingly.

" Arrre you going out?" enquires aunt anxiously.

"Yeah, only babysittin', auntie, for Toby 'n' Rosie, they're ever so sweet 'n' cuddly," Harriet replies. Hope she will not puncture aforementioned infants.

Meeting is scheduled for after aunt's bedtime, which has become erratic. At 9.30pm, she puts RSPB magazine aside with a satisfied sigh, informs me the crossbills are nesting at Abernethy, and waddles off to her bed. I make her Ovaltine, and a pot of tea for Gordon and myself. Tea will put him off his guard. I am determined not to yield. Aunt gave me the money and, as Alice insisted, I should be proud of what I've already done for her, and of my commitment to her future.

March proudly into sitting room, where Gordon has been waiting. Why should I give him anything, anyway, after the way he has behaved? Impregnating a neighbour may be common among house sparrows, but though aunt is an ornithological enthusiast she has never shown much approval of his second family, who have thrown him out and acquired a younger and more attractive stepfather. Resolved not to reveal my nest egg, or, if cornered, not to concede a penny.

Unfortunately, ex-spouse has tossed so many newspapers and books down on to the floor beside the sofa that I trip over them and go flying. As the carpet looms up at me, I expect my past life to flash before my eyes, but instead only glimpse one of the book titles: The Death Of Nelson. As I hit the carpet, which, unluckily, is of the cheap, abrasive sort, I cannot help feeling that I am about to fall short of Nelson's heroic composure in extremis . Stinging pain in grazed knees and tender cheekbone suggest scabby legs and black eye will be on the menu for the next few days. The tea tray has abandoned its precarious equilibrium and become a steaming heap of shards. Ex-spouse stares stupidly at me from the sofa. "What the bloody hell are you playing at?" he enquires, as if my fall is an elaborate practical joke on my part, or chic new form of aerobics.

Gingerly clamber off the floor, uneasily aware that I seem to have re-activated the back and groin injury I sustained while moving the cooker in St Ives, in order to clean behind it. Make private vow never to go on self-catering holiday again, but then, if I manage to hold on to aunt's money, I could be receiving, instead of providing, room service from now on.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: The 11 wines that follow are all available at Oddbins - some are available only at this retailer, in fact - and their average rating is 17.5 points out of 20. Their average price is £8.67.
fields.body:
The 11 wines that follow are all available at Oddbins - some are available only at this retailer, in fact - and their average rating is 17.5 points out of 20. Their average price is £8.67.

You might well protest - 'Why didn't the fellow just make up the case and give us a 12th wine? - but this perfectly logical query can be answered only by saying that nothing is logical where Oddbins is concerned.

I'll open with a trebbiano (or ugni blanc, as the French, who mostly use it to distil into cognac, call the grape disdainfully). This is an unsung white grape, not inspirational of bardic extravagances, and so a specimen that costs £8.99 must have a lot going for it to rate 17 points. It does: Marramiero Altare Trebbiano d'Abruzzo 1998 is the liveliest trebbiano I've ever tasted. It has gorgeous wood integration, gently yoghurty, with complex, unfolding layers of rich fruit: marvellously classy stuff. Comte Cathare Le Parfait, a non-vintage Vin de Pays d'Oc blanc, is half this price at £4.49, but still shows superb balance of plump fruit and gently insistent acidity. Stylishly baked and finely sliced, with underlying warmth and generosity, it rates 16 points.

Petaluma Riesling Clare Valley 1999 (17.5 points, £9.49, Fine Wine Stores only), from Australia, has fantastic mineral acidity, and undertones with rich fruit reminiscent of gooseberry and limes. It has a wonderful texture, on the fat side perhaps, yet also refreshing, and is not only great drinking now but will age well for years. Another Australian is Cullen Sauvignon/Semillon Margaret River 1999 (18 points, £11.49, Fine Wine Stores only), which is about as elongated, as satisfying from nose to throat and as sexy as a young white wine from this continent gets. Complex, textured and majestically quaffable, this is serious, thought-provoking tippling. Heggies Viognier Eden Valley 1999 (18 points, £12.99, Fine Wine Stores only) also has to be pedestalled, for it is the fittest, finest, most delicious Australian viognier I've yet encountered - it can only be compared with the legendary (but often scandalously disappointing) exemplar, Condrieu, in a great year and from a scrupulously managed vineyard. This specimen of the viognier grape is smoky, richly peachy, apricotty and nutty and extremely classy, and it stretches itself across the tastebuds like the luxurious artefact it is.

On the red side at Oddbins, Torres Atrium Merlot 1998 (18 points, £6.99), from Spain, is dignified, serene, deep, complex, severely deeply layered yet hugely quaffable. It has marvellous fruit, and is quite magical for the money. L'Ermitage Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998 (18.5 points, £6.99) is also extraordinary, offering a complete performance of stunning complexity (coffee, tar, blackberries, tobacco) and a tannically textured finish. Another remarkable wine for the money, it even has a label to write home about, which will impress anyone you wish to seduce with your taste and flair.

Domaine Clavel Copa Santa Coteaux du Languedoc 1998 (18 points, £8.99) has cough syrup texture, massive tannins (of tenacious depth and emulsified smoothness) and a superb layered finish. Peter Lehmann Cabernet Sauvignon Barossa 1998 (17.5 points, £7.99) is a masterclass in tannic tenacity with finesse, and a salutary lesson for all those Aussie winemakers for whom tannins are alien monsters to be shunned. The elegance of the fruit is not ruffled but enhanced by these tannins, which are finely balanced with the alcohol (the least appreciated aspect of red wine-making).

Bleasdale Frank Potts Langhorne Creek 1997 (17.5 points, £9.99) seems absurd for less than a tenner, but let us not remark on this to Mr Potts, as he may go gaga and treble his prices - at which point this wine would lose some of its attraction and competitiveness with Bordeaux. But then, Bordeaux was never so sensual, so spicy, so warm and so soft a spot as Langhorne Creek.

Finally, a whoppingly terrific rioja, a name not much given to greatness any more: Cosme Palacio y Hermanos 1998 (17 points, £6.99) is the savoury essence of how truly elegant and fine rioja can become when perfectly aged - although it is still young, it is packed with prime hedgerow fruit and gentle, savoury tannins of great smoothness.

fields.headline: A place in the sun
fields.standfirst: Your problem might be that damp patch on the ceiling. But just imagine you had a tropical hideaway all of your own . . .
fields.trailText: Your problem might be that damp patch on the ceiling. But just imagine you had a tropical hideaway all of your own . . .
fields.body:
Chris Blackwell's memories of Strawberry Hill, a Blue Mountains estate hovering 3,000ft above Kingston, Jamaica, go back a long way. "I used to come here for Sunday tea with my mother when I was a little boy, and I've always had a sentimental feeling about this place," says the entrepreneur and one-time owner of Island Records.

Strawberry Hill originated as an 18th-century coffee plantation, and Blackwell bought it in 1972 to use as a personal retreat. It was here in 1976 that his protégé, Bob Marley, recuperated from gunshot wounds after a politically motivated attempt on his life. In 1988, its Great House was destroyed by Hurricane Gilbert.

Blackwell began planning to develop the estate with a traditional Jamaican planter-style building at its centre. To do this, he hired architect Ann Hodges, who had grown up in Jamaica and trained in London. She created a new spin on Jamaican traditional architecture, using vernacular pitched roofs, decorative fretwork and over-large roof eaves extended to a point of exaggeration, allowing guests to sit outdoors and remain comfortably dry during rainstorms.

The 12 guest cottages are modelled on traditional Jamaican chattel houses, and the interiors are also typical of the island. Furnishings include planter chairs and mahogany four-poster beds shrouded with muslin mosquito netting. Interiors are crisp and white, giving a contemporary feel to the neo-colonial, romantic style of the furniture.

Interiors and exteriors are embellished with clever fretwork designs, which remind me of flourishes in a 30s Essex bungalow of my childhood, and make me wonder why this excellent and inexpensive device is not used more often, limited, as it is, only by the imagination. Whatever happened to the fret-saw?

As a result of Britain's 300-year colonisation of Jamaica, the island is dotted with impressive Georgian-style Great Houses, each the seat of a huge sugar cane plantation, and resembling the great haciendas of Latin America.

A smaller-scale Georgian building, Itopia, was originally the dower house to Cardiff Hall Great House, on the north coast. Surrounded by rainforest, Itopia is the home of author-director Perry Henzell, who directed the reggae movie, The Harder They Come, and his artist wife, Sally.

Itopia has been both family home and creative retreat since the Henzells discovered it more than 20 years ago. Perry has written several novels in the house, and it is the perfect retreat. There is no telephone, and drop-in visits are rare: situated in a rural area of maze-like lanes entirely unencumbered by street names or house labelling, it is almost impossible to find.

The Henzells christened the place Itopia, playing on the Rastafarian expression "I and I", which means "one with God". It is built of locally cut stone, and maximises the use of natural ventilation to keep everything cool. English-style sash windows are bordered by louvred openings that encourage air-flow, and the interior is open to the roof pitch to allow heated air to rise and the cooler air to stay at living level.

The house is decorated with a cheerfully eclectic mix of family furniture, local antiques and junk-shop finds accumulated over the years. The original plan was to repaint the interiors, but Sally fell in love with the mix of colours revealed as the old paint was stripped away. The richly decorative effect that the couple settled on was achieved by the unorthodox technique of scraping at the walls with a machete.

Colours - brilliant pinks, yellows and reds - are the predominant influence on the Pacific coast of Mexico, which boasts more than 2,000 miles of landscape, ranging from the dry desert of Baja California in the north to the states of Chiapas, Guerrero and Oazala in the south - a land of coconut palms, jungle and tropical humidity.

With their palapa, or thatched, roofs, and curved walls, houses of the Mexican Pacific have evolved a distinctive style. Thanks to the warm climate, it is possible to live outdoors throughout the year, with homes open to the elements. This living-with-nature lifestyle is a recent development, however. Until the 70s, international modernism was the style of choice in many Mexican coastal developments.

Then, in the mid-70s, Gloria Guinness and her husband, Loel, visited Acapulco and decided to build a holiday home. Searching for inspiration, Gloria noticed the indigenous thatched huts that adorned the local beaches. Together with a local architect, Mario Aldaco, she developed a new kind of resort house with a thatched palapa roof - an architecture without glass, with open-plan living areas.

Today, the spiritual home of palapa living is the elegant Costa Careyes, a tiny bay shielded by rocky headlands two hours' drive south of Puerto Vallarta. A village of colourful casitas (small houses) surrounds the harbour and a series of glamorous palapa-style houses edge the cliffs on either side, facing the ocean.

The festive Casa Dos Estrellas is a recent addition, reflecting the joie de vivre of its owners, actress (and former James Bond girl) Luciana Paluzzi and her movie producer husband, Michael Solomon. Designed by architect Manolo Mestre, it straddles a spectacular site on the southern headland of Careyes harbour, with sweeping 360-degree views of the coastline and numerous islets, the bay and the village of Costa Careyes.

Interiors of the Solomon house are bright and colourful, matching the hues of the bougainvillaea on the terraces, with Mestra-designed wood and rattan tables and chairs grouped in front of built-in banquettes. Sleeping platforms, shelves and counters are similarly built-in, giving the place a streamlined feel. "Cured profiles everywhere are good feng shui," says Mestre. "Curves between the floor, the walls, and the ceilings keep the energies flowing. Loel Guinness used to talk about his bedroom in Acapulco, also with the same curvatures: 'There is no place where the eye stops, allowing you to dream as you go to sleep.'"

Various decorative treatments reinforce the indigenous folklore theme. Floors are decorated with flowing patterns of inset pebbles. In the guest bedroom, stencilled patterns surrounding the bed echo those on primitive painted ceramic pots.

Mestre's portfolio also includes a collaboration with Isabel Goldsmith on her 90-acre Las Alamandas estate that she inherited from her grandfather, Antenor Patiño, in 1978. Patiño had major plans for Las Alamandas, intending to create a resort as grand as his earlier creation, Las Hadas, in Acapulco.

When Isabel took over Las Alamandas, situated on a lonely stretch of the Pacific coast and a 90-minute drive south of Puerto Vallarta, it consisted of an infrastructure of unpaved roads cut into the jungle, a landing strip for small planes and little else. She fell in love with this remote paradise with its perfect half-mile long beach, its lagoons rich in wildlife and its setting of low hills covered in trees and cacti.

She had no intention, however, of creating a miniature Acapulco. Instead, working first with architect Gabriel Orosco, and later Mestre after Orosco's death, she concentrated on building a small group of villas that friends might visit. Using her own interpretation of the vibrant colours of Mexico, Isabel created a festive mood for the place, together with an architecture which is unashamedly romantic.

The rooms are furnished in the folklore-style that Isabel loves, with indigenous rustic wood furniture including local wood and pigskin equipal chairs. Mestre designed four-poster beds made with local timber. Upholstering and fabrics are simple, woven in Mexico.

Back in Careyes, La Quebrada was designed by Italian architect and restaurateur Duccio Ermenegildo as a family home, although it is now owned by an English pop musician. It sits serenely on a cliff near the harbour with a 180-degree view of the Pacific - reminding the architect of the Amalfi coast. Ermenegildo is fond of visual surprises, and this house reveals itself stage by stage.

"I wanted there to be a sense of discovery," he says. The house is screened from the private street by high walls, as is the curved entry path that leads to a small piazza with a fountain. From here, the thatched roof of the 36ft-high living-and-dining room palapa and the separate bedroom tower reveal themselves. Between them, a narrow, stepped path edged with palms descends to the front terrace. Here, the senses are fully awakened, for beyond the living areas is a cascade of steps opening on to a vast panorama of blue - the ocean, the pool and the sky.

Ermenegildo has taken the usual Careyes look in a more rigorous modernist direction. "My dream was to marry minimalism with exotic local materials." The result, painted the orange of the poinciana flower, its edges defined by sinuous curves, is sensual and festive.

Concrete was used in the construction, and its organic properties are utilised for built-in banquettes in the living areas and bedrooms. The bathrooms have tubs moulded from a mixture of powdered marble, granite chips and cement, which was sanded and then waxed to give it a velvety-smooth finish. The kitchen is the exception to his idea of minimalism-meets-exotic local materials, and is built to gourmet standards. But what else would you expect from the owner of two of the most successful restaurants in Mexico City?

 Tropical Houses, by Tim Street-Porter, is published by Thames & Hudson at £29.95. To order a copy for the special price of £25.95, freephone 0800 3166102 or send your order, with a cheque payable to The Guardian, to Freepost Books, LON 3590, London W3 6BR.

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: The US election cliffhanger made me realise how entwined our cultures are, so I decided to celebrate Thanksgiving - à deux, because Migraine Alan is back (he still limps a bit, but otherwise he's made a full recovery).
fields.body:
The US election cliffhanger made me realise how entwined our cultures are, so I decided to celebrate Thanksgiving - à deux, because Migraine Alan is back (he still limps a bit, but otherwise he's made a full recovery).

I found delicious recipes for turkey with herbal rub, jalapeño cornbread stuffing, guilt-free gravy, scalloped potatoes, and pumpkin-and-praline pie at www. holidays.net/thanksgiving, and I got a fabulous organic turkey from www.foodferry.co.uk.

While chopping onions, I removed my contacts to cry freely, but then I couldn't find them again. Fumbling around, I managed to prepare everything and lay the table. The bell rang just as I was zipping up my slinky Versace gown. Half-seeing Alan's sweet face made me yearn for him even more . . . We sipped champagne and exchanged sweet nothings; the atmosphere became really charged. I asked him to bring in the turkey and carve - the first of his manly duties that evening - while I lit the candles.

I thought I had fitted candles into the Murano glassholders, but the half-seen creamy cylinders on a shelf turned out to be something quite different: the left-over Big Bertha, Royal Jewels and other fireworks I had ordered from www.Kaboomfireworks.com for Guy Fawkes Night. In a second, my loft was a riot of comets, shooting stars and fireballs in all the colours of the rainbow. Crazed by the explosions, Migraine Alan flung the turkey out of the window and fled. By the time the fire brigade arrived, I was alone again. Luckily, the damage was not as serious as I had thought, and one of the firemen was really cute. He offered to come back to give me some fire-protection advice. I pretended I'd never visited www.london-fire.gov.uk, and therefore knew nothing on the subject.

webTitle: The secret of a happy, healthy child

fields.headline: What's the secret of a happy, healthy child?
fields.standfirst: An interest in cooking helps, says Joanna Blythman.
fields.trailText: As soon as my 11-year-old spotted Easy Peasy Sweetie Pie, she jumped on it with a fervour generally reserved for the latest Harry Potter. "Is that a book for me? A baking book?" She couldn't wait to get into the kitchen.
fields.body:
As soon as my 11-year-old spotted Easy Peasy Sweetie Pie, she jumped on it with a fervour generally reserved for the latest Harry Potter. "Is that a book for me? A baking book?" She couldn't wait to get into the kitchen.

But baking has always had a spellbinding appeal for children. I, too, spent hours producing idiosyncratically-sized rock cakes with burnt currants that cooled within minutes to the consistency of their name. Baking is the ideal occupation to while away hours of childhood boredom.

I'm not talking about stereotypical children's recipes, such as melting cheap and nasty cooking chocolate and topping it with Smarties. That's too fast, and the results make you sick. We can learn pretty young that, as long as there is flour, sugar, butter, and eggs in the house, plus a helpful adult with a basic recipe on tap, you can produce something good to eat. Gradually, you realise that the results cost you nothing and taste a lot better than what you spend your pocket money on at the sweet shop.

You make the connections about cooking techniques without being taught them explicitly: making a scone is pretty much like making pastry, or even a banana loaf. A cr pe is just a pancake of a runnier consistency made in a non-stick pan. How to use the cooker, the scales, a whole batterie de cuisine? You learn it on the hoof.

No one appreciates that more intuitively than the author of Easy Peasy Sweetie Pie, Mary Contini, a director of the celebrated Edinburgh delicatessan Valvona & Crolla, where she also holds classes and tastings, teaching children how to cook and appreciate good food. Contini believes that the modern child can be weaned off the junk-food diet, and that the key is to tap in to their receptiveness to culinary education. Not only does she want them to like tomatoes, say, but she also hopes to see them revel in the differences between green Camone, cherry, and plump Sardinian vine varieties - and to have a favourite balsamic vinegar or olive oil to go with them.

The key, she says, is getting children interested in the kitchenprocess: "Cooking empowers children to understand the importance of their diet and the real pleasure they can have from making and sharing food." Her first book, Easy Peasy (which was co-authored with Pru Irvine), is a brilliant attempt to do just that, engaging kids with mainly savoury real cooking, not dumbed-down, in an accessible, appealing way.

There is a wide choice of cookbooks for kids on the market, but they all make the same mistakes: the style is a toe-curling, adult attempt to communicate with kids, employing an "I'm one of you" tone; or there are dishes that look delicious in the pictures but that, in reality, taste revolting; or they are full of fiddly food-stylist creations, such as jelly castles and marshmallow forts, that in the hands of an amateur, however enthusiastic, end up looking like something that's been run over.

Contini's books, by contrast, have adult-standard recipes presented with a spin: a simple pound cake becomes Can't Go Wrong Cake; a wholefoodie granola is reinvented as Crunchy Munchies; shortbread is reborn as Stabby Stabby Biscuits. The language is confidence-building, you-can-do-it stuff. Kids lap it up.

But won't nutritionists baulk at all that fat and sugar? Contini is unrepentant, confessing to a sweet tooth of her own. "Baking and making delicious drinks and treats can be a great incentive to get kids into the kitchen. If they are normal kids, they'll be scoffing chocolate, crisps and spurious concoctions of sugared drinks throughout the day, anyway."

Contini sums up her approach thus: "Better A Honey Bunny [carrot muffin] and an Easy Freezy Lemon Lush [lemonade slush] than a Mars bar and a bottle of Sunny Delight. So, let's get them cooking their own treats and learning what goes into them. After that, it will be a natural progression to start cooking other things."

Christmas could provide the ideal opportunity to start

fields.headline: On the rack
fields.standfirst: Malcolm Gluck offers vintage advice : never judge a wine by its cover
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck offers vintage advice : never judge a wine by its cover.
fields.body:
Mr Chutten of Leicester wonders whether I have tasted any of the wines that Aldi sells. Mr Chutten is a brave man. To put this question to a wine scribe is like asking Marco Pierre White what he thinks of the ketchup at McDonald's. But then, I am not a wine scribe - I am a wine critic - and so the answer, Mr Chutten, is just one: I have tasted just the one Aldi wine, was very impressed (as I shall reveal in a moment), and I would like to try them all in due course. Indeed, I would also like to include Aldi in my regular Superplonk column and my annual wine guide.

So, what is Aldi? It is an acronym, formed from the name Albrecht Discount. It is a cash-and-carry operation, originally from Germany, which now has some 250 UK branches in which customers either fork out hard dosh or use a debit card - I am told that Aldi cashiers are so "highly trained" that they memorise all the prices. This in contrast to our other supermarkets, which rely entirely on bleeping machines to do this part of the job; and all their cashiers wear tags on their jumpers, presumably so that they don't forget their own names. But then, supermarkets can carry ranges offering more than 500 wines, whereas Aldi, I note from the colour brochure that Mr Chutten thoughtfully sent with his letter, has just 33.

One of which is an Alsace Arthur Metz 1999. To regard the bottle is to examine an elegant construct of lush, green glass that is embossed with a meaningless, but nonetheless impressive, heraldic emblem below which is an ogive label with pointillist gold specks and typography of gothic variety.

Somebody has obviously put an awful lot of thought into that packaging - as they have the fruit inside the bottle, which is a traditional Alsatian recipe (most usually pinot blanc, riesling, chasselas, sylvaner, and muscat) called Edelzwicker in German, or "noble blend". And that it is, being soft and simply delicious, carrying hints of melon, peach and nuts, with the dry-sided peachiness carrying on to the finish. It rates 15.5 points and costs - and this is another rather remarkable thing about this wine - all of £2.99. It is a marvellously fitting wine for parties, those affairs where we all put on false fronts, because it looks and tastes as if it costs a great deal more than it does.

The wine's manufacturer is the Arthur Metz company, one of Alsace's largest producers, which is owned by an even larger outfit called Grands Chais de France. This might suggest that the wine may be lacking a little in individuality, but it is indisputably Alsatian in aroma, texture and feel, although it is not at all complex or fine.

I am ashamed to admit that I did not acquire my bottle of the Alsace 1999 from a visit to an Aldi store, but rather got it through the post, sent by the company's PR outfit, Clarke Associates, for which I must thank them.

I thank Mr Chutten, too, who also expresses an interest in knowing what Aldi's "Special Wines" are like. So do I, sir, so do I. I will wait to see what comes through the post next and report back

fields.headline: A brush with the past
fields.standfirst: Just suppose the cities of LA and San Francisco hated each other so much they went to war . . . In his epic paintings, the artist and satirist Sandow Birk has chronicled the battles that might have been - with Pepsi logos and Mickey Mouse on the frontline.
fields.trailText: Just suppose the cities of LA and San Francisco hated each other so much they went to war . . . In his epic paintings, the artist and satirist Sandow Birk has chronicled the battles that might have been - with Pepsi logos and Mickey Mouse on the frontline.
fields.body:
How many people can remember the Great War of the Californias? Initially known as the War Of The Cities, it lasted for seven months, left 20,000 dead and saw hand-to-hand combat from Lake Tahoe to Tijuana. One of its heroes was a Mexican immigrant labourer with a bad back, and one of its bravest units was composed of 11-year-olds. It pitched Los Angeles against San Francisco, and more than 3 million Californians took up arms in defence of their cities.

It was also the first war in which the battleships were sponsored by Visa and Mastercard, in which a gay brigade marched behind a rainbow flag and in which one of the generals greeted the final peace agreements with the words "make it a tequila with lime".

Fortunately, for those who may have only a dim recollection of the war or who wonder if they have ever heard of it at all, it has now been commemorated in all its horror or heroism in the exhibition, In Smog And Thunder, Historical Works From The Great War Of The Californias. It pays tribute to those unsung combatants who made the ultimate sacrifice defending the Getty Centre or who perished in the assault on Telegraph Hill in San Francisco, a battle that would later be known as Bloody Telly.

The war itself took place not so much on the burning freeways of LA or beneath the fog shrouding the Golden Gate bridge, but in the imagination of Sandow Birk, a 35-year-old artist from Long Beach. Over a period of years he has taken every form of war art, from the epic paintings of Goya, Delacroix and Jacques-Louis David to the recruitment posters of the first world war, to create an 80-piece exhibition illustrating an imaginary war between the two great, growling rival Pacific coast cities of LA and San Francisco.

Birk's next Big Idea - painting all the prisons of California in the style of the great landscape artists - also uses classical and traditional art forms to deliver the sort of edgy, contemporary message that might otherwise be shunned. His work has also opened up a discussion on the "museumification" of America, where events or people are treated with a solemnity that they may not always merit. But first, to the War.

As a "southlander", Birk was always puzzled on his trips to San Francisco to encounter the deep loathing felt by many in the Bay Area for LA, which was seen as vulgar, bloated, exploitative, Disneyfied, uncultured, greedy and smoggy. While Angelenos did not feel quite the same visceral hatred for their northern relative, there was a simmering disdain for San Francisco as prissy, old-fashioned, pleased-with-itself and foggy. What if they took this mutual dislike to its logical conclusion, pondered Birk, and declared war?

So Birk took his idea to its logical conclusion and commemorated just such a war in a series of paintings in the style of the great classical artists' renditions of famous battles and retreats. He has taken all the iconography of war, the etchings and stiff military portraits and patriotic posters from Napoleonic times to the Falklands, and used them for his own fictional battlefields and heroes, from General James Walker, "who had lost his virginity unsatisfactorily at a Grateful Dead concert in his teens and despised the City [San Francisco] ever since", to the dashing young Colonel Don Ho Park, who was followed loyally by the WeHo Boys from West Hollywood, "leather chaps, manly men, who needed no uniforms". And who can forget Captain Chun Yeong Chang's battalion of 11-year-old computer programmers, or the hemp farmers of Big Sur, who joined the battle only because they feared that the approaching troops were members of the Drugs Enforcement Administration out to trash their crops? From Lieutenant Quincy Salino, sabre drawn and charging forward on a Ducati motorcycle, to the Great Battle of Los Angeles, every key participant and event is recorded.

The exhibition is accompanied by a soundtrack on a CD in which the battles are vividly recreated with the sound of gunfire and martial music. The attention to detail has its own epic scale. The LA cavalry horses in the battles have Nike swooshes on their flanks, one poster appeals for "porno for our men in camp and down there", and twin LA battleships are named the Richard M Nixon and the Bebe Rebozo. Hovering above the struggle are the two muses of the city - for LA, a pregnant Latina holding a skateboard and an Oscar; for San Francisco, an Asian woman in 501 Levis, a tie-dyed T-shirt and a SF Giants baseball cap.

Shown this autumn in its final and full version in Laguna Art Museum, in Laguna Beach, south of Los Angeles, the exhibition has won the sort of effusive plaudits for Birk that must have been quietly gratifying to those who have been buying his paintings - they include actor Nicolas Cage, Anthony Kiedis of the Red Hot Chili Peppers and Brazilian pop star Caetano Veloso. Now the exhibition is due to head north to Sonoma, where Birk's renditions of the great sea battles and the hand-to-hand combat on the freeways can be studied by the locals there. The bold nature of the venture has struck a nerve in the sometimes complacent art world of southern California.

Art critic Marcia Tanner wrote of it: "Revealing truth through fiction is the artist's task, and Birk challenges the spectacle with a counter-spectacle of his own. He treads on sensitive ground here. We Americans are sentimental about our relatively shallow past even as we trash it. We tend to exaggerate and glorify what little history we do have and fabricate what we lack." So it is seen as appropriate that Birk should use the form of war museums - what Umberto Eco called "cathedrals of iconic reassurance" - to tell his tale. "Like all good satirists, Birk's underlying intentions are serious," wrote Claudine Ise of the UCLA/Armand Hammer Museum.

In the meantime, another equally provocative and imaginative body of work is being assembled by Birk in LA: the prisonisation of California. Stunned to discover that California now jails a higher percentage of its population than anywhere else in the world, Birk embarked on the project of visiting all 32 of the jails in the state. He is painting them all in the style of landscape artists such as Joseph Turner and John Constable, so that the eye is drawn to what looks like a conventionally-rendered idyllic rural scene only to spot the jail buildings somewhere in the background.

The artist behind these prolific and seriously mischievous enterprises is the son of a car industry father and teacher mother, who grew up in the sunny southlands and looks more surfer than satirist, not least because he is almost as dedicated to surfing - and as good at it - as he is to art. One of the main reasons for having his studio in the slightly run-down Latino and Cambodian area of Long Beach is that it is not far from the waves of Huntington Beach and San Pedro.

After starting his art training at what is now the Otis College of Art and Design in LA, Birk dropped out and headed for Brazil, where he survived for two years by making surfboards and art-designing a surfing magazine; he is a specialist in the lamination of surfboards. But he returned to his studies in 1984 and, as part of an exchange programme, went to study first in Paris and then at the Bath Academy of Art in Corsham, which he remembers as a village "with little stone walls and fields and sheep".

He chose Bath mainly because of its proximity to surfing beaches: "We would travel out to the Gower Peninsula and then across the cow fields and go surfing." After two years of conventional art studies, he liked the freedom at the academy: "The school itself was excellent, probably the best I went to. Basically, they gave you a room to paint in and let you do what you wanted, and they had all these professional artists come around and talk to you and steer you. It was great, it was super-liberating."

There were two other side-benefits of studying in Paris and England. The first was the chance to visit the Louvre every day and, when in London, the Tate: "The big romantic 19th-century salon painting was super-impressive to me." He liked George Stubbs's horse paintings and Turner's seascapes, as well as the British war artists, whose work he was later to use as inspiration. The second bonus was the opportunity to skateboard beneath the Eiffel Tower, around the fountains of the Place de La Concorde and along the South Bank.

Birk returned to LA to finish his studies and rented a store-front studio in South Central, the heart of the city's black community. Inspired by the title of Charles Dickens's A Tale Of Two Cities, he catalogued the gang battles of the time between the Crips and the Bloods, the drive-by shootings, the sudden explosions of violence. By chance, his first exhibition opened just three weeks before the LA riots of 1992, which came in response to the acquittal of four white police officers for the beating of Rodney King. Birk's work was suddenly seen to have a prescient resonance and people assumed that, because of his South Central address, his themes and his ambiguous name, he was black. At least one would-be collector who made boyz in the hood-type films decided not to invest after discovering that Birk was white.

Birk's next project will be to take the Rake's Progress by William Hogarth - whose work he loves - and use it to tell the story of Rafael Perez, the corrupt LAPD officer who was caught stealing cocaine from a police locker, decided to inform on his former colleagues in return for a sentence of five years, and is now the centre of the biggest corruption scandal in the city's history. Perez's revelations about shooting unarmed gang members, planting weapons and recycling cocaine have shocked the city and led to more than 100 cases being reopened and an as yet unknown number of officers facing charges. Now he will be immortalised by Birk.

Birk has had some criticism of his work, however. "Some have said that my stuff is technically not up to the art that I am copying - which is true - and one said I was being flippant and shallow, which I don't think I am being."

The idea of a war between LA and San Francisco need not be seen as exclusively Californian, because it taps all the resentments between competitive cities; it is not hard to imagine, say, an angry Liverpool invading London, Glasgow laying waste to Edinburgh or Sydney sacking Melbourne. But who actually emerged as victor? "I never really say who won. I think of the whole project in terms of art history, while other people think in terms of the politics. Part of my intention was to play on the idea of the museum. They don't explain everything to you in a museum - you're supposed to know what happened when you go into the Gettysburg museum - so I wanted to use that attitude." What is clear is that Tijuana, the bad-boy town just south of the border, eventually comes to the rescue of LA.

"Tijuana has such a bad reputation that I like to bring it in often. There is the whole anti-Mexican thing, keeping them out, so I just thought it would be so cool to bring them all in suddenly. The people we most look down on would be the ones to save us. Somehow in the end the underdog would win and Tijuana would be the new capital of southern California."

He has also gradually come to explore the "museumification" of America, a country which has museums for everything from lingerie (Fredericks's Lingerie Museum in Hollywood ) to newspapers (the Newseum in Arlington, Virginia) and Tolerance (the Museum of Tolerance in Los Angeles.) "It's like America is trying to build a history where there isn't one; they're trying to build a history where things are only 10 years old," says Birk, who exudes the sort of sunny charm that befits someone who carries a surfboard under one arm and an easel under the other. "There is a museum for every single president, 42 museums or something; as soon as you become president, the house you were born in becomes a museum. I've been driving around California a lot looking at these prisons and all these little towns are so grasping at anything. There's 'the artichoke capital', the 'more flowers than anywhere' place, the museum of mining."

He says he is often asked what other contemporary artists he admires, and he never knows what to say. "Should I say Damien Hirst? I think that guy gets enough publicity! I haven't seen his stuff, but I like what he's doing, and I want to see one of the cows. In Los Angeles, Ed Rusche is consistently good and Vernon Fisher from Texas."

Maybe in 100 years' time, the Great War Of The Californias will have its permanent home in a museum and will be earnestly studied by students uncertain of whether it was true that Silicon Valley secretly betrayed its neighbours in San Francisco or whether Las Vegas really declined to assist LA but instead offered the desperate General Gomez "a coupon for three free spins at our $10 roulette". And Sandow Birk will be puzzling the art historians as they try to work out how galleons had Visa logos on their sails in the 90s and whether the third battalion of the LA brigades was really led by "a struggling actress from Fresno . . . hoping for the starring role that had always eluded her" .

One of the main reasons for having his studio in the slightly run-down Latino and Cambodian area of Long Beach is that it is not far from the waves of Huntington Beach and San Pedro. After starting his art training at what is now the Otis College of Art and Design in LA, Birk dropped out and headed for Brazil, where he survived for two years by making surfboards and art-designing a surfing magazine; he is a specialist in the lamination of surfboards. But he returned to his studies in 1984 and, as part of an exchange programme, went to study first in Paris and then at the Bath Academy of Art in Corsham, which he remembers as a village "with little stone walls and fields and sheep". He chose Bath mainly because of its proximity to surfing beaches: "We would travel out to the Gower Peninsula and then across the cow fields and go surfing." After two years of conventional art studies, he liked the freedom at the academy: "The school itself was excellent, probably the best I went to. Basically, they gave you a room to paint in and let you do what you wanted, and they had all these professional artists come around and talk to you and steer you. It was great, it was super-liberating." There were two other side-benefits of studying in Paris and England. The first was the chance to visit the Louvre every day and, when in London, the Tate: "The big romantic 19th-century salon painting was super-impressive to me." He liked George Stubbs's horse paintings and Turner's seascapes, as well as the British war artists, whose work he was later to use as inspiration. The second bonus was the opportunity to skateboard beneath the Eiffel Tower, around the fountains of the Place de La Concorde and along the South Bank. Birk returned to LA to finish his studies and rented a store-front studio in South Central, the heart of the city's black community. Inspired by the title of Charles Dickens's A Tale Of Two Cities, he catalogued the gang battles of the time between the Crips and the Bloods, the drive-by shootings, the sudden explosions of violence. By chance, his first exhibition opened just three weeks before the LA riots of 1992, which came in response to the acquittal of four white police officers for the beating of Rodney King. Birk's work was suddenly seen to have a prescient resonance and people assumed that, because of his South Central address, his themes and his ambiguous name, he was black. At least one would-be collector who made boyz in the hood-type films decided not to invest after discovering that Birk was white. Birk's next project will be to take the Rake's Progress by William Hogarth - whose work he loves - and use it to tell the story of Rafael Perez, the corrupt LAPD officer who was caught stealing cocaine from a police locker, decided to inform on his former colleagues in return for a sentence of five years, and is now the centre of the biggest corruption scandal in the city's history. Perez's revelations about shooting unarmed gang members, planting weapons and recycling cocaine have shocked the city and led to more than 100 cases being reopened and an as yet unknown number of officers facing charges. Now he will be immortalised by Birk. Birk has had some criticism of his work, however. "Some have said that my stuff is technically not up to the art that I am copying - which is true - and one said I was being flippant and shallow, which I don't think I am being." The idea of a war between LA and San Francisco need not be seen as exclusively Californian, because it taps all the resentments between competitive cities; it is not hard to imagine, say, an angry Liverpool invading London, Glasgow laying waste to Edinburgh or Sydney sacking Melbourne. Part of my intention was to play on the idea of the museum. They don't explain everything to you in a museum - you're supposed to know what happened when you go into the Gettysburg museum - so I wanted to use that attitude." What is clear is that Tijuana, the bad-boy town just south of the border, eventually comes to the rescue of LA. "Tijuana has such a bad reputation that I like to bring it in often. There is the whole anti-Mexican thing, keeping them out, so I just thought it would be so cool to bring them all in suddenly. The people we most look down on would be the ones to save us. Somehow in the end the underdog would win and Tijuana would be the new capital of southern California." He has also gradually come to explore the "museumification" of America, a country which has museums for everything from lingerie (Fredericks's Lingerie Museum in Hollywood ) to newspapers (the Newseum in Arlington, Virginia) and Tolerance (the Museum of Tolerance in Los Angeles.) "It's like America is trying to build a history where there isn't one; they're trying to build a history where things are only 10 years old," says Birk, who exudes the sort of sunny charm that befits someone who carries a surfboard under one arm and an easel under the other. "There is a museum for every single president, 42 museums or something; as soon as you become president, the house you were born in becomes a museum. I've been driving around California a lot looking at these prisons and all these little towns are so grasping at anything. There's 'the artichoke capital', the 'more flowers than anywhere' place, the museum of mining." He says he is often asked what other contemporary artists he admires, and he never knows what to say. "Should I say Damien Hirst? I think that guy gets enough publicity! I haven't seen his stuff, but I like what he's doing, and I want to see one of the cows. In Los Angeles, Ed Rusche is consistently good and Vernon Fisher from Texas." Maybe in 100 years' time, the Great War Of The Californias will have its permanent home in a museum and will be earnestly studied by students uncertain of whether it was true that Silicon Valley secretly betrayed its neighbours in San Francisco or whether Las Vegas really declined to assist LA but instead offered the desperate General Gomez "a coupon for three free spins at our $10 roulette". And Sandow Birk will be puzzling the art historians as they try to work out how galleons had Visa logos on their sails in the 90s and whether the third battalion of the LA brigades was really led by "a struggling actress from Fresno . . . hoping for the starring role that had always eluded her" .

fields.headline: Make merry
fields.standfirst: Don't head down to the deli for your stocking fillers this year. Some homemade fudge or a jar of chutney makes the perfect gift, says Jeremy Lee.
fields.trailText: Don't head down to the deli for your stocking fillers this year. Some homemade fudge or a jar of chutney makes the perfect gift, says Jeremy Lee.
fields.body:
Who kept the pomander - you know, that orange stuck with myriad cloves, which came wrapped in a little gold box and then had the wardrobe reeking long after Christmas? Next to the accursed potpourri, nothing in the line of homemade Yuletide gifts causes quite so much nostril abuse as the pomander. It made sense in the great days of Versailles, when the smell of that sprawling palace was so pungent that it would hit the nostrils miles before you clapped eyes on the place - but these days?

Before I am strung up as a killjoy, let me say that I've got nothing against the idea of the DIY Christmas present. The tradition of giving a little something that is pretty and personal is an honourable one, going back to the times when there was not a great deal of pretty at all, when style and taste were as distant as the moon, except for small pockets of resistance in such shops as Elizabeth David and Habitat. Armagnac was rare, Pruneaux Fourées, from the Maison Sabat in Tours, were hard to come by, and olive oil was as exotic as myrrh.

Nowadays, things are quite different, but price and indifferent quality make a mockery of much that is sold at this time of year. The delicatessens with those bottles containing floating twigs, leaves and berries, redolent of a drowned witch, take the biscuit. Is it really so difficult simply to buy a good olive oil, and then drop a chilli in it to make your very own Olio Santo?

No, there's no need to be grand when it comes to the homemade Christmas present. The smallest gesture may make the deepest impression. When I rang my Mum to ask for a good recipe for fudge, or tablet, both of us simultaneously recalled the wee shop in Tobermory on the Isle of Mull, with its tiny windows full of bags of fudge in various flavours. It was a small shop, quite different from the celebrated Maison Sabat - which was so splendidly glamorous and its prunes so glorious - but my memory of eating those small squares of fudge that lovely afternoon in Tobermory is just as delightful and powerful. Happily, it is much easier to make fudge than it is to make the journey to Tobermory.

Mincemeat may be an obvious gift, but answer truthfully: when was the last time you had a delicious homemade mince pie, warm from the oven, as opposed to the dull commercial variety?

The same applies to the simple delight of plum chutney: a homemade chutney, as opposed to bought, has true texture, as the ingredients are chopped by hand and consequently require less cooking because there is less liquid to reduce. The added smell of spices and vinegar simmering together is very soothing during the pre-Christmas mayhem.

And talking of spices, how about a jar of your own spice mix? I have a dread of cabin fever after Christmas, when we all feel over- fed and the temptations of the sofa and the TV prove irresistible. Outside it may be cold and the mood bleak. Then the first whiff of spices cooking gently in a pot of stew or soup brings on a feeling of well-being among everyone, and normal service is quickly resumed.

A last small plea for fruit curd, as this is the time of year when all the citrus fruits are at their best. Also, curd can be put to plenty of uses, from topping a steamed fruit pudding, to filling a tart case, to spreading on hot buttered toast. Clementines are a favourite fruit of mine, and while the resulting curd may not have the resulting zing of one made with lemon, it nevertheless has a soft deliciousness all of its own.

Mincemeat
The blending of spices mixed through dried fruits, even the more mediocre varieties, is one of the more pleasurable jobs in the kitchen and can be done, advisedly, as early on in the winter as possible. It is worth noting that this lovely preserve is a treat to be savoured throughout the whole season, rather than simply at Christmas. A little fruit-filled pastry with a thin slice of spiced butter atop is as delightful in March as it is on Christmas Eve. Technically, it is almost indestructible, but to be on the safe side use it up within six months.

750g apples (Churchill's or Cox's)

400g stoneless raisins

400g currants

150g mixed peel

400g suet

400g sultanas

60g whole almonds

½ tsp grated nutmeg

½ tsp ground cinnamon

½ tsp ground mace

375g muscovado sugar

1 lemon

1 orange

5 tbsp dark rum

Peel and finely chop the apples. Place all the ingredients in a large bowl and mix together. Scrupulously clean and dry some jars, fill them with the mincemeat and seal. Label and date the jars, and store in a cool, dark place.

Chocolate biscuit cake

250g plain chocolate

250g unsalted butter

2 very fresh eggs

2 level dssp caster sugar

250g digestive biscuits

1 small handful walnuts

1 heaped tbsp glacé cherries

1 tbsp rum

Put the chocolate and butter in a bowl and place over a pan of simmering water to melt. Put the eggs and sugar in another bowl, place over simmering water and whisk until pale, thickened and cooked through. Break the biscuits into small pieces, and roughly chop the walnuts and cherries. Combine the chocolate and egg mixture, then add the nuts, cherries and rum. Decant into a lightly buttered tupperware dish, and pop into the fridge to set.

For an icing (optional):

60g plain chocolate

1 large tbsp of rum

60g unsalted butter

Melt the chocolate with the rum. Cut the butter into small pieces and beat into the chocolate, a little at a time. Pour the icing over the cake swiftly before it sets.

Fudge

1kg granulated sugar

125g unsalted butter

200ml fresh milk

½ vanilla pod, or 1 tsp vanilla extract

1 tin of condensed milk

Put the sugar, butter and milk in a saucepan, then set it over a low heat and stir until the sugar is completely dissolved. Pour in the condensed milk and vanilla pod (or extract) and turn up the heat. Boil for 20 minutes or so, then fold back your shirt sleeves and beat the fudge for 10 minutes with a wooden spoon. Under no circumstances do it in a machine. Pour into a lightly oiled tin and leave to set. Cut into squares, and store in an airtight tin.

Chocolate fudge
Most certainly of another time, one when there was such a thing as a sweetie shop.

290ml water

450g caster sugar

1 large can condensed milk

30g unsalted butter

110g very good dark chocolate

½ vanilla pod

1 pinch ground cinnamon (optional, but very good)

Scrupulously clean and dry two shallow baking tins. Lightly oil them. Split the vanilla pod and scrape the seeds from within. Put the seeds with the sugar and water in a pot and heat gently, stirring to ensure that the sugar dissolves before the mixture comes to the boil. Add the condensed milk and butter to the pot. Boil, stirring from time to time, until the mixture leaves the side of the pot, or for about 30 minutes. Remove the pan from the heat. Melt the chocolate in a bowl over warm water. Stir the melted chocolate into the fudge mix, combine thoroughly, then pour into the tins. Cut the fudge into squares, and leave to set. Cut the set fudge into bite-sized squares, and store in an airtight tin.

A good plum chutney
Come the deluge of fruit, a good chutney will make a considerable dent in any orchard of plenty.

1.5kg stoned plums

250g sliced onion

50g raisins

250g muscovado sugar

1 level tsp salt

2 cloves

1 big thumb-sized piece fresh ginger, peeled and grated

1 level tsp ground allspice

600ml good red-wine vinegar

Place all the ingredients in a large stainless-steel pot and mix. Put the pan over a gentle heat and bring slowly to the boil. Let the brew simmer until it thickens and takes on the consistency of a chutney. (This part of the operation should take about 45 minutes.) Scrupulously clean some jars, fill them with the chutney and seal. A word of warning: don't use metal lids, because these will react with the vinegar. While it is understandable that everyone will be itching for a large spoonful, ideally the chutney should be allowed to mature for four to six weeks. So be patient.

Clementine curd
Be aware when you are making this preserve that the juice content may vary from fruit to fruit, so a little adjustment in terms of the amount of individual ingredients may be required. Use within a month or so.

12 clementines

220g unsalted butter

500g caster sugar

10 very fresh eggs

Carefully grate the zest from the clementines, taking care not to take any of the pith. (For those so inclined, measure some of the sugar in cubes, and use these to 'grate' the zest from the clementines.) Squeeze out the juice from the fruit, then place this, along with the zest and all the other ingredients, in a large bowl and sit it upon a pan of simmering water. Stir from time to time, until the mixture begins to thicken, then stir frequently until the mixture has reached the required curd-like consistency. Have ready some jars, which have been cleaned, dried and warmed, tip the curd into them, then label and date them accordingly.

A good spice mix
A spice mix that will produce a pot of vegetables, or vegetables and meats, or soup, to soothe even the most jaded Christmas palate and restore comfort and well-being. This is the culinary equivalent of Alka-Seltzer - in other words, its properties are bang on for this time of year. Use within three months.

3 tbsp coriander seeds

8 tsp cumin seeds

2 tsp turmeric

3 blades mace

½ stick cinnamon

½ nutmeg

3 cloves

8 green cardamom pods

1 tsp fennel seeds

½ tsp whole fenugreek

2 tbsp paprika

1 level tsp cayenne pepper

Put all the spices in a coffee mill (you'll have to do this in batches), and grind to a powder. Mix well, then divvy up between clean, dry jars, preferably of a darkened hue to protect from light

 Jeremy Lee is the chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.
