webTitle: Witness saw boy minutes before death

fields.headline: Witness saw boy minutes before death
fields.standfirst: More about the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: The killers of Damilola Taylor struck in four "missing" minutes between the last sighting of him alive and his death in a council estate stairwell where he staggered after he had been stabbed, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
The killers of Damilola Taylor struck in four "missing" minutes between the last sighting of him alive and his death in a council estate stairwell where he staggered after he had been stabbed, police said yesterday.

A woman told detectives she looked out a window and saw the 10-year-old, who was wearing a silver puffa jacket, walking alone along Cronin Street in Peckham, south London, at 4.45pm on Monday. She was fairly sure he was not being followed.

Four minutes later, Damilola was found by a workman lying on concrete steps between the first and second floors of a block on the North Peckham estate. He had a wound to his left leg which left a trail of blood for 100 metres.

The evidence of the new witness has given detectives a clearer picture of Damilola's last movements, and they hope to get further details when they interview two children seen with him 20 minutes before he died. The boy and girl were walking beside Damilola when he left a computer class at Peckham library.

Detective Superintendent David Dillnutt, who is supervising the investigation, said the children had been identified from CCTV footage. They were expected to be questioned yesterday afternoon.

The detective said further work had shown that the boy seen by another witness being dragged along in a headlock by one of three youths was not Damilola. However the prime suspects still remain three hooded youths who were spotted at the bottom of the stairwell when Damilola was found.

Yesterday, well-wishers and friends continued to pay tribute to Damilola, and bouquets were left close to the spot where he collapsed.

Among them were flowers left by the workman who found Damilola, cradled him and tried to stem the flow of blood with his fingers.

Specially trained officers have spoken to 11 children who knew Damilola from Oliver Goldsmith primary school. Another 28 interviews have been arranged.

Damilola said he was bullied at school and left a note in his locker with the Christian name of another pupil who might have been taunting him.

Damilola's father, Richard, arrived at Gatwick airport from Nigeria yesterday morning. He has asked for time to be left alone with his family to come to terms with the loss of his son.

webTitle: Sacks empty in rout of the self-deluded

fields.headline: Sacks empty in rout of the self-deluded
fields.standfirst:
Britain embraced risk, American-style in the tech boom. Now ballooning losses threaten private investors with financial calamity

Net news
fields.trailText: Christmas may be coming, but the goose on many investors' tables is unlikely to be very fat this year. The slump in technology stocks is really biting. Some of the bigger private punters are strapped for cash and fire sales of portfolios are the order of the day. No doubt the stock exchange is on amber alert for systemic risk.
fields.body:
Christmas may be coming, but the goose on many investors' tables is unlikely to be very fat this year. The slump in technology stocks is really biting. Some of the bigger private punters are strapped for cash and fire sales of portfolios are the order of the day. No doubt the stock exchange is on amber alert for systemic risk.

The FTSE Techmark indices of hi-tech stocks in the UK were launched in November 1999, on the wave of enthusiasm for new economy investment that reached its crescendo in the spring. The Techmark 100 began at a level of 2,000 points. Within four months it had hit a high of 5,743 points, creating many self-acclaimed investment geniuses in the process. The index cratered to 2,405 points this week. For self-acclaimed read self-deluded.

The tech stock boom was fuelled by the revolutionary potential of the internet - ratified by signs of changing business practice and consumer attitudes. The boom was facilitated by the availability of credit for private investors within the machinery of the stock market. Leverage and speculation strode hand in hand towards the dawn of a new industrial era.

This leverage took many forms. Some remortgaged properties. Others availed themselves of the facilities on offer to pri vate investors to trade stocks on margin. Earlier this year the willingness to embrace risk was hailed as a sign that the British had at last adopted the US frontier spirit towards investment, with all its positive entrepreneurial associations.

This financial engineering need not give rise to concern at the individual level, provided lending institutions have applied their credit checks effectively. But even the best credit systems struggle with collective failures. Leveraged investment has been concentrated in a narrow segment of the equity market. The collapse in values in this segment could trigger a mass margin call on private investors.

At least overt leverage is observable and measurable, giving grounds for hope that it is also controllable. Margin brokers and lenders face tricky decisions about when to tug the reins on clients. But they rarely have a full picture of their financial obligations. Erring on the side of caution and taking an early decision to cut credit lines can precipitate a liquidity crisis, however - no wonder everyone hopes they can trade their way out of trouble.

More insidious has been the practice of using the breathing space available in the market's trading and settlement system to punt shares on a short-term basis. Signs are that the leverage this allows is really hurting investors nursing ballooning losses.

Until six years ago the market operated a fortnightly trading account system. All transactions were settled on a set date after the end of each period. If one bought and sold a share within the account all that was required was a cash transfer.

This was a punter's paradise. Indeed the system even allowed for extended credit, buyers being able to purchase stock for the new account, thereby deferring payment until the settlement day of the next, rather than current account.

In 1994 this system was changed for one more in line with international practice. In 1995 rolling five-day settlement, T+5, was introduced. One consequence was to make it much more difficult to effectively trade on credit. Another was an overwhelming burden on the back offices of private client brokers to ensure settlement deadlines were met.

The response of the retail brokers has been to request T+10 settlement from market makers, effectively stretching the time available to complete paperwork. Market makers have been content to swallow funding costs resulting from timing mismatches, because they want to see private investors' deals flow and they are often able to use a request for T+10 settlement to fatten their prices.

With a bit of paper juggling, investors with a very short-term horizon have been able to recreate many of the financing advantages of the old system. Exploitation of the T+10 facility was widespread early in 2000, when tech stocks were soaring. With individuals booking profits not losses it was nearly impossible for retail brokers to spot which of their clients were overtrading. The growth of online brokerages compounded this risk. How can you "know your client" when he or she is nothing more than a mouse click to you?

Now circumstances are very different. The standard settlement period is being compressed by retail brokers. There has been a rash of requests for T+2 settlement from private investors desperate to realise cash. Not because they want to be out of the market - for which T+5 would suffice - but because they need readies as soon as the settlement machinery will allow.

I find the surge in T+2 deeply worrying. It points to financial calamity for those individuals who were carried away by their investment success at the start of the year who have spent recent months mesmerised by falling share prices, too confused to act.

Prices have now fallen so far that they are forced to sell by financial circumstances that were avoidable, if only it had not seemed so easy to make money at the outset.

The cool-headed with liquid assets will use this period of panic to build portfolios of the quality tech stocks that have been sold down indiscriminately. But it may be some weeks yet before all the poison is drawn from the market's wound.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

webTitle: Britain criticises French presidency of Europe

fields.headline: Britain rounds on 'inept' French
fields.standfirst:
Chirac blamed for faltering buildup to talks

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Chirac blamed for faltering buildup to talks.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour and Jon Henley in Paris
fields.body:
Senior British diplomats and government members fear that next week's summit on the future of the EU could end in failure due to the French government's increasingly inept handling of negotiations.

The criticism is echoed across other European capitals, the brunt of the flak falling on President Jacques Chirac, who is currently on the final leg of a whirlwind tour of European capitals. While it is aimed at ensuring the summit's success, Mr Chirac's marathon appears to be having the opposite effect.

He has angered many of the union's 10 smaller countries, whose support he needs if Nice is to produce agreement and a treaty.

The French have held the presidency of the EU in the six months of talks leading to next week's summit in Nice. But Downing Street is scathing about the political incoherence of the French government, pointing to the inability of President Chirac and the Socialist prime minister Lionel Jospin to adopt agreed policies. The two men are also being criticised for putting the interests of France ahead of its EU presidency role of honest broker.

Senior British figures are damning about the multi-layered and warring French leadership. Apart from the inbuilt conflict between Mr Chirac and Mr Jospin, British diplomats complain that the French foreign minister Hubert Védrine and the European minister Pierre Moscovici offer competing versions of events. "One is a politician and the other an official and they contradict one another," said one British diplomat.

Inside the European Commission the French presidency is being described as the worst since the British presidency of 1992. The British criticism, now being echoed across European capitals, is centred on the political immobility created by the bitter political rivalries between Mr Jospin and Mr Chirac. Neither is willing to make concessions for fear they will be attacked by the other.

One senior government figure said: "They don't seem to know whether they should be honest brokers as presidents or simply representing their own national interests."

The French are being criticised for demanding other countries abandon the veto while themselves refusing to back down on the national veto over intellectual and property rights. The French are also facing criticism for refusing to concede that the rise in the German population requires Berlin being given extra seats on the Council of Ministers.

Treasury sources also claim the French demand that the level of excise duties should still be subject to national veto is born out of French determination to protect cheap domestic wine. "It is an entirely hypocritical and incoherent position."

Mr Chirac also stands accused of acting like a bull in a china shop over his treatment of 10 smaller nations. Britain is critical of the French pursuing an old-style social policy agenda, which it was finally forced to abandon at talks on Monday.

President Chirac is due to complete his tour of European capitals this weekend. So far Finland's prime minister, Paavo Lipponen, walked out of one meeting complaining of French bullying, and Sweden, Denmark, Austria and Portugal are all refusing to accept a deal reducing their commission seats.

The personal animosity between Mr Jospin and Mr Chirac, both of whom have as good as launched their campaigns for the 2002 presidential elections, has most se verely hampered the presidency, analysts say.

"There is a widespread view in the Commission that ... they have put national interests before the common good," said Charles Grant, director of the British Centre for European Reform.

"Neither Chirac nor Jospin dares back down on entrenched French interests, because they know the other will exploit it politically. It has neutered the French presidency."

webTitle: Days when any tech will do

fields.headline: Days when any tech will do
fields.trailText: Volatility has made a big name for itself in equity market this year. In fact 2000 has been the most volatile year to date for equities, and on the basis of yesterday's evidence it is not difficult to see why.
fields.body:
Volatility has made a big name for itself in equity market this year. In fact 2000 has been the most volatile year to date for equities, and on the basis of yesterday's evidence it is not difficult to see why.

From the beginning of trading yesterday there was a big squeeze in technology stocks, and as usual the explanation could be found on the other side of the Atlantic.

There was not, however, any obvious event on Wall Street on Thursday night which should have triggered a 126.9 point rise to 2,594.73 for the FTSE Techmark 100. After all, the Nasdaq had closed 109 points lower, hit hard by profits warnings from firms such as PC maker Gateway.

But a few market players noticed the situation at the close of trading in New York. Apparently after the second busiest day yet on the Nasdaq composite there was still a huge amount of unfinished business. Such was the level of unfilled orders that US traders reckoned the Nasdaq would have finished flat if trading had been extended by 30 minutes.

Dealers in London reasoned that these buyers would return at the start of trading in New York and trigger a rally - and as every London trader knows, if the Nasdaq goes up, tech prices in London will follow.

What followed was described by market participants as a mad scramble for tech stocks of all shapes and sizes as market makers and hedge funds tried to avoid being caught short.

Up went firms such as Bookham Technology, 148p better at £10.27p, Baltimore, 51p stronger at 341p, and CMG, 75p higher at 955p. Lower down the ladder it was much the same. Orchestream gained 39p to 237.5p, Geo Interactive added 90p to 615p and Surfcontrol put on 112.5p to 850p.

Of course there was some genuine buying interest from fund managers as a number of analysts pushed the line that after recent falls there were some bargains to be had. Nomura, the Japanese broker that has rated chip designer ARM Holdings - up 75p to 515p - a "sell" for most of the year, announced it had turned into a buyer of the stock on the grounds that it now represented some sort of value.

Meanwhile, computer services group Logica advanced 160p to £15.61p after Deutsche Bank issued a glowing report on the company. Deutsche analyst David Rees was telling clients that Logica's present valuation provided "an attractive long-term entry price into the stock".

Nevertheless, the tech fight-back left the wider market virtually unaffected. The FTSE 100 went into the closing auction - the method by which the LSE calculates the day's closing prices - flat. It emerged the other side 28.2 points better at 6,170.4, but most of that gain was delivered courtesy of the market's biggest stock, Vodafone - up 12.75p at 254p.

What held back leading shares throughout the session was a poor showing from the market's defensive stocks, which were undermined by the move back into technology.

Heavyweight pharmaceuticals were the worst affected. AstraZeneca fell back 140p to £34.60, while prospective merger partners Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham lost 103p to £19.54p and 33.5p to 886p respectively. Retailers also suffered, with Sainsbury shedding 22.75p to 392p and Tesco 10.5p to 272.5p.

South African Breweries provided the Friday afternoon takeover tale. It shares ended 46p to 471p amid expectations of a merger or takeover involving a major European player. Oddly, the name in the frame was Interbrew, which only made its debut on the market yesterday.

A takeover tale that did come true involved construction group Alfred McAlpine. Its shares finished 13.5p higher at 225.5p after admitting it had been approached about a possible 235p a share takeover offer. McAlpine rebuffed the approach, saying the offer materially undervalued the firm.

fields.headline: At this price?  Sopheon
fields.trailText: Sopheon, the software group specialising in database management products, surprised traders yesterday by warning that revenues for the year would fall short of expectations.
fields.body:
Sopheon, the software group specialising in database management products, surprised traders yesterday by warning that revenues for the year would fall short of expectations.

Shares in the company slumped 27% to 185p, less than one-tenth of the year's high of £19.62p.

Analysts who had been forecasting revenues of around £18m for the year to December 31 are now looking for nearer £15m after Sopheon said poorer than expected market conditions and the strategic shift of the company had slowed sales. Losses will increase to reflect greater investment in new products.

Sopheon is shifting from reselling other firms' software towards selling its own. Although its products are said to be doing well, some titles will reach the market later than expected.

Slowing demand in the software integration industry where Sopheon offers consultancy will also have an impact. With the reselling business being wound down revenues would inevitably be lower, a spokesman said.

Sopheon chairman Barry Mence emphasised that two acquisitions this year and an increase in the group's working capital placed it in a strong position to develop. He said the company's Accolade product was generating an "exciting" level of interest.

The performance of Sopheon shares between January and March this year, when they increased eightfold in value ,made them a punters' favourite and bulletin board discussion topic.

Bargain hunters moved in during afternoon trading yesterday to mop up a few shares and help Sopheon off its low for the day.

Valuing the new, unproven Sopheon is not easy. Management is bullish but with volatility among tech stocks forecast to continue and individual shares being hit indiscriminately buyers should beware.

Nervous shareholders should play safe and sell now.

fields.headline: Claims Direct upbeat
fields.trailText: Like one of its clients, Claims Direct is fighting back after a number of accidents.
fields.body:
Like one of its clients, Claims Direct is fighting back after a number of accidents.

Last week shares in the personal injury compensation business, which floated in July at 180p, dived after the company was forced to take a £5m provision to help clients whose compensation awards had been eroded by costs.

It followed that with a disappointing set of interim figures and by Wednesday night the shares were sitting at 87.5p.

They have since bounced back. Yesterday they rose 17p to 130p, taking the gains over the past two sessions to nearly 40p.

According to dealers the recovery followed upbeat presentations to institutions and purchases by company directors.

On Wednesday, chairman Anthony Sullman bought 500,000 shares at 87.5p. Fellow director Roger Plantier on Thursday picked up 10,000 at 102p.

webTitle: Pay TV abuse makes McMahon holler

fields.headline: Pay TV abuse makes McMahon holler
fields.standfirst: 30m fans tune in to WWF's pantomime punch-ups. Football is next for the treatment
fields.trailText: Vince McMahon is an unlikely chairman of one of America's biggest and highest profile public companies. Tonight in Sheffield he will walk into an arena packed with 14,000 of his loyal customers and verbally abuse them in front of national pay-television audience.
fields.body:
Vince McMahon is an unlikely chairman of one of America's biggest and highest profile public companies. Tonight in Sheffield he will walk into an arena packed with 14,000 of his loyal customers and verbally abuse them in front of national pay-television audience.

If he is feeling particularly feisty the 54-year-old bodybuilder might even get one of his key employees into a headlock and then body-slam them face first into the floor.

The reaction from the crowd is sure to be hysterical because that is the way Mr McMahon and his customers love it. Indeed the only sound capable of drowning out the hollers of approval is the ringing of cash registers as customers rush to buy T-shirts, posters and videos that capture the moment.

For this particular part of south Yorkshire it will be a case of welcome to the weird - and very lucrative - world of the Worldwide Wrestling Federation, a land where Mr McMahon has reigned for 25 years.

Last month the WWF moved up from the Nasdaq Stock Exchange to the New York Stock Exchange to claim a listing alongside industrials like General Electric Corporation and Ford Motors.

The 83% stake that Mr McMahon shares with his wife and two children, who are all senior executives within the firm, is worth $1bn (£695m). Only Mrs McMahon abstains from the on-stage punch-ups.

The recipe has turned the WWF into the most popular pay-per-view television sport in the world ahead of boxing and soccer. More than 30m viewers worldwide tune in every week to follow the soap-opera style fortunes of performers like Stone Cold Steve Austin, the Rock and the Undertaker.

Muscle-bound and extravagantly dressed, they specialise in throwing each other around, displaying acting talents more usually associated with pantomimes at this time of year and bellowing insults above the sound of deafening, heavy metal music.

Hundreds of thousands of BSkyB viewers are expected to pay £12 a time to tune into tonight's show, with millions more tuning into highlight programmes on terrestrial TV later in the week. The tickets for the live event sold out in 90 minutes.

"No one in entertainment knows how to build a brand and maintain interest in a product better than the WWF," said Mr McMahon.

The WWF's expansion has seen the McMahons set up a branded record label and a dragster racing team. It has also opened a store in New York's Time Square, published a series of best-selling autobiographies by its leading stars and developed WWF.com into one of the world's most popular websites among young people.

But after the final punch is landed tonight Mr McMahon's thoughts will be directed to a far bigger prize. On February 3, the WWF and NBC will launch the XFL, an $100m no holds barred version of American football's NFL, which Mr McMahon believes has gone soft.

"The NFL would have everyone believe that football players are nice to each other and everything is gentlemanly but what professional footballers really want to do is take each other's heads off. We're going to go out there and promote that, not hide behind it."

Critics say Mr McMahon is stretching the brand too far and that taking on the mighty NFL could be a fight too far. The market has taken note of the rumblings and marked WWF shares back sharply.

Mr McMahon disagrees. "A lot of people with a vested interest in the NFL want to disparage us but we haven't even played our first game. When people see how successful its going to be I think the shares will skyrocket."

Indeed the only sound capable of drowning out the hollers of approval is the ringing of cash registers as customers rush to buy T-shirts, posters and videos that capture the moment. For this particular part of south Yorkshire it will be a case of welcome to the weird - and very lucrative - world of the Worldwide Wrestling Federation, a land where Mr McMahon has reigned for 25 years. Last month the WWF moved up from the Nasdaq Stock Exchange to the New York Stock Exchange to claim a listing alongside industrials like General Electric Corporation and Ford Motors. The 83% stake that Mr McMahon shares with his wife and two children, who are all senior executives within the firm, is worth $1bn (£695m). Only Mrs McMahon abstains from the on-stage punch-ups. The recipe has turned the WWF into the most popular pay-per-view television sport in the world ahead of boxing and soccer. More than 30m viewers worldwide tune in every week to follow the soap-opera style fortunes of performers like Stone Cold Steve Austin, the Rock and the Undertaker. Muscle-bound and extravagantly dressed, they specialise in throwing each other around, displaying acting talents more usually associated with pantomimes at this time of year and bellowing insults above the sound of deafening, heavy metal music. Hundreds of thousands of BSkyB viewers are expected to pay £12 a time to tune into tonight's show, with millions more tuning into highlight programmes on terrestrial TV later in the week. The tickets for the live event sold out in 90 minutes. "No one in entertainment knows how to build a brand and maintain interest in a product better than the WWF," said Mr McMahon. The WWF's expansion has seen the McMahons set up a branded record label and a dragster racing team. It has also opened a store in New York's Time Square, published a series of best-selling autobiographies by its leading stars and developed WWF.com into one of the world's most popular websites among young people. But after the final punch is landed tonight Mr McMahon's thoughts will be directed to a far bigger prize. On February 3, the WWF and NBC will launch the XFL, an $100m no holds barred version of American football's NFL, which Mr McMahon believes has gone soft. "The NFL would have everyone believe that football players are nice to each other and everything is gentlemanly but what professional footballers really want to do is take each other's heads off. We're going to go out there and promote that, not hide behind it." Critics say Mr McMahon is stretching the brand too far and that taking on the mighty NFL could be a fight too far. The market has taken note of the rumblings and marked WWF shares back sharply. Mr McMahon disagrees. "A lot of people with a vested interest in the NFL want to disparage us but we haven't even played our first game. When people see how successful its going to be I think the shares will skyrocket."

fields.headline: Byers targets rogue traders
fields.standfirst: Consumer protection pushed through
fields.trailText: Rogue traders who persistently flout the law will face unlimited fines or up to two years in prison under new measures to be introduced early next year.
fields.body:
Rogue traders who persistently flout the law will face unlimited fines or up to two years in prison under new measures to be introduced early next year.

Public and consumer bodies will be able to seek a "stop now" order from the courts requiring the dealer to stop illegal trading immediately.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said present legislation gave consumers the power to seek redress for past offences. But the"stop now" orders, to be in place by February, would allow bodies such as the Consumers Association and Shelter to seek injunctions to prevent future offences.

He said many rogue traders when apprehended went to court, paid a fine, then continued to offend. They saw paying the occasional fine as part of their normal business.

"Failure to comply with a 'stop now' order will be treated as contempt of court and can be punished by a fine or a term of imprisonment," he said.

"We want to target doorstep selling, distance selling, misleading and comparative advertising, unfair contract terms, consumer credit, package travel, timeshare, sale of goods rights, TV broadcasting activities, the advertising of medicines and the growing area of e-commerce."

Public bodies such as the office of fair trading, trading standards departments and industry regulators will also be able to apply to the courts for "stop now" orders.

Mr Byers said the action was especially necessary to protect the elderly and vulnerable. He cited a case of a salesman who spent two hours persuading an 80-year-old man to buy a vacuum cleaner for £1,500 and then drove him to a building society to draw out the money.

In another case a car dealer in Swindon had been the subject of 326 complaints since 1988. He had been taken to court seven times for offences such as wrongly describing cars as having "immaculate body work" or "a new engine".

Mr Byers also announced plans for dealing with two other issues raised in last year's consumer white paper - full pints and mortgage tie-ins. "We will introduce proposals before Easter to tighten the law on the selling of beer, lager and cider, probably under existing weights and measures provisions," he said.

Publicans will be required to provide a pint which is 100% liquid, rather than including the head on the beer. But the measure will not come into full effect for two years, giving publicans sufficient time to change their glasses for those showing the pint level.

Mr Byers said no new regulations were needed to deal with mortgage tie-ins. Only 17 small building societies still insisted that mortgage customers bought an insurance policy through them, he said. They accounted for less than 5% of mortgage products and he had decided the best thing to do was to publish their names so the public could be "informed and assertive".

The announcement of this latest batch of consumer measures, to be achieved through existing or secondary legislation, makes it appear increasingly likely that Mr Byers has lost the battle to have a consumer bill included in next week's Queen's speech.

webTitle: Macho man builds up bogus head of steam

fields.headline: Macho man builds up bogus head of steam
fields.standfirst: Let Railtrack sort out its problems
fields.trailText: When the French environment minister, Dominique Voynet, branded John Prescott an "inveterate macho man" last week, the deputy prime minister responded with an amused and affronted "moi?"
fields.body:
When the French environment minister, Dominique Voynet, branded John Prescott an "inveterate macho man" last week, the deputy prime minister responded with an amused and affronted "moi?"

Yet the boardroom in Railtrack's Euston bunker must have echoed with cries of "here here" in response to Mme Voynet's accusation.

Never a day seems to pass at the moment when the deputy prime minister is not making loud noises about the rail network. The men who run Railtrack have been regularly hauled into Downing Street.

Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the shadow strategic rail authority, has waded in amid suggestions from his own organisation that there is dissatisfaction with the group's senior personnel and with Railtrack's ability to recruit the right man to be its next chairman.

Now the government is to set up a railway "action group", headed by transport minister Lord Macdonald - clearly suggesting that Railtrack's own efforts are best described as inaction.

Lord Macdonald will oversee a group of senior rail officials to ensure they are "totally focused" on their task, again, insinuating that normally they are not.

They will have regular meetings - one yesterday, another Monday; but just in case the Railtrack bosses were wondering whether they would any get any work done or would always be in top-level power meetings, Mr Prescott said reassuringly: "It isn't necessarily every single day."

Just until he could "get more confidence into it".

Surely he is seizing control? "Moi?" you could imagine Mr Prescott mumbling. Absolute nonsense, he said, "we don't have the power to do that".

He is just being a touchy feely "two Jags", who simply wants to "bring people together" and work with the industry to sort out the problems.

The government does have the right to a level of intervention at Railtrack. It is pouring billions of pounds into the rail system through Railtrack and the City therefore accepts a degree of political influence in the company.

But it is getting out of hand. The senior personnel at Railtrack may not be the very best. But it is a public company and the government is now hindering rather than helping.

Railtrack's failings are an emotive public - and therefore electoral - issue and Mr Prescott seems to have decided that his tough guy kick-ass tactics are a vote winner.

There can be no other explanation for the constant criticising and undermining, the demands for meetings at such frequency that the management are bound to be hindered and the hints that the railway equivalent of Rambo will be installed as the group's next chairman.

If the government really wants to run the railway, and believes that it can do so much of a better job, it should renationalise it.

Of course it would never do that. It would mean carrying the can when things went wrong, and how much more convenient to have a handy private sector whipping boy.

How much better to be able to look macho by banging a few heads together now and again, demanding action and blaming others.

The government wants all of the influence and none of the attendant responsibility.

Full stop

Stephen Byers appears to have lost the battle to get a consumers bill included in next week's Queen's speech. But the trade and industry secretary has come up with an ingenious way of clobbering rogue traders without having to introduce primary legislation.

It has long been a scandal that dodgy traders have been able to continue their illegal practices even after being caught and fined. The fines available to the courts have been so small that traders have regarded them as little more than a normal business expense.

It is no surprise that trading standards officers become demoralised when a villain is back on the streets duping people within hours of being found guilty in court of that very practice.

The device which Mr Byers and his department have come up with to deter rogue traders from carrying on as before is simple.

Once a "stop now" order has been made against an offender, the trader no longer has the option of paying a modest fine if caught. The offence becomes the much more serious one of contempt of court, which carries harsh penalties.

In addition, a "stop now" order cannot be lifted. It will remains as a permanent record of a trader's misdemeanours - even if he reforms. As a DTI official said, it would be nonsense to apply for the lifting of an order to abide by the law.

It is a neat move by Mr Byers, the former senior law lecturer at Newcastle Polytechnic.

webTitle: Now the old economy can play FTSE

fields.headline: Now the old economy can play FTSE
fields.trailText: Recent panic selling of technology stocks is likely to trigger another set of sweeping changes to the composition of the benchmark FTSE 100 index next week. Several old-economy stalwarts stand to be among the biggest beneficiaries.
fields.body:
Recent panic selling of technology stocks is likely to trigger another set of sweeping changes to the composition of the benchmark FTSE 100 index next week. Several old-economy stalwarts stand to be among the biggest beneficiaries.

Index compiler FTSE meets on Wednesday to adjudicate on its latest quarterly review and three old-economy companies which were ejected at the last review in September are likely to rejoin the listing. FTSE will base its decision on the ranking of companies by market capitalisation at the close of business on Tuesday.

As things stood last night, Bookham Technology, the optical chip maker, the internet security group Baltimore and Sema, the embattled software group, will be leaving the blue-chip index, along with Emap, the publisher, and cruise liner group P&O Princess.

Their places will be taken by Associated British Foods, brewer Scottish & Newcastle and aero engineer Rolls Royce. All three fell out of the index at the last review following a brief revival in the fortune of technology stocks at the start of September.

Also likely to be promoted are the supermarket chain Safeway and Autonomy, the intelligent software group, if the mini-revival in technology stocks witnessed yesterday continues.

If the tech revival runs out of steam, Autonomy's place will be taken by Matalan, the discount clothing retailer.

According to City analysts the latest changes reflect the volatility in the stock market caused by investors fleeing the tech sector after a string of profits warnings from high-profile American companies.

FTSE will also make changes to the FTSE Mid 250 index. As things stand, recently floated EasyJet, up 2p to 357.5p yesterday, will join the mid-cap benchmark.

webTitle: House prices and industry bounce back

fields.headline: House prices and industry bounce back
fields.trailText: House prices rose and manufacturing activity rebounded last month as production lines returned to normal after the fuel crisis, according to figures published yesterday.
fields.byline: Mark Atkinson, Rupert Jones and Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
House prices rose and manufacturing activity rebounded last month as production lines returned to normal after the fuel crisis, according to figures published yesterday.

As the prime minister pledged to make improving Britain's productivity a priority of a second Labour term the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply's monthly snapshot of activity in Britain's factories showed both orders and ouput had recovered last month.

However, the CIPS said growth was sluggish, and that many exporters continued to suffer from the strength of the pound against the euro.

Peter Luxton, an analyst at Standard & Poor's MMS said: "Manufacturing is just about keeping its head above water."

After signalling contraction in October for the first time since April, the CIPS's index of activity rose from 49.8 to 51.3 in November. Any reading above 50 denotes expansion, below 50, contraction. A lack of demand for UK exports in euroland was offset by increased business in US dollar markets and the Far East.

Ross Walker, an economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland, said sterling's slide this week against a range of currencies including the euro should be a source of optimism in the coming months.

Signalling a continued modest recovery from falls in the summer, Nationwide said house prices rose 0.9%, or £734, in November, taking the average value to £81,770.

However, the annual rate of house price growth continued to decline- at present it stands at 9.1% from 9.9% in October, down from 17.5% in April.

"This is the third monthly price rise in succession and shows confidence beginning to return to the market after the summer slowdown," said Nationwide's David Parry.

City economists said neither the house price figures nor the manufacturing data changed the perception that interest rates would be left on hold at 6% next week when the Bank of England's monetary policy committee holds its monthly meeting.

Speaking in his Sedgefield constituency in County Durham, Mr Blair said the economy was strengthening, but was not yet as strong as it could be.

"The 1980s saw a restructuring of British industry. We have now the right conditions for economic stability," he said.

"But the challenge of creating a powerful, modern, knowledge-based economy still confronts us. Our productivity is too low. Our investment levels must be higher.

"In science, technology, electronic commerce and small business, we have great strengths, but also real challenges," Mr Blair said.

He also promised regulatory reform for telecommunications and broadcasting in an imminent white paper in order to provide cheaper and faster access to the internet.

webTitle: Ofgem lifts last gas price limits

fields.headline: Ofgem lifts last gas price limits
fields.standfirst: Regulator says poor must be protected
fields.trailText: The energy regulator, Ofgem, yesterday gave the go-ahead for all price controls to be lifted from British Gas in April, making Britain the first European Union country to embrace a fully open market in gas supply.
fields.body:
The energy regulator, Ofgem, yesterday gave the go-ahead for all price controls to be lifted from British Gas in April, making Britain the first European Union country to embrace a fully open market in gas supply.

Price controls on the 35% of the 20m gas customers who pay by direct debit, the most-coveted consumers, were lifted in February this year. By April 2002 the electricity market will also become wholly competitive with the lifting of the last price controls there.

But Callum McCarthy, Ofgem director general, said British Gas Trading (BGT), part of Centrica, would have to give a public commitment not to widen the differentials among its domestic tariffs.

The new consumer body Energywatch estimates the gap between the lowest bills (normally direct debt payers) and the highest (usually people on pre-payment meters) can be as high as 60%. BGT says its widest differential is 11% and it is precluded by the Competition Act from extending this.

Mr McCarthy, a fierce protagonist of measures to help the fuel-poor, also specified that BGT must make "substantial" progress in allowing customers who are in debt to switch supplier.

He calculates that 700,000 households have been lifted out of fuel poverty since competition in gas supply began more than three years ago but there are still 4m who spend more than 10% of their income on energy. Between 1.5m and 2m gas customers using pre-payment meters or credit payment plans are said by Ofgem to be in debt.

Most energy suppliers have no interest in taking over such customers but Mr McCarthy wants to reach an agreement with BGT which will enable them to benefit from competitive prices.

Centrica welcomed the Ofgem proposals. It has retained 71% of the gas supply market but 85% of customers using pre-payment meters, largely because it claims to be offering the cheapest prices.

"We are pleased that the regulator intends to remove price controls for all customers, recognising that gas competition is now sufficiently well developed," BGT said.

Energywatch chairman Ann Robinson said the market could hardly be rated as competitive given BGT's dominance but Mr McCarthy told MPs this week he had no evidence that the company was abusing its position.

webTitle: Fuller's sees opening in Whitbread pub sale

fields.headline: Fuller's sees opening in Whitbread pub sale
fields.trailText: Brewer and pub owner Fuller's wants to buy up to 70 large, managed pubs put up for sale by Whitbread. Fuller's, which brews the famous London Pride bitter, said it was looking at some of Whitbread's 3,000 pubs, which are under the hammer as a job lot.
fields.body:
Brewer and pub owner Fuller's wants to buy up to 70 large, managed pubs put up for sale by Whitbread. Fuller's, which brews the famous London Pride bitter, said it was looking at some of Whitbread's 3,000 pubs, which are under the hammer as a job lot.

Chairman Anthony Fuller said the brewery, based in Chiswick, London, had approached venture capitalists looking at the block sale and in formed them of the Fuller, Smith & Turner group's interest.

"We could be looking to buy around 50 to 70 large, managed pubs for around £750,000 each," he said. "It is a good opportunity for us, but we will be looking for a good price. We are not going to expand for the sake of it."

But Nigel Popham, an analyst at Teather and Greenwood, said the group could afford to buy more than 100 of the pubs. "They certainly need a major acquisition to boost their earnings in the medium term," he said.

Mr Popham added that the group had very low borrowings and could afford to finance a large acquisition through debt.

Mr Fuller outlined his expansion plans as the group released its results for the six months to the end of September.

The figures showed a 47% increase in profits to £10.4m - although this included a one-off gain from the disposal of 61 Fuller's Wine Merchants ear lier this year.

Underlying profit was up 5% to £7.2m on sales of £63m, an increase of 10%.

The brewer said its results had been hit by poor summer weather, stiff competition and an "increase in red tape". He added that the recent floods, the worst on record, had further damaged trade but said the company was financially and operationally strong, and that the opportunity for acquisition was unique.

Underlying profit was up 5% to £7.2m on sales of £63m, an increase of 10%. The brewer said its results had been hit by poor summer weather, stiff competition and an "increase in red tape". He added that the recent floods, the worst on record, had further damaged trade but said the company was financially and operationally strong, and that the opportunity for acquisition was unique.

webTitle: Leader: Facing the Aids crisis in Africa

fields.headline: The crippled continent
fields.standfirst:
Facing the Aids crisis in Africa

Special report: the Aids crisis
fields.trailText: The plight of Miriam Mbwana is a stark example of the tragedy being played out in millions of families across sub-Saharan Africa. Six of her 11 children have died of Aids.
fields.body:
The plight of Miriam Mbwana is a stark example of the tragedy being played out in millions of families across sub-Saharan Africa. Six of her 11 children have died of Aids. Just as she might have imagined she could take life more slowly in her 60s, she faces the biggest challenge of her hard life: bringing up 28 orphaned grandchildren, all of whom are under 15 years old.

This was just one of the terrible stories, on one day in one hospital in Malawi, told by Kevin Toolis and Gideon Mendel in our special report in today's Guardian weekend to mark World Aids Day. They present a deeply disturbing picture of a continent, its social and economic life shattered. Aids is likely to cut the gross domestic product of South Africa, one of the region's strongest economies, by 17% by 2010. Meanwhile, hopes for development have been crippled in many African countries where teachers, nurses and doctors are dying as fast as everyone else. We are only beginning to glimpse the implications for the political stability of the continent.

The cruelty of any disease is that it bears most heavily on the poor and the marginalised. This is particularly true of Aids. It is always among the socially excluded - sex workers, drug addicts - that the disease first thrives, as the shocking new statistics from the Russian federation published by the United Nations programme on HIV/Aids this week indicate; the number infected, most of them drug-users, has more than doubled there in just one year. Not only are the poor and socially excluded most likely to catch the disease, they also have the least resources with which to fight it. There is an enormous gulf between the treatment of HIV/Aids in the developed world and in the developing world. In the former, the disease can be con trolled with drugs, but in the latter it is a death sentence.

What the west urgently needs to address is how a handful of hugely profitable drug companies are still protecting their patents on the drugs which could save millions of lives. For example, fluconazale made by Pfizer is used for treating the infections to which many HIV/Aids sufferers are prone. Pfizer, anxious to protect its lucrative patent, refuses to allow generic versions (which cost 29 cents a day compared to $12 a day) and instead, offers time-limited donations - dismissed by critics as nothing more than a public relations gimmick. Another crucial drug is neviraprine, which stops mother-to-baby transmission of HIV. As contentious is the expensive combination antiretroviral therapy which has now been produced in generic versions in Brazil, Thailand and India. Today we report that Glaxo Wellcome has accused a drug distributor in Ghana of violating its patents by importing a generic version from India. This is unacceptable. While it is true that drugs will never solve the crisis, they can ease it. The drug companies need to inject some urgency and sense of global responsibility into their negotiations with the poorest and worst affected countries.

Along with cheaper drugs, sub-Saharan Africa needs aid for its inadequate health services, which are swamped by the needs of the dying. And it needs aid for the biggest challenge of all: how to change a continent's sexual practices. The task is enormous, touching as it does on the most intimate relationship and the balance of power between men and women. But it can be done: Uganda has shown that high-profile, honest prevention campaigns can slow the rate of infections. Miriam Mbwana's grandchildren don't have to die like their parents.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Pepsico nears Quaker deal
fields.body:
Pepsico nears Quaker deal

The boards of PepsiCo, the world's second-largest soft drinks company, and Quaker Oats, the US consumer group, are expected to meet this weekend to agree on a merger after weeks of on-off talks.

A deal expected to value Quaker and its sought-after Gatorade sports drink at more than $14bn could be announced as early as Monday.

Quaker Oats was understood to have rejected Pepsi's original offer as too low. Pepsi's position was helped when rival suitors Coca-Cola and Danone walked away from negotiations.

Coca-Cola's board made a last minute intervention to scupper a deal that would have valued Quaker at more than $15bn two weeks ago.

Pepsi intends to widen international distribution of Gatorade, which has 84% of the fast-growing US sports drink market.

Dagenham battle ends

Ford workers have in effect abandoned their fight to keep vehicle production at the Dagenham plant by voting almost three to one against taking strike action.

Car assembly is due to end early in 2002 with the loss of 1,300 jobs. The closure follows Ford's decision to build the new Fiesta model in Germany rather than Britain, and to expand the diesel engine plant at Dagenham.

Tony Woodley, chief motor industry negotiator for the TGWU, said: "Ford has bribed and blackmailed our members into submission.

"The company has encouraged the remaining workforce to believe that if a strike was held further investment would be jeopardised."

McAlpine rejects offer

Housebuilder and construction services group Alfred McAlpine has rejected a 235p a share offer valuing the company at more than £230m.

In September McAlpine said future prospects for both its core businesses were favourable.

It had reported pre-tax profit of £21m in the six months to June 30, up from £17.3m.

Ford cuts US production

Ford Motors has cut its north American vehicle production forecast for the first quarter by 113,000 units - or 10% below actual results for the first quarter last year - to 1.157m vehicles.

Car production is expected to drop by 80,000 units or 20% to 402,000 units, while truck production is forecast to fall 33,000 units or 4% to 755,000 units, Ford spokesman George Pipas said yesterday.

Mr Pipas said Ford plans to "idle" some north American passenger car assembly plants for the week beginning December 18 to cut excess inventories of unsold cars. However, he declined to provide any details.

"There are a couple of down weeks planned at the end of December, right before the holidays," he said. "Those are in passenger car plants."

webTitle: Barclays rules out bid for Abbey National

fields.headline: Barclays rules out bid for Abbey National
fields.trailText: Barclays yesterday seemed to rule out the idea of mounting a competing bid for Abbey National, thereby leaving the path clear for Bank of Scotland.
fields.body:
Barclays yesterday seemed to rule out the idea of mounting a competing bid for Abbey National, thereby leaving the path clear for Bank of Scotland.

Amid speculation that Abbey and BoS are negotiating terms to clinch a deal, Barclays told City analysts that it did not intend to buy another mortgage bank after taking over Woolwich two months ago.

Matt Barrett, Barclays chief executive, told a City audience keen to find out about any Abbey offer: " "We have already bought a mortgage bank."

While that leaves BoS with a potential window for a bid, industry sources said it turned the tables on Lloyds TSB, which will now be cited as the most likely predator for either of the two banks.

Abbey and BoS have been working furiously behind the scenes to heal rifts about which set of management would run a combined institution.

One month ago, when details of their talks leaked to the media, the problems between the two sets of management appeared irreconcilable. They are now understood to have given themselves seven to 10 days to try to conclude any deal.

In the meantime, Lloyds TSB faces a tough decision whether to risk incurring the wrath of the competition authorities by wading into the situation.

By bidding for one of the banks - most likely Abbey - Lloyds TSB would destroy the creation of a combined Abbey/BoS, which could be a strong competitor to Lloyds and the major high street banks.

At a time when the competition commission is conducting an investigation into small business banking, industry sources believe this could increase the political sensitivity of any bid. Lloyds TSB, which has appointed investment bank JP Morgan to advise it on a potential offer, has a reputation for growing through acquisition.

fields.headline: Christian Marquand
fields.standfirst: Multilingual actor famed for screen frolic with Brigitte Bardot
fields.trailText: There must have been worse ways of earning a living than passionately making love to the 22-year-old Brigitte Bardot on the beach of St Tropez. Christian Marquand, who has died aged 73, was a lucky man.
fields.body:
There must have been worse ways of earning a living than passionately making love to the 22-year-old Brigitte Bardot on the beach of St Tropez. Christian Marquand, who has died aged 73, was a lucky man.

The film was And God Created Woman (1956), and the steamy scene was directed watchfully by Bardot's husband, Roger Vadim. Mostly shot on location, the rather silly, but certainly sensual, tale was a good excuse for him to display his wife's amoral charms in various forms of dress, which mainly comprised jeans, and undress.

But the film also gave Marquand's career a boost. Vadim's debut movie tells of how Bardot, shortly after her marriage to a wimpish Jean-Louis Trintignant, finds she is more attractive to her dour but handsome brother-in-law, Marquand. Coincidentally in real life, Trintignant was to marry Marquand's sister, Nadine, a few years later. But back on the beach, Bardot teases Marquand into ripping off her clothes and taking her.

The film created a scandal in France. This was mainly because of the discreet nudity of the beach scene, but Vadim complained that the censors forced him to cut the sequence.

Marquand himself was no stranger to scandal. The previous year he had a role in Marc Allègret's Lady Chatterly's Lover, which had starred Danielle Darrieux as the erring English aristocrat. In his private life, he married Tina, the daughter of Jean-Pierre Aumont and Maria Montez, in 1963, then had a son by the actress Dominique Sanda in the early 1970s. Thus he seemed to reflect his adulterous film persona.

One of his best pictures was Alexandre Astruc's Une Vie (1958), based on a Guy de Maupassant story. In it, Marquand was the womanising husband of a young, innocent aristocrat, played by a cloying Maria Schell.

His affair with a friend's wife (beautiful Antonella Lualdi) leads to his death. The main strength of the film, apart from Claude Renoir's wonderful impressionistic Technicolor photography, was the way in which Marquand managed to find many nuances in the unsympathetic character he played.

Marquand was born in Marseilles, the son of a Spanish father and an Arab mother; the fact that he spoke Spanish, Arabic, French, English and Italian - all learned as a child - aided his international career. At the age of 21, his dark good looks got him a bit part in Jean Cocteau's Beauty And The Beast (1946), and he was soon getting slightly bigger roles, such as the Bohemian officer friend of the caddish soldier hero (Farley Granger) in Luchino Visconti's lush melodrama, Senso (1954).

In the 1960s, he moved with ease between films made in France and those coming out of Hollywood. Among the uninspiring latter were the D-Day epic, The Longest Day (1962), in which Marquand enlisted as part of the French contingent; Fred Zinnemann's post-Spanish civil war film, Behold A Pale Horse (1964), in which he played a Spaniard; and, as the French doctor among the aircrash survivors, in Robert Aldrich's The Flight Of The Phoenix (1966).

Marquand was better served by Claude Chabrol in The Road To Corinth (1967), in which he portrayed an American Nato security officer investigating mysterious boxes jamming US radar installations in Greece. In 1962, he made Of Flesh and Blood, a competent thriller featuring Anouk Aimée, and the first of two films he directed.

Marquand's succès de scandale was Candy (1968), about the conquests of a nymphet, played by Ewa Aulin, and adapted by Buck Henry and Terry Southern from the latter's novel. In the movie, a large international cast, including Marlon Brando, Richard Burton, John Huston, Walter Mathau, James Coburn, Charles Aznavour, Elsa Martinelli, Ringo Starr, and even the boxer Sugar Ray Robinson, did a series of star turns.

The result, according to the Monthly Film Bulletin, was that "hippy psychedelics are laid on with the self-destroying effect of an overdose of garlic". Disappointed by this mainly negative reception, amidst the era of the love generation, Marquand returned to acting.

Tragically, in the early 1980s, however, he was struck by Alzeimer's disease and retired from the world. He spent many of his last years in hospital, not knowing anybody who visited him. His sister, the director Nadine Trintignant, wrote a moving book about his plight, Ton Chapeau au Vestiaire (His Hat in The Cloakroom).

She survives him, as do his actor brother Serge Marquand, his former wife Tina Aumont, and his son.

fields.headline: Ron Storme
fields.trailText: The huge drag balls that Ron Storme, who has died of liver cancer, probably aged 74, organised at London's Porchester Hall in the late 1960s - with his hefty Canadian friend and fellow drag queen, Jean Fredericks - offered the first opportunity for British gay men to meet in large numbers in public.
fields.body:
The huge drag balls that Ron Storme, who has died of liver cancer, probably aged 74, organised at London's Porchester Hall in the late 1960s - with his hefty Canadian friend and fellow drag queen, Jean Fredericks - offered the first opportunity for British gay men to meet in large numbers in public.

Advertised mainly by word-of-mouth, the balls attracted around 800 gay men, usually under the cover of drag. With homosexual acts only decriminalised in 1967, a year before the Porchester Hall events began, the crowd of shop workers, theatre queens, hairdressers and merchant seaman were thrilled at being able to dance and socialise together.

Ron decorated the place with stock on unofficial loan from Selfridges. Outside, crowds would often gather to watch the fabulous frocks and elaborate costumes. One could argue that Porchester Hall was where British gay life finally emerged from the shadows, and where the modern gay club scene began.

Ron Storme came from a working-class family in Richmond, Surrey. His theatre career began as a child dancer in 1938. During the second world war, he toured in the then popular, all-male drag review shows, but, after the anti-gay clampdown of the mid-1950s, he moved to Tunisia, where he worked for several years as a stripper and singer. After returning to London, he featured in a series of risqué shows, including the Gaiety Box Revue, fronted by Larry Grayson. A talented costume-maker, Ron made outfits for himself and many of London's best-known drag acts.

His love of frocking-up was not confined to the stage. He wore drag at private parties, and out on the town. He looked so stunning that many people failed to realise he was a man. Earlier this year, he recalled in Gay Times, one night in the 1960s when he had emerged from the London Hilton's Starlight Rooms: "I was walking with this guy, and these two burly coppers were on the pavement. They both stepped aside and tipped their helmets as I walked by. And I thought, 'Yes mate, if you only knew'."

During the early 1960s, Ron and his partner George, whom he had met in 1947, were renowned for the parties they held at their house in Putney, south London. Guests included Kim Philby, Dusty Springfield and Ronnie and Reggie Kray. When the events outgrew the property, the Krays reputedly suggested what became the fancy dress balls at Porchester Hall.

In 1980, Ron opened a new night-spot, Club Travestie Extraordinaire, in Stepney, east London. It rapidly became an east end institution, attracting a devoted crowd of straight cross-dressers, drag queens and admirers. Earlier this year, the club celebrated its 20th anniversary, and is arguably the country's longest-running gay night spot.

Until last summer, when he was taken ill, Ron was always on the door, welcoming people in - and almost invariably looking more fabulously dressed than anyone else. His partner died in 1981.

fields.headline: More whine, François?
fields.standfirst:
John Prescott did his best but the French are not merely different, they are deluded

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: John Prescott did his best but the French are not merely different, they are deluded
fields.body:
Anglo-French relations took another turn for the worse this week. It began with John Prescott being a bit patronising towards his French counterpart. As the UN talks on climate change fell apart, she screamed: "Unless we act now most of the world's land mass will be underwater, oxygen will disappear and the entire planet will suffocate!"

And Prescott said: "All right love, all right. It's not the end of the world."

Tony Blair tried to smooth things over by taking Jacques Chirac out for lunch to a pub in his constituency but things reached rock bottom when the French president was greeted with the words: "Hello, have you been to a Harvester before?"

It was, of course, a calculated piece of revenge by the British government. They could have retaliated to the French outburst by cancelling trade talks or banning French beef, but no, far more vicious to buy Chirac a glass of wine from a British pub. And then film him drinking it. "Any more attacks on my deputy," said Tony, "and we're stopping at the Little Chef on the way back to the airport."

Anglo-French relations have been precarious ever since King Harold asked the Normans what they were doing in Sussex and they stuck an arrow in his eye, which is only marginally less cooperative than most of the French guards on the Eurostar today.

The Normans then went backpacking round their newly conquered land, and if you look closely at the Bayeux tapestry you can make out lots of little figures spitting out warm beer and laughing at the primitive public transport facilities. Things got worse when Joan of Arc decided to drive out all the posh English people who had holiday cottages in Normandy. She was then burnt to a cinder by the English, to the horror of the French who thought that two minutes either side would have been plenty.

After that the two countries fought wars with all the regularity of football tournaments, with the difference that the French didn't win quite as often. Henry V took a couple of thousand English troops over the channel, who won a famous victory and then came back loaded up with lots of little bottles of French lager and a big piece of Brie for the missus. The last big bust-up ended with the Battle of Waterloo, precipitating 100 years of unchallenged British supremacy and a number one hit for Abba.

Except that is not how history is viewed on the other side of the channel. I recently found myself chatting with a French woman and the subject turned to the French attitude to the US. "I think the French feel hostile to the Americans," she said, "because before the rise of the United States, the most powerful country in the world was France."

There was a slight pause while I picked myself up off the floor.

"Sorry?" I said "When was this exactly?"

"Before America was the major world power, it was France."

Obviously as a liberal and an internationalist I don't care who was the major world power before America, it just so happens that it was Great Britain, that's all. She countered my amusing interpretation of history by reminding me of the French empire in North Africa. "That was all desert!" I exploded. "Now yer British empire, that was a proper empire, India, Australia, South Africa, Canada, why the sun never set..." I went on as the strains of Land of Hope and Glory rose behind me and union flag tattoos popped out all over my skin. European socialists have a duty to recognise the shameful inheritance of our imperialist history. But the French had better accept that we've got a bigger imperialist tradition to be ashamed of than they have.

The historical baggage that we British carry around with us is of course the real reason that we struggle to accept the increased status of the French in Europe. The tabloids and the Conservative party have attempted to sustain the flattering fantasy that Britain's status in Europe is roughly unchanged since the happy days of the second world war, portrayed so accurately in 'Allo, 'Allo. And what's really underneath all this week's anti-French rhetoric is the nagging resentment that France and Germany are now the dominant partners in Europe. We have clung to an over-inflated view of ourselves which has left us as bit part players in the shaping of the European Union.

A few years back there began an attempt to improve understanding between the two historical rivals by organising school exchange visits, in which French teenagers were apparently supposed to endear themselves to us by wearing kagoules and wandering around Bournemouth shoplifting. The idea of the cultural exchange has now been extended into a scheme under which the French send us their brilliant football players and we send them bovine spongiform encephalopathy. Perhaps as part of the final stage of Euro-integration, this project should now be allowed to reach its logical conclusion and French and British cultures can become fully entwined.

We will have to listen to their pop music, they will have to keep their pants on in the sauna. They will have to watch Animal Hospital but we'll have to let them eat any of the animals that don't make it. But we have no choice but to learn to get along. Racism can have no place in the future of Europe; and so let France and Britain lead the way in doing away with chauvinism and petty nationalism.

And then the British press will proudly boast of how we built a Europe free of intolerance, xenophobia and bigotry, how we learned to love one another irrespective of race or creed. "If racial prejudice is what you're into," the tabloids will say, "frankly, you'd be far better off with those bloody krauts."

webTitle: Letters: Giving support in Papua and Timor

fields.headline: Giving support in Papua and Timor
fields.trailText: Clare Short and I visited Indonesia in October and discussed West Papua with the president and senior ministers. We urged tolerance and restraint. Our embassy is also in regular contact with the West Papuan human rights group, Elsham, about the situation on the ground. This hardly counts as ignoring the West Papuans
fields.body:
Clare Short and I visited Indonesia in October and discussed West Papua with the president and senior ministers. We urged tolerance and restraint. Our embassy is also in regular contact with the West Papuan human rights group, Elsham, about the situation on the ground. This hardly counts as ignoring the West Papuans (George Monbiot, November 30).

The government did not "sanction" the use of Hawk jets over West Papua. On the contrary, we insisted they should never be used to intimidate West Papuans. They were removed within days.

To suggest we did nothing on East Timor is to rewrite history - George Monbiot's taxes helped pay for our substantial peacekeeping contribution there. I was in Jakarta at the time, persuading the Indonesian regime to let international troops in. We were the first government to send a representative to Dili to be supportive.

It is misleading to state baldly that the British government sells arms to Indonesia. We have consistently refused the sale of firearms to Indonesian security forces - or of any equipment that might be used to repress the population. But we did approve, for example, the sale of tyres used on the transport planes that ferried refugees form West Timor back to their homes.

John Battle MP
Foreign Office Minister

fields.headline: Equal at last
fields.trailText: On a day when the press, the politicians and the public are struggling to come to terms with the death of Damilola Taylor, all many of Britain's religious leaders can think about is how to oppose justice in relation to equalising the age of consent.
fields.body:
On a day when the press, the politicians and the public are struggling to come to terms with the death of Damilola Taylor, all many of Britain's religious leaders can think about is how to oppose justice in relation to equalising the age of consent (Gay campaigners celebrate legal milestone, December 1). Is it any wonder that most churches are increasingly empty?

Rev Dr David L Gosling
Cambridge

How appropriate - if criminally overdue - that 100 years to the day from the death of Oscar Wilde, the government should equalise the age of consent at 16.

Robert Palmer and Alan Clark
London

Oscar Wilde will be smiling this morning. And I for one hope that Baroness Young's milk is sour.

Peter Bradshaw
Liverpool

webTitle: Letters: Sorry, we haven't a clue

fields.headline: Sorry, we haven't a clue
fields.trailText: At the age of 101 I share Margaret Kewell's enthusiasm for the Guardian Quick Crossword (Letters, November 30). Although I usually complete it, I must confess it is sometimes rather later than noon.
fields.body:
 At the age of 101 I share Margaret Kewell's enthusiasm for the Guardian Quick Crossword (Letters, November 30). Although I usually complete it, I must confess it is sometimes rather later than noon.

Ethel Hansson
Liverpool

 Move over, Margaret Kewell. I am 98, and I finished today's Guardian Quick Crossword at 11.30am.

Ruth Andrew
London

I am sure Margaret Kewell is far from alone. Up to six weeks before her death in 1997, my 87-year-old mother regularly completed the Guardian Quick Crossword. She enjoyed reading the paper too!

Jennie Aron
Ilkley, West Yorks
Bob@burners.demon.co.uk

 Our combined age is 134 and we still look forward to jumping eagerly into bed each night with the Quick Crossword. The permutations are endless: alternative turns, faking, guessing where your partner wants help, being too tired to finish et al.

The trouble is, in the last few months, I've discovered I can actually do a few Cryptic Crossword clues and am seduced by this new opportunity. My husband says I am getting bored with the Quickie. Any advice please?

Yvonne Craig
London

Please stop printing letters from octogenarians who have completed the Quick Crossword in no time at all. Yesterday I only managed to do three-quarters of it. A phone call to my 88-year-old father proved unhelpful as he was too busy completing the main Guardian crossword.

Margery Hyde
St Albans

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In an article headed Laugh? I'd like to, page 24 (Opinion), November 25, we said that Ben Elton had "defected" to Sky from the BBC "for the money", thereby showing "contempt for the public" and "spitting in the face" of the "concept of entertainment". We expressed surprise at the absence of public outcry at Mr Elton's lack of principles.
fields.body:
In an article headed Laugh? I'd like to, page 24 (Opinion), November 25, we said that Ben Elton had "defected" to Sky from the BBC "for the money", thereby showing "contempt for the public" and "spitting in the face" of the "concept of entertainment". We expressed surprise at the absence of public outcry at Mr Elton's lack of principles.

Mr Elton has informed us that he has no contract of any sort with Sky Television, nor has he ever been in negotiation to acquire one. He points this out as a matter of public record while in no way subscribing to the thesis of the article that his working for Sky Television would be an act of hypocrisy deserving bitter public censure.

Mr Elton points out that while recognising the legitimacy of the commercial sector he remains an outspoken supporter of the BBC and the principle of public service broadcasting. We apologise to Mr Elton for suggesting otherwise.

In a report headed New Express owners set the tone with Beckhams' visit, page 7, November 29, we attributed a quoted remark to "one veteran at the in-house newsletter, Crusader". Our media correspondent had simply used the term "the Crusader", meaning the paper itself, the Daily Express, and was referring to the crusader device in its masthead. He had no idea that it had an in-house newsletter called the Crusader (a reference inserted in the editing) and that is not where his quote came from.

A picture captioned Ian Dury and the Blockheads, page 11, Friday Review, yesterday, in fact showed Ian Dury's first band Kilburn and the High Roads.

Tourtour, the mountain village in Provence where Ronald Searle lives, Profile, pages 6 and 7, today's preprinted Saturday Review, styles itself the "village in the sky" not the "village in the clouds". The Rake's Progress, Searle's tribute to Hogarth, was purchased by the British Museum, not the British Library.

Extracts from Mrs Slocombe's Pussy, the book by Stuart Jeffries, may be heard daily on Radio4 at 9.45am from December 26 to December 29. We gave the wrong starting date, page 11, G2, November 30.

We incorrectly attributed the television review, page 18, G2, yesterday to Adam Sweeting. It was by Rupert Smith. Apologies to both.

The readers' editor writes about newspapers and accountability, page 7, today's Saturday Review. It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. fields.trailText: Your leader (November 30) overlooks the recycling opportunities presented by the surplus contents of the gravy boat. The flavour of the next day's cottage pie can be enriched greatly by the addition of a mature gravy.

 Your leader (November 30) overlooks the recycling opportunities presented by the surplus contents of the gravy boat. The flavour of the next day's cottage pie can be enriched greatly by the addition of a mature gravy.

KD Boardman Bury-St-Edmunds
kdb@boardman.keme.co.uk

 In the 40s I regularly had Yorkshire pudding with gravy for starters, then with the main course, and any left was dished up as pudding, with sugar or treacle. I have never understood why I have always had a weight problem!

Dr RN Smith
Birmingham
normansmith@btinternet.com

 Roast beef and Yorkshire pudding? Pshaw! Typical of those unadventurous Tykes. Over the border, we prefer the traditional Lancashire dish of curried prawns, chips and chapattis, followed by a couple of cans of Boddie's bitter.

Manchester
omickiam@lineone.net

 Who are these people leaving a third of their gravy on the plate? It's the best bit of the meal - use a spoon.

Stanstead Abbotts, Herts

 Our only hope for the environment would appear to be that eventually the lard-butts will be too big to squeeze into their gas-guzzlers.

Cardiff

 "One of the last great silent movies... is given elemental force by the shrieking wind." (Watch this, G2, November 30). Subtitled, I presume.

Dr John Baker
Cambridge

Don't knock spell-checkers. Mine has just suggested I change "GNER" to "goner". The dictionary defines that as "A person or thing that has no chance of succeeding". Sounds right to me.

David Mallen London

webTitle: Leader: Waterstone's image is in steep decline

fields.headline: Shoot-out at OK Corral
fields.standfirst: Waterstone's image is in steep decline
fields.trailText: Waterstone's image is in steep decline
fields.body:
The story has several familiar features. There's the man wearing the black hat, the boss of the big company, who has ridden into town and is bullying the 600 smallholders. Once upon a time, the big company only took 35% of the price of goods provided by the small-timers. Now, with barely more than a week's notice, he has decided to take a 50% cut. Worse still, the boss has sent out a letter declaring that a failure to return a document surrendering to this new demand will be taken as "an indication of compliance with the new terms". To add insult to injury, the big boss has also demanded smallholders extend the length of credit they've always provided from 60 to 90 days. What's missing, so far, is a John Wayne figure riding in and helping rally the small-timers.

One twist in the tale is that the small-timers have not needed a John Wayne. The 600 small publishers threatened by Waterstone's new 50% cut have already got together and written a joint letter to the Office of Fair Trading, claiming that Waterstone's is abusing its dominant market position. They claim the bookseller chain, with its 200-plus high street stores, accounts for 40% of the specialist book market. They do not see how they can survive such a hike. The new procedure will mean the bookseller gets 50p of every £1, the author up to 8p, the distributor 5p, the publisher's representative 5p, production 20p, leaving just 12p or so for the publisher.

David Kneale, Waterstone's boss, remains unrepentant. He is concerned by the 50% of new titles which have not sold a single copy. He does not believe his company should be subsidising small publishers. Yet although its profits fell, the bookseller made £27m profit last year. Its arrival on the high street forced many smaller concerns to close. Clearly, where Waterstone's was once run by booksellers, it is now operated by book-keepers. But even bean counters should be able to make a profit on a 35% cut.
