fields.headline: A vanishing coalition
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats were criticised (Letters, November 17) for not persisting with further amendments to the freedom of information bill when it was being considered in the House of Lords, and for making an agreement with the government which secured a number of important amendments that otherwise would not have been agreed.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats were criticised (Letters, November 17) for not persisting with further amendments to the freedom of information bill when it was being considered in the House of Lords, and for making an agreement with the government which secured a number of important amendments that otherwise would not have been agreed.

It has been asserted that if we had "stood firm" the Conservatives and ourselves could have defeated the government and made radical improvements to the bill. This view seems a little puzzling to me as the Conservatives had made it clear during their 18 years of office that they were opposed to any such legislation. However, this view of a Liberal Democrat-Conservative coalition was sincerely held by a number of people.

I hope they will now study what happened over the part-privatisation of the National Air Traffic Services, in the Lords on Wednesday. (The Conservatives had joined us in attacking this foolish proposal and the government had previously been defeated in the Lords on this issue.) And what happened this week? The Conservatives ran away, accepting an almost nonsensical government "compromise", leaving the Lib Dems, joined by two Conservatives and three Labour rebels, to vote on the issue of principle.

This is what would have happened if we had not concluded our agreement with the government on the FOI bill, leaving the bill without the important Lib Dem amend- ments that we secured.

Lord Harris of Greenwich
House of Lords

The Conservatives ran away, accepting an almost nonsensical government "compromise", leaving the Lib Dems, joined by two Conservatives and three Labour rebels, to vote on the issue of principle. This is what would have happened if we had not concluded our agreement with the government on the FOI bill, leaving the bill without the important Lib Dem amend- ments that we secured. Lord Harris of Greenwich House of Lords

webTitle: Letter: Real price of rail safety

fields.headline: Real price of rail safety
fields.trailText: You report that the retiring chairman of Railtrack, Sir Philip Beck, has written to ministers stating, in respect of his replacement, that "the appointment is not subject to any external approval."
fields.body:
 Suggestions that the government has over-reacted to the Hatfield rail crash are little more than an attempt to support the lifting of speed restrictions imposed by the health and safety executive after Hatfield (Emergency team to hasten rail recovery, December 1).

Similarly, the argument that speed restrictions make rail travel more dangerous (because of the alleged increased risk of drivers passing signals on danger) is not supported by all of the rail unions. I suspect that it stems from a desire by Railtrack to avoid compensating the train operating companies for the delays and cancellations caused by the speed restrictions on track which has yet to be repaired.

It is clear that the real cause of the Hatfield crash was financial. The privatisation model compels Railtrack to compensate the train operating companies if it delays their services. As a result, there is a reluctance to allow contractors to carry out repairs on the track.

Put at its starkest, the economics make it more cost effective for Railtrack to delay essential repairs (and risk an accident like Hatfield, or worse) than to carry them out.

Railtrack, having admitted liability, may face compensation claims of £5m for the deaths of four people and injuries to others. The speed restrictions and closures imposed after Hatfield are estimated to have cost the company £250m. In such a situation some may argue that delaying work makes economic sense. Perhaps they should explain their economic arguments to the wives who have lost husbands, the children who have lost fathers and the parents who have seen their children die prematurely in such horrific circumstances.

As the friend of one of the victims, I wrote to Railtrack on behalf of his widow after the directors had written offering condolences and suggesting a willingness to answer questions. My initial letter went to Gerald Corbett. It and the reminders to him, his replacement and a fellow director, remain unanswered and unacknowledged one month later.

"Safety first" seems to mean protecting their own position first and last, and failing to admit that the Hatfield accident could and should have been avoided by a timely replacement of the track.

Railtrack were aware that the track in question needed replacing last year, and were reminded again in January when gauge corner shelling was "showing bad".

The awful truth is that a corporate manslaughter conviction will not alter matters. Even if Railtrack could be massively fined and put out of business, what good would that do? There can be no real benefit in that, certainly not on the same scale as the huge damages awards against American tobacco companies (which can close them down).

The only hope is that those responsible recognise their own guilt, and that we all resolve to put safety ahead of a share price. Some hope.

Russell Deards
Nottingham

 If Railtrack will not tolerate interference from the government (Labour warned off by rail boss, November 30), presumably we can look forward to the return of all the public subsidy?

Once again privatisation of public services shows its true colours: directors and shareholders make all the decisions and take all the benefits; the public forks out the money.

The only reason that Labour cannot admit this and take Railtrack back into public ownership (having already paid more than the Tories sold it for) is that this would show up its other privatisation schemes for what they are and Prescott would have to go.

Alan Dockree
Worthing
adoc@mistral.co.uk

 You report that the retiring chairman of Railtrack, Sir Philip Beck, has written to ministers stating, in respect of his replacement, that "the appointment is not subject to any external approval."

Not only do the directors not know how to run a railway, but they do not know the law either. The new chairman will have to resign at his first annual general meeting and be elected by the shareholders. If that is not external approval then I don't know what is.

The directors should remember that the government owns a "golden share" and, as Mrs Thatcher would say, the company is spending "our money".

RN Barton
Twickenham
rneilbarton@yahoo.com

webTitle: Leader: Fox promises a new Mexico

fields.headline: Death of a dynasty
fields.standfirst: Fox promises a new Mexico
fields.trailText: Since communism collapsed in the Soviet Union, Mexico has had the distinction of living under the longest one-party dynasty in the world. Yesterday it ended when Vicente Fox was inaugurated as the first opposition candidate to become president for 71 years.
fields.body:
Since communism collapsed in the Soviet Union, Mexico has had the distinction of living under the longest one-party dynasty in the world. Yesterday it ended when Vicente Fox was inaugurated as the first opposition candidate to become president for 71 years. The losers, the Institutional Revolutionary party (PRI), still control Congress and more than half the state governorships, so Fox will not have a clear run in making the constitutional and structural changes he would like. But his arrival on the scene still marks a historic sea-change in Mexican politics. It is bound to shake up a system of political patronage and corruption which has gone on too long. It will also produce a change of style since Fox is a flamboyant figure with an eye to breezy public relations. He had breakfast with a group of street children before taking the oath of office and has vowed to spend his first days in power on the road meeting people, including migrant workers returning from the US.

His economic policies reflect continuity more than change. He has retained several senior figures from the outgoing PRI regime and will pursue their orthodox monetarism. If there are to be radical moves, they will come in a new effort to deregulate the economy, break up and liberalise the energy sector (though not, he maintains, the state-owned oil monopoly) and change the tax structure. He will reduce taxes on oil in order to reduce the government's vulnerability to changes in the world price, and may introduce value-added tax on food and medicines. This could produce rapid disappointment among Mexico's poorest, although Fox plans a big increase in spending on education.

His most imaginative move has been to give the foreign ministry to Jorge Castaneda, a celebrity intellectual who was once a leftwing critic of the US and the North American Free Trade Area. The president's aim is not to confront or resist Washington, but rather to urge it to treat its southern neighbour as an equal. Fox hopes eventually to move towards a system of open borders in which the flow of north-bound immigrants ceases to be a source of violence and tension, and where people need not live illegally in the US but send home their earnings openly. For a real test of whether globalisation means that labour can one day move across national boundaries with as few restrictions as capital, watch Mexico.

fields.headline: Aids story: part 2
fields.standfirst:
Aids story: part 1
Special Report: the Aids crisis
fields.trailText: Pharmaceutical companies make their profits in the rich west, not in the poor south. The companies want to protect those markets. They want to keep prices up, maintain their monopolies, reward their shareholders. There is no money in the African poor and the companies don't want to undermine their elaborate pricing policies in the western high street by creating secondary markets where the same drugs retail for a fraction of western price levels.
fields.body:
Pharmaceutical companies make their profits in the rich west, not in the poor south. The companies want to protect those markets. They want to keep prices up, maintain their monopolies, reward their shareholders. There is no money in the African poor and the companies don't want to undermine their elaborate pricing policies in the western high street by creating secondary markets where the same drugs retail for a fraction of western price levels.

The drug companies are quick to justify their prices by talking about their hundreds of millions of dollars spent on research programmes, their commitment to science, and international retail price differentials. But the unspoken bottom line is this: if tens of millions of poor Africans have to die to maintain western price tags on lucrative Aids drugs, then they are just going to have to die.

In reality, western governments, particularly the US government, actively enforces these trade policies that ensure millions of Africans will die. Under the terms of the 1994 World Trade Agreement, countries can, in the midst of a "national emergency", issue a compulsory licence, manufacture the drugs themselves, and pay a pharmaceutical patent holder a small licence fee. Twenty per cent of South Africa's adult population, more than four million people, are HIV-positive. It would be hard to think of a better case of a "national emergency", but when South Africa considered issuing such compulsory licences in the late 90s, Vice President Al Gore threatened US trade sanctions. The US government has also made similar threats to Thailand, whose HIV population is 755,000.

Some pharmeutical companies, such as Pfizer, would prefer to give their drugs away rather than allow a free market to dictate the price. In April, Pfizer, which makes Viagra and has a major research UK base in Kent, announced it was donating its drug fluconazole to the South African government for use in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis, a nasty, fatal infection associated with Aids. Cryptococcal meningitis, whose spores are found in bird droppings, is a fungal infection of the membranes of the brain and fluconazole is the only effective drug treatment. The drug must be taken daily for life. Under the Pfizer plan, 100,000 South Africans would receive the drug for free.

In the west, fluconazole costs $5,000 a year. Pfzier's donation was worth half a billion dollars. The donation seemed like an act of benevolence. But the effect of it was to maitain Pfzier's worldwide market restricitons on its proprietory brand of fluconazole, marketed under the name of Difulcan. The exact same drug is legally and generically manufactured in Thailand where a daily dose costs US75 cents rather than the $14 pzier charges. The annual cost of treatment in Thailan per patient is $273. Giving the drug to the South African government, under tight restrictions, neutralised its American-based critics, allowed Pfizer to continue to charge the rest of Africa hard cash, and protected its real monopoly at home. "The issue is not donations, it's sustainable low-cost antiretrovirals. And you can only do that through generic competition," says Zackie Achmat, chairman of the South African Aids drugs lobbying group Treatment Action Coalition. "People are dying here every day. My cousin died last week, one of the guys in our workshop died two days ago. You can see from Thailand that the pills cost practically nothing. Pfizer are donating the pills to avoid a possible court case because of patent abuse. They don't want people in the US and the UK to say, 'Hey, those drugs don't cost as much as you say they do.' " As part of a Treatment Action Coalition protest, Zackie Achmat personally, but illegally, imported 5,000 doses of the Thai version of fluconazole, distributed them in South Africa for free and then "confessed" his crime to the police. It is now eight months on from Pfizer's April press release, but not one single "free donation" of fluconazole has reached South African clinics. Pfizer and the South African government are still negotiating the exact terms of the agreement. And Pfizer has no plans to donate fluconazole to Malawi or other sub-Saharan countries. Pfizer is unashamed about its monopolistic marketing techniques. "We are a drug company and we do need to make a profit. A drug takes 15 years from concept to market. Drug companies need to recoup their investment and research," says Jennifer Perry, a Pfizer spokesperson.

In Brazil, the government has produced its own generic versions of antiretrovirals; the cost of annual treatment has tumbled from $15,000 to less than $3,000. Some activists claim effective combination drug therapy that stops the virus destroying a patient's immune system could cost as little, on a mass scale, as $200 a year per patient. That's too much for Malawi, but frankly not a lot for the west, which has donated a pittance of its available medical resources to saving Africans from the Aids plague. "It is obscene that 98-99 per cent of those in the greatest need are denied access to drugs because they cannot afford them," said Nathan Ford, a spokesperson with Mdecins San Frontires, a charity that has lobbied for greater access for Aids drugs in Africa. There is not much left to believe in this world, but we can still, if we want to, believe in our own potential power of goodness. We can, through western governments, through charities, through our will, through political pressure on the economic interests that preserve drug monopolies, try to save some of those in Africa who are plagued by a tiny but deadly piece of RNA. In the hospital courtyard surrounded by the dying, and the living, I asked Christina Mondhali, the HIV-positive nurse on the TB ward, what she wanted. "I want," she said so softly I had to strain to hear, "to live. I want antiretrovirals. I know it does not heal. But I know it prolongs life. My condition changes, I'm having symptoms, serious symptoms, pelvic inflammatory disease and recurrent respiratory infections. I don't want to die."

Thanks to ActionAid for research and contact with local HIV/Aids groups in Malawi. For more information about ActionAid's HIV/AIds campaign, call 01460 238080.
