fields.headline: While the world looks away
fields.standfirst:
Aids has taken a terrifying grip in Africa. The disease is making alarming inroads across the globe, but at least two thirds of those who are HIV-positive live in Africa. It is the leading cause of death, ruinous economically and tragic in its consequences, orphaning millions of children. In the west, drugs are making Aids manageable - in great swathes of Africa, barely anyone can afford them. Kevin Toolis and the photographer Gideon Mendel went to a small district hospital in Malawi and, over 24 hours, followed the lives and deaths in three particular families.

Special Report: the Aids crisis
fields.trailText: Aids has taken a terrifying grip in Africa. The disease is making alarming inroads across the globe, but at least two thirds of those who are HIV-positive live in Africa. It is the leading cause of death, ruinous economically and tragic in its consequences, orphaning millions of children. In the west, drugs are making Aids manageable - in great swathes of Africa, barely anyone can afford them. Kevin Toolis and the photographer Gideon Mendel went to a small district hospital in Malawi and, over 24 hours, followed the lives and deaths in three particular families.
fields.body:
It's 1am on the female medical ward of Nhkotakota Government District Hospital by the shores of Lake Malawi, and Eliza Mwase rises from her bed for a sip of water. Pulled into a sitting position by her aunts, Jane and Patricia, Eliza calls out in Chewa, the local language: "It hurts, it hurts." Tenderly, as if soothing a child, the women repeat her name, "Eliza, Eliza", as they lift the cup to her lips. Eliza's hands writhe involuntarily at her wrists, as if they have taken a life of their own and seek to escape their dying host. Eliza coughs, struggling to clear her lungs, and her eyes blaze black, uncomprehending, with pain. As she sips, the water spills over her chin and down her front.

Eliza is 21, but she has become a child again. She is three hours from death. A light African rain begins to drum on the ward's tin roof. Two paces from the foot of Eliza's bed, a baby sleeps beside his mother on the concrete floor. Every inch of floor space is covered with patients and their relatives, "guardians" who tend their every non-medical need. The dying and living are crowded in here, meshed as one. In the morning, the sun will rise and these sleeping bodies return again to life. But not Eliza. The rains drum on. It is the last sound this child of Africa will ever hear.

Eliza Mwase died at 4am that morning, another victim of the Aids epidemic that is tearing its way through Africa. In the west, Aids has become a non-story. Antiretrovirals, drug combination therapies, $15,000 per annum treatment programmes and the disease, if not curable, is at least controllable. Aids has dropped away from the public eye. World Aids Day has become an annual ritual, something that can be marked in a calendar and then forgotten about the following day.

But in Africa, Aids is a catastrophe without end, a searing epidemic that has destroyed families, orphaned millions of children, killed the elite and crippled the already impoverished economies of the world's poorest countries. Aids has killed 18.8 million worldwide since the early 80s, but the overwhelming death toll - 16 million - has been in Africa. The United Nations estimates that there are now 34.3 million living with the virus - 24.5 million of those live in sub-Saharan Africa. Millions more, possibly hundreds of millions more, will become infected.

In contrast, in Britain there are 31,000 people living with Aids out of a population of 59 million. Among the adult population - which, for the purposes of the UN report, means 15 to 49-year-olds - there is a prevalence rate of 0.11%. There were 450 Aids deaths in the United Kingdom last year. In Germany, the prevalence among adults is 0.10%, and there are 37,000 HIV-positives out of a total population of 82 million, and a 1999 death toll of 600. In the US, the prevalence rate, at 0.61% of the adult population, is higher, but that still gives just a total of 850,000 HIV-positive people of all ages out of a population of 276 million. There were 20,000 Aids deaths in the US last year.

Malawi, one of the poorest countries with an annual per capita income of $190, has an official HIV prevalence rate of 16% among the 15-49 age group. The population of Malawi is 10.7m. The total number of people infected with the virus in Malawi, including 40,000 children, is 800,000 - almost the same as in the US. Last year alone, 70,000 Malawians died of Aids. The incubation period for the virus is eight to 10 years; the death toll is accelerating.

Malawi is not even at the epicentre of the Aids pandemic. Many other sub-Saharan countries, Botswana (35%), Zimbabwe (25%), Lesotho (23%), Zambia (20%), and Namibia (19%) have higher rates of infectivity among adults. Aids has replaced war, drought, every other disease, including malaria, as the leading cause of death. Demographically, many African societies have become shaped like pyramids; you start out with lots of babies at the base and then taper away like a pyramid as death, disease, mortal happenstance, take its toll until you have a narrow tip of 80-year-olds at the apex. But in Africa, Aids is slicing huge chunks out of the economically productive middle generations as 15 to 49-year-olds succumb to the virus. The pyramid is turning into a narrow chimney. Life expectancy is falling by a decade. A 15-year-old Zimbabwean boy now has a 50% chance of dying of Aids before he is 50. If anything, Malawi is a backward province in the Aids catastrophe, yet the death toll, the devastation of human lives, is awesome.

To walk the concrete corridors of Nhkotakota District Hospital is to enter a charnel house of human suffering. Aids is a hydra-headed medical monster that manifests itself in the withered tubercular bodies of the patients. It is there in the suppurating leg ulcers of 35-year-old Mary Mbwana, who is suffering from the skin cancer, Kaposi's sarcoma. It lies deep behind the weeping herpes genital sores of one-time tobacco clerk, 29-year-old William Chimwavi. It is the plague that infects the body of 18-month-old John Phiri, who has, through recurrent bouts of infection, diarrhoea and vomiting, failed to thrive. Three of John's brothers have already died - five-year-old Gift, Romeo, four months, and four-year-old Levinson. It has laid low his mother, Madrind, 35, who suffers from undetermined rashes, infections, wasting and who, too, will soon die like her first husband, Rajab Phiri. Just as Eliza's mother, Frieda Mwase, 42, did. And just as Eliza's father, Thomas Mwase, 49, did earlier this year. As did the four sisters and one brother of Mary Mbwana. And the virus has infected, too, Christina Mondhali, the night nurse still working on the TB ward at Nhkotakota, and the local coffin-maker, Christopher Msowoya.

There is no end to this long day of dying.

No one dies of Aids in Malawi. Malawians die of a "short illness", or they contract an unspecified "fever", or they vomit so much they cannot drink. Since 1994, 29 of Malawi's 177 members of parliament have died from "short illnesses" - as did the president's brother.

In Chewa, Aids is known as "matantanda athu omwewa". It means "this new disease of ours". Sometimes Aids is also called "the government disease", meaning "this thing we all have in common". The graveyards are filling and everyone knows someone who has died of Aids, but from fear and superstition, the word is never spoken. Even the medical charts of the sick do not betray the secret. Eliza's charts just read "fever" and "anaemia".

"Here in Malawi, it's still a shameful disease. If someone dies of Aids, even the churches will say he or she was an adulterer or a prostitute," says Christina Mondhali, who is one of few medical professionals in Malawi who is open about her HIV status.

Malawi is in denial. Malawi's First Lady, Patricia Shanil Muluzi, may have adopted six Aids orphans. The walls of Malawian brothels may have condom murals. And every Malawian school is visited by "drama groups" warning of the dangers of teenage sex. But Aids is talked about in the abstract, not the personal. It is the same across most of southern Africa. Last month, the Alastair Campbell of South Africa, Parks Mankahlana, chief press aide to Nelson Mandela and South African president Thabo Mbeki, died of Aids, even though his widow, Nthabiseng, insisted that he died of "chronic anaemia". In a pointed rebuke to his successor, Mandela recently called for the war against Aids in South Africa to become a top priority, clearly referring to Mbeki's strange flirtation with the rejectionist theories of Professor Peter Duesberg, of the University of California, Berkeley, who disputes that Aids is caused by a virus.

The denial is counter-productive, but the fear is understandable. Even for the Malawian elite, there is no hope of containing the disease. No one can afford the expensive western antiretrovirals that can stem the virus and save your life. To declare yourself HIV-positive is to live out your death sentence in public. Most Malawians still refuse HIV tests. "People think it's better not to know. 'You will die from your worries.' They think you do the test and just prepare to die. They think there is no cure for Aids, and it's true," said Sam Ndhlovu, a nurse at Nhkotakota.

Attitudes are changing, but changing slowly. "It's not a shameful thing. It's an illness, just the same as malaria or TB. If I hide, I am still going to die with it," says Christina Mondhali.

In the west, we have, through our medical power, lost all understanding of what plague is. Our experiences of epidemics is restricted to winter flus, colds, medical irritations that carry off the old and the vulnerable. We take a hostile attitude to personalised infection. If you get gonorrhoea, a sexually transmitted disease, you go to the STD clinic, get antibiotics, go home and you might shout at the person who passed on the infection. There is a causal link. And a cure. But in Malawi, the Aids epidemic is everywhere.

The first 17 Aids cases were reported in 1985, but the virus was already spreading exponentially throughout the general population. The virus's latent potential, up to a decade between infection and symptoms, masked its spread throughout the population. Aids fatally shadows every sexual encounter, every sexual act, between adult Malawians for the past 20 years. "It's difficult to say, 'You are the one who gave me the virus,' " says David Nyirongo, an organiser with the charity ActionAid, who is himself HIV-positive. "I might have a girlfriend and I might have infected her with the virus. But she might not exactly know it's me. She might have slept with other men. She could have got it from them. She could have given it to me. It's difficult to know the history of anyone. That's why we are unable to point the fingers of suspicion."

Even those such as Christina Mondhali who can point the finger - her husband gave her herpes when she was four months pregnant with their first child and she later tested HIV-positive - are stoic. "I do not blame him. And even if I did, what can be done now?"

In Malawi's "final days", there is no room for self-pity. "I am not afraid of dying," says David Nyirongo, who married again and has three children with his new wife, Juliana, also HIV-positive. "I have not yet started suffering. I feel sad every time you hear of the death of someone you know with Aids. I think, 'Tomorrow it's me.' Then I forget. I hope, I dream, we can get the new drugs [antiretrovirals] and start a new life."

Nhkotakota is not an important town in Malawi. It's a place between other bigger places. It has grown up around an old mission station and nearby Lake Malawi, one of Africa's largest freshwater lakes. There is a petrol station, a line of market stalls, shops, another line of bars/ brothels/resthouses, the A K Paradise Club, the Arizona Special Bottle Store, and the Zabwino Bar. Beyond lies a string of villages, some with mud walls and thatched roofs, others built of brick and corrugated iron, that run into each other before turning to bush. You could drive past in five minutes. Nhkotakota is a dorp, a small unnoticed place in a small unnoticed country in southern Africa.

If you turn right at the petrol station and drive a mile off the Tarmac road towards the lake, you'll find Nhkotakota's two hospitals. For some reason, the Government District Hospital was built half a mile away from the old mission hospital of St Ann's. Both hospitals are a jumble of one-storey brick buildings with corrugated roofs. In the back yard of the government hospital is a scatter of broken-down ambulances, their parts cannibalised to service the rest of the decrepit fleet. The outside latrines stink and the sewage runs into the surrounding bush. Recently, a new male medical ward was built at the government hospital, or Boma, as it is known, to relieve the grotesque overcrowding in the main buildings, but the donor funding ran out after the roof went on. The ward sits there forlorn, an empty hulk, waiting for the dying to enter its walls. Across the courtyard, in the main compound, the sick are crowded so tightly against each other that even in the day you must pick your way carefully through the prostrate bodies.

The conditions at St Ann's are better, but not that much better. Besides St Ann's is a tree where David Livingstone, the explorer, supposedly met the African chief Jumbe in 1861 and persuaded him to give up the slave trade. The tree has been designated a Malawian National Monument and earns Nhkotakota its only mention in tourist guidebooks. The total population of the outlying Nhkotakota district is around 250,000. There are three doctors for the whole district.

Medical treatment in Malawi is theoretically free in government hospitals such as the Boma. The government provides the beds, the drugs and the medical care. Your family, your guardians who sleep on the floor beside your bed, provide the washing, the cleaning, the cooking and the food. But it does not really work out like that. In Malawi, if you are sick, you shop around. If you have money, $10 or maybe $20, you go to a private clinic or a mission hospital such as St Ann's, where the daily costs of being an in-patient are 250 kwacha - about £2 - but the conditions are cleaner, drugs more readily available and the quality of treatment higher. But you need money. We were at St Ann's one morning when an ambulance arrived with a desperately sick man suffering from cerebral malaria - fatal within hours unless treated. He was dying in front of our eyes, but the ambulance was turned away; his family did not have the 250 kwacha for the deposit on the bed for the first day.

If you have no money, then there is no choice; you must queue in the morning heat of the Boma's outpatients clinic and hope to be admitted. Demand outstrips supply. There are 130 beds, and every morning another 250 would-be patients appear at the gates. All but the sickest are turned away, as well as the medically hopeless, who are sent back home to die. There is not enough staff, not enough drugs, not enough needles, not enough anything. On one of the days the photographer Gideon Mendel and I were there, the hospital had run out of plasters. After begging the right-sized needle for the child's tiny veins from the nearby mission hospital, staff used cotton wool and a piece of masking tape to bind the drip needle to 18-month-old John Phiri's arm in order to rehydrate him and save his life.

There is no hope of change. Malawi is poor and getting poorer. The price of its main export crops - tea and tobacco - is falling. Since last year, the kwacha, has slid downwards against the US dollar, from 43 kwacha to 80, doubling the interest payments on Malawi's international debts. The interest payments on these loans is now one-and-half-times greater than the national health budget.

But even if the kwacha was soaring, it would not make any difference. Malawi's hospitals are under siege. Up to 80% of all patients are HIV-positive and have complex, multiple, difficult-to-treat, and ultimately untreatable, infections. The government has an annual health budget of about $10 per capita. Malawi relies on foreign donations to fund its spiralling medical bills. Crucially, for the past two years Malawi has been unable to afford to pay for the reagents used in HIV test kits. There is barely enough reagent to test blood donations. In 1997, even St Ann's mission hospital ran out of money and could not pay its staff for two months.

"We are overwhelmed in every aspect of the epidemic, the lack of equipment, the lack of staff, all angles. We have been engulfed by the problem," says Dr Maurice Bonongwe, Nhkotakota District Hospital's sole physician. Every one of those 800,000 Malawian citizens who are HIV-positive, just like every one of the 24.5 million sub-Saharan Africans with the virus, is going to die of Aids unless the west intervenes.

We found Eliza again, wrapped in a sheet and lying on the floor of a mud-walled hut in her grandfather's village, Selemani 2, on the shore of Lake Malawi, about 10 miles from the hospital. She had gone home on the metal floor of the government ambulance/hearse. The hospital morgue, like the hospital, is tight for space; by 8am there was another patient in the same bed. The hut was lit by a paraffin lamp and in death Eliza seemed impossibly small, a girl-child. Selemani 2 is a beautiful place; fishermen's boats ride the freshwater swell and the shore is dotted with the blood-red blossom fallen from bougainvillea trees.

Eliza had come back here in early October, to her grandfather's house, after she grew too sick to be in the city. But Eliza just got sicker and sicker. She had been living in Mzuzu, a town 300km away, with her parents, and then the catastrophe struck. In 1998, her mother Frieda, 42, grew sick and died and then her father Thomas, 49, died earlier this year. Eliza, her family said, was a schoolgirl even though she was 21. That's not uncommon in Malawi, where pupils often drop out for a year or two as the family saves to pay school fees. Someone else said Eliza had worked in bars. Even as she was dying, you could see that she had been beautiful.

Like most societies, Malawians are hypocritical about sex. Malawi is a religious country. Open homosexuality is still a cultural taboo. Intravenous drug misuse is virtually unknown. Families go to church, listen to sermons, believe in God, chastity, the Ten Commandments, and then the men go to bars at the weekend and sleep with prostitutes. Malawi is poor, the workforce unskilled, there is a lot of unemployment; unsupported women are at the bottom of the economic heap. Sex is cheap, 250 kwacha - about £2 - for a brief session. Prostitution is casual, semi-open, and culturally acceptable. Until recently, most Malawian men did not want to use condoms; there were 500,000 cases of sexually transmitted diseases (STD) in 1998; 70% of prostitutes test positive; 50% of men attending STD clinics also test positive. After the weekend, the men go back and have unprotected sex with their wives. The virus spreads.

Changing private sexual behaviours is incredibly difficult. Since the 60s, the British government, rich and infinitely powerful by Malawian standards, has bombarded its citizens with propaganda about contraception and the follies of teenage pregnancy. Hundreds of millions of pounds have been spent on advice centres, public education campaigns, free contraceptives. After 30 years, Britain still has the highest teenage pregnancy rate in Western Europe.

Iasked Dr Bonongwe if, in the midst of all this death, he was confident that Malawians would change and practise safer sex. He paused for a moment, as if searching for a complex answer: "No, I don't think so. There is no prospect that people will change their behaviour. We advocate the use of condoms, but the churches do not support the use of condoms," he said with a sad finality. "I expect many, many people over the next 10 years to die. For those who have been sexually active, it's a disaster. Only the children, those aged five to 15, who we are cherishing as a future, will survive." Children make up a large proportion of the Malawian population and, despite the danger of HIV-positive mothers passing on the disease to their babies, so far the infection rate among those 14 and under is a fraction of that among the adult population.

Culturally, Malawians are accustomed to straight vaginal sex. But there seem to be some crucial differences in the way the virus infects men and women. Women are more easily infected. And women get infected younger because men tend to sleep with younger women and can use their greater economic power to buy sex. But it all evens out in the end. The older you are, the shorter the time span between infection and death; sugar daddies die, too.

Eliza's family were poor, poor beyond our imagining. Malawian funerals are great public events. The entire village gathers to spend the night at the house of the deceased. Songs are sung; Jesus is praised, the Devil is condemned. The songs go on all night long. The mourners must be fed, the food cooked, and firewood gathered. Funerals are expensive. The price of her coffin - 2,400 kwacha, about £20 - was beyond them. We gave a little money and a lift to the coffin-maker back into town. Business is brisk in the Malawian coffin trade. In a good week, Christopher Moswoya, one of two coffin-makers in the town, takes orders for 10-12 coffins. They come in three sizes; standard, middle, small. But Christopher was not planning to expand; he was also sick with the virus. As he sanded and varnished Eliza's coffin, we fell into conversation. The coffin trade in Malawi was a good business, but life would be easier if he could afford power tools. Without those tools, he had to saw tree trunks by hand. It was arm-breaking work. "If I got sick, I could still work. You just press the button and it goes." But the price of power tools, like the price of western antiretrovirals, was beyond his reach.

Christopher wanted to know about the drugs, too. He wanted to know why western drug companies charged so much. "So, are they after business?" he asked shyly, not sure if these white foreigners before him were somehow connected to the drug trade. "The World Health Organisation, what is it doing to help people? I think that is a big organisation for the whole world. They should do something to control the price, or to put in a certain amount of money so that the drugs become cheaper. You've seen how people are dying in Malawi. It's a big pity."

Aids is economically ruinous. In a corner of the female ward at St Ann's lies Mary Mbwana. Mary, 35, twice married, is heavy, solidly built, but she, too, is in the final throes of the illness. Her sallow flesh is blotted and scarred with Kaposi's sarcoma. The disfiguring black-brown tumours under her skin run across her face, around her mouth, across her back and breasts. Her flesh has burst open at the thigh. There is a dinner plate-sized wound. She is running a fever, wallowing in pain, struggling in the last hours of life. Her "guardian", her aged mother Miriam, sits by her bed and drives the flies away that gather on the vomit-smeared sheets. Everyone knows Mary will die soon. There is no more hope for Mary than there was for her sisters Jessie, 42, Irene, 48, Agatha, 35, Dorothy, 52, and her brother Lawrence, 51, who all died from the virus last year. Mary will be the sixth sibling, out of a family of 11, to die of Aids. Miriam is now a mother again to her 28 grandchildren, all orphaned, and none older than 15.

The Mbwanas, never rich but once moderately prosperous by Malawi's meagre standards, are destitute. Whatever resources the family had have all been lost by the futile succession of medical bills, and then the coffins and funeral meals. Irene's husband is dead, Dorothy's "passed away" last year, the others are already weakening. Mary's husband is an ill man. There is no one left to pay the children's school fees, no one left to earn the money to buy the maize porridge to feed such a huge brood of children.

The extended family, the great support mechanism of Africa, is shattered. The family's fortunes have fallen so far that Mary is trapped in the hospital. To be discharged, even to go home to die, you must pay your medical bills. Mary owes 1,600 kwacha , about £13. The family do not have the money and so the medical bills mount. And Miriam and her eldest daughter, Georgina, wait for the inevitable.

"My sisters were very beautiful, and now they are all gone, " explains Georgina. "How can I feel when I see their houses, all three in a row, all empty. I used to be able to say 'do this for me, do that'. At that time, all of these were alive and so could easily contribute. But this time mum is alone, I am alone. These are the ones looking after the family. It's very difficult. If sometimes food is small, mum just gives to the children and sleeps without food. I also have nine children. And now I have nobody. This time I am helping Mary, and Mary will not help me back. So this is really powerful. And mum will have no one to look after her."

But Mary is not the end of Georgina's troubles. Back in the children's ward of the district hospital, John Phiri, Georgina's 18-month-old grandson, is running another fever. He is vomiting, he has diarrhoea. He is fatally dehydrating. He lies listless in the listless arms of his mother, 35-year-old Madrind, Georgina's mother. Madrind is herself sick with the virus. She scratches at the rash that runs from her feet to her chest. Her limbs are withered and her eyes utterly defeated. Madrind is John's "guardian", but she is so weak she can barely look after herself. Sometimes her second husband, Karimi Phiri, comes to support her and sometimes he does not. Three of Madrind's five children have already died, as John will soon. Only her oldest boy, six-year-old Alinafe - whose name, ironically, means "God is with us" in Chewa - will possibly survive.

"Madrind is beyond sad," says Georgina. "She is defeated. She knows she is going to die. She will not survive this, nor will John. She has the same rashes as her first husband, who passed away. They are exactly the same kind of rashes he was asking her to scratch. She is lonely, very lonely."

Back in Selemani 2, just before dawn, a barefoot squad of grave-diggers went down to the lakeshore to the dig Eliza's grave in the orange African earth. The singing never stopped and then sermons and speeches were given. They carried Eliza down to her final resting place on a succession of hands held at waist level, the pallbearers peeling off from the back of the coffin and rejoining at the front, to make a never ceasing human stream.

It was a long day in the African sun, and by the time we returned to the hospital, Mary Mbwana was dead. A year before, she had fought off tuberculosis. But there was no escape from the virus. Her funeral began that evening. The mourners danced all night around her empty coffin, they sang their hearts out. They sang, too, in the mortuary the next morning as the women unwrapped Mary from her winding sheet and washed and dressed her body for the grave. Mary was so disfigured by her facial tumours that the coffin, contrary to tradition, had to remain closed. There was no final viewing, no "final face". But nothing broke the rhythm of these women's singing apart from a moment as they left the mortuary. From outside came another sound, the high-pitched cry of other women keening; another dead patient, another funeral party, had arrived at the mortuary.

Mary's relatives took her home in the brown coffin, singing all the way as they passed through town. Later on, there were three-hour long soaring sermons in the blasting sun. No one mentioned Aids.

Viruses are strings of genetic material. The Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is composed of ribonucleic acid (RNA), a line of basic amino acids, CCs, UUs, AAs and GGs. It was not the HIV virus directly that killed Eliza Mwase; it infected her T-helper cells with its own genetic code. It turned Mary Mbwana's own CD4 lymphocytes into viral replication machines that produced more copies of its own genetic code and infected more CD4 lymphocytes and broke down her immune system. And then other opportunistic organisms, bacteria, other viruses, mutations, killed her.

The virus has replicated millions of counterfeit but immunologically useless copies of John Phiri's CD4 lymphocytes and stripped him of his ability to resist commonplace infections. The HIV virus blindly wreaks havoc, but it is just a genetic copying machine.

We could, in the west, try and put a stop it. To do nothing is to turn our hearts away, shut our ears to the soft words of despair, and wait to listen in silence to the sound of African keening. What should be done? There is not an easy answer. Africa is not another suburb of Europe. The infrastructure is poor, roads, schools, hospitals are, in places, rudimentary; life is harsher. But that is not why people are dying of Aids in Africa. They are dying because they are being denied access to the drugs that could treat their opportunistic infections, and the antiretrovirals that would stop that piece of genetic material - HIV - from replicating inside their bodies.

The patent rights on the drugs that could save them are owned by large western pharmaceutical companies such as Pfizer, Glaxo-Wellcome, Boehringer Ingelheim, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Merck and Hoffman-La Roche. These companies are powerful economic interests, with widespread political influence. They are supported by western governments such as Britain and the United States, as well as the World Bank, the World Trade Organisation, the United Nations, the World Health Organisation, even UNAIDS, the Aids arm of United Nations. These companies, and their tied political interests, are all part of the "international community" that is intensely concerned about Aids in Africa - but not quite concerned enough to do anything significant about it.

Aids story: part 2
fields.bodyText: It's 1am on the female medical ward of Nhkotakota Government District Hospital by the shores of Lake Malawi, and Eliza Mwase rises from her bed for a sip of water. Pulled into a sitting position by her aunts, Jane and Patricia, Eliza calls out in Chewa, the local language: "It hurts, it hurts." Tenderly, as if soothing a child, the women repeat her name, "Eliza, Eliza", as they lift the cup to her lips. Eliza's hands writhe involuntarily at her wrists, as if they have taken a life of their own and seek to escape their dying host. Eliza coughs, struggling to clear her lungs, and her eyes blaze black, uncomprehending, with pain. As she sips, the water spills over her chin and down her front. Eliza is 21, but she has become a child again. She is three hours from death. A light African rain begins to drum on the ward's tin roof. Two paces from the foot of Eliza's bed, a baby sleeps beside his mother on the concrete floor. Every inch of floor space is covered with patients and their relatives, "guardians" who tend their every non-medical need. The dying and living are crowded in here, meshed as one. In the morning, the sun will rise and these sleeping bodies return again to life. But not Eliza. The rains drum on. It is the last sound this child of Africa will ever hear. Eliza Mwase died at 4am that morning, another victim of the Aids epidemic that is tearing its way through Africa. In the west, Aids has become a non-story. Antiretrovirals, drug combination therapies, $15,000 per annum treatment programmes and the disease, if not curable, is at least controllable. Aids has dropped away from the public eye. World Aids Day has become an annual ritual, something that can be marked in a calendar and then forgotten about the following day. But in Africa, Aids is a catastrophe without end, a searing epidemic that has destroyed families, orphaned millions of children, killed the elite and crippled the already impoverished economies of the world's poorest countries. Aids has killed 18.8 million worldwide since the early 80s, but the overwhelming death toll - 16 million - has been in Africa. The United Nations estimates that there are now 34.3 million living with the virus - 24.5 million of those live in sub-Saharan Africa. Millions more, possibly hundreds of millions more, will become infected. In contrast, in Britain there are 31,000 people living with Aids out of a population of 59 million. Among the adult population - which, for the purposes of the UN report, means 15 to 49-year-olds - there is a prevalence rate of 0.11%. There were 450 Aids deaths in the United Kingdom last year. In Germany, the prevalence among adults is 0.10%, and there are 37,000 HIV-positives out of a total population of 82 million, and a 1999 death toll of 600. In the US, the prevalence rate, at 0.61% of the adult population, is higher, but that still gives just a total of 850,000 HIV-positive people of all ages out of a population of 276 million. There were 20,000 Aids deaths in the US last year. Malawi, one of the poorest countries with an annual per capita income of $190, has an official HIV prevalence rate of 16% among the 15-49 age group. The population of Malawi is 10.7m. The total number of people infected with the virus in Malawi, including 40,000 children, is 800,000 - almost the same as in the US. Last year alone, 70,000 Malawians died of Aids. The incubation period for the virus is eight to 10 years; the death toll is accelerating. Malawi is not even at the epicentre of the Aids pandemic. Many other sub-Saharan countries, Botswana (35%), Zimbabwe (25%), Lesotho (23%), Zambia (20%), and Namibia (19%) have higher rates of infectivity among adults. Aids has replaced war, drought, every other disease, including malaria, as the leading cause of death. Demographically, many African societies have become shaped like pyramids; you start out with lots of babies at the base and then taper away like a pyramid as death, disease, mortal happenstance, take its toll until you have a narrow tip of 80-year-olds at the apex. But in Africa, Aids is slicing huge chunks out of the economically productive middle generations as 15 to 49-year-olds succumb to the virus. The pyramid is turning into a narrow chimney. Life expectancy is falling by a decade. A 15-year-old Zimbabwean boy now has a 50% chance of dying of Aids before he is 50. If anything, Malawi is a backward province in the Aids catastrophe, yet the death toll, the devastation of human lives, is awesome. To walk the concrete corridors of Nhkotakota District Hospital is to enter a charnel house of human suffering. Aids is a hydra-headed medical monster that manifests itself in the withered tubercular bodies of the patients. It is there in the suppurating leg ulcers of 35-year-old Mary Mbwana, who is suffering from the skin cancer, Kaposi's sarcoma. It lies deep behind the weeping herpes genital sores of one-time tobacco clerk, 29-year-old William Chimwavi. It is the plague that infects the body of 18-month-old John Phiri, who has, through recurrent bouts of infection, diarrhoea and vomiting, failed to thrive. Three of John's brothers have already died - five-year-old Gift, Romeo, four months, and four-year-old Levinson. It has laid low his mother, Madrind, 35, who suffers from undetermined rashes, infections, wasting and who, too, will soon die like her first husband, Rajab Phiri. Just as Eliza's mother, Frieda Mwase, 42, did. And just as Eliza's father, Thomas Mwase, 49, did earlier this year. As did the four sisters and one brother of Mary Mbwana. And the virus has infected, too, Christina Mondhali, the night nurse still working on the TB ward at Nhkotakota, and the local coffin-maker, Christopher Msowoya. There is no end to this long day of dying. No one dies of Aids in Malawi. Malawians die of a "short illness", or they contract an unspecified "fever", or they vomit so much they cannot drink. Since 1994, 29 of Malawi's 177 members of parliament have died from "short illnesses" - as did the president's brother. In Chewa, Aids is known as "matantanda athu omwewa". It means "this new disease of ours". Sometimes Aids is also called "the government disease", meaning "this thing we all have in common". The graveyards are filling and everyone knows someone who has died of Aids, but from fear and superstition, the word is never spoken. Even the medical charts of the sick do not betray the secret. Eliza's charts just read "fever" and "anaemia". "Here in Malawi, it's still a shameful disease. If someone dies of Aids, even the churches will say he or she was an adulterer or a prostitute," says Christina Mondhali, who is one of few medical professionals in Malawi who is open about her HIV status. Malawi is in denial. Malawi's First Lady, Patricia Shanil Muluzi, may have adopted six Aids orphans. The walls of Malawian brothels may have condom murals. And every Malawian school is visited by "drama groups" warning of the dangers of teenage sex. But Aids is talked about in the abstract, not the personal. It is the same across most of southern Africa. Last month, the Alastair Campbell of South Africa, Parks Mankahlana, chief press aide to Nelson Mandela and South African president Thabo Mbeki, died of Aids, even though his widow, Nthabiseng, insisted that he died of "chronic anaemia". In a pointed rebuke to his successor, Mandela recently called for the war against Aids in South Africa to become a top priority, clearly referring to Mbeki's strange flirtation with the rejectionist theories of Professor Peter Duesberg, of the University of California, Berkeley, who disputes that Aids is caused by a virus. The denial is counter-productive, but the fear is understandable. Even for the Malawian elite, there is no hope of containing the disease. No one can afford the expensive western antiretrovirals that can stem the virus and save your life. To declare yourself HIV-positive is to live out your death sentence in public. Most Malawians still refuse HIV tests. "People think it's better not to know. 'You will die from your worries.' They think you do the test and just prepare to die. They think there is no cure for Aids, and it's true," said Sam Ndhlovu, a nurse at Nhkotakota. Attitudes are changing, but changing slowly. "It's not a shameful thing. It's an illness, just the same as malaria or TB. If I hide, I am still going to die with it," says Christina Mondhali. In the west, we have, through our medical power, lost all understanding of what plague is. Our experiences of epidemics is restricted to winter flus, colds, medical irritations that carry off the old and the vulnerable. We take a hostile attitude to personalised infection. If you get gonorrhoea, a sexually transmitted disease, you go to the STD clinic, get antibiotics, go home and you might shout at the person who passed on the infection. There is a causal link. And a cure. But in Malawi, the Aids epidemic is everywhere. The first 17 Aids cases were reported in 1985, but the virus was already spreading exponentially throughout the general population. The virus's latent potential, up to a decade between infection and symptoms, masked its spread throughout the population. Aids fatally shadows every sexual encounter, every sexual act, between adult Malawians for the past 20 years. "It's difficult to say, 'You are the one who gave me the virus,' " says David Nyirongo, an organiser with the charity ActionAid, who is himself HIV-positive. "I might have a girlfriend and I might have infected her with the virus. But she might not exactly know it's me. She might have slept with other men. She could have got it from them. She could have given it to me. It's difficult to know the history of anyone. That's why we are unable to point the fingers of suspicion." Even those such as Christina Mondhali who can point the finger - her husband gave her herpes when she was four months pregnant with their first child and she later tested HIV-positive - are stoic. "I do not blame him. And even if I did, what can be done now?" In Malawi's "final days", there is no room for self-pity. "I am not afraid of dying," says David Nyirongo, who married again and has three children with his new wife, Juliana, also HIV-positive. "I have not yet started suffering. I feel sad every time you hear of the death of someone you know with Aids. I think, 'Tomorrow it's me.' Then I forget. I hope, I dream, we can get the new drugs [antiretrovirals] and start a new life." Nhkotakota is not an important town in Malawi. It's a place between other bigger places. It has grown up around an old mission station and nearby Lake Malawi, one of Africa's largest freshwater lakes. There is a petrol station, a line of market stalls, shops, another line of bars/ brothels/resthouses, the A K Paradise Club, the Arizona Special Bottle Store, and the Zabwino Bar. Beyond lies a string of villages, some with mud walls and thatched roofs, others built of brick and corrugated iron, that run into each other before turning to bush. You could drive past in five minutes. Nhkotakota is a dorp, a small unnoticed place in a small unnoticed country in southern Africa. If you turn right at the petrol station and drive a mile off the Tarmac road towards the lake, you'll find Nhkotakota's two hospitals. For some reason, the Government District Hospital was built half a mile away from the old mission hospital of St Ann's. Both hospitals are a jumble of one-storey brick buildings with corrugated roofs. In the back yard of the government hospital is a scatter of broken-down ambulances, their parts cannibalised to service the rest of the decrepit fleet. The outside latrines stink and the sewage runs into the surrounding bush. Recently, a new male medical ward was built at the government hospital, or Boma, as it is known, to relieve the grotesque overcrowding in the main buildings, but the donor funding ran out after the roof went on. The ward sits there forlorn, an empty hulk, waiting for the dying to enter its walls. Across the courtyard, in the main compound, the sick are crowded so tightly against each other that even in the day you must pick your way carefully through the prostrate bodies. The conditions at St Ann's are better, but not that much better. Besides St Ann's is a tree where David Livingstone, the explorer, supposedly met the African chief Jumbe in 1861 and persuaded him to give up the slave trade. The tree has been designated a Malawian National Monument and earns Nhkotakota its only mention in tourist guidebooks. The total population of the outlying Nhkotakota district is around 250,000. There are three doctors for the whole district. Medical treatment in Malawi is theoretically free in government hospitals such as the Boma. The government provides the beds, the drugs and the medical care. Your family, your guardians who sleep on the floor beside your bed, provide the washing, the cleaning, the cooking and the food. But it does not really work out like that. In Malawi, if you are sick, you shop around. If you have money, $10 or maybe $20, you go to a private clinic or a mission hospital such as St Ann's, where the daily costs of being an in-patient are 250 kwacha - about £2 - but the conditions are cleaner, drugs more readily available and the quality of treatment higher. But you need money. We were at St Ann's one morning when an ambulance arrived with a desperately sick man suffering from cerebral malaria - fatal within hours unless treated. He was dying in front of our eyes, but the ambulance was turned away; his family did not have the 250 kwacha for the deposit on the bed for the first day. If you have no money, then there is no choice; you must queue in the morning heat of the Boma's outpatients clinic and hope to be admitted. Demand outstrips supply. There are 130 beds, and every morning another 250 would-be patients appear at the gates. All but the sickest are turned away, as well as the medically hopeless, who are sent back home to die. There is not enough staff, not enough drugs, not enough needles, not enough anything. On one of the days the photographer Gideon Mendel and I were there, the hospital had run out of plasters. After begging the right-sized needle for the child's tiny veins from the nearby mission hospital, staff used cotton wool and a piece of masking tape to bind the drip needle to 18-month-old John Phiri's arm in order to rehydrate him and save his life. There is no hope of change. Malawi is poor and getting poorer. The price of its main export crops - tea and tobacco - is falling. Since last year, the kwacha, has slid downwards against the US dollar, from 43 kwacha to 80, doubling the interest payments on Malawi's international debts. The interest payments on these loans is now one-and-half-times greater than the national health budget. But even if the kwacha was soaring, it would not make any difference. Malawi's hospitals are under siege. Up to 80% of all patients are HIV-positive and have complex, multiple, difficult-to-treat, and ultimately untreatable, infections. The government has an annual health budget of about $10 per capita. Malawi relies on foreign donations to fund its spiralling medical bills. Crucially, for the past two years Malawi has been unable to afford to pay for the reagents used in HIV test kits. There is barely enough reagent to test blood donations. In 1997, even St Ann's mission hospital ran out of money and could not pay its staff for two months. "We are overwhelmed in every aspect of the epidemic, the lack of equipment, the lack of staff, all angles. We have been engulfed by the problem," says Dr Maurice Bonongwe, Nhkotakota District Hospital's sole physician. Every one of those 800,000 Malawian citizens who are HIV-positive, just like every one of the 24.5 million sub-Saharan Africans with the virus, is going to die of Aids unless the west intervenes. We found Eliza again, wrapped in a sheet and lying on the floor of a mud-walled hut in her grandfather's village, Selemani 2, on the shore of Lake Malawi, about 10 miles from the hospital. She had gone home on the metal floor of the government ambulance/hearse. The hospital morgue, like the hospital, is tight for space; by 8am there was another patient in the same bed. The hut was lit by a paraffin lamp and in death Eliza seemed impossibly small, a girl-child. Selemani 2 is a beautiful place; fishermen's boats ride the freshwater swell and the shore is dotted with the blood-red blossom fallen from bougainvillea trees. Eliza had come back here in early October, to her grandfather's house, after she grew too sick to be in the city. But Eliza just got sicker and sicker. She had been living in Mzuzu, a town 300km away, with her parents, and then the catastrophe struck. In 1998, her mother Frieda, 42, grew sick and died and then her father Thomas, 49, died earlier this year. Eliza, her family said, was a schoolgirl even though she was 21. That's not uncommon in Malawi, where pupils often drop out for a year or two as the family saves to pay school fees. Someone else said Eliza had worked in bars. Even as she was dying, you could see that she had been beautiful. Like most societies, Malawians are hypocritical about sex. Malawi is a religious country. Open homosexuality is still a cultural taboo. Intravenous drug misuse is virtually unknown. Families go to church, listen to sermons, believe in God, chastity, the Ten Commandments, and then the men go to bars at the weekend and sleep with prostitutes. Malawi is poor, the workforce unskilled, there is a lot of unemployment; unsupported women are at the bottom of the economic heap. Sex is cheap, 250 kwacha - about £2 - for a brief session. Prostitution is casual, semi-open, and culturally acceptable. Until recently, most Malawian men did not want to use condoms; there were 500,000 cases of sexually transmitted diseases (STD) in 1998; 70% of prostitutes test positive; 50% of men attending STD clinics also test positive. After the weekend, the men go back and have unprotected sex with their wives. The virus spreads. Changing private sexual behaviours is incredibly difficult. Since the 60s, the British government, rich and infinitely powerful by Malawian standards, has bombarded its citizens with propaganda about contraception and the follies of teenage pregnancy. Hundreds of millions of pounds have been spent on advice centres, public education campaigns, free contraceptives. After 30 years, Britain still has the highest teenage pregnancy rate in Western Europe. Iasked Dr Bonongwe if, in the midst of all this death, he was confident that Malawians would change and practise safer sex. He paused for a moment, as if searching for a complex answer: "No, I don't think so. There is no prospect that people will change their behaviour. We advocate the use of condoms, but the churches do not support the use of condoms," he said with a sad finality. "I expect many, many people over the next 10 years to die. For those who have been sexually active, it's a disaster. Only the children, those aged five to 15, who we are cherishing as a future, will survive." Children make up a large proportion of the Malawian population and, despite the danger of HIV-positive mothers passing on the disease to their babies, so far the infection rate among those 14 and under is a fraction of that among the adult population. Culturally, Malawians are accustomed to straight vaginal sex. But there seem to be some crucial differences in the way the virus infects men and women. Women are more easily infected. And women get infected younger because men tend to sleep with younger women and can use their greater economic power to buy sex. But it all evens out in the end. The older you are, the shorter the time span between infection and death; sugar daddies die, too. Eliza's family were poor, poor beyond our imagining. Malawian funerals are great public events. The entire village gathers to spend the night at the house of the deceased. Songs are sung; Jesus is praised, the Devil is condemned. The songs go on all night long. The mourners must be fed, the food cooked, and firewood gathered. Funerals are expensive. The price of her coffin - 2,400 kwacha, about £20 - was beyond them. We gave a little money and a lift to the coffin-maker back into town. Business is brisk in the Malawian coffin trade. In a good week, Christopher Moswoya, one of two coffin-makers in the town, takes orders for 10-12 coffins. They come in three sizes; standard, middle, small. But Christopher was not planning to expand; he was also sick with the virus. As he sanded and varnished Eliza's coffin, we fell into conversation. The coffin trade in Malawi was a good business, but life would be easier if he could afford power tools. Without those tools, he had to saw tree trunks by hand. It was arm-breaking work. "If I got sick, I could still work. You just press the button and it goes." But the price of power tools, like the price of western antiretrovirals, was beyond his reach. Christopher wanted to know about the drugs, too. He wanted to know why western drug companies charged so much. "So, are they after business?" he asked shyly, not sure if these white foreigners before him were somehow connected to the drug trade. "The World Health Organisation, what is it doing to help people? I think that is a big organisation for the whole world. They should do something to control the price, or to put in a certain amount of money so that the drugs become cheaper. You've seen how people are dying in Malawi. It's a big pity." Aids is economically ruinous. In a corner of the female ward at St Ann's lies Mary Mbwana. Mary, 35, twice married, is heavy, solidly built, but she, too, is in the final throes of the illness. Her sallow flesh is blotted and scarred with Kaposi's sarcoma. The disfiguring black-brown tumours under her skin run across her face, around her mouth, across her back and breasts. Her flesh has burst open at the thigh. There is a dinner plate-sized wound. She is running a fever, wallowing in pain, struggling in the last hours of life. Her "guardian", her aged mother Miriam, sits by her bed and drives the flies away that gather on the vomit-smeared sheets. Everyone knows Mary will die soon. There is no more hope for Mary than there was for her sisters Jessie, 42, Irene, 48, Agatha, 35, Dorothy, 52, and her brother Lawrence, 51, who all died from the virus last year. Mary will be the sixth sibling, out of a family of 11, to die of Aids. Miriam is now a mother again to her 28 grandchildren, all orphaned, and none older than 15. The Mbwanas, never rich but once moderately prosperous by Malawi's meagre standards, are destitute. Whatever resources the family had have all been lost by the futile succession of medical bills, and then the coffins and funeral meals. Irene's husband is dead, Dorothy's "passed away" last year, the others are already weakening. Mary's husband is an ill man. There is no one left to pay the children's school fees, no one left to earn the money to buy the maize porridge to feed such a huge brood of children. The extended family, the great support mechanism of Africa, is shattered. The family's fortunes have fallen so far that Mary is trapped in the hospital. To be discharged, even to go home to die, you must pay your medical bills. Mary owes 1,600 kwacha , about £13. The family do not have the money and so the medical bills mount. And Miriam and her eldest daughter, Georgina, wait for the inevitable. "My sisters were very beautiful, and now they are all gone, " explains Georgina. "How can I feel when I see their houses, all three in a row, all empty. I used to be able to say 'do this for me, do that'. At that time, all of these were alive and so could easily contribute. But this time mum is alone, I am alone. These are the ones looking after the family. It's very difficult. If sometimes food is small, mum just gives to the children and sleeps without food. I also have nine children. And now I have nobody. This time I am helping Mary, and Mary will not help me back. So this is really powerful. And mum will have no one to look after her." But Mary is not the end of Georgina's troubles. Back in the children's ward of the district hospital, John Phiri, Georgina's 18-month-old grandson, is running another fever. He is vomiting, he has diarrhoea. He is fatally dehydrating. He lies listless in the listless arms of his mother, 35-year-old Madrind, Georgina's mother. Madrind is herself sick with the virus. She scratches at the rash that runs from her feet to her chest. Her limbs are withered and her eyes utterly defeated. Madrind is John's "guardian", but she is so weak she can barely look after herself. Sometimes her second husband, Karimi Phiri, comes to support her and sometimes he does not. Three of Madrind's five children have already died, as John will soon. Only her oldest boy, six-year-old Alinafe - whose name, ironically, means "God is with us" in Chewa - will possibly survive. "Madrind is beyond sad," says Georgina. "She is defeated. She knows she is going to die. She will not survive this, nor will John. She has the same rashes as her first husband, who passed away. They are exactly the same kind of rashes he was asking her to scratch. She is lonely, very lonely." Back in Selemani 2, just before dawn, a barefoot squad of grave-diggers went down to the lakeshore to the dig Eliza's grave in the orange African earth. The singing never stopped and then sermons and speeches were given. They carried Eliza down to her final resting place on a succession of hands held at waist level, the pallbearers peeling off from the back of the coffin and rejoining at the front, to make a never ceasing human stream. It was a long day in the African sun, and by the time we returned to the hospital, Mary Mbwana was dead. A year before, she had fought off tuberculosis. But there was no escape from the virus. Her funeral began that evening. The mourners danced all night around her empty coffin, they sang their hearts out. They sang, too, in the mortuary the next morning as the women unwrapped Mary from her winding sheet and washed and dressed her body for the grave. Mary was so disfigured by her facial tumours that the coffin, contrary to tradition, had to remain closed. There was no final viewing, no "final face". But nothing broke the rhythm of these women's singing apart from a moment as they left the mortuary. From outside came another sound, the high-pitched cry of other women keening; another dead patient, another funeral party, had arrived at the mortuary. Mary's relatives took her home in the brown coffin, singing all the way as they passed through town. Later on, there were three-hour long soaring sermons in the blasting sun. No one mentioned Aids. Viruses are strings of genetic material. The Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is composed of ribonucleic acid (RNA), a line of basic amino acids, CCs, UUs, AAs and GGs. It was not the HIV virus directly that killed Eliza Mwase; it infected her T-helper cells with its own genetic code. It turned Mary Mbwana's own CD4 lymphocytes into viral replication machines that produced more copies of its own genetic code and infected more CD4 lymphocytes and broke down her immune system. And then other opportunistic organisms, bacteria, other viruses, mutations, killed her. The virus has replicated millions of counterfeit but immunologically useless copies of John Phiri's CD4 lymphocytes and stripped him of his ability to resist commonplace infections. The HIV virus blindly wreaks havoc, but it is just a genetic copying machine. We could, in the west, try and put a stop it. To do nothing is to turn our hearts away, shut our ears to the soft words of despair, and wait to listen in silence to the sound of African keening. What should be done? There is not an easy answer. Africa is not another suburb of Europe. The infrastructure is poor, roads, schools, hospitals are, in places, rudimentary; life is harsher. But that is not why people are dying of Aids in Africa. They are dying because they are being denied access to the drugs that could treat their opportunistic infections, and the antiretrovirals that would stop that piece of genetic material - HIV - from replicating inside their bodies. The patent rights on the drugs that could save them are owned by large western pharmaceutical companies such as Pfizer, Glaxo-Wellcome, Boehringer Ingelheim, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Merck and Hoffman-La Roche. These companies are powerful economic interests, with widespread political influence. They are supported by western governments such as Britain and the United States, as well as the World Bank, the World Trade Organisation, the United Nations, the World Health Organisation, even UNAIDS, the Aids arm of United Nations. These companies, and their tied political interests, are all part of the "international community" that is intensely concerned about Aids in Africa - but not quite concerned enough to do anything significant about it. Aids story: part 2

fields.headline: Holidays are the best high
fields.standfirst: The sun is addictive, and, as with drugs, you'll constantly be convinced you haven't got enough. But your permatan is only the half of it . . .
fields.trailText: The sun is addictive, and, as with drugs, you'll constantly be convinced you haven't got enough. But your permatan is only the half of it . . .
fields.body:
As my hairdresser said the other day to the customer with a rat's nest of hair and winter flaky bits all over her scalp, "You don't need hair care, you need an airplane ticket." She is right, of course. Now that ecstasy has gone to the dogs, cocaine has become the province of the "stability and security" brigade, as indispensable as a mortgage, and Slim-Fast and marijuana haven't really kicked in yet, the sun remains the best high of them all. And, unique among drugs, the sun does not make you paranoid nor grind your teeth.

A new report shows that UK residents made a record 53.9m visits to hot, overseas countries last year. That's 3m up on the year before. True, British men still have the tendency to lie on Spanish beaches with bodies like wet fish shops and limbs flinching spasmodically as if the sun were a flock of flies, but evolution is creeping in.

When Gerald Corbett resigned from Railtrack, he didn't say he was going to be spending time in the relatively temperate climes of Tuscany or Majorca. He said he was off all the way to India. There, presumably, he will contemplate his place in an absurd and incoherent universe, and get alienated and have full-blown panic attacks.

It was time the British got out more. In the mid-90s, when I lived in Paris, the UK seemed a very exciting place. I would read about the "London Lesbian SM debate" and think, "Wow, how cool and sophisticated!" because I hadn't even managed to track down a single lesbian in Paris. Then I went to live in London and discovered that this "debate" consisted of three lesbians dressed in a Johnny Cash oiled-leather- and-chains look being challenged when they tried to get a post-10.30pm beer at the London Lesbian and Gay centre one Sunday night. The woman at the door, in fullest CND drag, said that their clothes were degrading to women. (The four of them ended up playing Trivial Pursuit together on several occasions.)

There is no more sexual abandonment. Tequila-fuelled orgies in bedfulls of dollars are nowhere to be seen; men walking in the slow lane of gym swimming pools talking into their mobile phones are all around. In the days when you had to get a Vietnam war vet to do it, body piercing was the outer manifestation of a good inner sex life; now, every Dorothy Perkins shop assistant has a face full of shrapnel.

It is an Anglo-Saxon fallacy that the sun is bad for your looks. Back in Cornwall, where I grew up in the 70s, they used to use olive oil as sun lotion. And it was quite sunny in those days, too. Much more harmful to people's looks was a senseless pasty complexion, just as nowadays people do far more harm to their faces with the new scourge of Botox - a dose of botulism that people inject to paralyse the face muscles and so do away with wrinkles - than they ever do with rays from the sun.

Where's the female equivalent of that "man just come off the oil rig covered in grease and fresh sweat" look? On a man, this look works on any age, from 17-year-old hunk to Burt Reynolds wrinkly. There are lots of women who carry off that Georgia O'Keeffe weather-beaten look well, but they don't get any press. There's Lauren Bacall, who's let herself go with the flow, but she's 70. What about in between? Why has the 40-year look vanished in the Bermuda Triangle?

Go to Bermuda, I say. Vitamin D is best. Like a crème brlée heated under the grill, the sun makes you look tasty and, with any luck, you might end up looking like Donatella Versace. Just be aware that, like all drugs, the sun is addictive. As with all drugs, you will constantly be convinced that you haven't got enough of it and will want more. But your permatan is only the half of it.

Hopefully, all those extra Brits now going to Spain every year will get over their British obsession with foxes and strangled birds. In the early evenings, when the British are watching Rolf Harris in Animal Hospital, the Spanish are tuning in to the bulls-being-hacked-to-death-in-a-ring channel.

The sun definitely has something to do with this state of affairs, and the plus point is that the Spaniards don't have boy band singers as heroes - they have 17-year-old bullfighters who all look like Ricky Martin, only better.

You can see the attraction. In one sense, bullfights are a very macho affair. If you kill the bull badly (that is, if the final sword thrust to the animal's neck goes in at the wrong place, so the bull capers around the ring with blood spurting out), the crowd cries out angrily to the bullfighter: "Maricón!" ("Maricón!" meaning "Poofter!").

Interesting that they use the term as an insult, since there is something very effeminate about the concept of machismo in general, and especially bullfighters who wear pink boleros and black ballet pumps and strut around in poses that outline their groin to the best advantage.

Bullfights make the English preoccupation with foxes and pheasants seem very arbitrary. It makes you ponder on the meaning of life in an absurd and incoherent universe. That pheasant the Queen killed might well be reincarnated as a bull in Andalusia, and it might get killed by a poofter, and then it would be sorry.

Besides, between bullfights and those people who phone up Radio 5 call-ins to say that homosexuality (pronounced with flat o's to make it sound like the BSE virus) is bad because the Bible says so, I'd take the bullfights - even though they grate after a while. You quickly get bored of seeing bulls being killed and start thinking that maybe it would be nice for a giraffe or two to be brought on. A few rabbits, too, maybe.

Happiness, as the Arabs say, is in the saddle. The best bit of the sun as drug is the part when you are sitting in the restaurant eating your paella, drinking your Penedes and experiencing an escapist rush like the distant echo of some happiness you once knew. By the time you are down to your last pieces of squid, you are glowing. You turn towards the sea and you scoff at the craving for stability and security.

 Stephanie Theobald's novel, Biche, is published by Flame at £10.99. Julie Burchill is away.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: While I agree with Michela Wrong (November 25) finding comparisons between Britain and the third world offensive, I find equally offensive her characterisation of the latter as all about living in fear of drunken soldiers.
fields.body:
While I agree with Michela Wrong (November 25) finding comparisons between Britain and the third world offensive, I find equally offensive her characterisation of the latter as all about living in fear of drunken soldiers. What limited glimpses the media here give us of the third world are full of such stereotypes, and it ill behoves Wrong to generalise so wildly from her unpleasant experiences in the Congo.
Erica Lewis
Welwyn Garden City, Herts

Michela Wrong is so right.
Patrick Dyke
Lechlade, Glos

What a marvellously refreshing page 3. Informative, coherent and challenging - unlike the teased-out navel-fluff Julie Burchill dishes up. How much would it cost us to keep JB 'away'? Can we have a readers' referendum on it? Please?
Brian Holt
Hayling Island, Hants

Despite what is written and spoken in the media, the expression 'third world countries' is not in common parlance among the rest of us. How would I know? I am a geography teacher, and the National Curriculum requires that I teach about LEDCs (Less Economically Developed Countries) and contrast them with MEDCs (More Economically Developed Countries) - so I do.

In any case, use of 'third world' is ludicrous now that we no longer have any so-called 'second world' countries.
Mrs JM Sawyer
Wilmslow, Cheshire

By and large, I agree with Alexander Chancellor's assessment of John Aspinall (November 25), but perhaps he should have been allowed to put his culling theory to the test. I suspect that, in most people's scheme of things, Aspinall, Goldsmith, Lucan and their ilk would be the first to qualify for a heroic plummet over the nearest cliff.
Robert Madge

fields.headline: Some strange elsewhere?
fields.standfirst: On TV, Bush stood between two American flags. The next day, Gore appeared with four flags behind him, to challenge Bush's victory claim.
fields.trailText: On TV, Bush stood between two American flags. The next day, Gore appeared with four flags behind him, to challenge Bush's victory claim.
fields.body:
A frustrated senior official of the Clinton White House has been emailing friends with his idea of how Americans would regard the presidential election if it had occurred in a developing country. Imagine, he wrote, that we read of an election in which the self-declared winner was the son of the former prime minister, and that the former prime minister was himself the former head of the nation's secret police (George Bush Senior was head of the CIA). Imagine that the self-declared winner lost the popular vote but won the election because of some old colonial holdover (the electoral college) from the nation's past. Imagine that the self-declared winner's "victory" turned on disputed votes cast in a province governed by his brother. Imagine that the poorly drafted ballots of one district that heavily favoured the self-declared winner's opponent led thousands to vote for the wrong candidate.

Imagine that members of the nation's most-despised caste, fearing for their lives/livelihoods, turned out in record numbers to vote in near-universal opposition to the self-declared winner. Imagine that hundreds of members of that caste were intercepted on their way to the polls by state police operating under the authority of the self-declared winner's brother. Imagine that six million people voted in the disputed province and that the self-declared winner's "lead" was only 327. Imagine that the self-declared winner and his party opposed a by-hand inspection and re-count in the disputed province or in its most hotly disputed district.

Imagine that the self-declared winner, himself the governor of a major province, was responsible for the worst human rights record of any province in his nation and led the nation in executions, and that a major campaign promise was to appoint like-minded human rights violators to lifetime positions on the high court of that nation. "None of us," the Clinton official concluded, "would deem such an election to be representative of anything other than the self-declared winner's will to power. All of us, I imagine, would wearily turn the page, thinking that it was another sad tale of pitiful pre- or anti-democracy peoples in some strange elsewhere."

Most Americans, though beginning to feel impatient and wanting Al Gore to concede just to get the whole thing over with, believe that the blizzard of law suits, re-counts, aborted re-counts and overturned executive decisions in the state of Florida reflect well on America's democratic institutions. Why would people go to all this trouble and expense if not out of concern for the principle that every vote counts?

Actually, the scenario offered by our partisan friend in the White House, for all its obvious exaggerations, is somewhat nearer the mark. Thanks mainly to Florida's primitive punch-card technology, which spews out ambiguous dimpled or pregnant chads, there is no way that every vote could be made to count, even if the Florida legislature had used its power to order a state-wide re-count, which it didn't.

Second, the candidates themselves have assiduously promoted the idea that the state officials responsible for administering the election are too politically biased to be trusted. The George W Bush camp questioned the integrity of the officials re-counting votes in Democrat counties, while the Gore camp never ceased to point out that Katherine Harris - the "Dragon Lady of Tallahassee" and the woman who used her position as Florida's secretary of state to sabotage the re-counts - had been an active campaigner for Bush during the election. Her certification of Bush as the winner was then rubber-stamped with indecent haste by the governor of Florida, Bush's brother Jeb, even though President Clinton still refused to give "President-elect" Bush the key to the transition office in Washington or the $5.3m in federal funds allocated for preparing the next president to take over.

Given Florida's inability or unwillingness, or both, to produce a plausible result, it is clearly a "will to power", not concern for democracy, that has driven the candidates on in their post-election struggle. No amount of fake humility and statesmanship has been able to disguise this. Bush, exuding shallowness and opportunism, stood between two huge American flags when he went on television humbly to assume the burden of an office that still wasn't his. Gore, as the underdog, had four flags behind him when he went on TV next day to challenge Bush's victory claim - for no other purpose, he said, than to preserve "democracy itself".

In the outcome of this election, because it was effectively a draw, the will of the people cannot be the decisive factor. Until the US Supreme Court makes some magisterial judgment, it can be decided not by numbers of votes but by which candidate blinks first and concedes: that is, whoever feels he is losing the television battle. Even to fans of the American democratic system, the US is looking like "some strange elsewhere".

fields.headline: Low profile
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: "You've got enough hair sprouting out yer nostrils to weave a mouse's shoppin' basket. And you look five months pregnant"
fields.body:
Monday, November 27, Ashby-de-la-Zouch

Today is only the first day of Ramadan, yet Mohammed at the BP garage is already in a bad mood due to the fasting laws imposed on him by his religion. In a normal day at work, he would eat three packets of cheese-and-onion crisps and a Kit Kat or two. I remarked to him that he could do with losing at least four stone in weight. To my astonishment, he burst into an angry denunciation of my character and appearance, ending up with, "You should take a good look at yourself in the mirror, Moley.

You've got enough hair sprouting out yer nostrils to weave a mouse's shoppin' basket. And you look five months pregnant". I apologised at once for my rudeness. I tried to explain that my therapists, Dave Mutter and Anjelica House, were encouraging me to be honest during social intercourse. This seemed to exacerbate his anger, but thankfully he was diverted from giving me another tongue-lashing by a strident female motorist complaining about the lack of toilet paper in the ladies.

As I walked across the forecourt, I pondered on our conversation. From where did Mohammed get his image of my nasal hairs being woven into a mouse's shopping basket? And what was his reference to my looking five months pregnant about?

Tuesday, November 28

I took off my clothes and examined myself carefully in the wardrobe mirror this morning. My front view is quite nice. My shoulders are slightly stooped, my pectorals are perhaps lacking definition, but I am still above average in the looks department. However, my profile leaves a lot to be desired and, yes, Mohammed, my old schoolfriend, you spoke the simple truth: in profile, I do look five months pregnant. My belly, once a discreet concave, is now distinctly convex. How did this happen without my noticing?

I am shocked to discover that my son, Glenn, is keeping what he calls a top secret dairy . He has also written on the cover in barbed-wire writing "Open This Dairy At Your'e Perul". I was very tempted to find out what the boy had written about me, and had I been able to prise the lock off without it being detected I may well have found out.

Wednesday, November 29

Can anybody tell me why we British export our beef to France and why the French export their beef to Britain? I have asked many people, but nobody has been able to provide me with a satisfactory answer. I had a session with Dave Mutter tonight after work. I told him about Mohammed's remark about the mouse's shopping basket. Dave said he found Mohammed's imagery to be "extremely disturbing". He suggested that Mohammed seek professional psychiatric help.

I am pleased to report that my fixation with Dave Mutter is over. He is simply a dull baby boomer with a Minnie Mouse voice and an out-dated pony tail. However, Anjelica House, my second opinion therapist, is a truly magnificent woman. Why did I not appreciate the attractions of late middle-aged women before? How come I have never noticed the beauty of their crows' feet or the delicious way their upper arms sag when they plump a cushion?

Midnight

Pandora has just rung to find out if my father has recovered from his hospital-borne infection yet. I told her that he was still being barrier nursed. She was delighted: she wants to use him to illustrate a point about privatised hospital cleaning services. Before she rang off, she hinted that the row between John Prescott and Dominique Voynet was in fact more of a lovers tiff! So, were they slaking their lust while the world festered on its axis? If so, we, the world's population, should be told.
