fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Quizzical country ways ensure the pub is no place to extend a townie hand of friendship
fields.trailText: Recently I mentioned the ferocious passions aroused by quizzes. The other day I ran into Rod Liddle, editor of Radio 4's Today programme, who told me about an experience he and his partner had shortly after they moved to the village of Heytesbury, Wiltshire. They decided it would be a good plan to join in village life, so on Saturday night they took friends and visitors down to the local pub quiz.
fields.body:
Recently I mentioned the ferocious passions aroused by quizzes. The other day I ran into Rod Liddle, editor of Radio 4's Today programme, who told me about an experience he and his partner had shortly after they moved to the village of Heytesbury, Wiltshire. They decided it would be a good plan to join in village life, so on Saturday night they took friends and visitors down to the local pub quiz.

There were 20 rounds, and each table swapped their answer sheets with another nearby to be marked. The first round was handed back, accurately marked, but with the words "townie bastards" across the top. They persevered, and were doing well - were in the lead at one point - when at round 18 they were expelled on a technicality.

They were determined not to give in, and so next weekend they returned. The questions were of much the same standard, and again they were scoring well, until a new final round: 50 questions on the history of Heytesbury. "The one that sticks in my mind," Rod tells me, "is 'What was the colour of old Geoff's front door before the fire of 1958?' We did not get a single answer right, and came last."

I asked how he's getting on now, a year after their move. "We don't do the quiz any more, and I still get called a townie bastard," he said. "But it's in a friendly way now."

One of the pleasures of having a literature don as a father was getting to meet famous writers. JB Priestly visited our house, and WH Auden came to stay. He liked a drink, and taught me how to make his dry martini. It consisted of an entire bottle of gin, a capful of vermouth, a whole lemon, sliced, and a trayful of ice cubes. It lasted him the whole evening.

When we lived in Birmingham, David Lodge and Malcolm Bradbury were colleagues of my father, and frequent visitors. I met him many times later and was always struck by his attractive, almost puppyish enthusiasm for everything that happened to him - the people he met, the places he visited, the books he'd read.

Once we were both on the same BBC2 programme, a sort of experimental chat show. The star guest was Kiri Te Kanawa. Malcolm was thrilled, and engaged her earnestly in conversation. I soon realised that, almost unconsciously, he was trying to find a point of agreement, so that later he could say: "D'you know, that's the very point Kiri Te Kanawa made to me..."

It was proving a little difficult, though she was both gracious and polite. They finally discovered that they had both holidayed in Portugal. Malcolm enthused about the landscape, the weather, the food, the wine, and the people.

"Oh, the people, they're just wonderful!" she agreed. Warming to his theme, Malcolm said: "And wasn't it marvellous? They had the only successful revolution in world history in which not one life was lost!"

The diva looked a little puzzled. "They had a revolution?" she inquired. "Well, my husband and I just go for the golf." She smiled sweetly, but poor Malcolm looked crestfallen.

Reader Madeleine Sims writes from Golders Green, north London, enclosing a flyer that came through the post, offering her "Congratulations!" on winning a "guaranteed" £150,000 in cash, or one of an amazing list of fabulous prizes, including DVD players, computers, a £5,000 luxury holiday, a dishwasher, or, at the end of the list, "male or female gold neckchains". To win one of these prizes all you have to do is phone. In the small print it says, "calls cost £1 a minute, likely playing time nine and a half minutes."

"Presumably," writes Ms Sims, "you spend £10 on the call, in order to obtain a "gold neckchain" worth 50p. Is this legal?" I fear it is. Premium rate phone lines are one of the world's great rip-offs. I'm going to set up dial-a-whinge. For 60p a minute people can phone me about their hellish train journeys. They will get it off their chest, therapy worth five quid of anyone's money, and I'll be rich.

There was a confrontation in a London pub this week when relatives of the people killed in the Omagh bombing discovered that the group which carried it out was having a fund raiser. Guests there included an Omagh councillor, some of whose voters may well have been killed. Possibly his election address said something like: "I believe that the path forward is of cooperation and conciliation. We can never win a united Ireland by force..." Or possibly not. The people of Northern Ireland, contrary to the old cliche, only rarely vote for peace.

So I was pleased to discover the dark savagery of John McBlain's diary, written by Dermot Harrigan, which appears in the Belfast Sunday Life. He, like me, has a fair old contempt for most of the players in that wretched, endless drama.

You don't need to know all the characters to enjoy the DUP MP Peter Robinson's attempt to get all the streets and buildings in Castlereagh named after him, instead of just most of them; the problems in the Derry water supply which meant that the city's protestants became "so dehydrated that even Gregory Campbell was unable to foam at the mouth".

Suspicions among republicans about Gerry Adams's regal lifestyle are explained by the fact that the Sinn Fein leader is the secret half-brother of Prince Michael of Kent, given up for adoption in 1948. Most of these grisly politicians take themselves very seriously, so it's a joy to find someone who doesn't.

No, I don't believe that Tony Blair sent John Prescott to the Hague deliberately to sabotage the climate change talks, but at least their failure means that, misled by the environmental prophets, we won't think that banging an extra 2p a litre on fuel plus a few new regulations will protect us from the changes in the weather which have occurred since the planet was formed.

It's fascinating to see how, slowly but surely, the scientific consensus is budging away from the certainty that climate change is all our fault. For instance, David Unwin, of the department of geography at Birkbeck College, London has sent me a splendidly sceptical letter about the whole thing.

It's very detailed, and I know what anguish journalists can cause academics by simplifying their arguments, so any mistakes here are my own. But Professor Unwin says that there have been continuous climate changes in the past, sometimes as much as 7C in a single century; that there is no way of separating natural cycles, often caused by ocean circulation, from any other type of change, and that the computer models trotted out by greenhouse effect zealots may be deeply flawed, since they link temperature and carbon dioxide in a way which makes their predictions of doom automatic.

The Hague talks, he said were "a farce"; even in the dubious event that "anthropogenic carbon dioxide" really is the culprit, we can do little about it, and would be much better off coping as the human race has for millennia: changing our habitat to cope with the new situation.

You don't need to know all the characters to enjoy the DUP MP Peter Robinson's attempt to get all the streets and buildings in Castlereagh named after him, instead of just most of them; the problems in the Derry water supply which meant that the city's protestants became "so dehydrated that even Gregory Campbell was unable to foam at the mouth". Suspicions among republicans about Gerry Adams's regal lifestyle are explained by the fact that the Sinn Fein leader is the secret half-brother of Prince Michael of Kent, given up for adoption in 1948. Most of these grisly politicians take themselves very seriously, so it's a joy to find someone who doesn't. No, I don't believe that Tony Blair sent John Prescott to the Hague deliberately to sabotage the climate change talks, but at least their failure means that, misled by the environmental prophets, we won't think that banging an extra 2p a litre on fuel plus a few new regulations will protect us from the changes in the weather which have occurred since the planet was formed. It's fascinating to see how, slowly but surely, the scientific consensus is budging away from the certainty that climate change is all our fault. For instance, David Unwin, of the department of geography at Birkbeck College, London has sent me a splendidly sceptical letter about the whole thing. It's very detailed, and I know what anguish journalists can cause academics by simplifying their arguments, so any mistakes here are my own. But Professor Unwin says that there have been continuous climate changes in the past, sometimes as much as 7C in a single century; that there is no way of separating natural cycles, often caused by ocean circulation, from any other type of change, and that the computer models trotted out by greenhouse effect zealots may be deeply flawed, since they link temperature and carbon dioxide in a way which makes their predictions of doom automatic. The Hague talks, he said were "a farce"; even in the dubious event that "anthropogenic carbon dioxide" really is the culprit, we can do little about it, and would be much better off coping as the human race has for millennia: changing our habitat to cope with the new situation.

webTitle: Damilola Taylor's father tells of bitterness at loss

fields.headline: Father tells of bitterness at loss
fields.standfirst:
Special report: policing crime
More about the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: Richard Taylor arrived in London from Nigeria yesterday and spoke of his final telephone call with his son, in which Damilola told him of being bullied.
fields.body:
Richard Taylor arrived in London from Nigeria yesterday and spoke of his final telephone call with his son, in which Damilola told him of being bullied.

Mr Taylor said his son told him: "Daddy, they are beating me. You must come to London now."

Mr Taylor, a manager with the Nigerian ministry of defence in Lagos, reassured his son that he would be with him at Christmas and would end the bullying.

Mr Taylor was critical of the headmaster of Damilola's school, Oliver Goldsmith primary.

"In Nigeria those responsible [for bullying] would have been confronted immediately.

"But from what I hear this headmaster seems to have been afraid of a confrontation. He didn't want to upset people," he said.

"I have great faith in the British police. But they must have a strong idea of who killed my son. Why have they not caught them yet?"

Mr Taylor believes his son was killed by people of Afro-Caribbean origin: "It was not racism in the same sense as we know it, but it was still racism in a way."

"My wife says there were three of them. They saw Dammy as different. They said he was half-caste and called him gay. Gay! He did not know what that meant."

Mr Taylor said his son would never have been attacked in such circumstances in Nigeria.

"Do you think this could happen in Lagos? No! It could never have happened there."

He said Damilola's dream had been to become a doctor to find a cure for the epilepsy suffered by his sister, Beme.

"They killed this lovely child. They knew he was being bullied. They knew Dammy was in danger. Why did they let it happen?"

Mr Taylor said: "I miss my son. He was my darling, my heart. He was such an innocent boy, a handsome boy.

"You cannot understand how great a loss it is to me."

fields.headline: Pinochet to stand trial
fields.standfirst:
Ex-president arrested and indicted for alleged crimes

Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: The former president of Chile, Augusto Pinochet, was last night placed under house arrest after he was indicted in Chile for his role in a series of crimes, including kidnapping, murder, torture, illegal burial and illicit association.
fields.body:
The former president of Chile, Augusto Pinochet, was last night placed under house arrest after he was indicted in Chile for his role in a series of crimes, including kidnapping, murder, torture, illegal burial and illicit association.

General Pinochet will be tried for his role in a series of crimes committed under his dictatorship, in a case that could last for several years.

Gen Pinochet will now be required to submit to medical examinations to determine whether he is fit to stand trial. However, under Chilean law, he will only escape prosecution only if he is mentally incapable of understanding the process or of defending himself.

The decision to indict Gen Pinochet comes nine months after the home secretary Jack Straw allowed Gen Pinochet to return from Britain to Chile on humanitarian grounds after a team of doctors ruled he was too ill to face trial.

Gen Pinochet's opponents rejoiced at the news. Carlos Reyes, of London-based human rights group Chile Democratico, who was tortured under the Pinochet regime, said many of his countrymen would be dancing in the streets.

"I am really deeply touched. He should be tried and judged for the crimes he committed during so many years."

Gen Pinochet's indictment was moved by Juan Guzman Tapia, a senior Chilean appeal court judge who has been leading the investigation. His decision was precipitated on Monday when a Chilean lawyer, Jose Galiano, submitted a formal request on behalf of a number of plaintiffs to indict Gen Pinochet, accusing him of crimes against more than 500 victims.

Among the cases that Judge Guzman has investigated are the disappearances of 19 prisoners in the first months of his 17-year dictatorship. The judge also looked into the deaths of more than 70 people in the so-called Caravan of Death - a special mission led by the then General Sergio Arellano Starck in October 1973.

Travelling by helicopter, Gen Arellano toured several towns, mostly in the mining areas of northern Chile. At all points on his route, several men were taken out and executed. Many were union leaders or functionaries of the government of Salvador Allende which Gen Pinochet overthrew in 1973.

There were several legal obstacles to the prosecution of Gen Pinochet in Chile, but these have been progressively removed. Gen Pinochet's par liamentary immunity, which he held by virtue of his position as a senator for life in the Chilean parliament, was removed by the Chilean supreme court in August.

The case remains highly sensitive in Chile. The indictment is likely to provoke a storm and to cause embarrassment to President Ricardo Lagos, who has been trying to improve relations with Chile's still powerful armed forces.

Gen Pinochet supporters last night denounced the forthcoming trial as a travesty of justice. "This is an aberration of jurisprudence," said Fernando Barros, a Chilean lawyer, who argued the indictment was an attempt by "certain persons intent on changing historical truths".

The investigation of Gen Pinochet was stimulated by his arrest in London in October 1998. Gen Pinochet was detained as a result of an extradition request by a Spanish judge, Baltazar Garzon, who wanted to try him in Spain for what he argued were crimes against humanity and therefore subject to international jurisdiction.

His last public appearance was on November 25, on his 85th birthday, when he greeted well wishers at his home in Santiago. Gen Pinochet called his detention in London "unjust" and said that he had argued that Chilean justice was as good as the justice of another country.

Timetable

October 16 1998 Pinochet arrested in London on Spanish courts' order

March 24 1999 British law lords rule he does not have immunity

September 27 1999 Formal extradition proceedings begin in London

October 8 1999 British magistrate rules Spain can extradite Pinochet

March 2 2000 Jack Straw releases Pinochet, declaring him unfit for trial

August 2000 Chilean supreme court strips him of immunity

December 1 2000 Formally charged

fields.headline: Britain to drop debt payments
fields.standfirst: Special report: debt relief
fields.trailText: Britain is to renounce its right to interest payments on £1bn owed by developing countries, in a last-ditch attempt to secure financial help for 41 of the world's poorest states before an end-of-year deadline set by anti-poverty campaigners.
fields.body:
Britain is to renounce its right to interest payments on £1bn owed by developing countries, in a last-ditch attempt to secure financial help for 41 of the world's poorest states before an end-of-year deadline set by anti-poverty campaigners.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, will unveil the government's initiative today at a farewell rally organised by Jubilee 2000, the umbrella group that has masterminded a four-year global debt protest.

With only 20 of 41 heavily-indebted countries on the International Monetary Fund and World Bank list likely to have been granted debt relief by the end of this month, Mr Brown and Claire Short, the international development secretary, have decided to put a moratorium on payments from the other 21.

"Neither you nor I will want the richest countries to benefit any more from the debts of those poorest countries," the chancellor will tell today's rally.

"From this day the British government will renounce our right to benefit from the historic debt owed by all 41 countries."

Payments will instead be placed in a special trust fund until the countries have put in place poverty reduction plans. Eleven of the 21 countries that stand to benefit are still involved in armed conflicts, and Mr Brown said yesterday that the only condition of the deal was that the money be used to tackle poverty rather than be squandered on armaments.

"Because of the conflicts there is no chance at the moment for some of these countries that debt relief would lead to poverty reduction. Had it not been for these conflicts we would have been able to move much more quickly."

Mr Brown and Ms Short have already started to lobby other members of the G7 industrialised countries in the hope that they will follow Britain's example. The government is hopeful that Bill Clinton will use the last days of his presidency to make a generous gesture on debt.

"The barrier now to debt relief and debt reduction is not money from us or other countries but the nations themselves getting out of conflicts and putting together a poverty reduction strategy," Mr Brown said.

Britain has already agreed to write off £600m of bilateral debts owed by the 20 countries that will get relief under the IMF and World Bank's Heavily Indebted Poor Country initiative. The chancellor said that the stock of debt owed by the remaining 21 countries was £1bn.

Mr Brown and Ms Short are optimistic that the move will speed up attempts to put together anti-poverty strategies and that five countries will be in a position to benefit in the first few months of next year. These may include Madagascar, Niger and Ethiopia.

Britain's move follows intense pressure by Jubilee 2000 for the rich western countries to speed up the debt relief process. The campaign officially winds up on December 31, although the reins will be taken up by a new group, Drop The Debt.

Mr Brown will tell the rally today that Britain wants debt relief to be used to start a cycle of poverty reduction and development, with the aim of meeting the UN target of halving world poverty by 2015, ensuring that every child has a primary school place and cutting infant mortality by two-thirds.

Jubilee 2000 welcomed the government's initiative but pointed out that Britain was only one creditor.


Jubilee 2000

fields.headline: Muted protests in Irian Jaya
fields.trailText: Separatists in the Indonesian province of Irian Jaya yesterday held muted ceremonies to mark the 39th anniversary of their unilateral declaration of independence after officials threatened repressive measures against anyone calling for secession.
fields.body:
Separatists in the Indonesian province of Irian Jaya yesterday held muted ceremonies to mark the 39th anniversary of their unilateral declaration of independence after officials threatened repressive measures against anyone calling for secession.

Surrounded by troops, several thousand West Papuans, as they call themselves, saw their movement's flag raised in the provincial capital, Jayapura. Similar events were held across the province.

Police in Jakarta used tear gas to disperse several hundred Papuans after protesters refused to lower their flag.

fields.headline: Glimmer of hope for elderly
fields.standfirst: The row over funding for care in old age rolls on but prospects are improving. Liz Stuart reports
fields.trailText: The row over funding for care in old age rolls on but prospects are improving. Liz Stuart reports.
fields.body:
Although the crisis surrounding the government's plans for the future of long-term care is still very much occupying parliament and the press, there was some good news from the courts earlier this month.

The Social Security Commissioner, Patrick Howell, ruled that someone living in a residential or nursing care home should be allowed to claim attendance allowance worth up to £53.55 a week while they are in the process of selling their home.

This could ease some of the strain for elderly people paying for their own long-term care, but nursing home funding continues to cause high levels of hardship to them and their families.

"We get at least one call a week from an elderly person who has run out of money and will have to either move into a smaller or shared room or move into a cheaper home. They are very frail and there is evidence that being moved kills them," warns Philip Spires, adviser with the Help the Aged Care Fees Advisory Service, a free service offering financial advice to elderly people and their families.

In July, the government rejected a Royal Commission's recommendation that personal care should be free, paid for by the state. Health minister Alan Milburn announced instead that registered nursing time in nursing homes should be free, but all personal care should be paid for after means testing.

Although just one care home occupant in five pays for their place, the average cost is £14,000 a year for a residential home and £20,000 for a nursing home. "What's worse is that when those who have sold their homes to afford nursing home fees run out of money, they appeal to their local authority, but often find that there quite simply is no money there," says Mr Spires.

In the past financial year, East Sussex County Council overspent its budget by £1.5m and attributes this to older people living longer and a growing number who had previously paid for their own long-term care but were forced to turn to social services once their money had run out. The council projects this will cost an additional £2.5m over the next two years.

The Help the Aged advisory service suggests seeking independent financial advice before an elderly person goes into a home. Many will be advised to take out an "immediate need care plan" to maximise capital from the sale of the home. "We will not only pass on the client's details to all the providers for quotation but we also understand what benefits the person might be entitled to," says Mr Spires.

In a recent case, an 80-year-old lady in need of care had sold her house for £75,000 and was receiving a pension of £67.75 a week, plus an attendance allowance. "

Had she put the money on deposit within five years, she would have had just £10,000 left. We advised her to take out a policy costing £34,000 which covered her annual fees and the rest of her capital, £41,000, was invested for growth." Bupa, PPP Lifetime, Norwich Union and the Pension Annunity Friendly Society are the main players in this market. The Advisory Service takes a commission from these providers when a plan is sold.

John Rynne, head of adult services at Bournemouth Borough Council, says: "Local authorities are not equipped to provide the level of in-depth legal and financial advice which someone going into care needs.

"Older people need specialist advice on care planning and, for our staff, referring their clients to Help the Aged Care Fees Advisory Service means they can do so without the fear of sending them off to receive poor or costly advice."

Help the Aged Fees Advisory Service freephone 0500-76-74-76; Help the Aged

webTitle: Top Tory admits election is lost

fields.headline: Top Tory admits election is lost
fields.standfirst:
Party needs more time to find itself, says shadow cabinet minister

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague's troubles deepened yesterday when a shadow cabinet colleague admitted it was obvious his party had not yet found its voice and was unlikely to do so before the next election.
fields.body:
William Hague's troubles deepened yesterday when a shadow cabinet colleague admitted it was obvious his party had not yet found its voice and was unlikely to do so before the next election.

Effectively admitting that the party was likely to lose next spring's election, Gary Streeter, the shadow international development minister, said it might take the Conservatives a few more years to complete its rehabilitation.

"I think it is obvious that we have not yet found our voice. We have not yet perhaps fully grounded what 21st century Conservatism looks like. We've got five months to do it before the next general election. OK, maybe we won't quite complete the task in time, but we have got to do that task within the next few years."

He also praised the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, for personally struggling with the dilemma of how the Conservatives needed to move on.

Mr Streeter, a Christian, said he longed for the Tories to be thought of as the party of the poor. He was speaking the day after the Tories deserted the first government inspired Commons debate on poverty in Britain, leaving Labour and Liberal Democrats to debate the issue alone.

The Labour MP Caroline Flint said the absence of any Tory MPs for more than two hours spoke volumes about the priorities of the Conservatives. The party's front bench spokesman, Eric Pickles, left after making a brief speech.

Mr Streeter said in an interview with GMTV's The Review programme, to be shown on Sunday, that many of the party's new leading figures are largely unknown to the public.

His comments came as both published and private polls yesterday showed the Tories trailing badly and on course for a 100-seat defeat.

A poll in the London Evening Standard put Labour on 50 points in the capital, 19 ahead of the Conservatives. The Tories lost three-quarters of their seats in the capital in the 1997 election and would be likely to fare no better if they continue to trail by such a margin. Private polls suggest the Tories are also doing poorly in vital marginal seats.

Mr Streeter said there was "a third limb to 21st century Conservatism and it's about dealing with some of the social problems of the poor".

"I long for us to be thought of now as the party of the poor, that we are the voice for the people who have nothing because we are going to come up with radical policies to penetrate some of our inner city problems ... we've got to find much more radical ways drawing on the voluntary and faith based charitable sector to find solutions to people's misery in some of our inner cities."

Although he said the party had a strong team and he was confident of Mr Hague's leadership, Mr Streeter said: "I think one of the problems is we're in a period of transition. Some of our big beasts are retiring and a lot of older people are retiring and lot of younger people are coming through, but people have not heard of them yet, so that will take a while".

Similar refrains have been heard about the Conservative front bench for three years.

In recent weeks, the Tories have been concentrating their fire on the issue of Europe, but a massive bombardment on the issue of the European rapid reaction force, backed by close supporting fire from the Eurosceptic press, had no impact.

Polls in both the Daily Telegraph and the Mail on Sunday by separate polling organisations showed most voters thought Britain should contribute forces. The Mail on Sunday poll backed British involvement by 55% to 38%. The Telegraph poll showed 48% to 34% support.

He was speaking the day after the Tories deserted the first government inspired Commons debate on poverty in Britain, leaving Labour and Liberal Democrats to debate the issue alone. The Labour MP Caroline Flint said the absence of any Tory MPs for more than two hours spoke volumes about the priorities of the Conservatives. The party's front bench spokesman, Eric Pickles, left after making a brief speech. Mr Streeter said in an interview with GMTV's The Review programme, to be shown on Sunday, that many of the party's new leading figures are largely unknown to the public. His comments came as both published and private polls yesterday showed the Tories trailing badly and on course for a 100-seat defeat. A poll in the London Evening Standard put Labour on 50 points in the capital, 19 ahead of the Conservatives. The Tories lost three-quarters of their seats in the capital in the 1997 election and would be likely to fare no better if they continue to trail by such a margin. Private polls suggest the Tories are also doing poorly in vital marginal seats. Mr Streeter said there was "a third limb to 21st century Conservatism and it's about dealing with some of the social problems of the poor". "I long for us to be thought of now as the party of the poor, that we are the voice for the people who have nothing because we are going to come up with radical policies to penetrate some of our inner city problems ... we've got to find much more radical ways drawing on the voluntary and faith based charitable sector to find solutions to people's misery in some of our inner cities." Some of our big beasts are retiring and a lot of older people are retiring and lot of younger people are coming through, but people have not heard of them yet, so that will take a while". In recent weeks, the Tories have been concentrating their fire on the issue of Europe, but a massive bombardment on the issue of the European rapid reaction force, backed by close supporting fire from the Eurosceptic press, had no impact. The Mail on Sunday poll backed British involvement by 55% to 38%. The Telegraph poll showed 48% to 34% support.

webTitle: Wembley in crisis as 30 banks say no

fields.headline: Wembley in crisis as 30 banks say no
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of Wembley
fields.trailText: The crisis surrounding the £660m plan to rebuild Wembley stadium deepened last night when it emerged that none of the 30 major international banks approached to back the project has so far agreed to put up any cash.
fields.byline: Jill Treanor, John Cassy  and  Vivek Chaudhary
fields.body:
The crisis surrounding the £660m plan to rebuild Wembley stadium deepened last night when it emerged that none of the 30 major international banks approached to back the project has so far agreed to put up any cash.

The banks are concerned about the viability of the business plan for the stadium and yesterday it emerged that their worries are shared by several senior directors of the Football Association.

The directors have insisted that their concerns are put on record in the minutes of FA board meetings. They have yet to see the full business plan for the already delayed stadium redevelopment.

The issue is creating deep tensions within the FA, focusing on the handling of the project by Ken Bates, chairman of Chelsea and Wembley National Stadium Ltd (WNSL).

Mr Bates has faced questions from Arsenal's deputy chairman, David Dein, during angry meetings at FA headquarters in central London.

It is understood that Mr Dein is concerned at the rising cost of the project and that it is proving to be a public relations disaster. At an FA meeting earlier this week some directors demanded to know why the project was not on the agenda as had been previously planned.

"There is a lot of anger at the way the project has been handled," said a source. "There is a feeling that we need new leadership and that is leading to a power struggle."

The rifts within the FA are increasing the difficulties faced by Chase Manhattan, the US bank which has been hired by WNSL to raise £410m from City banks and investors to fund the elaborate project.

Demolition work on the old stadium was due to begin last month but the bulldozers have not yet been called in. Chase approached up to 30 major banks to help raise the £410m loan but has so far failed to persuade any of them to sign up.

The banks which have turned Chase away include HSBC and at least one other high street giant.

It is understood that Chase is continuing negotiations with another 20 potential lenders and is due to give a crucial progress report to Wembley next week.

A spokesman for Chase said: "We are in discussions with Wembley and the FA as to how to address the banks' concerns."

Senior banking sources said last night that they would not back the loan unless they had better guarantees that Wembley would be able to repay. This means coming up with ways to bring in more regular revenue from the stadium.

Under the current plan, the FA is pledging to put up £21m a year. Bankers want that amount to be increased to give more certainty to the projections for increased revenues at the new stadium, which depends heavily on more expensive corporate hospitality seats being sold.

The new English national stadium will have 150 corporate boxes - five times the number at the old Wembley. WNSL is counting on selling them all to meet revenue projections at £80,000 a year. Critics do not believe WNSL will achieve this target.

"There are 29 boxes at the current Wembley and we had trouble selling all of them," said one former Wembley executive.

"It's a simple fact that people who want to watch England games and the FA Cup final aren't always interested in paying to see Scunthorpe and Swansea in the play-offs or summer pop concerts."

A spokesman for WNSL denied there was any friction with the FA. "The FA and Wembley are completely intertwined. The FA's chairman, chief executive and finance director sit on our board. To imagine there is a split is nonsense," he said.

"Chase Manhattan has approached 30 banks and we are due to hear back from Chase next week".

The FA yesterday referred all calls on the subject to WNSL.

To add to the confusion, the government is said to be frustrated with both WNSL and Sport England, which distributes lottery funding. The lottery is providing £120m for the new stadium.

Both the sports minister, Kate Hoey and the culture, sport and media secretary, Chris Smith, refused to comment yesterday on the new stadium.

The government is believed to be angry at Sport England's handling of the whole affair and claims that it has allowed WNSL to hijack the whole project.

Officials within the Department of Media, Culture and Sport had initially stated that lottery money could only be handed over for the new Wembley if the end result was a multipurpose national sports stadium.

webTitle: Watchdog plans BSE checks in Ireland

fields.headline: Watchdog plans BSE checks in Ireland
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Food safety watchdogs are stepping up checks on Irish beef and other processed meat from cattle to help reassure consumers that fast increasing floods of imports are at least as safe as home-grown produce.
fields.body:
Food safety watchdogs are stepping up checks on Irish beef and other processed meat from cattle to help reassure consumers that fast increasing floods of imports are at least as safe as home-grown produce.

The republic provides a tenth of all beef eaten in Britain, 20 times the amount imported from France, and the BSE epidemic has hit a far higher proportion of cows than it has across the Channel.

The board of the food standards agency has asked the government's BSE advisers to assess early next week whether present safeguards are good enough and has reinforced instructions to local authorities to ensure paperwork enabling food to be traced back to overseas suppliers is fully in order.

The agency may also send officials to Dublin to ensure that BSE controls in that country are adequate.

The turning of attention to Ireland coincides with an European Union-wide tightening of anti-BSE measures in an effort to support a rapidly collapsing market. These include a temporary ban on feeding all meat and bone meal to other livestock, and a ban on any animals over 30 months old going into food unless their carcasses have been tested and show no signs of BSE.

A meeting of agriculture ministers on Monday, to which health ministers have also been invited, is expected to endorse the package which brings the rest of the EU more into line with Britain. Commission officials are also likely to press for a speedy implementation of tougher rules on country of origin labelling.

The new focus on Ireland is unlikely to embarrass the food safety commissioner, David Byrne, an Irishman who has been urging member states to take far more seriously the dangers of BSE . He attacked Germany and Spain, which have recently reported cases, for being complacent. He has warned that enforcement of rules is essential if human health is to be protected and the beef industry is to survive.

Italy, Spain, Greece and the Netherlands have restricted some imports of French beef, but European commission scientists have so far said there are no grounds for such unilateral action.

Imports account for a quarter of the 1m tonne British beef market - a proportion that has been rising steadily as the British farming crisis deepens, and Irish beef makes up nearly 108,000 tonnes, or 40% of the 256,000 tonne total. By contrast French exports to Britain are 5,570 tonnes, but there is far greater political hostility because of the continuing French ban on British exports, lifted by the EU in August last year.

Many of France's exports here are in the form of corned beef and other processed products, whereas most of Ireland's is as carcass meat, whose origin is often easier to check. Neither country is allowed to export meat from animals over 30 months to Britain, even though, for a few weeks more, they are feeding their own populations such beef.

Only 14 countries that are BSE-free are allowed to do so, they include South American countries, much of whose supply is still as corned beef, Australia, New Zealand and the USA.

The Conservatives have been pressing hard for an import ban on French beef, but farmers have been more cautious especially because they do not want the export of live sheep to the continent to be jeopardised by tit-for-tat measures. But any doubts about Irish or French produce could only add to the crisis across Europe.

The food standards agency is also worried that controls in Britain are not perfect and are worried that some cattle, legally killed by farmers for their own consumption, are being distributed far more widely and escaping anti-BSE controls.

Main beef exporters to Britain in year to end August 2000 (tonnes)

Ireland 107,865

Brazil 71,662

Netherlands 12, 966

Argentina 9,735

Uruguay 9,124

Australia 6,814

Namibia 6,187

Zimbabwe 6.086

France 5,573

Botswana 4,746

Germany 4,042

fields.headline: Mary Quant quits fashion empire
fields.standfirst: Icon of the swinging 60s 'forced out' of company now run by Japanese businessmen in secret deal
fields.trailText: Mary Quant, the fashion icon who was the inspiration for the swinging 60s, has resigned from her empire under a veil of silence. The woman who claimed she invented the mini-skirt and did invent hot pants resigned as a director of her company, Mary Quant Ltd, and will no longer have control of her universally famous name or the simple daisy design that became synonymous with her creations.
fields.body:
Mary Quant, the fashion icon who was the inspiration for the swinging 60s, has resigned from her empire under a veil of silence. The woman who claimed she invented the mini-skirt and did invent hot pants resigned as a director of her company, Mary Quant Ltd, and will no longer have control of her universally famous name or the simple daisy design that became synonymous with her creations.

Speculation is rife that Ms Quant, who was the catalyst for the 60s revolution and put London fashion on the world map, has effectively been ousted from her position as director.

The affair has been cloaked in secrecy, with all staff having to sign confidentiality agreements with the Japanese businessmen who hold the licensing agreements for the Quant name.

A spokeswoman for Mary Quant confirmed that the designer had been made a "generous offer" by her Japanese licensees. She said Quant, whose married name is Plunkett Greene, no longer has anything to do with the day-to-day running of the company and, since October, came in to the office less. The spokeswoman said Quant would be a consultant and was happy with the arrangement.

James Matsumiya, Mary Quant Ltd's managing director, said yesterday: "At the moment I am legally bound not to talk about it until Mary Quant and I have agreed on wording. Then we will make an announcement. We do not want to mention what we are trying to do at the moment."

One former senior Quant employee said: "As a business, it wouldn't surprise me if Mary has been carved out. Mary was very independent minded and accountants were necessary evils. It's the story of an entrepreneur being forced into a large company environment and not liking it. Anyone can be a casualty, their name doesn't necessarily protect them."

Archie McNair, who co-founded the company with Quant and her late husband Alexander Plunkett Greene in October 1955 and was chairman until 1988, said he was unsure of the details of the deal. "As I understand it, the Japanese have made Mary an offer and I suppose it's too good for her to refuse. She's a very famous girl and has still got plenty to offer."

Mr McNair, who said he and Quant and her husband "had some wonderful times" with their business, said it was an unusual situation for someone now to have control of the Quant name. He added: "Mary had a very good working relationship with the Japanese. She hasn't just capitulated."

Quant is now 66 but sources said she was not yet ready for retirement. While she no longer designed collections, the woman who was given an OBE in 1966 and is represented in the Fashion Hall of Fame would design smaller pieces and cast her eye over products being manufactured in her name.

Quant's influence within the fashion community was once enormous. In Vogue: Twentieth Century Fashion, published this week, it says: "Quant had a cataclysmic effect on London, with her simple daisy motif, short skirts, mix of music and model, Twiggy." It points out that Quant's "international name and logo, associated with youth and freshness, enabled her to change direction and encompass kitchenware, stationery and fabulous make-up".

Quant was the unrivalled queen of swinging London, she created the Chelsea Girl and kicked off the trendiness of the city's Kings Road. One article said: "It is given to a fortunate few to be born at the right time, in the right place, with the right talents. In recent fashion, there are three: Chanel, Dior and Mary Quant."

Quant did not just design, but influenced the attitude of the 60s, dying her pubic hair green and telling the public about it and infamously talking about that taboo area "the crutch" in an interview for The Guardian's 1967 groundbreaking series, The Permissive Society.

Quant's shop Bazaar - which she set up with her husband and Mr McNair - was the place to be in London. The Beatles often popped in to buy designs for their girlfriends and George Harrison married the model Patti Boyd in clothes designed by Quant. Her friends include David Bailey and Terence Conran and Sassoon still cuts that famous hair every now and again.

Quant was responsible for hot pants, the Lolita look, the slip dress, PVC raincoats, smoky eyes and sleek bob haircuts, but it was make-up that eventually made her company the most money. Her immediately identifiable bottles of nail varnish and capsules of lipstick were licensed to be sold around the world. The current license is held by Mary Quant Cosmetics Japan Ltd - there are now more than 200 Mary Quant Colour shopsin Japan, generating around £95m a year, while there are just two in London.

Quant lives a quiet life between homes in Surrey and Grasse. She is a non-executive director of the House of Fraser group.

There had been speculation that the performance of Mary Quant Ltd was not as good as it could have been, with its retained profit falling from nearly £400,000 to less than £50,000. Quant's resignation leaves the company in the control of Mr Matsumiya, who lives in Buckinghamshire, and Masaaki Michitani and Juichi Nakayam, who both live in Japan.

Chelsea girl who instigated a new era

Jess Cartner-Morley, fashion editor

Contrary to popular legend, Mary Quant invented neither the miniskirt (that was Courrèges) nor coloured patterned tights (Balenciaga). In fact, she invented something much more important. She instigated a new era in style, one in which fashion was for any modern young working girl rather than just for rich ladies. Anyone could wear a Quant mini, if they had the legs.

At Mary Quant's Bazaar, the tiny shop which burst onto London's Kings Road in the mid-50s, the look was of a sulky, coquettish French schoolgirl - skinny rib poloneck sweaters, miniskirts, bright tights and knee-high boots, with geometric Sassoon bobs, kohl-rimmed eyes and coltish turned-in toes.

Quant's designs played with proportion: men's shirts were slimmed down and elongated and worn, just with tights, by women; hotpants appeared for the first time. Even knickerbockers made a brief comeback. Quant recalls that when she asked manufacturers to make up her unusual patterns, "most would just send us packing".

Quant has said that she identifies with Coco Chanel. Like Chanel, she liberated the women she dressed: "I wanted to make clothes that you could move in, skirts you could run and dance in," she has said. The original Chelsea Girl placed the girls of swinging London at the epicentre of fashion, but her influence stretched way beyond: by 1969 it was estimated up to 7m women had a Quant label in their wardrobe.

Quant was so inextricably associated with the sixties that the fading of her star once that decade ended was almost inevitable. In the 80s her name returned to glossy magazines - but in the beauty pages with blue nail polishes and silver eyeliners bearing the trademark daisy of the designer who said "good taste is death, vulgarity is life".

Quant may be bowing out, but the Mary Quant look is still being worn today - in Tokyo, where a cartoonish version, featuring short skirts, boots, white tights and pale lipstick, has become de rigueur amongst teenage girls.

webTitle: Oil price rise as Iraq cuts off supply

fields.headline: Oil price rise as Iraq cuts off supply
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: The Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, embarked on a new showdown with the west yesterday by choking off oil supplies in a determined attempt to break free of UN sanctions.
fields.body:
The Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, embarked on a new showdown with the west yesterday by choking off oil supplies in a determined attempt to break free of UN sanctions.

The crisis created mayhem in the oil industry and led to an immediate rise in prices.

Iraq sells about 2.3m barrels a day, 5% of the world's oil, and traders said a lengthy break in supplies could mean further rises in already high prices.

Robert Priddle, the director of the International Energy Agency Executive, appealed for calm, saying the development "should not be exaggerated".

The US stepped in to try to counter the impact by promising to release some of its reserves to make up for any serious shortages. Saudi Arabia and Kuwait offered to increase their production.

The Kuwaiti oil minister, Sheikh Saud Nasser al-Sabah, said his country "is in consultation with other members of Opec [Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries] to take possible collective steps to limit any negative impact on the oil market due to Iraq's decision".

Turkey confirmed yesterday that Iraq had turned off the flow from its main pipeline.

Saddam, after almost 10 years during which his country has been weakened and left on the defensive in the aftermath of the Gulf war, has seen the balance tilt in his favour over the last few months. The sanctions regime is being gradually eroded. Using oil as a weapon is his most ambitious move yet to force the west to drop or at least scale down sanctions, which are estimated to have contributed to the deaths of more than 1m civilians.

The dictator, whose regime appears to have been strengthened rather than undermined by the sanctions policy, is exploiting the opportunity presented by the current uncertainty over the US presidency, the Palestinian-Israeli conflict and the high price of oil.

All Iraq's oil revenues go to the UN. The body, rather than Saddam, then determines how that money should be spent, with most going on food and aid programmes.

As a first step in trying to take back control of its revenues, the Iraqi government has been in dispute with the UN this week, demanding that oil companies pay a surcharge of 50 cents a barrel to Baghdad. The UN has so far refused.

Britain, along with the US, has taken a hard line. A Foreign Office spokesman yesterday played down the significance of the Iraqi oil decision. "We are aware of the reports that many oil companies have stopped lifting oil and that Iraq has stopped supplying oil to some outlets. This suggests oil companies are keen to comply with UN sanctions and not to pay the Iraqi surcharge."

The Labour MP George Galloway, who has been leading a campaign against sanctions, said events were shifting decisively in Iraq's favour. "The calculation is that this is the most opportune time do to this."

fields.headline: Pinochet's last legal ramparts crumble
fields.standfirst:
Ten years after he quit the presidency, Chile's ex-dictator loses his immunity

Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: Yesterday's historic indictment of the former Chilean dictator, General Augusto Pinochet, on charges of kidnapping, murder and concealment of crimes was a moment that few of those who suffered under his dictatorship had ever expected to see.
fields.body:
Yesterday's historic indictment of the former Chilean dictator, General Augusto Pinochet, on charges of kidnapping, murder and concealment of crimes was a moment that few of those who suffered under his dictatorship had ever expected to see.

Despite the disappearance of some 4,000 people at the hands of his security forces, and the continuing efforts of the relatives of his victims to uncover the truth, Gen Pinochet's position, in Chile at least, seemed secure.

Before he stepped down as president, he erected a set of defences against any future legal problems that had seemed impregnable: there was his continuing position as commander in chief of the armed forces, which he vacated only recently, and his position as senator for life, which gave him parliamentary immunity. Finally, there was the continuing presence in the senate of nominated senators who seemed to guarantee that the parliament would never achieve a big enough majority to change the constitution.

In the 1980s, Gen Pinochet put in place a law that amnestied crimes committed from the time of his 1973 coup, thus covering the period of the most violent repression. But lawyers have since argued successfully that in cases where the remains of the victims of presumed extra-judicial killings have not been found, the case should be considered one of ongoing kidnapping - and therefore still open.

Executions

On the other side of the equation were the families of the victims who had been attempting for more than 20 years to bring legal cases connected with the extra-judicial executions and disappearances perpetrated under the dictatorship.

Few cases could prosper under the dictatorship, but when Gen Pinochet vacated the presidency in 1990, the slow return to justice began. For many of the families involved, there has been little progress until now. Many still do not know how their relatives were killed, by whom or what became of their bodies. But since the democratic transition began, the search for the bodies has been stepped up, aided by a slowly increasing willingness of witnesses to talk and the relentless accumulation of information obtained through judicial investigations.

Among the many cases that have been pending against Gen Pinochet, those that have been investigated by appeal court judge Juan Guzman - who yesterday took the historic step of indicting the former Chilean leader - were among the most notorious. They include 74 killings perpetrated during a 10 day period in October 1973 - an episode that is known as the Caravan of Death.

The caravan of death was led by General Sergio Arellano Starck, and left a trail of victims: 15 in the town of La Serena, including Jorge Pena, founder of the national children's orchestra, 16 in Copiapo, 14 in Antofagasta and 26 in Calama. In each of the towns Gen Arellano visited he picked out the names of detainees housed in the local jails or military barracks.

Some had been given sentences by adhoc military tribunals, others were awaiting release. By the time the caravan moved on, they were dead.

Judge Guzman has been investigating the caravan of death for several years and charges are pending against several of the officers who participated in the killings. In the last two weeks Judge Guzman has travelled to the towns of Copiapo, Antofagasta and Calama, in the north of Chile, where he staged several reconstructions of the events surrounding these killings and interrogated suspects.

The legal significance of the case rests on the fact that the prisoners were already in the custody of local military commanders when Gen Arellano arrived. When the local commanders protested against the executions - as several did - Gen Arellano cited his written authority from Gen Pinochet.

Other witnesses have testified that they notified Gen Pinochet of what had happened, but that he took no action. Under the military code, as well as the law of Chile, he had a responsibility to investigate and punish those responsible for the killings.

Jose Galiano, a respected lawyer and former army captain who this week asked Judge Guzman to formally indict Gen Pinochet, argued in his submission to the judge that the crimes committed during the caravan of death, and several other episodes that occurred between 1973 and Gen Pinochet's retirement as head of state in 1990 were of such magnitude that "they could only have been carried out under the orders of the head of state, or with his authorisation, ratification and, in any case, his subsequent concealment."

Firebrand

Judge Guzman was not regarded as a firebrand in Chilean judicial circles. The son of a diplomat, he was seen by many as a relatively conventional middle-ranking judge who had no track record of political opposition to the regime. But his determination to pursue his investigations has earned him the respect of human rights lawyers and the disapproval of those who continue to support Gen Pinochet.

Sources close to the case believe that Judge Guzman - who is now surrounded by police bodyguards - is the target of an intelligence operation that has attempted to find evidence to discredit him.

The indictment is expected to provoke a severe reaction from Gen Pinochet's supporters, who claim he saved Chile from the communism President Salvador Allende was trying to impose.

Gen Pinochet has claimed that the killings were part of a war against a well-prepared military resistance, aided and armed by Cuba. In the last two weeks, however, I have spoken to numerous witnesses who say that the situation in the north of Chile at the time of the coup was peaceful. All the witnesses, who include former military officers, deny there was armed resistance, and several point out that among men massacred were local mine managers and union leaders who, when the coup took place, acted to ensure the transition was free of bloodshed.

"This is not a matter of revenge," said Mr Galiano. "An eye for an eye, or a tooth for a tooth. It is a matter of historical truth."

For Judge Guzman too, the Pinochet affair goes beyond politics to the reputation of Chilean justice, that he feels was badly tarnished under the dictatorship.

Isabel Hilton will be presenting a BBC Correspondent documentary on the Caravan of Death in January.

webTitle: Scores killed by Colombian death squad

fields.headline: Scores killed by Colombian death squad
fields.trailText: A rightwing death squad in Colombia killed at least 36 people in the worst massacre of civilians in three years, the authorities said yesterday.
fields.body:
A rightwing death squad in Colombia killed at least 36 people in the worst massacre of civilians in three years, the authorities said yesterday.

Nine days after the raid on the fishing town of Nueva Venecia, on the Caribbean coast, the death toll was still uncertain and one report indicated that as many as 86 people may have been killed. The bullet-riddled bodies of the missing are still turning up in swamps around the town.

Nueva Venecia is in the heart of a fishing and banana-producing region where communist-led rebels and ultra-right paramilitary groups have long battled for control.

The bloodshed began at dawn on November 22 when gunmen - suspected members of the United Self-Defence Forces of Colombia (AUC), the leading paramilitary force - began calling out the names of towns people on a "hit list" of alleged collaborators of Marxist rebels operating in the area.

Colombia's national human rights ombudsman, Eduardo Cifuentes, who is expected to issue an official report on the massacre before the weekend, said 2,000 people had fled the town since the attack.

webTitle: IRA prisoners library at the Maze

fields.headline: Men of letters, men of arms
fields.standfirst: The Maze prison was a grim symbol of the troubles. But, as Kirsty Scott reveals, it was also home to a remarkable library amassed by IRA prisoners
fields.trailText: The Maze prison was a grim symbol of the troubles. But, as Kirsty Scott reveals, it was also home to a remarkable library amassed by IRA prisoners.
fields.body:
On Saturday July 8 this year, Yvonne Murphy, head of the political collection at Belfast's Linen Hall library, drove the 10 miles south-west from the city to the gates of the Maze prison. The authorities had been expecting her, and she came away with seven large brown paper sacks stuffed with books.

There were more than 1,700 of them. Books that told tales beyond the words they held. Books on politics and revolution, history, literature, language, and sociology. Books with spines split by overuse, pages thumbed thin, corners folded sharp as shirt collars, margins laddered with neat and painstaking notes.

This was the library of the IRA.

They used to say you could lose your sight if you were long enough at the Maze, so monotonously grey were the walls and wire. This bleak compound has become a headstone for Northern Ireland's agony. From the early internment camp of Long Kesh to the notorious H-blocks, through the blanket protest and the hunger strike to the genesis of the peace process and the final closing of its gates this summer, the story of the Maze is the story of the Troubles. And that story can be followed in the books that found their way into its cells.

For the last four months, the books that Yvonne Murphy retrieved have been listed and studied in the depths of the Linen Hall. This week they will be boxed up and returned to the republican ex-prisoners, and Murphy fears they might be lost for ever. She has no doubts about their cultural and political significance

"You have this very famous group of prisoners reading this material. For the whole period of the peace process the prisoners were viewed as very important and this was informing what they thought. It is hugely significant.

"We had heard there was this unofficial library, this vast resource, in the Maze, so we made contact with the IRA and the prison authorities and got permission to collect and record it."

Murphy is desperate to find a loyalist equivalent but has been unable to ascertain if one exists. There have been casually flung rumours that the loyalist collection consisted largely of a stash of pornography, body- building magazines and the biographies of serial killers. Loyalists who served time in the Maze tell a different story; of a passion for books to match the republicans', and a hunger for knowledge in a setting stripped of stimulation. But no evidence of any loyalist library has survived.

The IRA collection is almost exclusively paperback; hardbacks hide weapons. They are almost all worn, though not carelessly so. There is little doodling and almost no defacing. There are at least 11 copies of Lenin's The State and the Revolution, one carefully re- covered in a smoothed-out brown paper bag. There are also numerous copies of Marx and Engels' Manifesto of the Communist Party, and works by Freud, Trotsky, Kafka and Mao Zedong. There are biographies of Margaret Thatcher, Enoch Powell and Ian Paisley, and books on Nicaragua, El Salvador, Guatemala, Palestine, South Africa and the Basque separatists.

Frantz Fanon's classic anti-colonial text, The Wretched of the Earth, sits beside Henry Pelling's Origins of the Labour Party and works by the Brazilian theorist Paolo Freire. There is a shelf full of National Geographic magazines dating from 1974 to 1997 and a broad range of Irish-language texts as well as numerous works by Irish writers and thinkers. Ernie O'Malley and Sean O' Faolain compete for space with James Joyce and the Irish Feminist Review.

There is precious little light reading. Any novels are weighty and worthy; Dickens and Orwell and James Hogg's The Private Memoirs and Confessions of a Jus tified Sinner. There are a couple of John Grishams and Wilbur Smiths and the only apparent example of pulp fiction is a fat paperback, whose cover promises the adventures of an SAS sergeant-major and a beautiful Soviet spy, but which contains the text of Who Framed Colin Wallace?, Paul Foot's 1989 investigative work on the jailing of a military intelligence officer.

There are works that surprise by their presence and some that shock profoundly. The thin red spine of a book on the Enniskillen atrocity, when an IRA bomb killed 11 people on Remembrance Sunday in 1987, sits alongside Alexander Solzhenitsyn's Gulag Archipelago, and Jonathan Glover's Causing Death and Saving Lives: The Moral Problems of Life or Death Choices.

And, sometimes, amid the thought and fervour, a flash of poignancy. A parents' guide to epilepsy, a book on child development, a self-help guide to dealing with nerves, a joke book, home wine-making the right way, a pocket Roget's Thesaurus that lists three owners, a collection of Irish love stories.

"The first thing that strikes you is the seriousness and breadth of the material," says Richard English, professor of politics at Queen's University in Belfast, who has done a structural analysis of the collection. "The second is the amount of leftwing material. You get a sense of a revolutionary leftist movement and this reflects the period in which the books were put together and devoured. After the hunger strikes there was a very strong leftwing commitment by the republicans. It is an evocation of a particular episode in republican thinking.

"The collection also makes it clear they were just desperate for knowledge. The intensity of the material reflects that."

Jackie McMullan remembers that desperation. He served 16 years in the Maze for the attempted murder of an RUC officer and was on hunger strike for 48 days. Between 1976 and 1981, during the blanket and dirty protests, inmates were not allowed any reading material apart from the Bible.

"You can imagine there was a massive appetite for reading immediately after the blanket protest," McMullan says. "I had a list of about 20 books in my head. At the start it was only religious books we were allowed. But we were flexible enough to turn that into religious novels. Believe it or not, some of them are half decent. After a couple of years we were able to get political books."

McMullan's imagined list included John Reed's memoir of the Russian revolution, Ten Days That Shook the World; Wilfred Burchett's Grasshoppers and Elephants: Why Vietnam Fell; and Orwell's Homage to Catalonia.

"I got them all and I read them in about three weeks. I'm not a fast reader. I've known guys who can read 600 pages a day. I would read about 200 pages a day but there were weeks where I read three books, one after the other."

Rejecting the prison education service, the IRA set up its own education structure in the Maze. The £2 a week they got from the prison authorities was pooled to buy tobacco and set up a book fund. Copies came from friends, relatives and bookstores in Ireland and England.

"For us, education was central," says McMullan, who now runs a support group for ex-prisoners. "We used to say, 'You could be here for the next 20 years. You don't want to leave jail exactly as you came in. Put it to good use.' It was a driving force. It was very central to what we were all about.

The books we were really interested in were in relation to foreign struggles; Vietnam, Nicaragua, written revolution, Marxist Leninism, Irish history. There was a period after the protest when we were just totally Marxist Leninist; anything else was just not worthwhile. Even if you had a book on anarchists you would have not been taken seriously. If you had got a book in on football you would have got a bit of stick. It would have been like getting a comic. You would have to hide it.

"We had just come out of five intensive years of protest. Ten of our friends and comrades had died in the hunger strike. We were pretty serious people at that stage."

Danny Morrison, former publicity director for Sinn Fein, who served time in the Maze in the early 1990s, believes the intensity relating to the books reached an unhealthy level in the earlier days. As the inmates struggled to find a focus for their beliefs and used literature and learning to inform and fine-tune their attitudes, their families were dealing with the stark financial and social realities of life beyond the wire.

"I think the books are probably a a microcosm of the type of thinking that was going on. There was just this massive drive for a more ideological foundation for their beliefs," said Morrison. "But I believe that the atmosphere was so rarefied that it led to a distortion of the analysis. There was too much emphasis on Marxism and, I thought, too much dependence on the theoretical, particularly of a Marxist bent. It had to be tempered with the practicalities of life."

Morrison, now a writer, said the thinking, and the books, began to change with the collapse of communism, a shift that coincided with IRA inmates being paroled and a new generation of republican prisoners arriving.

"After the fall of the Berlin wall, the prisoners had to realign themselves and I think it was quite a shock to the main thinkers. They had been out of contact with the outside world and reality. I think after that people fell back into more traditional republican analysis. Certainly a more pragmatic approach started to be adopted.

"At that stage the republicans started taking parole. They had been in for 15 or 16 years and they were now getting out for a weekend and that informed their attitudes. Then there were others coming in from the 1980s with a less doctrinal approach."

Richard English notes that the IRA's identification with flashpoints elsewhere in the world tracks through the books. "The two places that seemed to be the most telling were the Middle East and South Africa," he says. "There are obvious differences between Northern Ireland and those two, but for the republicans the identification with Palestine and the blacks of South Africa had a resonance that was very important to them. In some way developments in those areas of peace processes meant that there was an echo of the kind of changes happening in the republican movement and a kind of reinforcement of that shift."

The fall of communism was deeply unsettling for the republican inmates, and McMullan says the collection reflects the reorientation taking place beyond the prison walls. "It did have an effect," he says. "Not to the extent where people would say, 'That's it, we can forget about it.' People adapted. In the late 80s more would have got into feminism, ecology and environmental issues."

He says the 1,700 books held at the Linen Hall library are representative but are only a fraction of the entire IRA Maze collection, which he estimates at 16,000 works. Most were taken home when the prisoners left.

There is talk of setting up a lending library with the remaining books, but McMullan is still wondering what to do with the part of the collection that the Linen Hall librarians have yet to see; five boxes full of the IRA's own works from the Maze - essays, theses, notes, letters and memos. They include a history of the prison in 24 chapters, a notebook titled Scenarios for a British Withdrawal, a five-page handwritten essay on Morality of the Armed Struggle, another notebook titled The Guerrilla Fighter, and letters from solicitors and politicians.

McMullan believes it is priceless. Richard English has seen the collection and believes that the seeds of the peace process may lie in the level of serious reflection infused in the documents and papers. As with the books that the Linen Hall has already studied and listed, the material in McMullan's boxes maps out the shifts and developments in republican think ing over the years: a thorough exploration of ideology.

Frankie Gallagher, however, might think it was propaganda. Gallagher, who works with loyalist ex-prisoners in east Belfast, says they felt no need to create an archive from the Maze or publicise their reading matter.

"The loyalists were very much a reactionary force," he said. "They were husbands, fathers, grandfathers who reacted to the bombs and the killing, the republican violence. And it was done in the background of what they saw as the government they were trying to defend imprisoning them. So it was not an ideology, a struggle for loyalists. It never came to that. That is why the loyalists didn't have the central plank of organising things or keeping things for posterity. They weren't into propaganda."

But they were into books, according to Martin Snodden, who served 15 years in the Maze for murder and is now director of EPIC, a support group for UVF ex-prisoners. "Books were almost in a sense like a life's blood," he said. "It was information. There was a hunger with regards to knowledge that existed within the prison itself from books to the quality papers like the Sunday Times and the Observer. They were scanned in great detail and there were waiting lists to read them. The Sunday Times would come in and it could be the following Wednesday before you got a look at it.

"There was no library as such. You have to understand that in the loyalist wings people more or less had their own books and they were passed between us. My experience was that if someone had a book in there were about 20 people waiting to read it. There were Irish history books, and other books on politics and social injustice."

Snodden's colleague at EPIC, Tom Roberts, who spent time in the H-blocks, said he and many of his fellow loyalist inmates took full advantage of the education service offered through the prison, and he dismisses the rumours that the loyalists' private collection was mostly made up of pornographic and weightlifting magazines.

"I can assure you that was not the case. Everybody had their own taste. There were a lot of history books, Irish history, English history and a lot about other conflicts in other parts of the world. There was a lot of educational reading went on, because many of us did degrees.

"I am not denying that people would have read whatever they would like to read and that includes the republicans. I think prisoners are like every cross- section of society. There is a wide variation in tastes."

Yet for all their differences, the books that filled the Maze show that those divided by politics and prison partition were linked by a common thread - a need to learn and an abiding love of literature.

In the days when books were still banned, Jackie McMullan managed to get hold of a smuggled copy of Robert Tressell's passionate defence of socialist ideals, The Ragged Trousered Philanthropists. He read 100 pages before it was confiscated and had to wait five years to finish it. It has stuck with him ever since.

Across in the loyalist block, Martin Snodden, too, had a book that had gripped him and stayed with him during his time inside - The Ragged Trousered Philanthropists. "The shared interests on the opposing sides have become clearer now they have left the Maze," says Richard English. "And we see there is a human community around all of these people. They did some appalling things but there is a poignancy on all sides. The whole thing looks tragic and frankly rather futile now. There is just a terrible sadness to it all."
