webTitle: Review: Emperors of Dreams: Drugs in the Nineteenth Century, by Mike Jay

fields.headline: Off their faces
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard gets high on Mike Jay's Emperors of Dreams: Drugs in the Nineteenth Century
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard gets high on Mike Jay's Emperors of Dreams: Drugs in the Nineteenth Century
fields.body:
Emperors of Dreams: Drugs in the Nineteenth Century

Mike Jay

(Dedalus, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

As every schoolboy knows, consciousness-altering drugs did not become illegal in this country until the early part of this century. Until then, people had been able to go to the chemist for any number of pick-me-up or put-me-down potions, tonics and powders, containing various concentrations of opium, cocaine, or cannabis. The situation was not even regarded as a problem, except for an unfortunate few.

What this excellent book does is tell us how we got from there to here; and also how we got there in the first place. For the true story of psychotropic substances in the modern world begins on 17 April 1799, as a young Humphry Davy inhaled four quarts of nitrous oxide from a silk bag in order to see what happened to his brain. (He also identifies "the first though by no means the last after-dinner guest to be subjected to an interminable cocaine-fuelled rant".) As Jay puts it: "This emergence of the effects of mind-expanding drugs into the clear light of science was both a cause and an effect of the birth of a new aspect of humanity - one which today we take for granted as part of our modern inheritance, but which in Davy's time was still emerging. To allow drugs into the mind in this way demands modern ideas of human agency, personality and responsibility; it both requires and generates an entirely new language for describing what goes on inside our heads; it holds up a mirror of self-consciousness which strips away the protective cladding of symbol, mystery and belief, leaving us naked in the keen air of the future, our inner workings visible as never before."

That is as purple as Jay's prose gets; but it states with precision as well as poetry the nature of the drug experience, and hints at one of the reasons why (as Nick Davies put it in one of his chilling reports on child abuse last week) we live in a society where police departments around the world are far happier to share resources and cooperate on the matter of the illegal drugs trade than on the kidnap and sexual enslavement of children. For it is not just that drugs were once tolerated and now are not; he traces the history of intolerance and fear surrounding them, showing that reaction to the pharmacopoeia was gradual, confused, and plausible; the most plausible and damaging myth being that we once lived in a society without drugs and could return there if we had the will and the power. We are, as he puts it, in the middle of a "noble experiment" - words used to describe the awful mistake of prohibition - and forget that fashionable ladies used to have ether parties.

Jay tries to be sober, as it were, and treat the historical record judiciously; he certainly gives the impression of being a trustworthy guide. (One test of this is how he treats the theory that Stevenson created Jekyll and Hyde during a cocaine binge. Some writers, in the face of no real evidence, assert it as fact, and it does seem as though it is on the way to being accepted as such; Jay just says that it is "likely". Which might still be going too far for some, but actually represents caution these days.) There is plenty of stuff here that is not news, but plenty that is, too; and if you are not quite familiar with the subject, or, like Jack Straw, brutally ignorant, you really should read this book.

webTitle: Small press corner:  A Short Survey of Surrealism, by David Gascoyne

fields.headline: A Short Survey of Surrealism
fields.trailText: One of the brightest small poetry presses, Enitharmon has smartly reissued David Gascoyne's classic 1935 history of the artistic and literary movement that, if it was short-lived in itself, continues to have an enormous influence on today's mass media.
fields.body:
A Short Survey of Surrealism

David Gascoyne

(Enitharmon, £8.95)
Buy it at BOL

One of the brightest small poetry presses, Enitharmon has smartly reissued David Gascoyne's classic 1935 history of the artistic and literary movement that, if it was short-lived in itself, continues to have an enormous influence on today's mass media. Born in 1916, still with us, and no mean poet himself, Gascoyne was one of the few English members of a group that counted André Breton, Paul Eluard, Louis Aragon, Tristan Tzara and Salvador Dalí among its infighting, posturing membership. Gascoyne helped curate the London International Surrealist Exhibition of 1936 and broadcast from Barcelona for the Republican side during the Spanish Civil war.

This book covers the birth and growth of the movement; though it swiftly became less a case of manifestos and a unitary identity than of the self-promotion of individual writers and painters. The art side has proved more durable (in part because of the poster ubiquity of Dalí's work), but there is much of enduring literary interest here, including analysis of and excerpts from many of the poets. Of these - leaving aside Gascoyne himself - Paul Eluard seems the most important 50 years on. But who's to tell what's what? As Dalí is proposed to remark in Paul Muldoon's poem 7 Middagh Street (see overleaf for two new Muldoon poems): "this lobster's not a lobster but the telephone / That rang for Neville Chamberlain".

webTitle: Review: John Maynard Keynes: Fighting for Britain 1937-46  by Robert Skidelsky

fields.headline: Battle for Britain
fields.standfirst: Hywel Williams  learns why Keynes had a bad war from Robert Skidelsky's John Maynard Keynes: Fighting for Britain 1937-46
fields.trailText: Hywel Williams learns why Keynes had a bad war from Robert Skidelsky's John Maynard Keynes: Fighting for Britain 1937-46
fields.body:
John Maynard Keynes: Fighting for Britain 1937-46

Robert Skidelsky

591pp, Macmillan, £25
Buy it at BOL

At Tilton, Maynard Keynes's Sussex home, there stood a fig tree which had never flowered. The Copernicus of economics, recently ennobled, stood before it and remarked: "Barren fig tree, Baron Keynes."

The childless man's self-pity was uncharacteristic as well as misplaced. Keynes had the faith of a liberal, both in the clarity of his own mind and in the amenability of the world to reason's dictates. His legacy even in his own lifetime had been prodigious. The Keynesian "middle way" was no shallow equivocation but an escape from the dead hands of both free trade and protectionism. The "paradox of thrift" became a generation's truism: saving during a depression only made a community poorer, therefore governments should spend in hard times and save in a boom. Keynesian magic dispelled illusion and showed that market economics had no automatic capacity to generate full employment. During the second world war he was an unofficial chancellor, the impresario of his own intellectual revolution. Budgets now had a social dimension and economic policy observed a divide between suburban south and distressed north. Rearmament spending was targeted to create jobs.

Keynes, though chilly in personality, had a vision of plenty. The world economist also attended to the wine list at the restaurant of the Cambridge Arts Theatre, where elastic demand suggested low prices for good vintages - and profits boomed despite warnings of local priggishness. Keynes's touch always banished the fear to consume, and he rescued economics from its Benthamite condition as the "dismal science". In his hands it became the handmaiden of a fuller life, a true science of happiness.

Robert Skidelsky's 20-year pursuit of that elusive figure, the real Maynard Keynes, has been an inspiring sight. In volume one of his biography he rescued the Edwardian intellectual aristocracy from clichés about Bloomsbury, while volume two recreated Keynes's intellectual architecture as his "General Theory" confronted the dragons of the slump. With volume three, we arrive at something no less impressive. In effect, Skidelsky has written an alternative history of Britain during the second world war; and in doing so he shows why Keynes, standing in front of his fig tree, had apparent occasion for gloom.

The economist who was in "deeply moved agreement" with Hayek's Road to Serfdom was no believer in central planning for its own sake. Nationalisation and incomes policies, the collectivist panoply of vulgarly mislabelled "Keynesianism", were abhorrent to him. His "comprehensive socialisation of investment" was not the same thing as public ownership; he meant rather the growth of institutions that pursued public-interest aims rather than short-term profit, such as universities and even newspapers. His was a stakeholder's vision.

Keynes was mercurial, but there was one grand continuity to him. A political and intellectual liberal, a man of property and city directorships, he believed in the protection of capital and the freedom to choose. Hating the idea of a totalitarian war economy, he had wanted a fiscal alternative to finance the struggle. His advocacy was done in straightforward class terms. Working-class purchasing power was to be reduced, inflation averted and war chests filled by compulsory savings. Treated with typical Keynesian aloofness, Labour and union leaders were outraged. The neo-pacifist had no feel for any war - but especially not for this one. Rationing was popular, and equality mattered: hence Kingsley Wood's 1941 budget with its 100% Excess Profits Tax and price fixing. Keynes was living in what he called a "slave state".

But the ailing prophet's war-time energies were mostly directed across the Atlantic. Skidelsky's story acquires its bite with details of Keynes's desperate negotiation of American financial support for a broke Britain. Although brilliant at the translation of his ideas into administrative practice, Keynes was a non-starter in American power politics. The product of one empire on the wane, he failed to understand the new empire's mentality, never grasping the dynamics of Congress and the division of powers. He couldn't lobby. That is one reason why his brainwave, the IMF, ended up as a hegemonic American policeman rather than as the leaner, genuinely international organisation he had imagined.

Above all, Keynes was disabled by a rationalist innocence that ignored the depth of America's suspicions about Britain. Skidelsky notes that America's third war aim after the defeat of the German and Japanese empires was the dissolution of the British version. In 1939-40 it mistook Britain for an opulent empire - one that had, moreover, defaulted in 1933 on its first world war American debts. Internationalist in trade when it had suited, in leaner times Britain had contracted into protectionism. America had made the same journey, but in an opposite direction. Now it wanted the abolition of imperial protection - both economically and politically.

"Lend-lease" was the background to Keynes's failure. Roosevelt's shifty improvisation was a solution to both Britain's penury and American isolationism. America's loan of equipment would help Britain "put out the fire"; it would also edge America towards war since the transport across the Atlantic would be vulnerable to U-boat attack. But behind the offer was a Democratic Party dominated by immigrant communities who hated all empires - including Britain's. In return Britain had to accept limitations of both its exports and its gold and dollar reserves, meaning that it started the peace with the largest external debt in its history.

Keynes was the negotiator of grudging loans to avert the financial Dunkirk that loomed in the war's second half. Justice mattered to him. It was important that Britain had suffered disproportionately during the war - but waving medals was a failure of tone. He had to deal with an American treasury official, Harry Dexter White, who thought that the world should be conveniently parcelled between the Americans and the Soviets. It was White's proposal that Germany be "pastoralised" after the war and its industrial capacity destroyed. The critic of the Versailles Treaty's vengeance was again among the barbarians.

There is comedy in Skidelsky's account of all those Keynesian quips falling dead from his lips as the illusionless bosses look down from the saddle. But the keynote is pathos - that of a high-minded liberal unable to understand the gut-instinct hostility of a strange new world. At its most cynical interpretation, lend-lease enabled Britain to protect its empire in the Middle and Far East - but at a cunning cost. The means of immediate preservation were also designed to be those of the eventual enslavement of Britain's domestic economy to the new imperium.

The "special relationship" had always been an artificial creation - the result of the fact that there were no other allies possible in 1939. Skidelsky shows the scale of self-deception involved in this alternative to Britain's traditional role in the European balance of power. It is all the more surprising, therefore, that he raises the fantasy of Nazi Germany's financial plans as the intellectual ancestors of the European Union. This is a rare sighting of Skidelsky the Tory peer squinting at us from the foliage of his footnotes. But it is a sighting happily dissolved in awed contemplation of his mighty achievement.

At its most cynical interpretation, lend-lease enabled Britain to protect its empire in the Middle and Far East - but at a cunning cost. The means of immediate preservation were also designed to be those of the eventual enslavement of Britain's domestic economy to the new imperium. The "special relationship" had always been an artificial creation - the result of the fact that there were no other allies possible in 1939. Skidelsky shows the scale of self-deception involved in this alternative to Britain's traditional role in the European balance of power. It is all the more surprising, therefore, that he raises the fantasy of Nazi Germany's financial plans as the intellectual ancestors of the European Union. This is a rare sighting of Skidelsky the Tory peer squinting at us from the foliage of his footnotes. But it is a sighting happily dissolved in awed contemplation of his mighty achievement.

fields.headline: Exile in the human zoo
fields.standfirst: Robert Potts  on  Peter Reading's  poems from a Texan hicksville, Marfan
fields.trailText: Robert Potts on Peter Reading's poems from a Texan hicksville, Marfan
fields.body:
Marfan

Peter Reading

64pp, Bloodaxe, £6.95
Buy it at BOL

Peter Reading's latest volume, Marfan , is the fruit of a year spent in small-town Texas as "a solitary, voluntary exile", funded by the Lannan Foundation, an American institution which gives generous awards to writers.

After a decade of increasingly gloomy and abstract work, Marfan returns to the anecdotes, characterisations, monologues and reportage that comprised much of Reading's earliest work. The result is one of the most impressive volumes he has written; vivid, hilarious, intelligent and engaged.

The book is composed of chunks - not always individual poems - in various metres and registers, as Reading describes the inhabitants of Marfa, its history, politics, superstitions, geology and fauna. Verbatim conversations, snippets from the local paper, caricatures, descriptions and satires are all mingled, interspersed with photographs by Jay Shuttleworth and collages by the author. Occasional epiphanies gleam through the darker moods and gallows hilarity, as Reading sardonically calls attention to his own peculiar place as an English poet in Texan Hicksville:

For I am catapulted to the grandeur of Marfan Literary Resident (sinecure recently inaugurated by the beneficence of Patrick Lannan - blessandpreservehimandhiswholefoundation).

The tradition of literary gratitude to patrons must have been irresistible carrion for Reading's caustic irony; later he writes, deadpan, "'Twas then they sent in Lannan's secret weapon", and (more realistically, given his candour about the townsfolk) also notes: "When this gets published I shall have to be / beyond the City Limits in a Greyhound".

Reading never misses a connection, and another artist with patronage gets it in the neck. "Seems to me carpetbaggers shouldn't complain," Reading remarks of Donald Judd, the well-funded artist who built "100 waist-high milled aluminium boxes ... billion-dollar, minimalist, / factory-finish, self-indulgent art games" in Marfa, but who whined about the noise from the mill near his apartment. Reading also has other "carpetbaggers" in his sights: the Americans who kicked out the "injuns" ("the indigenous can fuck off outa here") and are now kicking out the "Spiks" (the American fear of aliens, whether extraterrestrial or Mexican, is scathingly satirised); the "arties, architects, carpetbaggers, entrepreneurs / 'gallery owners', leather coat boutiquers" snapping up real estate in Marfa; indeed, the human species itself, replacing the pterosaurs who "in the late Cretaceous ... darkly traversed the Big Bend floodplain".

These various perspectives, constantly overriding or undercutting each other, demonstrate Reading's continual compassion for the dispossessed as well as a delicate blend of contempt and respect for the lunacies of the townspeople he encounters. His vicious and emetic response to the "How y'all" greeting of Marfan locals (it "induces ... a desire to puke against the wall, / or evacuate one's chitterling, or spawl") is offset by a quotation from Nathaniel Hawthorne on his trip to Liverpool: "The British / sodden in strong beer, have a conversation / like a plum pudding - stodgy, bilious." An incongruous Wisden in the public library "charts the achievement of that English summer / before climacteric and post-bellum slump". Reading is not, that is, an Anglophile xenophobe; and a gnomic one-liner ("we call it Marfa, but we mean the lot") suggests that drawing a clear line between the specific and the general is not part of the plan.

Amid a wealth of detail - personal stories, local history and folklore, politics, paranoia, art, religion - Reading situates himself as a small and transitory speck in the bigger picture (his cherished "Rothko sunset") while treating us to his witty spleneticisms, brief sentimentalities, precise descriptions and not ungenerous amusement. As ever, despair, both environmental and political, is never absent; but this is an appreciative, defiantly humane volume, and a remarkable poetic evocation of a real place. The Lannan Foundation is getting its money's worth. So are we.

webTitle: The Gate and The Bed by Paul Muldoon

fields.headline: The Gate and The Bed
fields.trailText:
As I roved out between a gaol

and a river in spate...
fields.body:
THE GATE

As I roved out between a gaol
and a river in spate
in June as like as January
I happened on a gate
which, though it lay wide open,
would make me hesitate.
I was so long a prisoner
that, though I now am free,
the thought that I serve some sentence
is so ingrained in me
that I still wait for a warder
to come and turn the key.

THE BED

A stone-breaker on his stone bed
lay no less tightly curled
than Opposite-leaved Saxifrage
that even now, unfurled,
has broken through its wall of walls
into this other world.

Commissioned by Reading Council, these poems were written to mark the centenary of Oscar Wilde's death on November 30, 1900. Three years earlier, he had been released from Reading Goal. The text of The Gate is incorporated into the new wrought-iron Oscar Wilde gates on a path near the former prison.

webTitle: Review: Dumbstruck: A Cultural History of Ventriloquism

fields.headline: Voices from the cellar
fields.standfirst: Stuart Jeffries  admires Dumbstruck, a cultural history of ventriloquism by  Steven Connor that's not for dummies
fields.trailText: Stuart Jeffries admires Dumbstruck, a cultural history of ventriloquism by Steven Connor that's not for dummies
fields.body:
Dumbstruck: A Cultural History of Ventriloquism
Steven Connor
449pp, Oxford, £25
Buy it at BOL

Bodies were usually kept in the cellar of the St Louis hospital in Paris for three days before burial. One midnight a man's voice was heard from the cellar, making those above believe that someone had come round from unconsciousness to find themselves surrounded by corpses. The cellar was searched, the bodies examined, but no living man was discovered. A few years later, in a Hamburg park, a voice was heard calling for help from a disused well. The police began to excavate frantically, but whenever they drew near to the voice it cried out from somewhere else.

These were just two of the apprentice pranks played by the great 19th-century ventriloquist Alexandre Vattemare. He was a wicked student at the Paris hospital and a shady walker in the Hamburg park - in the latter case slipping away undetected as darkness fell and the frantic police carried on digging. Steven Connor writes of these incidents: "Voices from holes, wells, cellars, sewers and chimneys testify to the dread of premature burial that would bubble up at intervals during the 19th century. The fact that these frantic searches for lost or locked-up children will always be in vain ensures both that the child (it is not always a child's voice that cries for help but it always has a child's helplessness) never quite dies (for its body is never found), but is never rescued either (for its body is never found)."

This, then, is not a funtime showbiz book: there is nothing here about the lime-green bird Orville or the doe-eyed yutz who spent his career with his hand up its (his? her?) jacksy. For which, Professor Connor, much thanks. If Orville had appeared in the index, it would have been wedged between "Orphism" and "otherness".

In fact, as Connor recognises, Vattemare's two pranks are even more resonant than he initially suggests. They show the ventriloquist's shamanic power to tamper with the apparent physical world. Vattemare's emergence in Europe came at a time when the ventriloquist had stopped being a subject of priestly opprobrium but was still a dodgy geezer at the margins of polite society. He was the untrustworthy, captivating man who met the demands of his audiences' other-worldly fantasies. No wonder, then, that Vattemare and his ilk prefigured spiritualism. True, spiritualists profess actually to raise the dead and Vattemare only seemed to bring dead bodies back to life, but he knew that to dabble in the dark side did good box office.

Ventriloquists have been around ever since the god Apollo possessed a priestess and drove her into a frenzy, and the result became the Delphic Oracle. Connor finds other hysterical women and phallocentric men throughout this richly detailed history. Indeed, he considers - only to reject - the notion that ventriloquism started with possessed women such as the Witch of Endor who, like Vattemare, produced a dead man's voice for a credulous audience, this figure mutating through history into the male secular entertainer speaking through another's body. It would be an oversimplification to divide ventriloquism up between passive women and active men, and one thing Connor can never be accused of is oversimplification.

Vattemare, who held European audiences in thrall during the 1820s, would even produce a nice joke at the expense of the etymology of "ventriloquism", a Latin translation of the Greek engastrimythos - en meaning in, gastri meaning stomach and mythos meaning word or speech. Instead of speaking through his own stomach, Vattemare would invite someone on stage and speak through theirs, thus combining two hitherto separate skills - throwing the voice and producing it from somewhere other than one's mouth.

We are a long way here from the boring modern ventriloquist who balances a doll on his knee. "Ventriloquism for us has become the art of making certain kinds of visible anthropomorphic object appear to talk," writes Connor. He is delightfully sniffy about such entertainers. He suggests that it is no wonder Ray Alan chose a sloshed aristocrat as his professional partner - Lord Charles's enunciation is easier to perform. And what's more, "Let us be candid: all ventriloquist dummies, the ones representing the humans at any rate, have the same face ... garishly coloured, with flushed cheeks and high gloss, bright and fixedly staring eyes, a stiffly jointed jaw ..." It is, in short, a parody of an adolescent boy (though one with a drink problem) with whom the ventriloquist (if he knows what he's up to) plays out an Oedipal struggle to sinister and comic effect.

I was hoping for rather more on the uncanniness of dolls who come to life; the chapter on automata is perhaps not as spooky as it could have been. But otherwise this book is an unexpected triumph: I would not have thought that Connor, previously the author of cultural-studies works of an Eagletonian bent, could have produced such a well-researched, elegantly written, intellectually satisfying book.

He throws his voice back through the past to a time when ventriloquism wasn't for dummies. Better than that, he encourages other voices - the phenomenologist Maurice Merleau-Ponty and the deconstructionist Jacques Derrida, among others - to climb out of their boxes and take over the narrative while Connor pauses, perhaps, for a gottle of geer. Refreshed, he returns to analyse these thinkers: Michel Foucault gets properly savaged for his misreading of Diderot's Les Bijoux Indiscrets , the story of a bored sultan who uses a magic ring to make women talk through their genitals and thus reveal their sexual pasts for his jaded delectation. It's not all about sex, Connor tells the monomaniac Michel, but also a clever philosophical disquisition on forced speech.

The book's first chapter is marvellously off-putting (for those looking for nookie) and virtuosic (for those who care about the phenomenology of space and the metaphysics of sensual awareness). For Connor, professor of modern literature and theory at the University of London, is utterly engrossing on his central prefatory theme: namely, that nothing else about a person defines them so intimately as their voice. This is why the upset is so profound when one hears one's voice on tape and finds it thin, piping and ugly. Normally, after all, when one speaks aloud one is embroiled in a self-caressing dance of tongue, palate and lips, counterpointed with the pleasurable muscular rhythms of the breath being drawn in and released. A recorded voice is cut off from these sensations - a defiled version of some vital part of the speaker.

While Stalin was Genghis Kahn with a megaphone, we are now all projectors of voices - barkers into mobiles, silver-tongued phone seducers. Our vocal space has expanded massively thanks to technology, the impact of which Connor patiently unravels. This is necessary groundwork for the cataclysm of Ps that follows: the book is divided between prophecy, possession, polyphonics, prodigies and prosthetics. And a glorious agglomeration of glossolalia and guttural grandeur it is too. Somehow I can't imagine Lord Charles getting his laughing gear around that lot.

fields.headline: Fiction - 2 December
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery reviews Speaking With The Angel, The Haunt, Grimm's Last Fairytale and Confessions Of A Lapsed Standard Bearer
fields.body:
Speaking With The Angel
ed Nick Hornby
(Penguin, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

If you haven't heard Hornby talking about the Treehouse, the school his autistic son attends, read the introduction. Otherwise rummage through this excellent collection of short stories that Hornby's friends have donated to raise funds. The cause is worthy and Hornby's contributors - Melissa Bank, John O'Farrell, Robert Harris, and Patrick Marber, among others - have given excellent work rather than castoffs, so this reads like a compendium of the kind of writing that newspapers and magazines would pay dearly to publish in their Christmas issues. Don't feel virtuous: charity is only a by-product of this very good sampler of contemporary literature.

The Haunt
AL Barker
(Virago, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

A thoroughly English novel that nods in the direction of Iris Murdoch, The Haunt shows Barker's brilliant command of language and nuance. A dysfunctional Cornish hotel is the focus for discontented characters drawn to the Cornish Riviera in the hope of healing their wounds, patching up relationships or probing the past. Emotions spill across separate tables and result in a rearrangement, but not a resolution, of their dilemmas. Barker has an almost brusque economy in her writing: dialogue is clipped, with the speakers woefully at odds and stilted by repressed feeling. Plot is almost incidental; situation and character are all in this highly charged set piece.

Grimm's Last Fairytale
Haydn Middleton
(Abacus, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Jacob Grimm, collector with his brother Wilhelm of folk stories, is an unusual subject. We know the tales, but Grimm's life and his contribution to the development of a sense of German nationhood is more problematic. Between an account of the the elderly Grimm returning to Hesse accompanied by his niece and a manservant of Jewish origin, a psychological retelling of the Rose Queen ("Sleeping Beauty"); and a potted Grimm biography, we must grasp a history of romanticism and post-Napoleon politics as well as understanding Bismarck and Nazism. Middleton's interpretation is subtly layered but his writing never unburdens Grimm from the weight of history.

Confessions Of A Lapsed Standard Bearer
Andrei Makine
(Sceptre, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Two boys grow up outside Leningrad at a time when the bright dawn of communism is an attainable goal rather than a dead letter: then come disillusionment, exile, and nostalgia. The author has lived it and knows what a western audience wants to learn about cheering Sputnik, going to Pioneer camp and discovering how the grown-ups lived through the war and Uncle Joe. Makine is a very good writer, poetic but never fanciful, and one who treats childhood reflected through experience with delicacy. My one quibble: last December I reviewed another Makine: same theme, Siberian location.

fields.headline: Non-fiction - 2 December
fields.trailText: John Dugdale on the fierce satire of Index on Censorship: The Last Laugh and the awe of the new in A Brief History of the Future: The Origins of the Internet
fields.body:
Index on Censorship: The Last Laugh
(£8.99)

The bi-monthly magazine Index on Censorship produces thematic issues displaying a liveliness and diversity few other periodicals could match, with big names attracted by its prestige and unrivalled internationalism. The Guardian 's Nicholas Lezard (attacking sold-out "alternative" comedians) and Martin Rowson (defending vitriolic political cartoons) are among the contributors to its comedy issue, which also includes pieces by Ken Campbell and the late Bill Hicks. Interwoven are reports on film censorship in Algeria and Egypt, Russian TV's Spitting Image, anti-government cartoons in Hong Kong, and - by Pieter-Dirk Uys - satire in South Africa.

A Brief History of the Future: The Origins of the Internet by John Naughton
(Phoenix, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

Trained as an engineer, Observer columnist John Naughton has a natural empathy with the oddball mathematicians and geeky programmers who contributed to the evolution of the internet, enabling him to depict the leap of imagination each development entailed with compelling vividness. And these advances, from the dreams of 1930s computer pioneers to the creation of the world wide web, are explained with unfailing lucidity. Most science books leave any reader who gave up physics and biology at 16 feeling stupid; this absorbing chronicle enables you to share its author's sense of amazement.

The Guardian 's Nicholas Lezard (attacking sold-out "alternative" comedians) and Martin Rowson (defending vitriolic political cartoons) are among the contributors to its comedy issue, which also includes pieces by Ken Campbell and the late Bill Hicks. Interwoven are reports on film censorship in Algeria and Egypt, Russian TV's Spitting Image, anti-government cartoons in Hong Kong, and - by Pieter-Dirk Uys - satire in South Africa. fields.headline: Gory stories for tiny tots
fields.standfirst: Oliver Burkeman  ventures into the weird world of Edward Gorey
fields.trailText: Oliver Burkeman ventures into the weird world of Edward Gorey
fields.body:
The Headless Bust: A Melancholy Meditation on the False Millennium

80pp, Bloomsbury, £8.99
Buy it at BOL

The Unstrung Harp; or, Mr Earbrass Writes a Novel

64pp, Bloomsbury, £5.99
Buy it at BOL

Edward Gorey

"Many of Edward Gorey's most fervent devotees think he must be both a) English and b) dead," reads the biographical note on one of his darkly illustrated tales of hapless babies, consumptive waifs and sexually traumatising furniture. "Actually, he has never so much as visited either place."

No longer, sadly: though Gorey never did make it across the Atlantic, he is now - owing to a heart attack in April, aged 75, in the cat-filled Cape Cod farmhouse where he lived alone - a permanent resident of the other side. It's easy to see why readers thought he moved there years ago, his more than 50 books seeming to have issued from the pen of the love child (orphaned, of course) of Ivy Compton Burnett and Edgar Allan Poe.

They are cautionary tales bereft of moral resolution - stories of gin-soaked children and pale-faced newborns brought low by nameless monsters, sudden fires and mysterious vapours. The titles set the tone: The Hapless Child, The Listing Attic, The Fatal Lozenge. Gorey always insisted they were aimed at "reasonably small children", and unconvincingly denied taking any morbid relish in their creation. They are, almost without exception, unspeakably funny. "To take my works seriously," as Gorey once put it, "would be the height of folly."

The really morbid stuff all happens out of sight. Winding staircases vanish out of the frame; inscrutable objects can just be made out in the depths of frenziedly crosshatched shadow. The Gashlycrumb Tinies, ostensibly a children's ABC, shows each of its protagonists immediately prior to meeting a grisly end ("I is for Ida who drowned in a lake / J is for James who took lye by mistake"). In The Curious Sofa - "A pornographic work by Ogdred Weary" - elegant furs vanish behind Edwardian screens and drawing rooms stand empty while captions archly tell the tale of a depraved dinner party: "That evening in the library, Scylla, one of the guests who had certain anatomical peculiarities, demonstrated the 'Lithuanian Typewriter', assisted by Ronald and Robert, two remarkably well-set-up young men from the village."

The Headless Bust - Gorey's final work and a sequel (to the extent that the concept makes sense in a world largely lacking in narrative logic) to The Haunted Tea Cosy - is an improvisation on the theme of Dickens's A Christmas Carol . An oversized beetle, The Bahhumbug, accosts Edmund Gravel in the small hours of the morning and takes him on a tour of every kind of haplessness:

Sir U- fell from a speeding train

Which did some damage to his brain

And after that he did not know

How to pronounce the letter O.

The seasoned Gorey reader, though, will not be expecting a moral at the end:

"Who were those people? Why did they

Appear to us along the way?"

"But then again, why should we care?

It's quelque chose d'un grand mystère."

The Unstrung Harp, originally published in 1953, is Gorey's first work, and is largely unconcerned with macabre deaths. Instead, it is a parodic meditation on the masochism of the novelist's life -specifically, the life of Mr Earbrass, a renowned writer resident "near Collapsed Pudding in Mortshire", who begins a novel on November 18 each year. Finding a subject is trial enough, but it is the rewrites that cause him the greatest agonies: "This is worse than merely writing, because not only does he have to think up new things just the same, but at the same time try not to remember the old ones." Already, Gorey's illustrative style seems fully developed - aspects of Japanese art, Beardsleyesque line drawings and modern American cartooning collide in a dark stew of tenebrous living rooms and sinister antiques shops.

Gorey's works deserve to be far more than a mere cult, and Bloomsbury has made an admirable start at bringing them to a UK audience. Along with these volumes, a handful already published here include The Doubtful Guest, the story of a mournful, plimsoll-wearing, unidentifiable furry creature that disturbs the calm of an elegant family home one winter's night and ends up staying ("It came 17 years ago, and to this day / It has shown no intention of going away").

But there ought to be many more yet to come - plenty to keep "reasonably small children" in Christmas presents for years, though probably also in therapy for several years after that.

webTitle: Guardian review: The Pornographer's Poem by Michael Turner

fields.headline: I was a teenage porn king
fields.standfirst: Michael Turner's The Pornographer's Poem is  Salinger with a strap-on. By Carrie O'Grady
fields.trailText: Michael Turner's The Pornographer's Poem is Salinger with a strap-on. By Carrie O'Grady
fields.body:
The Pornographer's Poem
Michael Turner
320pp, Sceptre, £12
Buy it at BOL

The Canadian Michael Turner has a knack for titles. Just as children's books with the word "chocolate" in the title sell unusually well, Turner's three novels seduce you with their promise of grown-up delights: alcohol, debauchery, sex. Hard Core Logo , his experimental novel about a punk band of the same name, is now a movie, a radio play and a comic book; American Whiskey Bar was picked up for television; and now The Pornographer's Poem has won him huge critical acclaim and an award in British Columbia.

Happily, the book justifies its hype: it's more generous with the porn than with the poems. Turner himself has called it "The Catcher in the Rye with a strap-on", and the Salinger bit is important, for the novel is at heart a coming-of-age story. It is 1978 and the nameless narrator is 16 when an unorthodox teacher introduces him to the techniques of Super-8 film. Disillusioned and frustrated by what he sees as almost universal hypocrisy, our boy keeps only one of his projects: a blurry home movie of his swinging neighbours having sex with their dog. The short is a hit on the Vancouver underground scene and he drifts into semiprofessional porn.

We're given the pornographer's story as he tells it, complete with exaggerations, half-truths and justifications. Turner's hero will not tolerate hypocrisy, in himself or in others, yet he does things our society considers morally unjustifiable: underage porn, hard drugs, abandoning friends. How would such a man justify himself? This is the fascinating riddle that weaves in and out of the narrative. Turner sets up a vague authority figure to interrogate the narrator about his misspent life; there's no process of judgment, just questions and statements. It is up to us, and our prejudices, to work out whether this is a life worth living.

The novel is pornographic in more ways than one. The erotic scenes are offered up to us without passion: we watch from a distance, as though through a camera lens. When The Pornographer's Poem is made into a film - as it almost certainly will be - it will be closer to that other unrelenting portrait of 1970s suburban sleaze, The Ice Storm, than to Boogie Nights. Like both films, though, it has its moments of humour. Turner has an especially good time with the narrator's early adolescence, when sex is still an escape, an exploration - something to be marvelled at.

A masturbatory photo found in a neighbour's drawer provides a brilliant passage on the feelings of a child forced to acknowledge and accommodate the fact of sexuality. "I remember the moment so well," recalls the narrator, "if only because of the way the photo seemed to animate that garbage, how each item - the Vaseline, the beer sausage, the tissues, the magazines - came to life, leapt from the page, how they danced about my neighbour like something from Fantasia." Disturbing, but, like the rest of this excellent novel, somehow disturbingly true.

webTitle: Review: From Caucasia, With Love by Danzy Senna

fields.headline: Colour bind
fields.standfirst: Maya Jaggi  on Danzy Senna's  parable of race,  From Caucasia, With Love
fields.trailText: Maya Jaggi on Danzy Senna's parable of race, From Caucasia, With Love
fields.body:
From Caucasia, With Love
Danzy Senna
413pp, Bloomsbury, £16.99
Buy it at BOL

Light-skinned African-Americans "passing" for white have long served in American fiction to expose the bizarre pathologies of the colour line. Danzy Senna's absorbing debut updates the theme to the tail end of black power in the 1970s and early 1980s, as seen through the eyes of a young girl coming of age. This is the searing perspective of Harper Lee's To Kill a Mockingbird , to which Senna gestures in naming her narrator Birdie Lee.

Birdie is the daughter of black Deck, an academic revolutionary, and white Sandy, the blonde, "blue-blooded" daughter of a Harvard professor, who is an activist for a black power cell. Birdie is so close to her older sister Cole that they speak a private language, but while Cole appears black, Birdie is taken to be white, provoking flickers of "surprise, sometimes amusement, sometimes disbelief" in strangers. The novel reveals how far identity is confined to "the illusions that were our skins", and how those illusions can fracture a family. While Cole is Deck's favourite - "proof that his blackness hadn't been completely blanched" - he is nearly arrested simply for walking in the park with his younger daughter. Sandy, meanwhile, feels inadequate to care for Cole's "nappy" hair, while her own mother lines Birdie up to receive the family heirlooms, praising her Italian or French looks. The eight-year-old senses these as "sinister compliments": her grandmother loves her not for herself but for her skin, hair, phenotype, "because they resembled her own".

In a racially divided Boston after the advent of civil rights, the sisters are sent to a black power school. But the family collapses when the FBI closes in, and Sandy and Deck separate. Deck heads for Brazil with Cole and his new girlfriend, while Sandy and Birdie go on the run to the "whitewashed" heartland of New Hampshire (the "Caucasia" of the title) camouflaged as "Sheila Goldman" and her half-Jewish daughter.

Birdie floats through a world of motels and women's communes, imbibing "trailah pahk cultcha" and learning to sway her hips "to the sound of heavy metal, wear blue eyeliner and frosted lipstick and snap my gum". Though fearing whiteness as "contagious", she is conscious of her body as a "toy" enabling her to disappear into different worlds like a shapeshifter. She imagines herself a "spy in enemy territory" and prefers trailerpark nuts to genteel racists like her grandmother: in that world, "I would know I was living a lie."

Senna deftly charts liminal states, not only of racial identity and womanhood but of sexuality and class. Deck falls into homophobic disdain for a friend who comes out after a lifetime of "passing" as straight; Birdie is befriended by a transvestite hooker. Sandy, too, has chosen to cross borders. She is among the privileged who are brave enough "to forgo their birthrights and switch their fates" - at the cost of losing a child to "this war they call America".

The novel gathers the pace of a thriller as the resourceful Birdie becomes a runaway searching for her scattered family. She rejects the person she has become and throws out as "Victorian crap" her grandmother's mantel of the "tragic mulatto", declaring: "You and all your ancestors are the tragedies. Not me." Birdie feels the lure of rappers and breakdancers in New York and Cole, stuck in Brazil, yearns for black America, "whose pathology she at least could call her own". Yet this novel is aimed less at black affirmation than at questioning the very meaning of race. As Deck spells out to Birdie, race is not just an artificial construct, but a 400-year-old scientific error: race is "just a costume. We all wear one. You just switched yours at some point". From Caucasia, With Love welcomes new possibilities, hinting at mingled identities. Deck describes the mulatto as a canary in a gold mine, a gauge of the poison of American race relations; Birdie's is the first generation of canaries to survive - however bruised.

Deck's theories threaten to make over-explicit what is more subtly revealed through metaphor. Reflecting on the way apparent opposites meet, Birdie says: "The snow looked tinted with blue, the way totally white things sometimes do. It's the same with things that are deeply black - an Asian girl's hair, a drop of ink, a stallion's coat. They turn to blue." This remarkably acute and controlled first novel is full of such moments of resonant clarity. It strives for honesty rather than show, illuminating both painful and heartening truths.

fields.headline: Sex, cake and cigars
fields.trailText: One could have easily concluded that Bad Sex runs in the family when novelist Sean Thomas scooped the Literary Review's prize of the same name earlier this week. Sean, you see, is D M Thomas's son
fields.body:
 One could have easily concluded that Bad Sex runs in the family when novelist Sean Thomas scooped the Literary Review's prize of the same name earlier this week. Sean, you see, is D M Thomas's son; had the Lit Rev been dispensing its little statuettes of half-naked women in 1981, The White Hotel's infamous bayonet rape scene might well have qualified. Rather more mundanely, Thomas fils drew his inspiration from hi-fi equipment, the winning passage comparing a woman to a Sony Walkman, but nevertheless, it caught the judges' attention. Less mundane was Thomas's acceptance speech, in which he revealed an previous liaison with the magazine - as a neophyte reviewer, he solicited work from Auberon Waugh, who kindly continued to send him books even when he was briefly detained at Her Majesty's Pleasure.

 Jumping out of a cake to present the award was Mick Jagger, who admitted to a certain confusion over what exactly bad sex was. For musicians, he asserted, bad sex could only be defined as no sex, quantity rather than quality being very much the issue. The assembled company - a mixture of braying public schoolboys, vamped-up-to-the-nines publicity assistants and Michael Aspel - whooped with delight, having never been in quite such close proximity to somebody really famous. The Loafer's companion whispered anxiously that something was twitching at her right buttock; with a swift backward glance, we took our leave.

 Continuing the sexual theme, a rather unseasonal gift - although who knows what arguments might brew over the brandy butter - arrives from Routledge, to accompany Castration: An Abbreviated History of Western Manhood. Whichever way you look at it, it's an offensive weapon, but the Loafer imagines it was originally intended for clipping cigars. One can hardly envisage how a razor neatly positioned over a small circle could be used for anything else. Top and tailing carrots, perhaps?

 News reaches us of art lover Henry Sutton, whose tale of life on a jumbo jet, Flying, boasts a handsome aeroplane on its cover - the work of none other than Turner Prize winner Wolfgang Tillmans. Lucky, then, that Sutton didn't select one of Tillmans's other air-related images - a shot juxtaposing a penis and an in-flight meal. Ugh.

webTitle: Review: Changing Stages by Richard Eyre and Nicholas Wright

fields.headline: Curtain call
fields.standfirst: Richard Eyre's theatre history,  Changing Stages,  works better on the box, says  Michael Billington
fields.trailText: Richard Eyre's theatre history, Changing Stages, works better on the box, says Michael Billington
fields.body:
Changing Stages

Richard Eyre and Nicholas Wright

400pp, Bloomsbury, £30
Buy it at BOL

British television is suddenly a brighter place because of two overlapping series. One is Simon Schama's History of Britain ; the other is Richard Eyre's survey of 20th-century British theatre, Changing Stages. Both are in the great tradition: informative, unpatronising, capable of speaking simultaneously to the expert and to the novice. Eyre's programme in particular makes marvellous use of visual testimony: old stills, nostalgia-soaked clips, eyewitness accounts. It was fascinating to hear Arthur Miller admitting that the House Un-American Activities Committee would have let him off lightly if only he'd brought along Marilyn Monroe for a photo opportunity.

The TV series, on the evidence so far, is a triumph. The book on which it is based, cowritten by Eyre and Nicholas Wright, is a bit of a baggy monster: a mix of the brusque and the brilliant that seems torn between weighty, cram-it-all-in reference book and opinionated guide to modern theatre. When the authors' sympathies are engaged or they are writing with inside knowledge, the book is full of bounce and verve; at other times it resorts to a breathless telegraphese in which key writers and movements are mentioned in hectic dispatches.

Shakespeare, oddly enough, was better served on TV than he is in the book. On the box Eyre made excellent use of surviving film - from Beerbohm Tree's King John to Peter Brook's A Midsummer Night's Dream - to illustrate radical changes in theatrical style. In the book one is unnerved by a series of factual and verbal howlers. April 23 1916 was not "the tercentenary of Shakespeare's birth": he was born in 1564. Glen Byam Shaw did not briefly succeed Anthony Quayle at Stratford in 1957: the two men were codirectors from 1952 with Byam Shaw taking sole charge in '56. And what on earth does it mean to say that Olivier's Othello was "a triumph of the actor as tyro"? In my dictionary a "tyro" is a beginner or novice.

As a guide to the past, then, the book is erratic. It's good on Brecht and Beckett, the twin pillars of modern drama. But the need to gallop through the century leads to some odd omissions and emphases. There is scarcely a mention of Galsworthy, although Justice led to a change in the law on solitary confinement. John Whiting gets a brisk paragraph but there is no mention of Saint's Day, one of the seminal plays of the 1950s. John Arden gets equally short shrift, with no acknowledgment of The Workhouse Donkey, a great piece of Brechtian political theatre. And while due tribute is paid to that maverick genius Joan Littlewood, it seems perverse later to claim that the post-Novello British musical lacked "an indigenous identity": not true of the shows pouring out of Stratford East in the late 1950s and early 1960s.

Where Eyre and Wright score is in dealing with writers and directors close to their heart. There's a model section on David Hare dealing with the imp that is "the unofficial, unacceptable part of the writer's psyche": in Hare's case it is the emotional tyrant symbolised by Lambert le Roux in Pravda (cowritten with Brenton) or the overweening Tom in Skylight. Tom Stoppard and Alan Bennett, both of whom Eyre has directed, are also affectionately evoked: it is shrewd to see that the woman as truth-teller is a persistent Bennett motif, rising from the headscarved Mrs Swabb in Habeas Corpus to the prying Queen in A Question of Attribution .

The book certainly gives you a sense of the vitality of post-war British theatre. One particular chapter, "Last Orders on the Titanic", pungently captures the smell and feel of the 1970s: the feverish politics, the rush of alternative companies, the excitement of discovering vintage Brecht down a back alley in Whitechapel and the sense that theatre was contributing to the national debate. As we get nearer to the present, the climate darkens. And even though the authors pay tribute to the latest new wave, they get the plot of Sarah Kane's Blasted totally wrong - it's not about a father and daughter but a tabloid hack and his abused girlfriend - and view the movement from a metropolitan standpoint: no mention of important Scottish writers such as David Greig, Iain Heggie or Liz Lochhead.

So, it's a mixed bag: highly readable when the authors' passionate commitment comes through, but shaky as a panoramic guide to modern theatre. What one can say is that in an age of cultural relativism Eyre and Wright have an unfashionable faith in the medium. And even if their book is an overstuffed suitcase, it has provided the material for a first-rate series that proves television can cope with something more than cookery shows, quizzes and the exhausted dilemmas of cops and medics.

fields.headline: Bottom rung
fields.trailText: Systems information services analyst
fields.body:
Michael Boyle Aged 25. Systems information services analyst Fidelity Investments

Time spent temping at Fidelity showed Michael Boyle that there were opportunities in IT and IS for graduates in non-technical subjects. He temped to raise money for travel after his management studies degree at Glasgow University.

He returned to temp again and 18 months ago joined the graduate scheme. He describes it as "fluid, not structured" and started his work on the helpdesk. "That was an excellent place to start because it gave me a broad insight into what services we use."

Training: A key moment was when he got a chance to find out the costs associated with IS and come up with a mechanism to recharge that back to individual departments.

"It has mushromed into a variety of other things including a system to track all our assets in the business - desktops, computers, telephones and mainframes."

The buzz? "Using my own initiative to find solutions. It's rewarding when you put something forward and it's accepted."

Ambitions? Project management or liaising between IS and the business side.

Tip for entrants: "Don't think that you can't get into IT and systems if you haven't got a technical background."

 For more details visit the website www.fidelity.co.uk/graduate

fields.headline: Top rung
fields.trailText: Information services director
fields.body:
Andy Myatt Aged 45 Information services director Fidelity Investments

Andy Myatt says he stumbled into IT when he began his career 25 years ago. "I didn't really know what I wanted to do. I got interested in technology and it has developed from there."

CV to date: Worked in IT for publisher Reed Elsevier and joined Fidelity four and half years ago as senior manager in telecommunications services. "It was a real eye-opener for me moving from multi-media to an investment company. They are totally different in the way they operate."

Day-to-day role: He is now boss to 145 information systems staff across three sites: Tonbridge in Kent, London and Reigate. "We manage all the live applications and support all the infrastructure that distributes those applications out to the end users."

Likes most? "Working with graduates like Michael Boyle and bringing them on to learn about information systems (IS)."

Must-have qualities: Andy looks for graduate recruits who are willing to learn and be flexible. He advises hopefuls to be open-minded and to try to find an area that offers something back to the organisation.

"There is a growing requirement for IS to be increasingly business-aware, to have relationships with each business area and to be more strategic than we were."

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Wine
fields.standfirst: Aidan Bell, sales and purchasing director with wine merchant The Bin Club, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Aidan Bell, sales and purchasing director with wine merchant The Bin Club, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.body:
When you have spent the day tasting up to 150 wines you start to yearn for a beer with dinner. The Bin Club specialises in providing its members with wines that will benefit from maturation and it's my job to help choose the wines and oversee their sale. Although the company has built a reputation for supplying wine to the ex-pat community, today half our 2,500 members are based in the UK.

Our members spend anywhere between £50 and £1,000 a month, and we do everything for the customer short of paying for and actually drinking the wine.

The process starts with the tasting. We source a lot of our wines from Bordeaux and Burgundy and I try to visit these areas at least once a year. While we are primarily there to taste - we could sample close to 1,000 wines on one trip - I am also trying to pick up any gossip and unearth the small producers making something out of the ordinary. I like to offer our members wines they may not have heard of as well as those from the better known chateaux. The vast majority of wine we buy is red and almost everything is bought to be laid down.

Once back in the office I will write up a description of each wine and include an indication on when it will be ready for drinking.

Every two months we write up our selections and send out our recommendations for that season. The membership divides into those who are happy to let us decide what to buy and those who decide for themselves after seeing our offers.

Either way, we execute their wishes and in most cases store the wine in our cellars.

Because of the sheer number of clients there is a vast amount of administration to deal with. We have an internet site which allows members to examine their portfolio or choose a wine to be sent out for drinking.

That said, it's a very people-orientated business -and that's the part I enjoy. Last week I was in Hong Kong meeting clients and organising tastings. Tonight I am hosting an event at a firm of local solicitors.

Another significant part of my role is making sure the wines behave as predicted. Because it is a rather inexact science and things can change, periodically we'll open a bottle to examine how the wine is maturing.

Once you're really involved in the wine world it becomes all consuming. Unearthing what may be one of the great wines of the next decade is very exciting. For example, anyone who bought the 1998 vintage from Chateauneuf du Pape will be drinking a truly fantastic wine in 2005.

fields.headline: Is the trend your friend?
fields.standfirst: How we will work in 2001
fields.trailText: How we will work in 2001
fields.body:
We've said goodbye to bowler hats and the typing pool but will we still be commuting to work on microscooters in 12 months time? Will dress-down Fridays be replaced by dress-up Mondays? And will the internet finally deliver on its promise to let us work from home? Some of Rise 's favourite experts give us their predictions for 2001...

1. Work/life balance

You've probably already heard rumblings about "work/life balance" since the government decided that something must be done to combat the legendary long hours and high stress levels of the British workforce. Next year, therefore, you might find your employer introducing measures to stop you working too hard. They may, for example, impose an "exit time", when you have to down tools and go home or offer you more "time sovereignty", where your hours are more flexible or you can choose to work from home occasionally.

2. Gimmicks

With this in mind, we can expect to see more and more gimmicks in the workplace as employers try to lighten the atmosphere in the office, says Cary Cooper, professor of organisational psychology and health at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology. "Companies are going to try and do whatever they can to make work more fun and make young people want to come and work for them." Office jesters, lunchtime aromatherapy and even the return of the tea lady are just some of the things we could see in the office next year, he predicts.

3. Back to basics

Employers often complain that graduate recruits lack basic workplace skills, says Andrew Parkinson of the Association of British Chambers of Commerce. "They've got academic ability but we're often told that they can't do simple things like operate the photocopier or construct a business letter." The coming months, he says, will see the launch of new work experience partnerships between employers and academic institutions to ensure that graduates leave university equipped to cope with the "real world".

4. Women at the top

"The glass ceiling hasn't been shattered but it's definitely moving up quite a bit," says Cary Cooper. "We've become very results-driven in recent years and women have proved they can deliver. Women are also in demand because they're very good at helping other people to cope with change and today's workplace is constantly changing," he adds. Expect to see more women in "male" environments like the City and engineering.

5. E-learning

Using internet technology for staff training, where materials are distributed to employees over the company intranet, will continue to grow in popularity says Jennifer Schramm of the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development. "People can read it in their own time, sitting at their desk anywhere around the country," she explains. "I think in future we'll see people blending traditional teaching methods with e-learning." If you join a new company in the next few months, your induction course may also be delivered by computer rather than a member of the personnel department, she says.

6. Interim agencies

Short-term contracts, traditionally the preserve of the consultant and the older, more experienced employee, are increasingly being offered to more junior staff via "interim management agencies", says Professor Cooper. Even recent graduates can find work through these recruitment agencies, moving from company to company every few months working on a variety of projects. The employer gets youth, enthusiasm and the chance to test-run people with a view to offering them something more permanent. You, the employee, build up a wide range of skills and experience.

7. Bounty hunting

Internet bounty hunting as a way of recruiting staff is currently being tried out by some American firms. "The idea is that the best people for a job aren't always those who apply for it," Jennifer Schramm explains. "So instead of posting your own CV on to a web site, your peers recommend you. If you get the job, they get a reward." Although it's still early days, we may see similar schemes in the UK if bounty hunting proves successful.

8. Right qualifications

It's not what you know or even who you know that counts any more, it's where you studied that's becoming increasingly important when it comes to getting a job, Professor Cooper warns. So if you earned your stripes at an institution that's well-known and respected in your industry, expect employers to be tripping over themselves next year to sign you up. And if no-one's ever heard of your alma mater, think about taking a postgraduate qualification from a more prominent institution.

9. Simulations

Online workplace simulations, where employees play at being their MD making big decisions or gamble on the stock market with imaginary shares, may also take off in the next few months. For the employees, playing a computer game is a bit of light relief during the working day with the added incentive of a bonus if you win. For the bosses, looking at how and why the employees play the game is a way of assessing what staff really think about the company. As the game is played anonymously, people are more likely to reveal their true feelings.

10. Web working

If you really can't stick the rat race, 2001 could be the year you set up your own dot.com enterprise and make it work, says Andrew Parkinson. "After the successes and failures of the past couple of years, people are much more aware of the risks of setting up an internet firm," he comments. "I think we'll continue to see a lot of start-ups in the coming months but more long-term successes. Internet technology is really changing workplace culture."

webTitle: Conquer your fears and that call

fields.headline: Conquer your fears and that call
fields.standfirst: Better on err on the side of doing too much when following up
fields.trailText: Better on err on the side of doing too much when following up
fields.body:
Your CV is red hot. The letter of application is on the screen. Two clicks and an attachment later, your claim for that dream job is whizzing through cyberspace and into the grateful arms of your prospective employer. You sit and wait for the phone to ring... but nothing happens. What do you do?

If delicious tension is your thing, you are probably never happier than when awaiting the response - particularly if it's a job you really want.

But with more applications being sent via the internet, and all the vagaries that entails, wouldn't it be good to know your application has survived spam trawls and "I Love

You" bugs to arrive at the correct PC?

Welcome to the should-I-phone-them dilemma. Considering almost everyone has access to a phone, human resources departments report receiving surprisingly few calls chasing up an application.

The problem most applicants have is deciding what is a sensible length of time to wait before making that call. I can tell you from personal experience that there is no normal time - some companies react in hours, others will take a month to even think about calling prospective employees in for an interview.

And that's before we even broach the reason many people don't make the call - the fear of being rejected.

According to Marion Rutley, human resources manager at one of the UK's largest publishers, Reed Business Publishing, very few applicants for jobs actually call to see how an application is progressing.

"There's no point in calling the day after sending in an application, but it would be fine after a reasonable time - probably four to five days.

"In many ways it shows a certain amount of initiative and, if they have applied for certain jobs in sales or as a journalist, it would probably be beneficial to hear their voice if they're going to be spending a lot of time on the phone as part of their job."

Marion says that far from annoying her office, it will probably get your CV noticed. "If I hadn't had a chance to look at their CV before the call, I'm sure I would go and dig it out if the caller had sounded professional."

However, she does offer one word of warning: "There is nothing worse than getting a call from someone who can't remember who they sent their application to - that definitely gets them noticed, but in a slightly different way," she says.

So, maybe it's just those British stiff upper lips or a fear of appearing too pushy that prevents us from calling. "The whole process of applying for a job should be as pro-active as possible," says Simon Parker, marketing manager at internet-based recruitment firm Monster.co.uk.

"It's up to the individual to look at the application on a case-by-case basis to determine whether they should ring up the company. You have to remember that getting this job may be the most important thing in your life, but it probably isn't for the person looking at the CVs.

"If in any doubt, make the call - it's always better to err on the side of doing too much rather than sitting back and waiting for something to happen."

He points out that the call doesn't need to be a long one. "Establish that they have received it, ask if they need any further information and get off the phone."

However while phoning up makes sense if you have applied for a specific job, it probably won't help if you have applied to a large company's graduate programme. Boots the Chemist receives "literally thousands" of applications to its graduate recruitment programme.

"Around half are filled in and sent electronically and a email receipt of the application is automatically generated," says Boots marketing manager for recruitment Allan Kerr. "To be honest, we wouldn't want to encourage applicants to ring up in large numbers although we will always deal with those that do.

"Because of the sheer number of graduates involved it will not improve their chances of getting a job with us as the person they speak to will not be looking at their application at the time.

Allan also says very few job-hunters ring up - he puts the figure at around 5% - but he does admit that because the email systems in some universities are not compatible, some students are unable to receive confirmation of their application.

And the moral of the tale? Next time you're left waiting, forget the "I don't want to bother or upset them" mentality. It's time to make that call.
