But with more applications being sent via the internet, and all the vagaries that entails, wouldn't it be good to know your application has survived spam trawls and "I Love You" bugs to arrive at the correct PC? Welcome to the should-I-phone-them dilemma. Considering almost everyone has access to a phone, human resources departments report receiving surprisingly few calls chasing up an application. The problem most applicants have is deciding what is a sensible length of time to wait before making that call. I can tell you from personal experience that there is no normal time - some companies react in hours, others will take a month to even think about calling prospective employees in for an interview. And that's before we even broach the reason many people don't make the call - the fear of being rejected. According to Marion Rutley, human resources manager at one of the UK's largest publishers, Reed Business Publishing, very few applicants for jobs actually call to see how an application is progressing. "There's no point in calling the day after sending in an application, but it would be fine after a reasonable time - probably four to five days. "In many ways it shows a certain amount of initiative and, if they have applied for certain jobs in sales or as a journalist, it would probably be beneficial to hear their voice if they're going to be spending a lot of time on the phone as part of their job." Marion says that far from annoying her office, it will probably get your CV noticed. "If I hadn't had a chance to look at their CV before the call, I'm sure I would go and dig it out if the caller had sounded professional." However, she does offer one word of warning: "There is nothing worse than getting a call from someone who can't remember who they sent their application to - that definitely gets them noticed, but in a slightly different way," she says. So, maybe it's just those British stiff upper lips or a fear of appearing too pushy that prevents us from calling. "The whole process of applying for a job should be as pro-active as possible," says Simon Parker, marketing manager at internet-based recruitment firm Monster.co.uk. "It's up to the individual to look at the application on a case-by-case basis to determine whether they should ring up the company. You have to remember that getting this job may be the most important thing in your life, but it probably isn't for the person looking at the CVs. "If in any doubt, make the call - it's always better to err on the side of doing too much rather than sitting back and waiting for something to happen." He points out that the call doesn't need to be a long one. "Establish that they have received it, ask if they need any further information and get off the phone." However while phoning up makes sense if you have applied for a specific job, it probably won't help if you have applied to a large company's graduate programme. Boots the Chemist receives "literally thousands" of applications to its graduate recruitment programme. "Around half are filled in and sent electronically and a email receipt of the application is automatically generated," says Boots marketing manager for recruitment Allan Kerr. "To be honest, we wouldn't want to encourage applicants to ring up in large numbers although we will always deal with those that do. "Because of the sheer number of graduates involved it will not improve their chances of getting a job with us as the person they speak to will not be looking at their application at the time. Allan also says very few job-hunters ring up - he puts the figure at around 5% - but he does admit that because the email systems in some universities are not compatible, some students are unable to receive confirmation of their application. And the moral of the tale? Next time you're left waiting, forget the "I don't want to bother or upset them" mentality. It's time to make that call.

webTitle: Pride and passion rewarded as Portman Road dreams of Europe

fields.headline: Pride and passion rewarded as Portman Road dreams of Europe
fields.standfirst: George Burley tells  Jon Brodkin why his Ipswich are the big surprise of the season
fields.trailText: George Burley tells Jon Brodkin why his Ipswich are the big surprise of the season.
fields.body:
George Burley is enjoying life, peering down at Chelsea, Leeds and Liverpool from third in the table. A smile flickers across the Ipswich manager's face. "It's amazing," he says, "at the moment we've got 27 points. We finished with that in our last season in the Premiership."

The Scot hardly needs reminding that many expected this visit to be the same. What hope was there for a provincial club packed with local lads and cast-offs whose transfer budget was the size of Manchester United's weekly wage bill and whose biggest foreign star was Hermann Hreidarsson? What hope indeed.

Fifteen games on, Leeds have been beaten and Manchester United and Arsenal held. Ipswich show no sign of bowing to the natural order. Having finally cast off the shackles of the First Division they have kept on running and no one is quite sure where they will stop. In Europe perhaps. That, at least, is the three-year plan.

"The chairman [David Sheepshanks] says if you don't dream about it you can't do it," explains Burley, named yesterday as November's manager of the month. "I don't know whether it's realistic but you set goals and try to get to them. I was at Ipswich when we played in Europe nine years out of 10 [in 1973-83]. It's much more difficult for clubs with our finances to qualify for Europe than it was 20 years ago but that's our aim."

Portman Road buzzes with ambition. A new stand is rising at one end; posters with messages such as "Make it happen" and "Believe and succeed" adorn the corridors, between montages of the great days of old - days when Ipswich were champions, when Burley was a full-back, when Bobby Robson had dark hair. Outside of the players' lounge is a reminder: "You'll always miss 100% of the shots you don't take."

Yet there is more than the power of positive thinking behind this flourish. Third place will be hard to maintain but the signs are that the success is built on more than a few good results. In the six years since Burley took over a side tumbling out of the top flight he has imbued not just his passion and passing principles but a fierce work ethic. The hunger is evident in more than the wolfing of sausages and beans at the training ground.

"Training finishes at, say, 12 o'clock and at quarter to one people are still kicking a ball around or practising free-kicks," says the captain Matt Holland, who will miss his first game since joining from Bournemouth if an ankle injury prevents him playing at home to Derby today. "There's a big desire in the squad. A lot of us come from lower leagues and it's given us an incentive to do well at this level."

Apart from the reserve goalkeeper Keith Branagan only four players - Hreidarsson, Jim Magilton, John Scales and Gary Croft - have real Premiership experience. Yet Ipswich have performed fearlessly. Just as Burley was hurled in at the deep end as a player, marking George Best at Old Trafford on his Ipswich debut, so a draw at home to Manchester United in the season's second match bred self-belief.

"I think the catalyst for our season was the United game after losing [3-1] to Tottenham," says Magilton, whose passing does much to make Ipswich tick. "We played very well at Tottenham for an hour and I was frightened it might have been the same old scenario: newly promoted team does well for an hour and then the stronger side overpowers them.

"That was playing on my mind. But that game against United dispelled all my fears. We took the game to them. Admittedly they played on the Sunday and then had to play on Tuesday, but it was great for our lads to see they could match David Beckham, Roy Keane, Ryan Giggs and so on."

John McGreal, signed from Tranmere for £650,000, and Mark Venus, a £150,000 buy from Wolves, are excelling at centre-back. Jamie Clapham, cast off by Tottenham after one league appearance, is being talked of as a solution to England's left-side problem. Marcus Stewart has enjoyed his first taste of the Premiership, scoring nine goals.

"If you look at Raul, he's a similar type of player," Burley says of Stewart. "Raul's not the quickest but because of his football brain and his movement and his eye for goals he's very difficult to mark."

The success is a tribute to Burley's ability to spot and improve talent, supplemented by a youth policy which has provided four first-team regulars, including Titus Bramble. The spirit is such that Burley plays golf with his players and three of the strikers - Stewart, David Johnson and James Scowcroft - holidayed together in France.

With a full-time fitness coach this season any excesses will have been worked off fast. The players have individual programmes with strength, speed and agility closely monitored. Burley said he wanted an extra 10% from his players and feels he has got that and more. They are fitter and stronger, he says, working better as individuals and as a team.

In a sense though, life outside the Nationwide is easier. "In the First Division there was a lot of respect for us and teams set their plan to stop us playing, whereas in the Premiership teams want to play their own game and allow us to do the same," Burley says. "That certainly has suited us more."

During a high-tempo practice session the ball rarely leaves the ground. The players have been swimming and cycling to break the routine but much of Burley's work focuses on team pattern and basics, and since Hreidarsson's arrival he feels confident in switching from 4-4-2 to 3-5-2 at the drop of a hat. "We're very repetitive in our training with the passing," Magilton says, "and that's probably bred the success."

On reflection, the play-off failures may have helped as much as they hurt. Each year Burley has felt the club get stronger, the habits more natural. He has built a squad which remains broadly settled, and it shows.

As he prepares for a Derby boasting his midfielder nephew Craig, the 44-year-old accepts it will be hard to keep this performance level going. "Just staying [up] would be a fantastic achievement," he says. Tell that to the fans checking flights to Barcelona and Milan.

 How Burley's defensive partners have struggled as managers

Terry Butcher

Two undistinguished seasons at Coventry at the start of the 90s were followed by a wretched year at Sunderland. Appointed in February 1993, Butcher saw his team avoid relegation to the Second Division by a single point. Despite buying five players for a total of almost £3m in the summer, the following season was little better. It began with a 5-0 hammering at Derby and after six successive defeats, culminating in a 2-0 home defeat by Southend, Butcher was sacked on November 26. Has since worked as a coach in Scotland and in the media.

Russell Osman

Got off to an uneasy start at Bristol City in 1993, being confirmed as manager on the same day Andy Cole was sold to Newcastle. Abruptly sacked in November 1994 after a bad run, only nine months after signing a new contract and discussing "a five-year plan to take Bristol City into the Premiership" with the board. City went down under his successor, Joe Jordan. Applied for the Norwich job jointly with Butcher in 1995, before joining Cardiff in November 1996. Took them into the Third Division play-offs in his first season but was sacked in January 1998, with City floundering.

Mick Mills

Stabilised Stoke City after record-breaking First Division relegation season in 1985 (three wins, 17 points). Four mid-table seasons followed, but Mills was sacked in November 1989 after only one win in the first 16 games of the season. (Stoke duly went down under his replacement, Alan Ball.) Mills took over at Colchester a month later, but could not prevent relegation to the Conference. Subsequently worked with Butcher at Coventry and is now coach at Birmingham City.

fields.headline: Strange case of Sol's silence
fields.standfirst: Roy Collins watches Sol Campbell play the waiting game like a master
fields.trailText: "Campbell seems on course to do a Bosnich and a Bosman simultaneously." Roy Collins on Sol's waiting game.
fields.body:
The England defender Sol Campbell, having recovered from injury to reclaim his place in the Tottenham team, has seemingly taken a vow of omerta regarding the possibility, however remote, of him renewing a contract that expires at the end of this season.

Those closest to him glibly insist his silence should not be interpreted as an admission of guilt, as it now can be by jurors in a court of law, that he is set to move to pastures new.

But similar protestations of keeping an open mind were made by the goalkeeper Mark Bosnich at Aston Villa when everyone assumed, rightly as it turned out, that he would join Manchester United when his contract expired in 1999.

Now Campbell seems on course to do a Bosnich and a Bosman simultaneously, while still trying to project a public image as a victim of Spurs' supposed lack of ambition.

But it seems unlikely that Campbell, opposing United today, has as certain a home at Old Trafford as Bosnich, let alone a pre-nuptial agreement.

Sir Alex Ferguson reportedly offered £17m for Campbell a year ago, but had apparently cooled on any deal because of doubts over the transfer system and the potential the younger Wes Brown has shown in central defence.

Neither Campbell nor his agent, Sky Andrew, will whisper a word, no doubt hoping the supporters' antipathy to the Spurs chairman Alan Sugar will leave them on the moral high ground even on the day he walks out. Both club and fans have resigned themselves to his exit.

According to George Graham, Campbell decided last season that he was going to see his contract through to the final hour of the final day. The manager says: "Sol will not talk to me about it and does not want to listen to an improved offer, even though I believe we could match any club in this country. And even if United came in with an enormous offer tomorrow, he wouldn't go."

Spurs fans will find this hard to believe, especially after seeing West Ham's apparently not-for-sale defender Rio Ferdinand sold to Leeds for £18m.

As Campbell has more than three times Ferdinand's number of caps, would he not have been worth £20m-plus? And have Spurs not poured that possible windfall away by refusing to seek a buyer? Despite Graham's insistence that Campbell will not listen to wooing noises from other clubs at present, it seems Sugar was also reluctant to cash in at the start of the season because of fears of fans' reaction.

Whoever is to blame in this mucky saga, if Campbell departs at the end of the season, as seems certain, Sugar is bound to come under increased pressure from Spurs fans. Meanwhile, the player himself keeps an undignified silence.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: England secure Eriksson for World Cup qualifiers

fields.headline: England secure Eriksson for World Cup qualifiers
fields.standfirst: Lazio president comes round to idea of allowing his coach to work with England for the World Cup qualifiers next spring
fields.trailText: Lazio president comes round to idea of allowing his coach to work with England for the World Cup qualifiers next spring.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson will be in control of England for the critical World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania in March, even if the Swede is still contracted to Lazio then.

The Italian champions' president Sergio Cragnotti had earlier set his face against England's coach-elect Eriksson being freed from club duties before his Lazio contract expires next summer. But Cragnotti's stance has clearly softened after lengthy negotations which the Football Association called "very productive".

Eriksson is now bound to have greater input into England's friendly with Spain on February 28, since that Villa Park game is an immediate forerunner to the back-to-back ties with Finland at Anfield and Albania in Tirana a month after.

Indeed there is still a chance of Eriksson being released by Lazio for the Spain game, for which Peter Taylor has just been reappointed as caretaker manager with "full control of team selection."

Even if the Spain game is ruled out of bounds for Eriksson, the FA may now have to reduce Taylor's role given the Swede's inevitable desire to use the friendly to shape personnel and tactics for the qualifiers.

Meanwhile in Rome as Eriksson's faltering team prepared for this afternoon's home game with Reggina and Tuesday's Champions League tie with Leeds, Lazio's Czech Republic midfielder Pavel Nedved rose to the coach's defence, rejecting suggestions that the coach was responsible for the team's slump.

Nedved denied widespread claims that Eriksson had become distracted by the England job. "He's always shown 100% commitment and I'm sure he'll continue to do so until the end of his contract."

webTitle: Boro pull out of Venables deal

fields.headline: Boro pull out of Venables deal
fields.standfirst: Middlesbrough go back to the drawing board as Tel sticks with the day job
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough go back to the drawing board as Tel sticks with the day job.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough yesterday admitted defeat in their attempts to lure Terry Venables to the Riverside, leaving Bryan Robson in charge until the end of the season and the Teesside club back at square one.

After 10 days waiting for an answer, Boro yesterday broke off negotiations over a £1m-a-year deal. The club refused to let Venables combine a return to top-flight management with his role as ITV's chief pundit. As a consolation, he is set to sign a lucrative new contract with the television network.

"We have concluded that Terry's present and future television commitments are incompatible with the role we were offering him here at Middlesbrough," said the Boro chief executive Keith Lamb.

"We have now brought our discussions to a close. We wish him well in his role as a television football pundit and can assure our supporters that everyone at Middlesbrough will continue to focus on the Premier League challenge ahead."

This afternoon Robson - effectively restored to a post he was prepared to relinquish - will attempt to rally his struggling side at West Ham. With the Venables negotiations providing an unsettling backdrop, the Boro manager has spent the week trying to lift a squad drained of confidence.

"The lads have been fine this week. It really doesn't matter to them who the manager is and I'm still confident we can turn the corner," he said.

Boro have secured one point in their past seven games, a slump which prompted Robson and his chairman Steve Gibson to approach Venables. Perhaps aware of the former England coach's likely decision, the Boro manager was quick to reaffirm his commitment to the club yesterday. "If Terry Venables says no, I will be manager of this football club until the end of the season," he said.

"It doesn't matter to me in which role I am best perceived - coach or manager - as long as it is successful for this club. I'm not more determined to get things right; I'm as determined.

"We have come a long a way since I arrived here and the chairman deserves success. The fans should appreciate that they have probably got the best chairman in the country. We both want this club to keep going in the right direction."

Robson always intended to review his own position at the end of the season. In the meantime, Gibson may turn his attention to finding a coach to work under his close friend, with Graham Rix as one possible candidate.

"The news is disappointing," said the Boro supporters' club chairman David Buckton. "We were looking for a solid, loyal commitment with Terry here seven days a week. If there was going to be any conflict then the club are probably quite right to dismiss it on those grounds.

"This leaves us with a major problem, but at least the club has accepted that this problem exists."

Boro have secured one point in their past seven games, a slump which prompted Robson and his chairman Steve Gibson to approach Venables. Perhaps aware of the former England coach's likely decision, the Boro manager was quick to reaffirm his commitment to the club yesterday. "If Terry Venables says no, I will be manager of this football club until the end of the season," he said. "It doesn't matter to me in which role I am best perceived - coach or manager - as long as it is successful for this club. I'm not more determined to get things right; I'm as determined. "We have come a long a way since I arrived here and the chairman deserves success. The fans should appreciate that they have probably got the best chairman in the country. We both want this club to keep going in the right direction." Robson always intended to review his own position at the end of the season. In the meantime, Gibson may turn his attention to finding a coach to work under his close friend, with Graham Rix as one possible candidate. "The news is disappointing," said the Boro supporters' club chairman David Buckton. "We were looking for a solid, loyal commitment with Terry here seven days a week. If there was going to be any conflict then the club are probably quite right to dismiss it on those grounds. "This leaves us with a major problem, but at least the club has accepted that this problem exists."  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: City fall for new Mr Wright

fields.headline: City fall for new Mr Wright
fields.standfirst: Shaun Wright-Phillips is making a name for himself at Maine Road, writes  Daniel Taylor
fields.trailText: Shaun Wright-Phillips is making a name for himself at Maine Road, writes Daniel Taylor.
fields.body:
Shaun Wright-Phillips last season dropped the "Wright" from the double-barrelled surname on his Manchester City jersey in an attempt to stave off unfavourable comparisons with a player who, after all, was something of a one-off.

For the City forward comparisions have always been unhelpful but this year Ian Wright's adopted son has gone back to life with a hyphen and is rapidly establishing himself in his own right. His close control, acceleration and eye for the spectacular have done much to dissuade City's supporters from open mutiny in recent weeks and in a season of increased foreboding at Maine Road the 19-year-old is flourishing while others wilt.

He has been Joe Royle's man-of-the-match in their last three Premiership games and now there is talk of an England Under-21 call-up. Not bad for someone whose build has seen him likened to an extra from Grange Hill.

"My dad was a great player and hopefully now I can achieve some success myself. But I would much rather just be known as me, not the next Ian Wright," he says.

"I don't think the comparisons are really fair because people shouldn't expect me to enjoy the same level of success. Everyone will always remember him and all the goals he has scored, while I am just starting my career.

"I watched a lot of videos of my dad when I was younger and early on he taught me a lot about the game. But as I've got older I've sort of made it up as I've gone along or learned from other people. He's always there if I need some advice or support and he just tells me to work hard and concentrate on my game."

The pair have regarded each other as father and son since Wright moved in with the youngster's mother, Sharon, a year after leaving school. She was bringing up her first son alone and Wright, then 17 and about to unleash his talents on the London and Kent Border League, willingly volunteered to take on parental duties. The couple had another boy, Bradley, but their relationship foundered and Wright moved out shortly afterwards.

Although they were together for a relatively short space of time, father and son have always been close. Wright watched the teenager make his first Premiership start in the Manchester derby two weeks ago and was also at Maine Road for last week's defeat by Ipswich.

"Shaun will always carry the burden of having me as his dad," he has said. "I think he's found it [the media attention] hard to handle already but he will realise he has to overcome bigger hurdles than that if he wants to be a top professional. I'm very proud of him."

On the pitch Wright-Phillips maybe lacks the presence and explosive finishing of his father. There are no gold teeth, no plans for a television show or a pop record. Nor the feeling that he might react to a last-minute defeat by trashing the referee's room or raking his studs down the centre-half's thigh. Those who remember Different Strokes on television will understand why some City fans have taken to calling him Arnold. He is as unassuming and shy as Wright is combustible and extrovert.

Yet for all the differences, there are just as many similarities. Wright-Phillips is another bundle of energy, another effervescent front player with a deep-rooted affection for the game and an in-built hatred of losing. "People have told me how well I'm playing but I can't be satisfied when we're not winning," he says. "Losing is the worst feeling for any footballer." Wright-Phillips travels with the City squad to Chelsea tomorrow despite suffering with a stomach bug as Royle's side looks to end their five-game Premiership losing streak.

Like his father, it all started with Ten-em-Bee FC in Bermondsey. His team-mates on the Old Bromley Road nicknamed him Rubber Man because of his dribbling skills and he attracted scouts from several London clubs before, on his father's advice, he left the capital and its various distractions and joined Nottingham Forest's youth academy, but after two years there he was told he was released.

From youth-academy games on the playing fields at Whalley Range grammar school in Manchester to a starring role in the Premiership, it has been a meteoric rise, prospering either in attack or wide on the right. Forest's loss has been City's gain. "Yeah he's tiny, but there's a big heart inside that little body," Royle points out. "He's done a lot to keep the crowd off our backs."

The City manager remembers the first time Wright-Phillips trained with the first-team. "There were a few people thinking: 'Who's this?' but he ran his heart out, bless him. He couldn't train for the next four days because of blisters. It's typical of his attitude. He was absolutely exhausted by the end but that was his statement to the lads: 'Here I am'."

And here he intends to stay. "If you want it badly enough, you can play football whatever size you are," he says. "Now I've had a taste of the Premiership I just want it more and more. I've worked really hard and things have been going well but I can do better, I know that."

Wright has another two sons, Brett and Stacy, and the future looks bright for this football clan. Indeed, there might even be a day when Moss Side boasts two brothers to rival the Nevilles of Old Trafford. While Brett is on Ten-em-Bee's books, Bradley is signed up to City and the club are quietly confident he will follow in big brother's footsteps. Now that would make the old man proud.

 Nine other current British Premiership players have footballing fathers: Frank Lampard Jr (West Ham), Jamie Redknapp (Liverpool), Gavin Strachan (Coventry), Stephen Clemence (Spurs), Ian Walker (Spurs), Andy Todd (Charlton), Scott Gemmill (Everton), Nicky Summerbee (Sunderland), Michael Owen (Liverpool).

webTitle: Crisis, what crisis? Bates bites back

fields.headline: Crisis, what crisis? Bates bites back
fields.standfirst:
Four coaches have departed this week, Chelsea Village is losing money and the Blues lie 14th in the table. But the chairman is not for turning
Wembley rebuild in doubt
fields.trailText: Four coaches have departed this week, Chelsea Village is losing money and the Blues lie 14th in the table. But the chairman is not for turning.
fields.body:
Claudio Ranieri may still be having trouble getting through to his players without an interpreter, but Chelsea's communications problems do not end with the linguistic ability of their Roman manager. The performance of Ken Bates, his chairman, at the club's annual general meeting yesterday indicated that the difficulty starts at the top.

Replying to shareholders' questions about the declaration of a £3.5m trading loss, the sinking share price, the increase in payments to directors, the confusing transfer dealings, the sacking of Gianluca Vialli and the team's recent plunge to 14th place in the Premiership, Bates appeared to have difficulty making himself heard through the amplification system of a club which, he boasted, had recently spent £350,000 installing a state-of-the-art television studio.

Several times when he was asked to speak up, Bates bashed the tip of the microphone with his palm, as if that might help. Only the sneering dismissals of unwelcome views, the frequent claims of media distortion and the occasional threats to those whose challenges grew too strident ("I'll discuss it with you outside, otherwise my learned friend here will take issue with you") were enunciated with perfect clarity. Strangely, other directors sitting alongside him in the Ted Drake room at Stamford Bridge had little difficulty making themselves understood.

Despite further questions about the poor performance of Chelsea Village's two hotels (65% occupancy this year) and travel agency (a £500,000 loss), Bates was his usual brusque and bullish self, apparently unworried by the storm clouds gathering over the other project of which he is chairman, the new national stadium at Wembley. Asked about the story in the Guaardian yesterday morning which suggested that the project is having difficulty raising the necessary backing, he said: "I don't read the Guardian."

Most of the 200 Chelsea shareholders present were more interested in when their team would win the championship than in when they would finally see a dividend on their holdings. But the brute realities of contemporary football were exposed when Bates said, in an aside: "We see supporting Chelsea on match days and owning shares in the company as two different activities."

Meanwhile, over at the club's training ground near Heathrow airport, Ranieri was taking a break from preparing his troubled squad for tomorrow's home match against Manchester City to explain his side of another turbulent week at Chelsea, which had seen the dismissal of the remains of Gianluca Vialli's senior coaching staff - Ray Wilkins, Graham Rix, the goalkeeping coach Eddie Niedzwiecki and fitness trainer Antonio Pintus - as the new manager consolidated his own men in their positions.

It was a case, he said, of reducing the staff to manageable proportions. "They had nothing to do," Ranieri said of Rix and Wilkins, speaking through a translator. "I put myself in their situation, looked at it from their point of view, and decided that it must be immensely frustrating for them to turn up here every day without anything to do."

Ranieri accepted full responsibility for the recent run of poor results - the team have lost six of the 10 games played since his arrival - and said that he understood the fans' disappointment. "I'm very disappointed myself with the way things are going at the moment," he said, "but I have a contract for three years, and I'm determined to win the championship. If I haven't won it at the end of three years, I will have failed."

The priority, he added, was to build for the future. "At the moment it's more important to build than to get immediate results and trophies."

This is a sudden and remarkable change of emphasis for a club that has spent the last five years attempting to strongarm its way into the very top echelon of European football, by attracting the most famous players through offering them the highest salaries. The unhappy recent sojourns at Stamford Bridge of Didier Deschamps and George Weah, both of whom earned more than a thousand pounds a week for each of their 30-plus years, appear to have prompted a reassessment of the club's personnel strategy.

Back at the agm, Bates was being questioned about the apparent imbalance between foreign and domestic players at a club which twice in the last year has started games without a single British footballer in the side, and about its possible relevance to the lack of urgency shown by the team in recent defeats at unglamorous places like Sunderland, Southampton and Charlton.

"Look at Kevin Keegan," he said in answer to the suggestion that English players would provide greater commitment to the cause. "That's where blood and guts gets you. Nowhere. England have won nothing since 1966."

Nevertheless, he said, the acquisition of English players was now a priority. "There is a consensus on the board about this. We'd much rather have English players, or even foreigners from Scotland, Ireland or Wales. The problem is getting them. Nobody will sell to the opposition. At one time I bought Partick Thistle to use as a nursery club for Chelsea. But the moment Rangers under [Graham] Souness began buying success, the Scottish game became a wilderness."

Colin Hutchinson, the club's managing director, described their vain efforts during the summer to sign Nick Barmby, Andy Cole, Robbie Fowler and Gareth Southgate. Instead they have bought Slavisa Jokanovic, a Yugoslav, from Deportivo Coruna for £1.7m, and Jesper Gronkjaer, a Dane, from Ajax for £8m. Both are currently out injured - and Gronkjaer, in any case, will not be joining Chelsea until January.

Some supporters were clearly confused, thinking back to the vaulting ambitions expressed at the beginning of this season. "One down, four to go," Bates had said when they beat Manchester United in the Charity Shield on August 13, apparently looking forward to a clean sweep of the Uefa Cup, the FA Cup, the Premiership and the Worthington Cup. Now the defence of the FA Cup is their only realistic target.

"When we took the gamble in 1995 of paying £2m to bring Ruud Gullit to the club," Hutchinson said, "that was a big step on the path to building a team good enough to allow us to join the elite. We brought in a lot of world-renowned players to help us bring about that transition. But it can't go on indefinitely. We've got to have firmer foundations, and a mixture between those top-of-the-range stars and the next generation."

The policy of promoting new managers from within is another casualty of the new direction. "When the season started, there were a lot of difficult situations blowing up within the team," Hutchinson said, in answer to a question about whether the board had misjudged the fans' mood when they sacked Vialli. "One of the key factors in appointing Ranieri is man-management. We knew he'd kicked out Romario [from Valencia]. We've got some big players, and big players have big egos. We had to get someone who was ready to take on that kind of situation."

Big chairmen have big egos, too, although even in the present trying circumstances Bates has not entirely lost his sense of humour. During the 75 minutes devoted to questions, just two shareholders offered words of support and encouragement.

"We've had bad seasons before," one of them said. "Let's not panic. Let's buckle down and get through this crisis . . ."

"Please don't use that word," Bates yelled, for once totally intelligible.

webTitle: Shack attack was no laughing matter

fields.headline: Shack attack was no laughing matter
fields.standfirst: Memories of Len Shackleton's wit, footballing or comic, are another reminder of how far down the road the English game has come
fields.trailText: Memories of Len Shackleton's wit, footballing or comic, are another reminder of how far down the road the English game has come.
fields.body:
Len Shackleton was no clown. He was a serious footballer with a wicked sense of humour, which is not quite the same thing.

All right, his autobiography was entitled Clown Prince of Soccer, and even at a distance of 45 years the page left blank to reflect Shack's opinion of the average director's knowledge of football is good for a chuckle.

Yet the book contains relatively little humour and is more about the wrongs in the game, as Shackleton saw them, during the 50s. Directors, coaches and England selectors, they all caught the rough edge of Len's pen while managers were pitied as hapless victims of boardroom ignorance. Surprisingly, perhaps, referees got off lightly.

Shackleton stopped playing in 1957 so only those in their mid-50s or over can have a clear image of what he was about. Nevertheless, most of the obituaries which have followed his death this week have rightly emphasised the player's willingness to employ his considerable ball-playing skills in the cause of entertainment.

Not for the first time the modern spectator has been left with the impression that the game was much more fun then than it is now. Take almost any point in football history and there will always be voices decrying the lack of personalities compared with the old days, and Shackleton was certainly an individualist both on and off the field.

Presumably any modern player attempting to fritter away a few seconds at the end of a match by dribbling the ball along a touchline would be bawled out by his bench, but Sunderland were probably not too pleased with Shackleton when he indulged himself in similar fashion.

The fans, however, will always take to a maverick and even the allegedly home-leaning referee of a Sunderland away game, addressed throughout by Shackleton as "Mr Khayyam", roared with laughter when Len reminded him of the poet's forename - Omar. Maybe an Elleray or a Poll would also see the joke now, but one would not bank on it.

There is still plenty of fun in football but, given the frenzied nature of much of the modern game in England, it tends either to be fleeting and easily missed or misconstrued.

Woe betide a forward who, having beaten the defence and walked the ball round the goalkeeper, then paused to tease the embarrassed custodian, Shackleton-fashion, with a shout of "It's not over the line yet!". The player would probably be booked for unsporting behaviour with the police complaining about crowd-incitement.

Now, apart from the usual belly-laughs when a referee falls over, the humour has to be less contrived. There is little time for gags. Blessed are those like Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu who, with huge feet and ambling gait, can make a crowd roar with excitement and laughter in the same instant.

Given the virtual abolition of tackles from behind and the swift punishments meted out to those who insist on taking the man rather than the ball, a latterday Shackleton might be expected to thrive.

After all, he can now turn with less risk of exposing his ankles and achilles tendons to the sort of challenges once common in English football.

The problem is that the game has become so much more athletic that, even for natural creators like Zinedine Zidane or Dennis Bergkamp, anything more than a couple of touches are a luxury, while holding the ball for a second or two risks a movement losing momentum and the attacking side being caught on the break.

In Shackleton's day, when England teams were selected by a committee of FA councillors, there was a reluctance to employ his brand of football artistry, which of its nature was self-centred.

In the last of his five England appearances, against West Germany, who had just won the 1954 World Cup, Shack dribbled through the opposing defence only to overrun the ball.

The fact that Shackleton also scored in England's 3-1 victory did not persuade the selectors to extend his international comeback. With Dennis Wilshaw of Wolves in form and the young Johnny Haynes in the wings they were not short of options, and previously it had been Shackleton's misfortune to be around at a similar time to Wilf Mannion.

In England, idiosyncratic footballers have seldom been popular with those who pick teams; witness the ins and outs of David Ginola in the Premiership and Matthew le Tissier's hot-and-cold career at Southampton. Eric Cantona, of course, was a glorious exception, but only after he had joined Manchester United.

The young Paul Gascoigne's problem was that he saw himself as a comedian when he was less of a natural humorist than, say, Celtic's Charlie Tully. Players like Kanu or West Ham's Paolo di Canio amuse because they bemuse and would not consider themselves clowns any more than Shackleton really did.

When the journalist John Macadam congratulated Alex James, the inspiration of Arsenal in the 30s, on the way he had outwitted an opponent by saying "That was funny" the little Scot bridled. "I'm a fitba' player," he snapped, "no' a comedian."

Football needs the occasional comic and Rodney Marsh was one of the best. But when the hilarity dies down, the game is about results and these were never a laughing matter.
fields.bodyText: Len Shackleton was no clown. He was a serious footballer with a wicked sense of humour, which is not quite the same thing. All right, his autobiography was entitled Clown Prince of Soccer, and even at a distance of 45 years the page left blank to reflect Shack's opinion of the average director's knowledge of football is good for a chuckle. Yet the book contains relatively little humour and is more about the wrongs in the game, as Shackleton saw them, during the 50s. Directors, coaches and England selectors, they all caught the rough edge of Len's pen while managers were pitied as hapless victims of boardroom ignorance. Surprisingly, perhaps, referees got off lightly. Shackleton stopped playing in 1957 so only those in their mid-50s or over can have a clear image of what he was about. Nevertheless, most of the obituaries which have followed his death this week have rightly emphasised the player's willingness to employ his considerable ball-playing skills in the cause of entertainment. Not for the first time the modern spectator has been left with the impression that the game was much more fun then than it is now. Take almost any point in football history and there will always be voices decrying the lack of personalities compared with the old days, and Shackleton was certainly an individualist both on and off the field. Presumably any modern player attempting to fritter away a few seconds at the end of a match by dribbling the ball along a touchline would be bawled out by his bench, but Sunderland were probably not too pleased with Shackleton when he indulged himself in similar fashion. The fans, however, will always take to a maverick and even the allegedly home-leaning referee of a Sunderland away game, addressed throughout by Shackleton as "Mr Khayyam", roared with laughter when Len reminded him of the poet's forename - Omar. Maybe an Elleray or a Poll would also see the joke now, but one would not bank on it. There is still plenty of fun in football but, given the frenzied nature of much of the modern game in England, it tends either to be fleeting and easily missed or misconstrued. Woe betide a forward who, having beaten the defence and walked the ball round the goalkeeper, then paused to tease the embarrassed custodian, Shackleton-fashion, with a shout of "It's not over the line yet!". The player would probably be booked for unsporting behaviour with the police complaining about crowd-incitement. Now, apart from the usual belly-laughs when a referee falls over, the humour has to be less contrived. There is little time for gags. Blessed are those like Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu who, with huge feet and ambling gait, can make a crowd roar with excitement and laughter in the same instant. Given the virtual abolition of tackles from behind and the swift punishments meted out to those who insist on taking the man rather than the ball, a latterday Shackleton might be expected to thrive. After all, he can now turn with less risk of exposing his ankles and achilles tendons to the sort of challenges once common in English football. The problem is that the game has become so much more athletic that, even for natural creators like Zinedine Zidane or Dennis Bergkamp, anything more than a couple of touches are a luxury, while holding the ball for a second or two risks a movement losing momentum and the attacking side being caught on the break. In Shackleton's day, when England teams were selected by a committee of FA councillors, there was a reluctance to employ his brand of football artistry, which of its nature was self-centred. In the last of his five England appearances, against West Germany, who had just won the 1954 World Cup, Shack dribbled through the opposing defence only to overrun the ball. The fact that Shackleton also scored in England's 3-1 victory did not persuade the selectors to extend his international comeback. With Dennis Wilshaw of Wolves in form and the young Johnny Haynes in the wings they were not short of options, and previously it had been Shackleton's misfortune to be around at a similar time to Wilf Mannion. In England, idiosyncratic footballers have seldom been popular with those who pick teams; witness the ins and outs of David Ginola in the Premiership and Matthew le Tissier's hot-and-cold career at Southampton. Eric Cantona, of course, was a glorious exception, but only after he had joined Manchester United. The young Paul Gascoigne's problem was that he saw himself as a comedian when he was less of a natural humorist than, say, Celtic's Charlie Tully. Players like Kanu or West Ham's Paolo di Canio amuse because they bemuse and would not consider themselves clowns any more than Shackleton really did. When the journalist John Macadam congratulated Alex James, the inspiration of Arsenal in the 30s, on the way he had outwitted an opponent by saying "That was funny" the little Scot bridled. "I'm a fitba' player," he snapped, "no' a comedian." Football needs the occasional comic and Rodney Marsh was one of the best. But when the hilarity dies down, the game is about results and these were never a laughing matter.

fields.headline: Rocking cheers for Grandaddy
fields.standfirst:
Grandaddy
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
****
fields.trailText:
Grandaddy
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
****
fields.body:
Grandaddy have released three albums and tour regularly, but even so it feels as if they are still finding their feet on stage. When they played at London's Dingwalls earlier this year, frontman Jason Lytle and guitarist Jim Fairchild regularly broke into fits of embarrassed laughter at the whoops and dancing greeting their songs. People in the front few rows happily returned the grins, but those further back found it hard to connect with this uncommunicative band. At the packed-to-capacity Empire, a lovely old theatre with three balconies, the audience is both significantly bigger and more distant. Lytle is correspondingly more nervous and slightly more willing to engage in inane chat. "This is a biiiiiig place," he giggles, "the biggest place we've played...tonight."

They want to entertain: a troupe of people dressed as bears intermittently invade the stage; there's a charming film backdrop, scenes of fields across which cartoon ducks fly and strange mechanical bunnies leap; the gaps between songs are filled with the sort of chamber music you might hear in a tea room. But you can tell that Lytle is happiest when coaxing the squirling sound of a shower of shooting stars from his keyboards, stamping his feet to the rhythm, nodding violently as guitar chords spark off like fireworks towards the Empire's ornate ceiling.

With this year's album, The Sophtware Slump, Grandaddy have created drift-off music of the highest order, songs that carry you gently through a bright blue sky into the unfathomable space beyond. There is a ruminative quality to the tales of lonely people far from home, very different from AM 180 and Summer Here Kids, bright and bubbly tunes from the previous album Under the Western Freeway. This show ends up feeling weirdly divided: the crowd is euphoric when AM 180 and Summer Here Kids are played, bouncing up and down manically, then droops a little when the brakes are applied for Underneath the Weeping Willow and He's Simple, He's Dumb, He's the Pilot.

The contrast makes you realise, though, just how much the band improved between those two albums. They still have a fine line in robust slacker anthems - the way everyone shouts along with the line "I've lost my way again" from the chorus of Crystal Lake testifies to that - but they are also capable of an elegance that is rare in indie guitar music. He's Simple, He's Dumb, He's the Pilot sounds wondrous here, the spinning-meteor section in the middle so powerful you can feel the balcony rumbling beneath you. Dial-a-View and You'll Aim Towards the Sky, the swooning close to the show, are similarly rapturous. And the new songs, particularly the one weaving live and taped vocals, hint that the next album will be even better.

Maybe Lytle has the right idea: you don't want too much talking, because that would just bring you back down to earth.

fields.headline: RNCM Percussion Ensemble
fields.standfirst:
Sema Group Concert Hall, Manchester
****
fields.trailText:
Sema Group Concert Hall, Manchester
****
fields.body:
There is an element of spectacle in music for percussion that makes all live performances eminently watchable; in fact, to see them as well as hear them is an essential part of their appeal. One symptom of that is that a large number of 20th-century works are rarely heard, and almost never outside universities or colleges. So to hear pieces such as these - some more than 60 years old - was probably a first-time experience for the majority of even the Royal Northern College of Music audience.

The RNCM ensemble's selection of American classics included Cage's iconoclastic 4' 33" and Steve Reich's Vermont Counterpoint for flute and tape: not percussion works but absolutely dependent on live performance. Audiences may no longer be surprised by 4' 33", but a performance of this silent non-work still makes its point. Each audience reacts differently. Sometimes a reverential silence is observed; on this occasion a knowing and largely student audience evidently felt under some pressure to add to Martin Roscoe's enactment, with the amusing result that it felt more like a 1960s "happening" than a revelatory experience. Roscoe put on a virtuoso display of brow-mopping and stool-adjusting which provoked giggling; po-facedness is not his style.

Cage's much earlier Quartet was written not long after completing his studies with Schoenberg in the mid-1930s. It prefigures his later experiments with chance by some 15 years; the battery of percussion instruments may be varied according to availability and preference, and very few dynamic indications are given. Faithful to the spirit of Cage's own percussion group, plenty of unusual metallic and wooden objects were added to the conventional cluster of drums, shakers, bells and tam-tams. We were treated to a large dustbin, some gigantic cowbell-like objects, sheet metal and a couple of those long tubes found sometimes in children's play areas that make pleasing bonging noises when patted with table-tennis bats. It was beautifully done.

Reich's half-hour long Sextet was skilfully handled, as was his Vermont Counterpoint, in which Sarah Eckman was the soloist. Varese's wonderful Ionisation received two performances, both opening and closing the concert. Far from trying the audience's patience, the chance to hear this short work twice was welcome; who knows how long it may be before any of those present will hear it again.

fields.headline: Borodin Quartet
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall, London
***
fields.body:
Few ensembles today can make the Borodin Quartet's claim to have studied standard repertoire works with the composer himself. In fact, three members of the quartet have changed since Shostakovich worked with them around 50 years ago; only the cellist, Valentin Berlinsky, remains from the original line-up. Yet surprisingly it was Berlinsky's voice that was the freshest in this, the third instalment of their Beethoven and Shostakovich series. The Borodins have played these works hundreds of times, but occasionally during the first half of the evening it was all too apparent.

Shostakovich's deceptively simple First Quartet is more powerful than some might think - he could already conjure up slightly neurotic images of wide open spaces and infect the listener with the musical equivalent of agoraphobia. The Borodins opened the first movement, rightly, without a ripple of expression troubling the flowing lines. But the promise of later turbulence was never realised. While a certain amount of detachment suits this composer, the first violinist, Ruben Aharonian, maintained an almost impenetrable coolness throughout - sections of the allegro final movement sounded more like a technical exercise than living, breathing phrases of music. Only Berlinsky injected a little lightness into the proceedings, wryly throwing out his glissandos in the first movement, more mischievous than grotesque.

If the First Quartet can be unsettling, the Eighth is disturbing by any standards. Dominated by a four-note figure derived from the letters of Shostakovich's monogram, it's a shattering work, written in violent times and during a period of personal despair. Yet their cool detachment was still an excessive characteristic of the quartet's playing, begging the question of whether they are by now numbed to the work's effects, or feel that too much angst gets in the way of the work's impact. Either way, something was lacking.

After the interval and the first few grave chromatic notes of Beethoven's Quartet Op 130, the mood lightenedand the quartet were considerably more successful. Aharonian's bright tone was better suited to the joyous semiquavers of the first movement, and he and Berlinsky enjoyed their moments of musical dialogue.

The balletic middle movements brought a welcome lighter touch from the two inner players, while the Cavatina movement had enough expansiveness to argue a convincing case for it as the core of the work.

fields.headline: Mis-selling bill tops £13bn
fields.standfirst:
Pensions scandal is likely to become Britain's costliest financial blunder

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The bill for clearing up the pensions mis-selling scandal is expected to reach £13.5bn, it was announced yesterday, making it arguably Britain's most costly financial debacle.
fields.body:
The bill for clearing up the pensions mis-selling scandal is expected to reach £13.5bn, it was announced yesterday, making it arguably Britain's most costly financial debacle.

This figure has been revised upwards from the previous forecast of £11bn, the financial services authority said. The bulk of this sum is compensation for up to 1.2m people.

It exceeds the £12bn that the government this week announced it will pay to millions of victims of a blunder involving the state earnings related pension scheme (Serps).

Insurers and financial advisers have been ordered to compensate people who were mis-sold personal pensions between April 1988 and June 1994.

Commission-hungry sales staff at many companies persuaded people to leave or not join occupational pension schemes but take out inferior personal plans instead. Others were advised - wrongly - to transfer money built up in an occupational scheme into a personal plan.

Teachers, nurses, miners, firefighters, police officers and local authority employees were among the victims.

Dozens of companies have been fined for failures linked to mis-selling, ranging from household names such as Royal & Sun Alliance to small independent financial advisers.

Among the largest fines were the £500,000 imposed on Britannia Life in July 1999 and the £600,000 levied on Sun Life of Canada a year earlier.

Regulators began investigating into the scandal in late 1994 and this is continuing. Initially companies were told to concentrate on reviewing the 700,000 "priority" cases: people who had retired or were close to retirement.

Two months after coming to power in 1997, the Labour government started publishing monthly figures showing how the 41 worst-offending pension companies were doing in compensating victims. This naming and shaming approach continued until February 1999 when the last of the firms met government targets.

More than 98% of priority cases have been reviewed and almost £3.6bn in compensation has been paid to 406,000 people - an average of £8,800 each - in the form of pension funds contributions.

In January 1999 phase two of the investigation began, focusing on younger people, typically in their 30s and 40s, who might have been mis-sold a pension.

It was thought up to 2m in this age group might have been affected, and the FSA said yesterday that of the 1.2m people who have so far asked for their cases to be reviewed 872,000 are potentially in line for compensation.

The £13.5bn total includes £4bn likely to be paid out to the priority cases, £7.5bn compensation to younger victims and £2bn administration costs, the whole to be met by insurers and financial advisers.

The increase partly reflects "the change in financial conditions" since early 1998 when the £11bn figure was disclosed, the FSA said.

Last year the actuarial profession issued figures showing that people are living longer, and this has pushed up the costs because pensions will be paid for longer.

Pension companies have until June 30 2002 to resolve all cases.

By then every suspected victim should have received a letter stating how the company proposes to compensate the policyholder for any loss, or that the individual is not due any compensation.

fields.headline: Stripped-down Verdi with an extra edge
fields.standfirst:
Nabucco
Coliseum, London
****
fields.trailText:
Nabucco
Coliseum, London
****
fields.body:
The last true opera of ENO's Italian season is the company's first ever Nabucco, the work Verdi considered to have launched his career. It might also be the first production at the Coliseum in which the orchestra and conductor spend more time on stage than most of the singers.

In the shadow of recent sickening images from the Middle East, David Pountney's loosely modern-dress staging of this story of the struggle between the Jews and Babylonians takes on extra resonance. Pountney presents it as an almost epic fable, with a huge piece of Hebrew script hanging above the stage, and lines from the Bible recited by three schoolboys, in English and Hebrew, introducing each of the four parts.

In many ways it seems that Stefanos Lazaridis's designs for the Italian season have reached their natural culmination. Over the course of the autumn the auditorium has been filling up with odd props and features left behind after each production. And the scaffolding that has long surrounded the dress circle has now encroached on to the stage and joins in the middle.

In fact, in the same way that Lazaridis has been deconstructing our cosy image of an opera house, in this production we have most of the illusion of opera stripped away. Nothing is hidden. The workings of opera are turned inside out. The massed, khaki-costumed ranks of the orchestra are on stage throughout, and Nabucco himself is very much visible even before his first entrance.

The shirt-sleeved conductor Michael Lloyd starts off on stage and, with his singers making much use of the scaffolding runway, frequently returns there, moving around in order to communicate with them - though he absents himself for Zaccaria's monologue, leaving the handful of accompanying cellists to play as a chamber group.

This production features the British debut of the American soprano Lauren Flanigan, who sings the anti-heroine Abigaille. Flanigan's voice is striking - not for its acrobatic agility, nor for an unusual amount of beauty or warmth, nor for her rather cloudy diction, but rather because of its compelling dramatic power and ability to convey feeling. Another auspicious debut comes from the baritone Bruno Caproni, singing his first Nabucco - finely judged, rich and communicative. Indeed, there is no weak link in a cast that also includes Alastair Miles as Zaccaria, John Daszak as Ismaele and Anne Mason as Fenena. The chorus is on fine form, and the orchestra plays sensitively. The players' movements may be the visual equivalent of background noise but, if one can get past that, this Nabucco is an unusual and rewarding operatic experience.

In repertory until February 23. Box office: 020-7632 8300.

fields.headline: Pick and mix at fund checkouts
fields.trailText: Fund supermarkets are less than a year old and have just 1% of the market, but it would seem they are here to stay. But what are they, and are they worth using for your next investment?
fields.body:
Fund supermarkets are less than a year old and have just 1% of the market, but it would seem they are here to stay. But what are they, and are they worth using for your next investment?

An investment supermarket lets you put funds from several different providers into one Isa wrapper. The supermarket provider becomes the Isa provider just as Tesco or Safeway label their own goods even though they do not make them.

This enables customers to bypass the requirement that only one Isa can be taken out with one Isa provider in any given tax year.

Fund supermarkets usually offer a discount on the initial charge and often get lumped with discount brokers for this reason. But you can't mix and match funds bought from discount brokers.

The term supermarket is also being used to define any service which gives you access to lots of funds, regardless of whether or not you can mix and match them.

Egg and Fidelity are fund supermarkets. Virgin Money and moneyextra better fit the discount broker bill. They offer a variety of funds at discount prices, but do not become the provider of the fund you buy.

As to whether these supermarkets deserve your money, that depends on your requirements. If you are risk averse, then true fund supermarkets offer a good way of spreading your exposure. You could, for example, split your money four ways and put it in UK, European, technology and ethical funds.

If you think fund charges are too high then supermarkets will appeal. Buying direct from a fund manager usually involves an initial charge of around 5%. Fund supermarkets, however, usually slash this to between 1% and 2%, or discard the initial charge completely.

But if you don't know what kind of fund you're looking for, supermarkets are probably not for you. After all, if deciding on one fund is confusing enough, how are you going to decide on several? The alternative would be to use a supermarket with your financial adviser's help.

The big downside to fund supermarkets is the limit they put on the number of funds from which you can choose. Though some offer hundreds of funds they are far from comprehensive. As such, you might find that one of your favourite funds it not available through a supermarket - you can forget both investment trusts and funds from smaller groups.

It's also worth mentioning that the supermarkets operate in different ways. Some are completely interactive. Others have a strict minimum investment amount.

For example , Fidelity and Egg let you apply and manage your account online. But Fidelity asks you to invest a minimum of £1,000, while Egg's minimum investment is £20, and you have to open an Egg savings account.

We copied the Americans when we launched fund supermarkets in Britain: they have been selling them with some success for several years. And if we continue to follow the US pattern, around half of us may be buying funds from supermarkets in the not too distant future. Charles Schwab says 50% of its US fund sales now take place through its investment supermarket.

But the big test will come in the Isa sales season early in the new year. If the supermarkets grab a noticeable share of the market, then many financial advisers could follow the fate of the speciality high street shop and become an endangered species.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Digital TV banking

fields.headline: Check your balance in the ad breaks
fields.standfirst: Remote control banking lets telly addicts sort out their affairs from their armchairs
fields.trailText: Remote control banking lets telly addicts sort out their affairs from their armchairs.
fields.body:
Digital television is the future - or at least that's the way those offering 21st-century TV and the government like to see it.

But banks have yet to fully embrace the technology which lets couch potatoes sort out their affairs at the end of a remote control - if they can persuade other family members to free up the screen.

Only three banks - Abbey National, HSBC and Woolwich have interactive services fully running. Competitors seem to be waiting to see how the pioneers progress. Halifax is dipping its toes in the water while Barclays and NatWest are test-marketing on cable TV.

Interactive banking customers - Abbey National has 600,000 and expects 1m by May - can access current and savings accounts and pay bills via the Open platform run by Sky.

Woolwich's Open Plan customers can access all their accounts this way, although they have to be opened offline - in a branch or by post.

HSBC offers a similar range of services - customers can view their personal current, savings and credit card accounts, check standing orders and direct debits, pay bills and transfer money between accounts.

All viewers can access information on products and services and use calculators to obtain quotes for mortgages and personal loans.

Uniquely, HSBC went for TV before the internet. "There's a huge number who are either fearful of the net or who don't have access," explains HSBC's Carina Kemp. "But some use both - TV is great for a quick balance check as it's fast and you don't have to wait until the computer powers up.

"The internet is more text-friendly - it's better for complicated matters where you need to read a lot before making up your mind. And many customers want to apply for a loan online or via TV just in case they have a turndown."

All TV banks go for a "bricks and clicks" strategy, designed to give customers choice in how they deal with the bank, whether in a branch, over the phone, at a cash machine, via the internet, or through digital TV. And the banks are keen to attract more users - virtually everyone has a television, but only 25% are hooked up to the internet.

Abbey National intends to stretch its service range so customers will be able to open a cash Isa on screen next spring. It is also live on NTL and Ondigital - customers can look at brochures, ask for mortgage guides and request an Abbey person to contact them. These platforms will expand in mid-2001. Early next year, fully interactive e-banking will be available on both services, allowing customers to view balances, transfer money, set up standing orders and pay bills.

The most popular transactions, says Abbey National's director of retail e-commerce, Ambrose McGinn, are moving money between accounts and checking balances. "Down to the minute, the favourite time is 7.59pm -while the adverts are on between Coronation Street and The Bill," he says. "But we also had a peak after the final episode of Morse. Otherwise, given we have a predominantly young male audience. Sunday before lunch is a good time - they want to check accounts after their Saturday night out."

Abbey National research has found that for three-quarters of the population, one television isn't enough. More than a third (34%) own two sets, just under a quarter (23%) have three and an astonishing 6% have more than five TVs in the house.

The bank says almost half (47%) of all adults would be likely to use their televisions to access their bank or building society account simply by pressing a button on their remote control. Bank users can hit the yellow "secrecy button" if they don't want other household members to look at their financial affairs.

But is the service secure?

The banks think so - and, so far, interactive digital TV has not suffered major internet-style embarrassments such as the revelation of confidential details.

A customer inputs a unique TV banking ID number and security number to access his or her accounts. All information is encrypted.

But the biggest problem could be attracting attention away from multi-channel entertainment.

"Banking is boring," says Ms Kemp at HSBC. "We need to lift the level of interest so we offer prizes to attract attention, such as visits to Formula One, Wimbledon tennis or major football matches."

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Solve your financial ignorance

fields.headline: Go back to school with e-lessons
fields.standfirst:
Feel too ignorant to invest your earnings? Your computer can teach you how

Net news
fields.trailText: Feel too ignorant to invest your earnings? Your computer can teach you how.
fields.body:
Confused by financial matters? Money to invest, but too frightened or busy to ask an expert to explain?

If you have access to the internet, there's no excuse for financial ignorance. A growing number of websites offer courses aimed at private investors, students and finance professionals - indeed anyone who wants to develop their financial expertise or get their finances in order.

This week, for example, Motley Fool launched a three-week interactive course teaching investors how to plan and secure the finances they need for their retirement.

"People are perfectly capable of managing their own finances," says Nat Price, the Fool's online seminar director. "But until now there has been little in the way of education or informative materials and typically it's been provided by organisations looking to sell financial products.

"We've produced this seminar so that people, no matter what their age, sex or financial position, can make a plan for their retirement and put it into action."

The three-week seminar, which costs £30, consists of 10 virtual lessons. At the end of the course, participants will have their own individual retirement plans and understand everything from the relative merits of state, occupational and personal pensions through to Isas, share buying, funds and trackers.

"Many people assume that pensions are the best or only way to save for retirement," says the Fool's spokesman. "But this is simply not the case. One of the keys to the course will be weighing up all the alternatives to make an informed choice."

Participants are organised into virtual teams and assigned a dedicated online discussion board. Supported by Motley Fool tutors, each team will be encouraged to apply the lesson theory to a series of practical group homework assignments.

Stock Academy, an online stockbroker, has its own education centre. It has just introduced a workshop on reading the financial pages to help both novice and regular investors to gain advantages in the stock market.

The free 40-minute workshop identifies what to look for in the financial press, where to find it, when it is published and how to interpret the information.

An optional assessment test is also available to participants wishing to test their knowledge. And as the final self-assessment deadlines loom, a separate workshop on basic taxation teaches investors how to minimise capital gains, inheritance and income tax on their earnings and capital.

Again, participants can choose to take an optional exam at the end. Stock Academy offers 20 other workshops which provide introductory, intermediate and advanced-level information taught with the help of video clips, interactive spreadsheets, interviews, recommended reading, relevant articles and weblinks and comprehensive financial glossaries.

One of the most experienced online educators is Wide Learning. Founded in 1997, the company has built up a client base of more than 70 blue-chip organisations, including BP Amoco and PricewaterhouseCoopers.

But private investors can also access 50 hours of financial learning on the web. The courses are highly interactive and content covers basic finance and investment topics. Each course lasts between 30 and 90 minutes and contains animations, interactive exercises and self-assessments. Some cost less than £10 for 30 days' access.

fields.headline: Enough of boys' toys, women say
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: When it comes to politics, vive la différence still applies, as the French environment minister, Dominique Voynet, could testify. But when it comes to using the internet, is there really a difference between men's and women's approaches? Or are women second class net citizens - back to the days before Germaine Greer's Female Eunuch.
fields.body:
When it comes to politics, vive la différence still applies, as the French environment minister, Dominique Voynet, could testify. But when it comes to using the internet, is there really a difference between men's and women's approaches? Or are women second class net citizens - back to the days before Germaine Greer's Female Eunuch.

The figures bear out the idea of a gender gap, with 32% of men but only 20% of women claiming to have used the net to find out information about financial products, according to the latest NOP internet user profile survey.

The same survey shows that while 57% of men are considering using the internet to apply for a financial product or service in the next 12 months, only 41% of women would do so.

This may be explained in part by the fact that fewer women than men - 25% compared with 39% - feel secure about sending their personal details over the net.

But there is also qualitative evidence to show that yin versus yang is more than just figures. The Norwich and Peterborough Building Society has relaunched its internet banking service, NetmasterGold, after extensive research assessing rival systems on the market.

Focus groups were split into those people who wanted a system with bells and whistles, and those who wanted something simple.

All the people who came forward for the hi-tech service were men.

Psychologist and author Dorothy Rowe says that women are generally not as keen on net surfing as men, and they prefer simple websites. "It's boys who make this stuff, and boys like toys. They don't ask themselves how the person who is reading their website thinks."

Other banks play down any differences. "We find it a tad condescending to presume that women don't want to push as many buttons as men," says Erica Harper of NatWest. "We differentiate between customers in terms of their needs rather than their gender."

Few of the big players seem keen to design their internet services around female customers. But the banks have not been bashful about using women's websites to woo customers - NatWest has a link to the female website Everywoman, providing information on setting up small businesses, and Barclays is about to link up with Mothercare.com.

Online broking is also an area dominated by men - DLJdirect, one of the UK's biggest online brokers, says men make up nearly 90% of its customer base.

There is, however, one area in which women have traditionally been far superior to men - and that's the world of gossip. Finance site Motley Fool has set up a women-only discussion board which has been very successful. "Women look for something more community-focused, and express themselves more sensibly," says the Fool's Phil Southgate. "Some of the other chatrooms are dominated by men and are full of meaningless comments."

fields.headline: Fast sell can be risky for net dealers
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Buying and selling shares has never been easier or cheaper now that several stockbrokers offer online dealing services. Most sites give real-time pricing and stock price alerts, so you can take action when shares reach levels you think significant.
fields.body:
Buying and selling shares has never been easier or cheaper now that several stockbrokers offer online dealing services. Most sites give real-time pricing and stock price alerts, so you can take action when shares reach levels you think significant.

The are other advantages: lower commissions; not worrying about engaged phone lines; huge volumes of research and other background information; and not having to stick with the 8am-to-4pm London stock exchange opening times. Dealing out of hours allows stocks to be bought or sold at the next day's opening price.

But online broking is not for the novice investor, whatever the brokers may claim. While traditional stockbrokers can supply buy and sell recommendations, online broking is an execution-only service.

And it is all too easy to press the buttons and deal without thinking seriously of the consequences; there is no cooling-off period. Even phone-based brokers would raise a few eyebrows if someone dealt 50 or 100 times a day.

Yet there has been a surge in online dealing, with around 15% of all private share trading now carried out through one of the UK's 25 online broking sites.

But with such a smorgasbord of online brokers scrambling for business, the challenge is determining which broker best suits your needs. Comparing charges is rarely straightforward. The only similarity is that all share purchases are subject to 0.5% stamp duty.

Some dealers charge an establishment fee, while others zap you with an annual management charge. All charge commission, but some increase this according to the size of the transaction.

A number of brokers also hold out special deals to lure new investors. Charles Schwab offers free dealing for the first 30 days of opening an account and DLJdirect promises trades with a flat £5 commission for the first 50 days.

Investors making smaller punts should look to online brokers whose commissions are cheaper at the lower end of the transaction scale.

The Share Centre, for example, charges just 1% commission, with the minimum charge being £2.50. There is no establishment fee, but an administration fee of £5 for every transaction is charged. But the Share Centre is not for larger transactions, which can involve £250 in commission for a £25,000 trade. The same transaction would cost as little as £9.95 with Hargreaves Lansdown, or £10 with idealing.com, which both charge flat fees.

Other brokers to charge flat fees include Stockacademy (£15), Sharepeople (£17.50), James Brearley (£20) and Xest (£20). The downside is that these sites levy annual administration charges, though these are easily swallowed up by frequent trades.

The lowest of the annual administration charges is at idealing.com, which charges £20, followed by James Brearley (£25 plus VAT), Stock Academy (£40 plus VAT), Sharepeople (£42.56) Hargreaves Lansdown (£50) and Xest (£20 set-up and £45 annual administration).

An attractive site is Self Trade, which charges a £12.50 flat commission fee, without set-up or annual charges. Halifax Share Xpress offers a similar deal.

With so many sites on offer, it has become a business in itself contrasting costs and services of the online brokers. One site that does this is Investment Gateway, which also offers links to individual brokers.
